turned into polluted cesspools, dumping people’s trash into the ocean – an ocean
we all share, each and every one of us! This is the story of many rivers across
the world.              I knew that by doing something about this problem in my community,
that I could inspire others around the world to do the same. Since our local
government wasn’t doing anything about the problem, I knew the solution would
involve changing how we relate to our waste.Plastic Fantastic - an Idea is BornIn 2013, while attending the Amani Institute – a Social Innovation
Management school, based in Nairobi – I was challenged to transform my initial
desire to clean up the river into a socially engaged business. I was then
joined by my co-founder and fellow Amani student, Jesah Segal, who helped me implement
the idea and turn it into where it is today
marries a strong social and environmental impact with a sustainable revenue
generating model.The MissionWe knew that any business worth its salt needs razor sharp clarity
to keep it focused on its objective. So, we created the following mission
statement: To elevate environmental consciousness through the arts.How it Works
We
partner with local school systems and facilitate ongoing recycling campaigns. Through the recycling campaign, we plant
seeds of environmental appreciation in young children.
We then gather the plastic
generated from the recycling campaigns. Plastic waste which people have thrown out, is effectively transformed into a fantastic raw material (i.e. commodity) that artisans can use.
We then co-design and
collaborate with professional artisans to upcycle the waste into cool products
that conscious consumers love!
For
organizations and artisan groups, we also provide workshops
that teach upcycling techniques and foster environmental stewardship. We then develop
relationships with artisans who show exceptional skill and commitment, and
market and sell items on their behalf.

We then generate revenue by marketing and selling these products to consumers who appreciate one-of-a-kind, handmade creations. We’ve done our market research and there’s a huge and growing segment of consumers who prefer one-of-a-kind over mass-manufactured items. Selling upcycled handcrafts serves as a vehicle which ignites conversations and sustains our social impact.
From our research, no one else in the world incorporates elements
of education and product sales in such a way. Not only that, this idea is
scalable and can be implemented in any community in the world.By the Numbers
We are deeply grateful for the impact we have achieved over the past six months. We have:1.  Kicked off a sustainable
and ongoing recycling campaign in partnership with Aga Khan Academy, the
largest school system in the greater Nairobi area with an enrollment
of 800+ students.2.  Trained over 70 people in five
upcycling workshops – one workshop of which, was in partnership with Kenya Red
Cross. It’s unbelievable how thirsty people are for new knowledge and ideas!
3.  Eleven artisans (and their families) that we work with are currently benefiting from the Fair Trade principles we abide by.

4.  Through sales and workshops we have generated 66,000 KSH (that’s $724!), over the past six months.Fun in the Sun!Aside from all this hard work we’ve been doing, we also have a fun side-project we’re really excited about. We hold a monthly tree growing event that engages local youth to grow trees on the side of Ngong Hills – voted by Travelzoo.com as one of the most romantic sites in the world, beating out Paris, New York, and Rome! We’ve had three tree growing events so far, and planted 54 trees. Wowza! Our goal for 2015 is to plant and grow 100 trees. You’d never guess how easy and fun it is to plant a tree in your neighborhood. It really is a walk in the park!The TeamAs I mentioned earlier, my name is Ciru - I’m a multi-dimensional
artist, leveraging eight years of creative experience and four years of law
school to build the social enterprise, Plastic Fantastic Kenya. I’m a hopeless
optimist and often engage in long afternoon sessions of day dreaming about a
better world - much to my co-founder’s consternation, of course.
As the “Creative Orchestrator” of Plastic Fantastic Kenya, I am
responsible for artisan relationships and product design. I lead upcycling
workshops and have a deep local network which I draw upon for sales and
marketing.
Jesah, my co-founder, grew up in the unspoiled, mountainous
terrain of Montana, USA. He was appalled when I showed him the plastic waste
profusely littered along the local river in Ngong. Having come to Kenya to
chase the dream of elevating consciousness through the curation of handcrafts
made by artisans from exotic cultures around the world, Jesah immediately saw
the viability of my vision on how to change the world through Plastic Fantastic.
Jesah acts as the Business Architect directing Plastic Fantastic’s
business trajectory. With a degree in Business Administration and five years
working as a consultant in corporate America, he isn’t your average westerner
living in Kenya. As a world traveler Jesah has lived in 26 places around the
globe – Kenya being just one of them. When Jesah isn’t building Plastic
Fantastic, he’s an amateur Buddhist Monk, and Mixed Martial Arts fighter (1 win
– 1 loss).
Learn about where Plastic Fantastic is going in 2015!

In order to be sustainable, we need to increase our income generated from sales. We will do this by creating as many distribution points for conscious consumers as possible. So far, we have entered into wholesale relationships with a shop in the U.S., a shop in Finland, and will soon be offering our items to a number of storefronts in Nairobi, Kenya. Our goal is to have 20 vendors worldwide selling our products by the end of the year.
We are half way through incorporating our business and should be fully registered by the end of January.
We are actively collaborating with a local artisan to handcraft upcycled display stands for our jewelry and accessories in retail shops.
The recycling campaign isn’t stopping with just one of Aga Khan’s schools – we hope to include four more schools into our recycling campaign before the year is out.
We need to finish developing our website – only 10% to go!
We need your help to raise funds to
accomplish these goals for 2015!
Help Us Get There!

We have “bootstrapped” by exhausting most of our available resources and now we need your help to maintain this impact.Both of us, eat, sleep, and breathe Plastic Fantastic - it has been A TON of hard work for Jesah and me. With your help, we won’t let up anytime soon!Check out the donation perks to the right to see which contribution tugs at your heart.We’ve done our market research and have reached out to people in all walks of life throughout the Nairobi community. They are relieved and thrilled someone is doing something about all the plastic flying around…and yes, the plastic is literally FLYING!Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand not everyone can make a monetary contribution, but that doesn't mean you can’t make a huge difference! We need your voice!You can support us by getting word out to your friends, family and social networks about this exciting movement we are building in Kenya! Without you this isn't possible!Like and share our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/plasticfantastickenyaFollow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/plasticfuntastyIf you have any questions or comments, please email us at plasticfantastickenya@gmail.comIf you want to contribute using M-Pesa, then use the following number: 0726 381 070And last, but not least, we have to give credit where credit is due. With such a crazy and interconnected world, there are people who have touched our hearts, books we've randomly happened to come across, and life experiences we've had (both good and bad) which, without, we wouldn't have the passion to have built Plastic Fantastic to where it is today. Thank you to Amani Institute, for without it, Jesah and Ciru would never have met, and the idea for Plastic Fantastic would have stayed just that - an idea. And, finally, thank you to our supporters, the people who believe in us, because without your belief this wouldn't be possible.Asante sana!!",9.0,1,"2 Campaigns
|","Nairobi, Kenya",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/plastic-fantastic-from-plastic-to-fantastic/pica

My name is
Adrian Petre. I <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >am writing on behalf of

column1: a very special initiative dedicated to promoting environmental stewardship and conservation
education and providing a healthy camp experience for underprivileged children.
The goal of the first phase of the
iPlanTree project is to plant 25,000 trees by the end of 2015 for the
purpose of generating oxygen in a location that
is currently “oxygen deprived.”
The value
of our trees should never be taken for granted! An average size tree creates enough
oxygen in one year to provide oxygen for an entire family of four. If we could plant
20 million trees, the earth could get with 260 million more tons of oxygen. And
just as importantly, trees are renewable, biodegradable and recyclable!
During the second phase of our
project, we will be building bungalows for impoverished children to attend
summer camp to play and learn in a “green” environment.
For most
children, summer camps are incredibly fun but not unusual. Year after year they
look forward to making new friends, learning new skills, and enjoying a summer
of outdoor activity. But for children living in poverty, it’s a far different
story. During the summer, these children usually play on city streets or on asphalt
playgrounds. They have no reprieve from the difficult circumstance in which
they live. Giving them a healthy camp experience gives them a window into
another way of life. They learn about the environment
become their role models
is strengthened.
We have already purchased the land
for Phase I of our project – planting the trees. We are reaching out to you
today to ask for a donation to help us reach our 2015 goal of planting 25,000
trees and to position us to move ahead with Phase II – building the bungalows.
Please give whatever you can. Every dollar that you donate
goes directly to executing this two-phase effort. If you are unable to provide
financial support – please share this message to all of your friends and
colleagues on social networks so that they may have the opportunity to donate.
THANK YOU!
On behalf of our environment and the
children who will benefit from a healthy camp experience, I am deeply grateful!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spreed: the word out there about our goal.

  • Share on Social Networks with your friends.
  • use Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you all, and hope we will make this happen!

PLEASE HELP US GROW MORE SAND DUNES ON OUR POPULAR FAMILY BEACH
Last year we raised funds for a pilot to protect and grow sand dunes on our popular beach. We got permission from the Dept of the Environment and from the Council and local farmers who own the beach.  

We bought and planted hundreds of native beach plants following the An Taisce guidelines and protected them with tall sturdy posts, sheep fencing and created sand-traps with horticultural netting.

The success has been remarkable and we want your help to extend the sand-traps that protect the new dunes. £5 buys a post, and £50 a roll of galvanized sheep-fencing and £30 netting for sand traps. Donate using button on the right - there is also a Paypal option there as well.

WHAT IT LOOKED LIKE BEFORE OUR PILOT PROJECT 
This photo shows what the area looked like before the pilot project - note the bare crumbling cliffs. Notice the bare rocks with no sand and no purchase available for protective screens of plants. Compare this to to the photos above.

The original 2 meter sand traps in the pilot project have been so successful that you can now step over them as less than 500mm is visible above the sand.

We have £250 in the kitty and need another £750 to go another 100 meters. All the labour is voluntary and equipment is lent by local farmers. If we get more than £750 we will be able to protect more of the beach - the road to our village is threatened by the erosion on the beach.

This project is organised by independent Councilor Cadogan Enright a local environmentalist 

The project is owned by the Ballyhornan Development Association and  It is supported by the 3 local beach community beach campaigns in Kilclief ,Ballyhornan , Coney Island and Killough .

WELCOME TO YOU AND YOUR FAMILY
Our thanks to you is our Céad Míle Fáilte to you and your family to our lovely beach, our well-maintained car-park with public toilets and litter-bins for your use.

The regular litter-picks our community orgnise along our coastline reflects our pride in our area and our welcome to you and your family to come and enjoy this beautiful beach with a lovely walk that leads to the Kilard nature reserve to the East and the wonderful Sheeplands coastal walk to Ardglass to the West.

Project Brief

The Aurora Artist Residency Program and Space (AARPS) is a newly founded, non-profit and independent, art program and space that sits between the vast Sierra Madre mountain rangers and the Pacific Ocean, in Dingalan Municipality, Aurora Province, Philippines.

In the past months, we have been forging partnerships with the local government unit and the communities in Dingalan, including the including the Dumagat indigenous peoples communities, for our numerous art, research and cultural projects such as Cultural, Biodiversity and Marine Biodiversity Mappings and Cultural-Eco Tourism and Sustainability Program, as well as projects from our Art Residency Programs.

This coming April 2017, we invited several installation artists from all over the Philippines in order to participate in our Jazz Up Our Town Project, to install interactive art installations all over the town proper of Dingalan, Aurora Province. Moreover, in connection with the town's promotion of bicycle use and bike trails in the Sierra Madre mountains, we are also soliciting donations for bicycle parts to be used as main materials for the installations, as well as functioning bicycles for community use, especially far flung areas which are only accessible either by foot or by bike.

YOUR HELP is crucial, not only easing the transportation difficulties of our hard to reach communities, but also will be a great contribution to shaping artistic, creative and critical communities, by helping us realise our diverse art/creative projects with and for the communities.
Our Creative Partnership
At present, we are trying to raise to as much as $5,000 to compensate for:
1. Cost of Living Allowance for the Artists (Transportation, Accommodation and Food)
2. Artist Materials for the Installations
3. Catalogue Production of the Said Event
4. Partial Funds for procurement of old/second hand bikes for community use in the far flung areas of our town.

5. Jump start money for the next projects of our residency programs including biodiversity and marine biodiversity rapid mapping as base research for an environmentally friendly cultural eco-tourism program.
From our end, depending on the amount of your contribution, we will:
1. Install a special sponsorship plaque to be installed beside the art pieces.
2. A copy and special sponsorship page in our catalogue
3. A copy of a personalised special thank you postcard
4. A personalised thank-you e-card
Of Needs and Urgency
Needless to expound the environmental and community impact of Climate Change throughout the globe
column2: and the most vulnerable countries and communities, are ironically, those who do do less harm to the environment, such as most third world countries, such as the Philippines, and small communities such as our town of Dingalan.

column1: There is a vast number of natural resources and wonders in our area, and yet, without much research, partnerships, livelihood and activations in our communities, especially amidst development aggression and destructive tourism, there will always be limited impact of our efforts to enact on environmental protection programs and eventually maintain a sustainable environment.

Our projects are always in partnerships with communities. We make sure that the community have a sense of ownership in these outputs as well as an educative exchange between our projects and the communities. Starting from the ground, in humility and with the living people in these communities is always a good place to start programs such as these and ensure a slow but steady impact in the environment.
Creative Solutions for Challenges

All projects and programs will eventually face challenges, mostly through limitations of funding and other forms of resources, and lack of support from the communities. We believe that art always breaks barriers and forge openness. Moreover, creativity and art, also allows us to head on challenges by looking into other perspectives and means of achieving our goals. In other words, we treat our challenges not as hardships per se, but puzzles towards ingenious and creative solutions that could give birth to new ideas and/or new perspectives, an openness towards new directions.
Other Ways You Can Help
PLEASE PROMOTE OUR PROGRAMS at the Aurora Artist Residency Program and Space (AARPS) and continue to help projects such as these. Thank you very much and we hope you visit us soon!

Short Summary

I'm Wendy Fachon, Storywalker, writer, environmental educator and after-school walking club facilitator. In an era dominated by highly-programmed electronic media, how many youth actually know how to play outdoors? As a parent and an independent educator, I've watched children become more programmed, less connected to their outside world, and less inclined to active play.  This isolation poses serious health risks.  Furthermore, IF a child is secluded indoors and kept from experiencing nature, how can such a child truly appreciate and properly care for the environment?

My project, Wild Plant Magic Cards, has the objective of encouraging more kids to shift from ""screen time"" to ""green time"" - get outdoors, exercise and have fun while they learn. The cards offer a simple and fun way to reconnect with nature. Wild plants grow everywhere, even in the city. These cards highlight the beauty, variety, value and magic of the plant kingdom... fascinating aspects that are not covered in a standard science curriculum.
For example: Do you know which weeds growing in your neighborhood are actually edible?
Can you identify Poison Ivy AND the wild plant will protect your skin from getting the itchy Poison Ivy rash?

Do you know how the Dandelion got its name?
Hint: It is NOT named for the color and shape of its flower.

Wild Plant Magic Cards hold the answers inside.

Story Cards, Clue Cards and Plant Cards offer stories, facts and play-based activities that teach children how to safely navigate the woods and fields outdoors. Kids love to go outdoors to play and explore, IF others will go out with them. The images and short text weave a mysterious web of information that inspires imaginative game play and nature detective adventures.
What is my fundraising goal? $3,333. This is based on the costs for the printing and the perks. A limited number of original card sets are available for a $25 or $35 donation.

My colleague Gail Ahlers and I will be using these cards with over fifty elementary students in the city of Pawtucket's summer school program. These cards will help us enhance a computerized reading and math curriculum with arts, storywalking, plant studies and story writing.

If I raise more than my goal, I can produce more sets to give to the Rhode Island Wild Plant Society, RIEEA,, RIFIN and other environmental education organizations, as well as RIASPA and affiliated afterschool providers. If I earn well above my goal, maybe, I can also produce sets in Spanish.
What's in it for YOU besides some fun perks?
Would you like to get some kids off the couch and convert their ''screen time"" into ""green time""?
Would you like to see some children become more actively engaged with the natural world around them?
Do you know some kids who might like to develop the skills of an environmental detective and help protect the plants and the pollinators that rely on the plants for survival?
Would you like to help bring quality active learning programs for urban schools?

If you support this cause, you will receive gifts in return that can begin to help make these things happen. Among the perks available are an e-subscription to THE STORY TIMES, an Angel Heart Lucky Charm, an audio CD of nature stories, a signed copy of THE ANGEL HEART story book and a Peter Pan Pajama Party with Wendy.
In what other ways can you support this cause, if not monetarily?
Volunteer to start a Netwalking club at your school or in your community.
Visit the ""Find a Story"" page on our website, and share some Storywalker audios with family and friends.
Get word out about this Indiegogo Campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Share the http://netwalking.com link and the Netwalking facebook page, so friends can learn more about the Storywalker program and the many health benefits of walking. Follow me on twitter @wendyfachon for campaign news and updates.
Thank you for taking an interest in this project.

Share the http://netwalking.com link and the Netwalking facebook page, so friends can learn more about the Storywalker program and the many health benefits of walking. Follow me on twitter @wendyfachon for campaign news and updates.
Thank you for taking an interest in this project.",4.0,0,"1 Campaign

I have just graduated from university and I'm trying to fulfill my ultimate dream as a marine biologist to work in the Chilean Patagonia. I have travelled to other continents before but South America has always been at the top of my list. This time, I want to extend my trip to a year, hoping to make a documentary (video and photography) of the entire experience and in particular, the beauty of the latino-american coastline and marine wildlife.

In my travels, I intend to capture as much as my experiences offer. My goal as an amateur photographer, marine biologist and professional diver, is to picture the beauty of our oceans  and the culture surrounding the marine environment. Pollution and human impacts are slowly destroying our beloved seas and raising awareness on society, especially the young generations, is the only way to stop all these harmful anthropogenic activities.

You can see some of my previous work here: http://clararvives.wix.com/the-neverending-road

Since 2013, Fundación Macaw has actively  participate  protecting  Sea turtles in the Caribbean Coast of  Costa Rica. The Sea  turtles here  are poached for meat and eggs for sale.

Our organization will Patrol  the beach of Moin during 2015, collecting important  data of the sea turtle population nesting in the area
column2:
All collected  information will be process to  determine the environmental impact of new infrastructure projects being built.

On May 30th, 2013, at Moin beach Jairo Mora Sandoval was killed because of his work with Sea turtles. The legal system of Costa Rica recently  has play “NOT GUILTY” for the 7 men acquitted of murder of Costa Rica sea turtle conservationist. As now no one knows who killed him or why...But we know that his work must continue and the sea turtles still need a voice out, that is why our work is important more than  ever today.

With your support you will be helping to monitor and protect the habitat and nesting area of four species of sea turtle, also  support the movement to protect the  Wetland Cariari, declared a natural World Heritage. Now at risk for new infrastructures projects like  the Terminal of Containers of Moin. Being build in the  middle of the wetland Cariari  by APM Terminals  disrupting the ecosystems of the area breaking different laws.

To continue with our work  we  need security, equipment  food  and housing  for every volunteer that patrols the beach at night, collecting the  data of the sea turtle population
column3:
All collected  information will be process to determine the environmental impact of this mega port. with the finality to create modifications in the project  to protect the sea turtles.

We need to cover all expenses for  6 volunteers that go out on  6 hours  patrols trying to find the sea turtles and their nest collecting all the information, to create a data base, legal evidence of this population of sea turtles, to fight against the destruction of its  habitats,

Every volunteer is welcome to join our patrols and make a difference saving the sea turtles
column7:
>Write us at  fundacion.macaw@gmail.com

Every penny receive will be use for  Sea turtles conservation programs your contribution will help to continue our work.

Since Jairo Mora Sandoval was murdered all the goverment organizations responsible to monitor the area,had remove their presence.  Moin is the second most controversial and dangerous area of Limón Costa Rica  which is province with the highest rates of insecurity, poverty, lack of access to public services, among other social factors. Moin beach has vast expanse of beach (about 21 km) is surrounded by mangroves, through which hundreds of water channels use as maritime routes.  

The region of Moin has become no man's land since 2013
column8:
police presence in the area has declined, leaving the 21  km of Moin beach free for criminals and poachers,  making our work very dangerous. Under these conditions of insecurity we need your help  to establish our project keeping safety as our first priority.

Donate,become a volunteers and join our patrols, share the information, support our projects, work with us, sponsor a patrol, adopt a nest,adopt a baby turtle.

Hawai'i Forest Institute (HFI):
<h1><u style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
<u style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column3: >Give Back to the Forest

column1: PROJECT:
<div>
The Pana‘ewa Rainforest Zoo &
column2: Gardens, which is operated by the County of Hawai‘i Department of Parks and Recreation, is located in the middle of a lush Hawaiian tropical rainforest in Hilo, Hawai‘i. The zoo is a popular attraction for both residents and visitors, with an estimated 170,000 visitors annually. The  Discovery Forest exhibit features a demonstration of native, cultural, and medicinal plants. Culturally significant plants that once grew in traditional farms and native forests of East Hawai‘i, including Polynesian-introduced plants that arrived with migrating canoes are featured. These “canoe plants,"" along with many endemic species, play essential roles in Hawaiian culture, for food, fiber, tools, implements, building materials, and medicine, as well as biodiversity and ecological health.

column1: <h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Hawaii's Forests Play a Key Role in Island Sustainability!

column1: PROJECT BREAKDOWN:
Phase I: Engaged community volunteers in creating and maintaining Native and Agro‐forest (Polynesian-introduced species) demonstration gardens.                             COMPLETED 2011
<div>
Phase II: Installed interpretive signage and plant ID labels and engaged community volunteers in planting seedlings and site maintenance.                                           COMPLETED 2014

Phase III: Clearing the remaining undesirable trees and engaging community volunteers in planting seedlings, building a Traditional Hawaiian Hale, and continued maintenance and outreach.                                                     
IN PROGRESS FOR 2015
<div>
For project outline visit:
PROJECT NEEDS:
$6,000 for COMPLETION of PHASE III tree removal, planting, hale building workshops, and site maintenance.
<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Your donation will hep support a unique urban forest restoration and education exhibit at the Pana'ewa Zoo!

column1: WHY THE PANA'EWA DISCOVERY FOREST MATTERS:

column5: >The Pana'ewa zoo Discovery Forest is providing education, recreation, and volunteer opportunities for community residents and visitors. In addition to community volunteers, students from Kamehameha Schools, Pacific Quest, Ka'u High, Kiwanis Kids, Prince Jonah Kūhiō Kalani‘ana‘ole Elementary and Intermediate School, and Malamalama Waldorf School have all participated in the creation of the Discovery Forest. As of January 2015, over 300 volunteers have helped to create and maintain the Discovery Forest.

column1: In March, Certified Traditional Hawaiian Hale Builder “Unko Waltah” began working with community volunteers to build a traditional Hawaiian Hale at the Discovery Forest. This important aspect of the project is helping to perpetuate the Hawaiian culture by revitalizing and sharing the skills of building a structure out of materials from the ‘āina. Materials for the Hale Ku’ai/Papa’a will come from Pana’ewa lands.
<h3 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Help Continue Student Education and Community Involvement of Hawaii's Forests!

column1: PROJECT AFFILIATES:
<div>

MAHALO ‘ĀINA: Give Back to the Forest is a new initiative of the Hawai‘i Forest Institute.  In partnership with the Hawai‘i Forest Industry Association (HFIA), the goal of MAHALO ‘ĀINA is to expand our community partnerships and gain support for the protection and perpetuation of Hawaii’s forest ecosystems.  Funds raised through MAHALO ‘ĀINA are helping to support:  Propagation, outplanting, and long-term care of plantings

column5: >MAHALO ‘ĀINA is not simply a tree planting
column9: >initiative. In addition to planting trees, MAHALO ‘ĀINA is helping to support total ecosystem management and providing forest stewardship opportunities and educational programs at over a dozen project sites throughout the state.

Mahalo to our donors:
","Hawai'i Forest Institute (HFI):
MAHALO 'ĀINA:
Give Back to the Forest
PROJECT:

The Pana‘ewa Rainforest Zoo & Gardens, which is operated by the County of Hawai‘i Department of Parks and Recreation, is located in the middle of a lush Hawaiian tropical rainforest in Hilo, Hawai‘i. The zoo is a popular attraction for both residents and visitors, with an estimated 170,000 visitors annually. The  Discovery Forest exhibit features a demonstration of native, cultural, and medicinal plants. Culturally significant plants that once grew in traditional farms and native forests of East Hawai‘i, including Polynesian-introduced plants that arrived with migrating canoes are featured. These “canoe plants,"" along with many endemic species, play essential roles in Hawaiian culture, for food, fiber, tools, implements, building materials, and medicine, as well as biodiversity and ecological health.
Hawaii's Forests Play a Key Role in Island Sustainability!
PROJECT BREAKDOWN:
Phase I: Engaged community volunteers in creating and maintaining Native and Agro‐forest (Polynesian-introduced species) demonstration gardens.                             COMPLETED 2011
Phase II: Installed interpretive signage and plant ID labels and engaged community volunteers in planting seedlings and site maintenance.                                           COMPLETED 2014

Phase III: Clearing the remaining undesirable trees and engaging community volunteers in planting seedlings, building a Traditional Hawaiian Hale, and continued maintenance and outreach.                                                      IN PROGRESS FOR 2015
For project outline visit: http://www.hawaiiforestinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Panaewa-Zoo-Discovery-Forest-Brochure.pdf
PROJECT NEEDS:
$6,000 for COMPLETION of PHASE III tree removal, planting, hale building workshops, and site maintenance.
Your donation will hep support a unique urban forest restoration and education exhibit at the Pana'ewa Zoo!
WHY THE PANA'EWA DISCOVERY FOREST MATTERS:

The Pana'ewa zoo Discovery Forest is providing education, recreation, and volunteer opportunities for community residents and visitors. In addition to community volunteers, students from Kamehameha Schools, Pacific Quest, Ka'u High, Kiwanis Kids, Prince Jonah Kūhiō Kalani‘ana‘ole Elementary and Intermediate School, and Malamalama Waldorf School have all participated in the creation of the Discovery Forest. As of January 2015, over 300 volunteers have helped to create and maintain the Discovery Forest.

In March, Certified Traditional Hawaiian Hale Builder “Unko Waltah” began working with community volunteers to build a traditional Hawaiian Hale at the Discovery Forest. This important aspect of the project is helping to perpetuate the Hawaiian culture by revitalizing and sharing the skills of building a structure out of materials from the ‘āina. Materials for the Hale Ku’ai/Papa’a will come from Pana’ewa lands.
Help Continue Student Education and Community Involvement of Hawaii's Forests!
PROJECT AFFILIATES:

MAHALO ‘ĀINA: Give Back to the Forest is a new initiative of the Hawai‘i Forest Institute.  In partnership with the Hawai‘i Forest Industry Association (HFIA), the goal of MAHALO ‘ĀINA is to expand our community partnerships and gain support for the protection and perpetuation of Hawaii’s forest ecosystems.  Funds raised through MAHALO ‘ĀINA are helping to support:  Propagation, outplanting, and long-term care of plantings

MAHALO ‘ĀINA is not simply a tree planting initiative. In addition to planting trees, MAHALO ‘ĀINA is helping to support total ecosystem management and providing forest stewardship opportunities and educational programs at over a dozen project sites throughout the state.
Support other HFIA and HFI projects HERE: http://www.mahaloaina.org/
Share the Pana'ewa Discovery Forest Campaign With a Friend and Make Double the Impact!
Learn more about the importance of Hawaii's forests  HERE:
http://www.hawaiiforestinstitute.org/
http://www.nature.org/media/hawaii/the-last-stand-hawaiian-forest.pdf
Mahalo to our donors:",10.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Help us Restore Ash Creek
Who Are We?

Hi! We're volunteers for the Luckiamute Watershed Council -- some of us are landowners, some are scientists and technical experts, but all of us care about this  creek that runs through the communities of Dallas, Monmouth and Independence, Oregon, before entering the Willamette River.
We hope you care, too! Will you contribute to this project?
Why do we want to plant native trees, shrubs and flowers?

For decades, human activities have had harmful effects on Ash Creek, from dredging to dumping and development to ditching. One result of our impacts is non-native weeds have grown up along the creek and crowded out the native plants that would normally be there.

Please note: When you contribute (thank you!), a message will appear that your contribution was received by the Marys River Watershed Council. As the fiscal sponsor to the Luckiamute Watershed Council, the Marys River WC receives and manages funds on our behalf. Rest assured, all contributions will be dedicated to the Ash Creek project. Call with any questions! 503-837-0237. Thank you!
What are we doing?

column2: >The Luckiamute Watershed Council and our project partners have been hard at work clearing away these weeds and adding native plants. Your contribution will help us purchase more plants and pay professional restoration crews to plant and maintain them. Check out the perks!

column1: You may think this is just a matter of aesthetics, but it's more: Where there are native plants, there is shade for native fish. With a little care, Ash Creek could support the young fish that seek refuge in shady pools, as well as the birds, butterflies, bees, and other native animals that depend on native plants.
But wait! That's not all!

In the winter, when the Willamette River is high, its waters back up into Ash Creek, and it becomes a quiet refuge for fish from the raging river. In addition, a healthy creek helps those living downstream by holding back the flood waters, just a bit.
Ash Creek's potential. Our vision for the future.
Another benefit:  native shrubs and trees do a better job of holding the banks in place, offering some protection from erosion that cuts into the stream banks.
This project helps Ash Creek and our community in so many ways!
As full description of the project is at http://www.luckiamutelwc.org/ash-creek-restoration-project.html.
We've got a great team!

We're not in this alone. In addition to you, we have support from the Cities of Independence and Monmouth, Oregon Watershed Enhancement Board (OWEB), the Ash Creek Water Control District and Central School District 13J and many generous landowners.

In addition to our project partners, our fiscal sponsor, the Marys River Watershed Council (MRWC), is an important partner, too. You'll notice on the ""Contribute Now"" page that donations will be received by the Marys River Watershed Council. As a 501(c)(3) entity, MRWC provides fiscal sponsorship for the Luckiamute Watershed Council, which is why the funds will be received by MRWC.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We have some funds from these generous partners, but we need $8,000 more to continue the work of planting and maintaining the planted areas:

  • It costs approximately $30 an hour per person -- or $180 per crew -- to plant and maintain, including administration and oversight. We estimate the cost to purchase, plant and maintain at about $1.20 per plant.
  • In the listings of perks on this page, we've calculated how much we could purchase with each level of contribution.
  • When you contribute, your name or company's name will appear on this page, or you may donate anonymously. We will be publicly thanking you in an ad in our local paper, and in our quarterly newsletter.

The Impact

Your contribution really helps!

  • Without your help, we couldn't do this work!
  • We have a great track record with many successful projects similar to this one. You can see them all at www.LuckiamuteLWC.org.
  • If you live in the Monmouth-Independence communities, you'll see the difference now, and later. Native flowers will bloom in the spring. Later, as the trees begin to shade the creek, it's cooler waters may attract fish.

Risks &
column3:
Challenges

Part of the reason we're seeking funds from you for this project is because weather, vandalism and critters can take their toll on the plants we put in the ground. The money you donate will help up keep our project area planted and growing for years to come! In our years of doing these projects, we know the importance of planning ahead and preparing for plant damage and loss.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? You can still help the Luckiamute Watershed Council with its continuing work.

  • Share the link to this campaign on your Facebook or web page. Tweet it! Text it! Talk about it. Send the link to your friends via e-mail. All of that will help spread the news about this campaign.
  • Volunteer to help our council. Visit www.LuckiamuteLWC.org, or call us, 503-837-0237, or e-mail coordinator@LuckiamuteLWC.org.

We can't wait to work with you! Thank you for your support.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3><span style=""font-weight: normal

column3:
>In den Tagen nach dem Erdbeben im Himalaya wird das Ausmaß der Katastrophe immer deutlicher. Mehr als 5.000 Leichen wurden bislang geborgen. Rettungsteams liefern sich bei der Suche nach Überlebenden einen Wettlauf gegen die Zeit. Verzweiflung macht sich breit. Es heißt, mehr als 70.000 Menschen seien auf der Flucht.
Der Round Table Bamberg möchte mit dieser Indiegogo Kampagne den Menschen in Nepal helfen. Unsere Dachinstitution, der Round Table Deutschland steht bereits in Kontakt mit den Tablern aus Nepal und den internationalen Tablern und organisiert schnelle Hilfe. Round Table ist aber auch dafür bekannt, dass durch uns unterstützte Projekte nachhaltig sind. Unser Ziel ist neben der schnellen Hilfe also vor allem auch die Wiederherstellung der Infrastruktur und der Wiederaufbau.

column1: <span style=""font-size: 24px

Spendenprojekte gibt es, zugeben, viele - jedoch unterscheiden wir uns auch von diesen:
Zum Einen haben wir einen direkten Kontakt nach Nepal durch die dort ansässigen Tabler. Es ist also nicht einfach nur eine anonyme Spende, sondern die Menschen vor Ort wissen genau wo es an etwas fehlt und die Gelder können gezielt eingesetzt werden.
Zum Anderen gibt es bei Round Table keine ""Versickerung"" von Geldern - die Spenden gehen zu 100% dorthin, wo sie benötigt werden. Unsere Strukturen sind durch die Arbeitsweisen von Round Table vollständig durch die Mitglieder getragen. Es fallen also keine Aufwende für das ""Durchreichen"" von Geld an.
Wir arbeiten als Service Club vollkommen transparent und beantworten euch gerne jederzeit jede Frage zu den Projekten und den Geldern.
Wer also dem Aufruf des großen blauen Konzerns mit dem f im Namen und den 2,x Milliarden Dollar Jahresumsatz nicht folgen möchte, sondern den Weg des Geldes nachverfolgen mag, ist bei uns genau richtig.
<div> <h3><span style=""font-weight: normal
column2: >Was macht Round Table mit dem Geld?

column1: Die damit umgesetzte Soforthilfe realisiert Round Table Deutschland in Zusammenarbeit mit der ""action medeor"".

""action medeor"" hilft, indem Medikamente und Materialien zur Wund- und Operationsbehandlung sowie Wasseraufbereitungsanlagen gezielt vor Ort den Betroffenen zur Verfügung gestellt werden. Bereits am Sonntagmorgen waren die ersten Nothilfe-Pakete unterwegs nach Nepal. Weitere werden in diesen Tagen folgen.

Hilfe ist bereits mit den unterschiedlichsten Beträgen möglich - drei Beispiele:
70 Euro: Antibiotika für 20 Menschen mit schweren Wundinfektionen 
700 Euro: Nahtmaterial, lokale Betäubung und Desinfektion kleinerer Verletzungen für 200 Menschen
10.000 Euro: Emergency Health Kit - eine knappe Tonne schwer, mit Schmerzmitteln, Verbandsmaterialien und chirurgischem Besteck zur Versorgung von etwa 10.000 Menschen für drei Monate.
Der Round Table 187 Bamberg hat bereits €2.000 gespendet und hofft, dass sich möglichst viele unserer Freunde dazu entschließen diese Summe mindestens noch zu toppen!
Ihr könnt euch jederzeit auf unserer Facebook-Seite und natürlich in der indiegogo Kampagne über den aktuellen Stand informieren.
","Round Table 187 Bamberg hilft Nepal

In den Tagen nach dem Erdbeben im Himalaya wird das Ausmaß der Katastrophe immer deutlicher. Mehr als 5.000 Leichen wurden bislang geborgen. Rettungsteams liefern sich bei der Suche nach Überlebenden einen Wettlauf gegen die Zeit. Verzweiflung macht sich breit. Es heißt, mehr als 70.000 Menschen seien auf der Flucht.Der Round Table Bamberg möchte mit dieser Indiegogo Kampagne den Menschen in Nepal helfen. Unsere Dachinstitution, der Round Table Deutschland steht bereits in Kontakt mit den Tablern aus Nepal und den internationalen Tablern und organisiert schnelle Hilfe. Round Table ist aber auch dafür bekannt, dass durch uns unterstützte Projekte nachhaltig sind. Unser Ziel ist neben der schnellen Hilfe also vor allem auch die Wiederherstellung der Infrastruktur und der Wiederaufbau.
Warum ausgerechnet über Round Table unterstützen?

Spendenprojekte gibt es, zugeben, viele - jedoch unterscheiden wir uns auch von diesen:Zum Einen haben wir einen direkten Kontakt nach Nepal durch die dort ansässigen Tabler. Es ist also nicht einfach nur eine anonyme Spende, sondern die Menschen vor Ort wissen genau wo es an etwas fehlt und die Gelder können gezielt eingesetzt werden.Zum Anderen gibt es bei Round Table keine ""Versickerung"" von Geldern - die Spenden gehen zu 100% dorthin, wo sie benötigt werden. Unsere Strukturen sind durch die Arbeitsweisen von Round Table vollständig durch die Mitglieder getragen. Es fallen also keine Aufwende für das ""Durchreichen"" von Geld an.Wir arbeiten als Service Club vollkommen transparent und beantworten euch gerne jederzeit jede Frage zu den Projekten und den Geldern.Wer also dem Aufruf des großen blauen Konzerns mit dem f im Namen und den 2,x Milliarden Dollar Jahresumsatz nicht folgen möchte, sondern den Weg des Geldes nachverfolgen mag, ist bei uns genau richtig.
Was macht Round Table mit dem Geld?
Die damit umgesetzte Soforthilfe realisiert Round Table Deutschland in Zusammenarbeit mit der ""action medeor"".

action medeor"" hilft, indem Medikamente und Materialien zur Wund- und Operationsbehandlung sowie Wasseraufbereitungsanlagen gezielt vor Ort den Betroffenen zur Verfügung gestellt werden. Bereits am Sonntagmorgen waren die ersten Nothilfe-Pakete unterwegs nach Nepal. Weitere werden in diesen Tagen folgen.Hilfe ist bereits mit den unterschiedlichsten Beträgen möglich - drei Beispiele:70 Euro: Antibiotika für 20 Menschen mit schweren Wundinfektionen 700 Euro: Nahtmaterial, lokale Betäubung und Desinfektion kleinerer Verletzungen für 200 Menschen10.000 Euro: Emergency Health Kit - eine knappe Tonne schwer, mit Schmerzmitteln, Verbandsmaterialien und chirurgischem Besteck zur Versorgung von etwa 10.000 Menschen für drei Monate.Der Round Table 187 Bamberg hat bereits €2.000 gespendet und hofft, dass sich möglichst viele unserer Freunde dazu entschließen diese Summe mindestens noch zu toppen!Ihr könnt euch jederzeit auf unserer Facebook-Seite und natürlich in der indiegogo Kampagne über den aktuellen Stand informieren.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Bamberg, Germany",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/round-table-bamberg-unterstutzt-nepal/pica

Introduction
India is one of the recognized mega-diverse
countries of the world, harbouring nearly 7-8% of the recorded species of the
world, and representing 4 of the 34 globally identified biodiversity hotspots
(Himalaya, Indo-Burma, Western Ghats and Sri Lanka, Sundaland). Along with
species richness, India also possesses high rates of endemism.
At the same time, as per the IUCN Red List version
2010.4, 94 species of mammals, 78 species of birds, 66 species of amphibians,
30 species of reptiles, 122 species of fish, 113 species of invertebrates and
255 species of plants in India are listed as Critically Endangered, Endangered
and Vulnerable.
For India, conservation of biodiversity is crucial
not only because it provides several goods and services necessary for human
survival, but also because it is directly linked with providing livelihoods to
and improving socio-economic conditions for millions of local people, thereby
contributing to sustainable development and poverty alleviation. An example of
a benefit derived from biodiversity in India is reflected by the forest sector,
which is increasingly being looked upon as a major performer in poverty
alleviation programmes. India’s forests neutralize nearly 11% of India’s
greenhouse gas emissions. Nearly 200 million people are dependent on forests
for livelihood in India.
In the backdrop of the varying socio-cultural milieu
and often conflicting demands of various stakeholders, there is an urgent need
for augmenting and accelerating the efforts for conservation and sustainable
use of biodiversity.
This effort can best be spear-headed by young students,
researchers and scientists, who are the future of nature conservation in India.
<b>Young Ecologists Talk and Interact (YETI:
www.meetyeti.com) is a conference, which brings together such young ecologists
early in their career, and provides them with a friendly and inspiring platform
to present and discuss their work, exchange ideas, and strike up collaborations
with contemporaries.
YETI
is an all-student event – for students, by students. YETI is entirely run by student volunteers from different research
institutes and universities of the country. A democratically functioning core
committee of student volunteers organise this conference every year, with new
volunteers joining each year from different institutes and universities.
We
need help !!!
YETI, being comprised of a body of
volunteering students, does not have a fixed source of funds to support them to
hold these conferences every year. So every time we approach research
institutes, big NGOs and some government funding agencies to raise the money.
This time we thought of going out and asking for help from the international
community, which we believe consists of individuals who believe that the
biodiversity in the Indian Sub-continent is worth saving.
We need money for the following
purpose:
<li>
Paying for the venue (conference halls, class rooms etc.)
where we wish to hold the conference
<li>
Paying travelling expenses to students, who will be selected
to present their study at the conference
<li>
Paying travelling expenses for visiting eminent scientists
and conservationists who will be giving plenary talk and conducting workshops
<li>
Paying for accommodation of the students and the scientists
<li>
Expenses for providing food for the conference days to the
attendees
Impact
of the conference
This is a National level conference, but with
far reaching effects on biodiversity conservation in the Indian Sub-continent.
This conference represents a snapshot of all the conservation work from all
corners of India. To dissipate the conservation efforts of all the presenting

their work at the conference, we wish to upload an abstract book on the website.
The size and diversity of YETIs have grown every year


Some snapshots from previous YETIs

waste.
We all know about the
staggering amount of plastic in the oceans, but the quantity of waste engine
oil may be even worse.  The UN estimates
we dump about 30 million tons of waste oil onto the soil and into the water
every year.   This is more than all the oil spills in the 20th
century combined.
As difficult as it is to
clean up plastic from the ocean, it is even more difficult to clean up waste
oil.  In fact, one tablespoon of oil is
enough to put a film the size of football field on a body of water.  It is full of heavy metals and other
carcinogens which are entering the food chain of every marine organism on the
planet.
column9: >We must stop oil pollution before it begins

column1: The best option is to
recycle waste oil.  But even countries
with strong legislation and infrastructure recycle less than half of their oil.
Most of the world just dumps it on the ground and into the water.
So what’s our solution?
Our solution to this
“mess” is simple- pay people to recycle.  By creating an effective market in poor
countries, we will provide two solutions- save the environment as well as give
local populations much needed income.
We have invented the Mini
Recycling Facility (""Mini"" for short), that fits on a small trailer
and converts waste engine oil into pyrolysis oil which is a diesel-like fuel.
The Mini uses a process called ""pyrolysis"" - the same process used by
refineries but thanks to diligent work over three years, we've shrunk it down
to make it mobile.
The Mini’s unique
portability allow us to practice ""Compensated Recycling"" - traveling
around even the remotest areas, and paying people not to dump their waste oil
on the ground.
Our critics have claimed we clean up
one type of pollution but still put carbon into the atmosphere.  True.  But
by making fuel from already existing petrochemical waste, we not only clean up
the environment, but we help reduce the need for further oil extraction. Not
only that, but our diesel-like fuel can primarily be used for low-cost public
transportation, reducing the need for automobiles.
Furthermore, while advances in carbon
sequestration appear to be on the horizon, no one currently has any ability to
practically or affordably clean up waste oil once it’s in our water
system.
Remember- one tablespoon of waste can
cover a surface of water larger than an acre.
According to http://www.timeforanoilchange.org, 4.37 billion gallons of motor oil and other lubricants are
lost in use, while 1.85 billion gallons of used motor oil and lubricants are
illegally dumped per year globally.  Imagine the impact of over SIX BILLION
GALLONS of waste oil a year going into the water table, and ultimately into the
ocean.  Estuaries, which are nurseries
for both land and sea creatures are particularly hard hit.  Surface phytoplankton are absorbing hardcore
carcinogenics and heavy metals from ingesting the oil.  When the bottom of the food chain dies, how
long does the top of the chain have?
By the Numbers.
Our triple bottom line
organization is good for the environment, it can easily double the income of some
of world’s poorest people, and it is a sustainable business.
A single Mini running 5
days a week for fifty weeks can distill 500,000 liters of waste oil a year
(132,086 gallons). Within 5 years we want to have 100 Minis in operation,
meaning we can be recycling over 50,000,000 liters of waste oil a year
(13,208,602 gallons).  That is a lot of
oil not in ocean and not in the ground water!
The
economic benefits are as big as the environmental impacts. By paying $1
(or more) per 10 liters of waste engine oil each Mini is paying close to
$100,000 into the local economy per year.
Recycled oil is then resold locally, with profits going to build more
Minis.  Through our profits and your continued support our goal of 100 machines
in 5 years is attainable. Can you imagine? 100 Mini recyclers working where

recycling is now impossible.

What We Need Now!

1  Transportation, customs duty                          $15000

2  Storage Tanks and Cargo Motorcycles          $10000

3  Licensing and Legal Fees                                  $10000

4 Begin construction of second machine          $15000

Total Donations needed                                        $50,000

Donate Today!  This campaign is only two weeks!

column2:
>

Landfill space in America is dwindling, and Green Purpose is on a mission to conserve it through the Race for Zero Waste! With your help, we’re raising $50,000 by America Recycles Day (November 15, 2015) to help us continue raising awareness and keeping millions of pounds of recyclables out of landfills.

>As an Eco-Capitalist company, Green Purpose excels at helping companies maximize the profitability of their recycling programs. With the exciting new Race for Zero Waste competition that we have developed, companies now have the opportunity to bring in higher recycling revenues and recycling rates than ever before! Throughout the competition, participating companies receive environmental credibility and the tools and resources necessary to achieve profitability, add value, and save money through recycling and Zero Waste practices. If you want to position yourself as a sustainability leader in your industry, then this is the competition for you.

column1: <div>
What Will Campaign Donations Go Towards?

With your support, we will expand our Race for Zero Waste competition into a worldwide movement in which businesses and individuals can participate for a more sustainable future! Donations will go toward a wide range of things that will help us reach our goal, including:

- Improving our internal platform so that we can have the biggest impact
- Upgrading platform connectivity for both businesses and individuals to get involved in the Race for Zero Waste movement
- Adding to our team of experts who will focus on developing advanced standards

Lastly, a part of the funds will go towards building on to our successful internship program. We believe it's important to give interns from multiple fields of study an opportunity to gain hands-on experience with solving real-world issues.

We're excited to announce that our Race for Zero Waste campaign is in partnership with Protect Our Winters, a cause that is very dear to us.

 10% of ALL funds that are pledged to our crowdfunding campaign will be donated to POW!
What Is Protect Our Winters?

Protect Our Winters (POW) is the leading environmental advocacy group for the winter sports community. Their focus is on educational initiatives and community-based activism in order to improve our overall environment for the snow-sports community and future generations.
What We Need

In order to continue expanding our Race for Zero Waste initiative and reaching companies across the globe, we need your help raising $50,000 in 30 days. We have established a wide range of perks that you will receive in exchange for your generosity. 
Our amazing Race for Zero Waste judge, Olympic medalist Gretchen Bleiler, has joined us in raising awareness about this initiative. Because Gretchen has been so helpful, a percentage of the proceeds from this campaign will also go toward Protect Our Winters (POW), a powerful sustainability initiative that she passionately supports.

What You Get

We've compiled a wide range of exciting perks that you will receive in return for pledging your support! Here are a few of them: 

• A Race for Zero Waste recycling t-shirt
• Recycling bins labelled with the recycling bin sticker of your choice
• Color-coded recycling label stickers
• Our trademarked Green-o-Gram™ posters
We're constantly adding more perks, so make sure to check back often!
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

Waste is not just a problem, it is a globalized catastrophe that is not going away nor solving itself. Due to population increase and limited space, the dwindling supply and increasing demand of landfills will continue to increase costs and pose an extremely negative impact for future generations.

The United States produces 1/4 of the world’s waste, yet it has less than 5% of the population. Nationally, it is estimated that the non-residential sectors generate between 35 and 45% of all Material Solid Waste (MSW). The Race for Zero Waste is designed to assist corporations in the non-residential sector to achieve their sustainability goals in a more efficient and effective manner, but in a format that educates and energizes their employees to recycle every possible material.

Green Purpose established the Race for Zero Waste competition in 2014 as a way to encourage, celebrate and maximize commercial recycling. Some of the world’s most reputable companies have participated in past two Race for Zero Waste competitions, including Kraft Foods, Rockwell Automation, The Libman Company and Dart Container Corporation. Throughout the competition, each participant implemented new ways to increase their recycling efforts for a chance to win the title of the most successful program and earn our esteemed Zero Waste Seal of Excellence. What’s really exciting is that all of the participants have collectively diverted over 15 million pounds of materials!

We are extremely proud of this accomplishment and are committed to expanding our Race for Zero Waste initiative in order to have a positive global impact on commercial waste generation. We are asking for a total contribution of $50,000 in order to keep this momentum going. With your help, we can make a sustainable change for future generations.
<div>
Race for Zero Waste Hall of Fame

Green Purpose has launched two successful Race for Zero Waste competitions so far. Our inaugural Race for Zero Waste competition officially kicked off on America Recycles Day 2014 and was an extremely close race! It was so close, in fact, that two of the companies (Kraft Foods and Rockwell Automation) both ended up receiving the title of the Grand Prize Winner!
<div>
<div>

Both Rockwell Automation and Kraft Foods Group did an exceptional job at engaging their associates in their recycling programs. In an effort to engage more employees, the two highly distinguished companies have made sustainability more relevant to everyday work and easier to opt in rather than opt out.
<div>

Both Rockwell Automation and Kraft Foods Group also did an outstanding job of informing associates about their recycling programs through a variety of educational materials, resources and communication tools. In an effort to educate their associates, Rockwell has recently transformed one of the walls in their main entrance as their official Recycling Wall. The wall has ample information about their recycling metrics, including monthly reports on their annual recycling goals in order to inform associates about the progress of their recycling efforts.
<div>

Lastly, both Rockwell Automation and Kraft Foods Group have advanced recycling collection systems and processes that have maximized the efficiency of their recycling operations. Each facility is structured for ingesting materials that can be diverted from the landfill.
<div>
<div>
Other participants in the inaugural Race for Zero Waste competition did an amazing job as well! In return for their outstanding efforts, each company received their own Seal of Excellence:
MTD won an Employee Participation Seal of Excellence:
<div>
Plastipak won a Collection Systems and Processes Seal of Excellence:
And Silgan White Cap won an Associate Education Seal of Excellence:
About Our Company
<div>
<em>
Green Purpose, LLC is the world's GREENEST Eco-Capitalist enterprise that provides businesses with cutting-edge solutions to our society’s growing waste problem.

At Green Purpose, we are committed to providing businesses with a complete recycling solution, with multiple intuitive products that work together to maximize the effectiveness of their recycling programs as a whole. For years we have been helping some of the most influential companies in the world reduce or eliminate expenses related to waste disposal by developing a universal recycling platform that can be used in any manufacturing, retail, office, school or home setting. Our recycling label stickers, educational posters, bins and other recycling supplies/accessories go together seamlessly and are engineered to help recycling programs succeed from the first day of implementation.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many things that you can do to help us make a LARGE IMPACT on commercial waste! We highly encourage you to join us in raising awareness about the Race for Zero Waste in the following ways:
1. Add your voice for a better future. Share our message online and stay up to date with a follow.
2. Reach out to your favorite brands and educate them about this opportunity. Together we can increase recycling rates by engaging brands in the solution.

The United States produces 1/4 of the world’s waste, yet it has less than 5% of the population. Nationally, it is estimated that the non-residential sectors generate between 35 and 45% of all Material Solid Waste (MSW). The Race for Zero Waste is designed to assist corporations in the non-residential sector to achieve their sustainability goals in a more efficient and effective manner, but in a format that educates and energizes their employees to recycle every possible material.

Green Purpose established the Race for Zero Waste competition in 2014 as a way to encourage, celebrate and maximize commercial recycling. Some of the world’s most reputable companies have participated in past two Race for Zero Waste competitions, including Kraft Foods, Rockwell Automation, The Libman Company and Dart Container Corporation. Throughout the competition, each participant implemented new ways to increase their recycling efforts for a chance to win the title of the most successful program and earn our esteemed Zero Waste Seal of Excellence. What’s really exciting is that all of the participants have collectively diverted over 15 million pounds of materials!

We are extremely proud of this accomplishment and are committed to expanding our Race for Zero Waste initiative in order to have a positive global impact on commercial waste generation. We are asking for a total contribution of $50,000 in order to keep this momentum going. With your help, we can make a sustainable change for future generations.
Race for Zero Waste Hall of Fame

Green Purpose has launched two successful Race for Zero Waste competitions so far. Our inaugural Race for Zero Waste competition officially kicked off on America Recycles Day 2014 and was an extremely close race! It was so close, in fact, that two of the companies (Kraft Foods and Rockwell Automation) both ended up receiving the title of the Grand Prize Winner!

Both Rockwell Automation and Kraft Foods Group did an exceptional job at engaging their associates in their recycling programs. In an effort to engage more employees, the two highly distinguished companies have made sustainability more relevant to everyday work and easier to opt in rather than opt out.

Both Rockwell Automation and Kraft Foods Group  also did an outstanding job of informing associates about their recycling programs through a variety of educational materials, resources and communication tools. In an effort to educate their associates, Rockwell has recently transformed one of the walls in their main entrance as their official Recycling Wall. The wall has ample information about their recycling metrics, including monthly reports on their annual recycling goals in order to inform associates about the progress of their recycling efforts.

Lastly, both Rockwell Automation and Kraft Foods Group have advanced recycling collection systems and processes that have maximized the efficiency of their recycling operations. Each facility is structured for ingesting materials that can be diverted from the landfill.
Other participants in the inaugural Race for Zero Waste competition did an amazing job as well! In return for their outstanding efforts, each company received their own Seal of Excellence:
MTD won an Employee Participation Seal of Excellence:
Plastipak won a Collection Systems and Processes Seal of Excellence:
And Silgan White Cap won an Associate Education Seal of Excellence:
About Our Company
Green Purpose, LLC is the world's GREENEST Eco-Capitalist enterprise that provides businesses with cutting-edge solutions to our society’s growing waste problem.

At Green Purpose, we are committed to providing businesses with a complete recycling solution, with multiple intuitive products that work together to maximize the effectiveness of their recycling programs as a whole. For years we have been helping some of the most influential companies in the world reduce or eliminate expenses related to waste disposal by developing a universal recycling platform that can be used in any manufacturing, retail, office, school or home setting. Our recycling label stickers, educational posters, bins and other recycling supplies/accessories go together seamlessly and are engineered to help recycling programs succeed from the first day of implementation.

Other Ways You Can Help There are many things that you can do to help us make a LARGE IMPACT on commercial waste! We highly encourage you to join us in raising awareness about the Race for Zero Waste in the following ways:
1. Add your voice for a better future. Share our message online and stay up to date with a follow.
2. Reach out to your favorite brands and educate them about this opportunity. Together we can increase recycling rates by engaging brands in the solution.

Spread this campaign on Facebook

column3: >Changing the world means changing our <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column5: >behavior and there’s no better place to start than with our children.

column1: $10,000 = 40 free workshops to approximately 1200 youth!
<div>
Did you know the fashion industry is the 2nd largest polluter next to oil?
This is an astounding fact, and one that has made many people question where our clothes come from, who makes our clothes, and where they end up when we are done with them.

column2:
>Fashion Takes Action is Canada's only non profit organization devoted to the social and environmental impacts of the fashion industry. While reaching adult consumers remains important to us, we have chosen to also educate and empower youth - BEFORE they become consumers.
 
If we can help them understand what goes into making our clothes, and relate to the people who farm the fields, process and dye the materials, cut and sew the garments, then perhaps we could see a large-scale shift in how we make, buy and care for our clothes.

column1: My Clothes My World is available for grades 4-12  (in both English and French). Our full and half-day workshops elicit discussion around consumerism, human rights and environmental degradation while we open the students' eyes to the truth about the apparel industry and inspire them to take meaningful action.

Why Fashion?

Some of the negative impacts of the fashion industry that we cover in our workshop include:
• The use of toxic chemicals to grow, process and treat fabric
• Unfair and unsafe labour practices
• The enormous amounts of water required to make clothing
• Unethical and often unregulated disposal of contaminated water into global rivers and lakes
• Fast fashion and over-consumption contributing to the growing number of textiles in landfill each year.

Through a holistic lens the program presents students with a number of questions about the industry and their direct impact. By the end of the day they are able to describe several problems that exist, and come up with sustainable solutions.

     

    Our most popular  activity, turning an old t-shirt into a bag, is a hands-on opportunity to explore the idea or solution, of upcycling or repurposing.
column5: >Sounds great right? It is, but we need your help!!

column1: What We Need to Make this Happen

Our goal is to expand the reach of My Clothes, My World Neighbourhood Improvement Areas (NIAs) in Toronto with the hopes of expanding the program across Ontario with our 206-2017 campaign. As we are not funded by any school system, nor do we receive any third party or government support, the hard cost to each school to deliver our workshop is $500, so $10,000 would allow us to fully subsidize 40 schools, reaching an average of 1,200 students in local NIAs. 

With the help of our charitable partner, Inner City Angels, and a small subsidy fund we created in 2015, we were able to deliver the program to more than 300 students in schools in NIAs across Toronto, which would otherwise not have been reached.
Fashion Takes Action
FTA is Canada’s premier non-profit organization that focuses on sustainability in the fashion industry. Our goal is to shift behaviour toward more positive social and environmental impacts.

Since FTA began in 2007 we have worked with more than 300 fashion designers, retailers and brands. As an awareness and advocacy group, we have run a number of campaigns across Canada, and have hosted or participated in several public events, helping to bridge the gap between industry and consumers.

FTA is a volunteer-run organization that has yet to receive funding of any kind. In the nearly 9 years since inception, every success has been made possible because of our amazing volunteers and the personal investment of our founding executive director Kelly Drennan. For more information please visit our website.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to donate to our cause at this time, here are some suggestions of other ways you can support FTA and My Clothes, My World:
<ul>
• Email your friends and share the campaign page link.
• Share through social media
• Contact your School Council to find out how you can fundraise or access funds to get My Clothes, My World into your child's school.

Thank you for helping us bring this valuable workshop to children who would otherwise not have access!

I'm Geoff Wakeling, a plant lover, conservationist and wildlife enthusiast - and I want to plant a wildflower meadow. Why? Because with intensive farming stripping the land, we're losing native flora and fauna. Once they're gone, they're gone forever. Without many of them, such as bees, even our own existence as a species is put in danger.

column9: >When my grandfather (a Suffolk farmer, born and bred) died, our family had to sell off the farm buildings. However, we kept as much as the farmland as possible and allowed the land to be managed by local growers in need of extra acreage. Now, worried by the rate that natural habitats are being lost across the UK and the battle many of our flower, insect and animal species are facing, I want to create a small safe haven in an area that's largely been stripped of vegetation and turned into prairie-like fields.

column4: >As phase one, two thirds of the field will be sown. The upper third is being set aside for woodland expansion.

column3: >I'm determined to sow a meadow as the first phase of an ongoing project which also includes extending existing woodland, rescuing plant-choked ponds and reestablishing traditional British farmland hedgerows. With a little help from you, I can sow the entire field this spring, allowing wildlife and the entire ecosystem, to mature and benefit sooner.

column1: How can you help?
This spring the first phase will begin, with the wildflower seeds being sown by hand
column2: a process known as broadcasting. I have the field, I have the time, I have the funds for some seeds, and I have the determination......but I need £1,300 to sow the entire 1.5 acre field.

column1: ANY donation is gratefully received as it means I can sow more seeds. A few pounds/dollars gets more flowers, and we have perks including wildflower postcards, cotton tote bags and even the chance to have your name engraved upon a bench in the field itself, so please take a look at what's on offer.
<h1><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

You might not think that a tiny meadow in a remote part of Suffolk is going to have much environmental impact, but you'd be surprised. For the area, it'll have huge benefits, ensuring wildlife and flora can thrive undisturbed. Insects, such as bees and butterflies, will be able to find food and go on to pollinate the crops we rely on. AND, if this single meadow can gain funding and make people sit up and take notice, perhaps it'll encourage others to do something similar.

If you can donate, I'd be eternally grateful. If you can't, then don't worry as you can still help hugely by sharing our project on social media (there's some handy sharing options at the top of this page). You could even decided to plant a small wildflower patch yourself and improve your local area - that's what it's all really about!!

I run The Guide to Gay Gardening website, and you can also follow me on Twitter and Facebook where they'll be additional updates and fundraiser shoutouts. Thanks SO much for taking the time to read a little...let the Great Wildlife and Flower Meadow commence!
(HUGE thanks to David Smith of Gravy Designs for contributing the beautiful logo!)
Fund it, Sow it, Grow it Logo © G. Wakeling

","I'm Geoff Wakeling, a plant lover, conservationist and wildlife enthusiast - and I want to plant a wildflower meadow. Why? Because with intensive farming stripping the land, we're losing native flora and fauna. Once they're gone, they're gone forever. Without many of them, such as bees, even our own existence as a species is put in danger.

When my grandfather (a Suffolk farmer, born and bred) died, our family had to sell off the farm buildings. However, we kept as much as the farmland as possible and allowed the land to be managed by local growers in need of extra acreage. Now, worried by the rate that natural habitats are being lost across the UK and the battle many of our flower, insect and animal species are facing, I want to create a small safe haven in an area that's largely been stripped of vegetation and turned into prairie-like fields.
As phase one, two thirds of the field will be sown. The upper third is being set aside for woodland expansion.

I'm determined to sow a meadow as the first phase of an ongoing project which also includes extending existing woodland, rescuing plant-choked ponds and reestablishing traditional British farmland hedgerows. With a little help from you, I can sow the entire field this spring, allowing wildlife and the entire ecosystem, to mature and benefit sooner.
How can you help?
This spring the first phase will begin, with the wildflower seeds being sown by hand
column2: a process known as broadcasting. I have the field, I have the time, I have the funds for some seeds, and I have the determination......but I need £1,300 to sow the entire 1.5 acre field.

column1: ANY donation is gratefully received as it means I can sow more seeds. A few pounds/dollars gets more flowers, and we have perks including wildflower postcards, cotton tote bags and even the chance to have your name engraved upon a bench in the field itself, so please take a look at what's on offer.
A single meadow's impact

You might not think that a tiny meadow in a remote part of Suffolk is going to have much environmental impact, but you'd be surprised. For the area, it'll have huge benefits, ensuring wildlife and flora can thrive undisturbed. Insects, such as bees and butterflies, will be able to find food and go on to pollinate the crops we rely on. AND, if this single meadow can gain funding and make people sit up and take notice, perhaps it'll encourage others to do something similar.
Help us spread the word....

If you can donate, I'd be eternally grateful. If you can't, then don't worry as you can still help hugely by sharing our project on social media (there's some handy sharing options at the top of this page). You could even decided to plant a small wildflower patch yourself and improve your local area - that's what it's all really about!!

I run The Guide to Gay Gardening website, and you can also follow me on Twitter and Facebook where they'll be additional updates and fundraiser shoutouts. Thanks SO much for taking the time to read a little...let the Great Wildlife and Flower Meadow commence!
(HUGE thanks to David Smith of Gravy Designs for contributing the beautiful logo!)
