''Be the change you wish to see in the world''
How two girls in their 20s can make more people aware of danger of the global warming , wrong resource management and also help the animals living captive in factory fur farms?
We faced those questions while trying to live by Mahatma Gandhi’s famous words. That’s how ‘’Raising awareness and helping animals’’ project has been created.

What Do We Want To Do?

We want to inspire the largest possible group of people to get involved in helping to solve the burning issues of environment/animal protection and social injustice. We believe that by doing it in a creative way we can get more people to act towards making the positive change.

Our Plan

column5:
>A three months bicycle tour through Central Europe and the Balkans! During the trip we will stop in the largest cities to organize free screenings of excellent documentary movies such as ‘’Samsara’’ , ‘’Earthlings’’ , ‘’Cowspiracy’’ and ‘’HOME’’. The events will provide a great occasion for discussion and idea’s exchange ,but also will be a chance to expand the participants’ knowledge on the given subjects. Every person who takes part in the screening will bring a small gift – an item that for some reasons is important for them or have an interesting history. Our bikes and all the items we will have collected during the tour are going to be sold at the charity auction we plan to organize in October in our city. Collected income is going to be donated the most effective non- profit organizations in Poland fighting for animal rights and well- being ( ''VIVA!''- helping to improve condition of Polish animal shelters , ''Centaurus''- rescuing horses from slaughterhouses) . 

Wait ,there's more!

column1: <div>

You can follow our trip and find stories about all the collected items on our facebook page. It means that a person who buys any item on the October auction, will be able to contact the former owner with ease. We hope to create the entire community of travelers making a positive change in the world!

Depending on the funds raised ,we plan to produce a professional documentary about the ‘’Raising awareness and helping animals’’ project.

Why On Bicycles?

We want to get the largest possible group of people ( including media) involved in the project. We believe that actions speak louder than words! Through a bicycle tour we hope to – as a positive side effect- promote healthy ,eco – friendly lifestyle and show that persistence ,passion and will can do miracles.
About Us
<div>

column3:
/>

We are two students from Kraków passionate about travelling. Last year we took a year off from regular life to hitchhike all across Europe and Canada. One of us hitchhiked Canada coast to coast (and a couple of islands) ,biked in Mexico and came back craving for more adventures. The other hitched through Spain AKA ''the most unhitchhikable place on Earth'' and has done permaculture volunteering in France and Portugal.  We both want to dedicate our future to finding ways of combining travels and social activism.

column1: What We Need Fundig For

BIKES – the most demanding and at the same time the most important element of the practical project’s organization. They need to survive a three months long tour. It means we have around 3000 km to go!
PUBLIC SCREENING LICENSE – of course we want all the documentaries to be shown from a legal source.
Optional :
GEAR – GPS , bicycle bags , spare tires etc.

DOCUMENARY PRODUCTION – crossing the 2500 $ threshold allows us to make a professional documentary about ‘’Raising awareness and helping animals’’ project ( covering a camera ,professional editing and post –production costs)
How Else Can You Help?
<div>
Share : post the information about our campaign on your favourite social network site!
Follow : here you will find the news regarding our project - Our Facebook Page
Join us : come to one ( or more) of our documentary screenings , donate an item for the charity auction and share your story!

Help us to organize a documentary screening : if you want to take an active part in the project and you have a possibility to organize a documentary screening in your city , we will be very happy to hear from you! Please ,contact us by mail : magdalena.wrobel1780@gmail.com
All the contributors are invited to visit us in Kraków or come for the charity auction!
Together We Can Do Anything. Let's Make A Change. Thank You For All Your Help!

My name is Brandon Michael and I am an entrepreneur from Nashville, TN. My background, for over ten years, is in healthcare waste management and compliance services. Our new venture SafePoint is as a platform to provide your local veterinarian, dentist, medical doctor and yes, even the tattoo parlor with a secure solution to dispose of healthcare products (such as used needles) and cost-effective compliance services. SafePoint allows its clients to use our services on their terms with NO contract. Our goal at SafePoint is to make the customer experience as incredible as possible. Our services prevent pharmaceuticals from entering our water sources, and we provide recycling options to minimize the carbon footprint of medical waste.

With proper funding, SafePoint can develop into a platform and thriving business that can assist healthcare providers and even home users with a better solution for waste streams. New laws and regulation (as well as implementation) will continue to increase in healthcare and trust me, some major changes will be coming soon in regards to segregating waste streams, accountability, disposal and properly storing them. And as per usual, healthcare providers look for cheaper ways to dispose of medical waste while the industry giants tack on more fees and raise costs, making the market very vulnerable to an honest company that does business the way it should be done.
SafePoint offers a mail back program for all 50 states for expired &
column2:
unused pharmaceuticals and used needles, sharps and RMW (regulated medical waste). We have strategically partnered with trusted companies to provide onsite services throughout the US for sharps and red bag as well. Another partnership allows SafePoint to make sure all hazardous medical wastes can be securely picked up onsite and accounted for according to EPA regulations. Our bundled products and services offer destruction and compliance services for controlled and non-controlled pharmaceuticals, used sharps (needles) and hazardous healthcare products. Our website, www.safepointsecure.com is still under construction, as we our adding the store to make it easy for clients to order and pay online 24/7/365.
Our team at SafePoint has worked with numerous healthcare and pharma companies, and even stewardship programs (just Google 'pharmaceutical take back programs in Alameda County (CA) and King County (WA)'..  where the pharma manufacturers are responsibl for waste costs associated with expired and unused medications.. big pharma lost in the Supreme Court on the decision). We are experienced and knowledgeable, and I have taken the time to hand select each person involved with our organization. We have the capabilities to handle any bandwidth, no matter if it's small facility or larger GPO, for healthcare providers needing these services.
From my experiences and insight, I have learned there a few major publicly traded companies that have created monopolies in this niche industry. It has also come to my knowledge that the largest company in the market is hand-cuffing healthcare providers to these contracts with adjusted price increases and unethical business practices. The market would turn to other providers for the services, but the industry giant is acquiring small businesses in this sector faster than the speed of light. As I see it, this is typical in the healthcare arena and that's why the price for healthcare in general is exponentially growing everyday.

OUR PRODUCTS &
column4:
*Pharmaceuticals:
   - Instant Return is a simple, flat-rate system (cardboard box, proper compliance forms, etc.) that healthcare providers can dispose of their unused and expired medications, whether they are controlled or non-controlled. The 1 gallon system will be retail for $100, while the 3 galllon system will retail for $150.
*Sharps &
column5:
Used Needles:
   - For sharps and used needles, we have the SafeSharp Professional Pack. We have containers in a 1 quart, 1 gallon, 3 gallon and even 8, 12, and 18 gallon sizes. We have mail back programs (meaning you can send everything through the mail) for each size and we even have combination packs. Yes, these are the conatiners located in the doctor's office by the sink or hanging on the wall.
*Hazardous Medical Waste:
   - For any pharmaceuticals or medical waste that is deemed hazardous, we have a partnership with a repubtable company that provides onsite service nationwide.
*Secure Document Destruction Services
*Spill Kits for Various Reasons

column1: WHAT SAFEPOINT NEEDS &
column3:
We are looking to raise $52,000 that will carry us through the end of the year for our start-up expenses. Here is a break down of the #s:

*Start-Up Costs &
column4:
Requirements for 6 Months (07/15 - 12/15)

Security Cameras, Internet and Electric       $1,200
Legal/Licensing/Training      $6,000
Online SAS &
column6:
Insurance    $10,400
Pollution Liability Insurance     $1,200
Salary of Operation Manager    $12,000

**Total Start-Up Expenses for 6 Months:      $52,000 
So what does the investor get out of the deal? How did I know you would ask. We have a list of perks for 'helping a biz out'. And just know that you have invested into a company that is conscious about our environment and not out to deceive our clients.

MARKETING --->
column7:
The key message associated with SafePoint’s products and services are affordability and reliability for customers. SafePoint believes it can achieve success through the bundling our products and services provided. We will have a competitive edge in the market because we are able to cater to our client’s needs and service needs, unlike our competitors. We will be able to act promptly to questions and concerns from our customers with real people that respond quickly, giving them results transparently and instantly while keeping it simple!

THE IMPACT --->
column8:
SafePoint has been a concept for over three years. In that time, we have crafted a viable business plan, trusted partnerships and a product line. The effort and time to develop this strategy has been constant, yet we will not be able to get to Day 1 unless we can get funding. I have tried every bank, investment group and uncle possible without signing away my parental rights to my son or selling body parts on the black market. Trust me, funding is the hardest part for an entrepreneur like myself. If anything, feel good about the fact that your donation is greatly appreciated, and will go toward funding a company that cares about people and the environment.
Our competition is bullying healthcare providers through unfair contracts and threatening to sue anyone trying to break their contract. On top of their scheme, the industry giant sales reps are telling healthcare providers that they will ""have to use the big guys"", because they will ""end up buying all the little companies in the way."" Those are the exact words and their attitude towards the market. And, that's probably why over 13 states are suing the big company due to unethical business practices at schools and other government healthcare facilities. Feel free to google this info and look on the BBB to see how they are currently deceiving healthcare facilities all over the US. 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP --->
column10: Help us out by promoting our company on Facebook, LinkedIn or simply ask your dentist, veterinarian or medical doctor who they are using for their healthcare waste stream services. Visit our website at www.safepointsecure.com for more information.

column1: ","My name is Brandon Michael and I am an entrepreneur from Nashville, TN. My background, for over ten years, is in healthcare waste management and compliance services. Our new venture SafePoint is as a platform to provide your local veterinarian, dentist, medical doctor and yes, even the tattoo parlor with a secure solution to dispose of healthcare products (such as used needles) and cost-effective compliance services. SafePoint allows its clients to use our services on their terms with NO contract. Our goal at SafePoint is to make the customer experience as incredible as possible. Our services prevent pharmaceuticals from entering our water sources, and we provide recycling options to minimize the carbon footprint of medical waste.

With proper funding, SafePoint can develop into a platform and thriving business that can assist healthcare providers and even home users with a better solution for waste streams. New laws and regulation (as well as implementation) will continue to increase in healthcare and trust me, some major changes will be coming soon in regards to segregating waste streams, accountability, disposal and properly storing them. And as per usual, healthcare providers look for cheaper ways to dispose of medical waste while the industry giants tack on more fees and raise costs, making the market very vulnerable to an honest company that does business the way it should be done. SafePoint offers a mail back program for all 50 states for expired & unused pharmaceuticals and used needles, sharps and RMW (regulated medical waste). We have strategically partnered with trusted companies to provide onsite services throughout the US for sharps and red bag as well. Another partnership allows SafePoint to make sure all hazardous medical wastes can be securely picked up onsite and accounted for according to EPA regulations. Our bundled products and services offer destruction and compliance services for controlled and non-controlled pharmaceuticals, used sharps (needles) and hazardous healthcare products. Our website, www.safepointsecure.com is still under construction, as we our adding the store to make it easy for clients to order and pay online 24/7/365.Our team at SafePoint has worked with numerous healthcare and pharma companies, and even stewardship programs (just Google 'pharmaceutical take back programs in Alameda County (CA) and King County (WA)'..  where the pharma manufacturers are responsibl for waste costs associated with expired and unused medications.. big pharma lost in the Supreme Court on the decision). We are experienced and knowledgeable, and I have taken the time to hand select each person involved with our organization. We have the capabilities to handle any bandwidth, no matter if it's small facility or larger GPO, for healthcare providers needing these services.From my experiences and insight, I have learned there a few major publicly traded companies that have created monopolies in this niche industry. It has also come to my knowledge that the largest company in the market is hand-cuffing healthcare providers to these contracts with adjusted price increases and unethical business practices. The market would turn to other providers for the services, but the industry giant is acquiring small businesses in this sector faster than the speed of light. As I see it, this is typical in the healthcare arena and that's why the price for healthcare in general is exponentially growing everyday.OUR PRODUCTS & SERVICES ---> *Pharmaceuticals:   - Instant Return is a simple, flat-rate system (cardboard box, proper compliance forms, etc.) that healthcare providers can dispose of their unused and expired medications, whether they are controlled or non-controlled. The 1 gallon system will be retail for $100, while the 3 galllon system will retail for $150.*Sharps & Used Needles:   - For sharps and used needles, we have the SafeSharp Professional Pack. We have containers in a 1 quart, 1 gallon, 3 gallon and even 8, 12, and 18 gallon sizes. We have mail back programs (meaning you can send everything through the mail) for each size and we even have combination packs. Yes, these are the conatiners located in the doctor's office by the sink or hanging on the wall.*Hazardous Medical Waste:   - For any pharmaceuticals or medical waste that is deemed hazardous, we have a partnership with a repubtable company that provides onsite service nationwide.*Secure Document Destruction Services*Spill Kits for Various Reasons

WHAT SAFEPOINT NEEDS & WHAT YOU GET --->We are looking to raise $52,000 that will carry us through the end of the year for our start-up expenses. Here is a break down of the #s:*Start-Up Costs & Requirements for 6 Months (07/15 - 12/15)Security Cameras, Internet and Electric       $1,200Legal/Licensing/Training      $6,000Online SAS & Website Maintenance  $6,000Products - Containers   $1,500Marketing Materials      $400Rent (6 months @ $1200) & Insurance    $10,400Pollution Liability Insurance     $1,200Salary of Operation Manager    $12,000**Total Start-Up Expenses for 6 Months:      $52,000  So what does the investor get out of the deal? How did I know you would ask. We have a list of perks for 'helping a biz out'. And just know that you have invested into a company that is conscious about our environment and not out to deceive our clients. MARKETING --->The key message associated with SafePoint’s products and services are affordability and reliability for customers. SafePoint believes it can achieve success through the bundling our products and services provided. We will have a competitive edge in the market because we are able to cater to our client’s needs and service needs, unlike our competitors. We will be able to act promptly to questions and concerns from our customers with real people that respond quickly, giving them results transparently and instantly while keeping it simple! THE IMPACT --->SafePoint has been a concept for over three years. In that time, we have crafted a viable business plan, trusted partnerships and a product line. The effort and time to develop this strategy has been constant, yet we will not be able to get to Day 1 unless we can get funding. I have tried every bank, investment group and uncle possible without signing away my parental rights to my son or selling body parts on the black market. Trust me, funding is the hardest part for an entrepreneur like myself. If anything, feel good about the fact that your donation is greatly appreciated, and will go toward funding a company that cares about people and the environment.Our competition is bullying healthcare providers through unfair contracts and threatening to sue anyone trying to break their contract. On top of their scheme, the industry giant sales reps are telling healthcare providers that they will ""have to use the big guys"", because they will ""end up buying all the little companies in the way."" Those are the exact words and their attitude towards the market. And, that's probably why over 13 states are suing the big company due to unethical business practices at schools and other government healthcare facilities. Feel free to google this info and look on the BBB to see how they are currently deceiving healthcare facilities all over the US. OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP --->Don't have a dollar to give --> Help us out by promoting our company on Facebook, LinkedIn or simply ask your dentist, veterinarian or medical doctor who they are using for their healthcare waste stream services. Visit our website at www.safepointsecure.com for more information.",1.0,0,"1 Campaign

column7:
>Short Summary

My name is Ashley Teshima. I am a current design student at Grand Canyon University and hope to use my art to help communities in need. When the typhoons hit the Philippines, I knew that access to clean water would be an issue. I decided to design shirts and sell them in order to provide as many filters as I could to those in affected areas. Being born in the Philippines and spending a significant time of my life there, this project is close to my heart.

column5: >Our club is building a four-classroom schoolhouse/emergency evacuation center in Kabangbang, Bantayan Island Cebu.
column9: >I am already passing out school supplies to the children at the school and thought it would be a perfect time to also pass out water filters.

column1:
$5 Sticker pack
$10 (1) shirt of your choice 
$25 Both styles of shirts and sticker pack
$50 2 shirts, sticker pack, and signed poster prints 
$100 2 shirts, sticker pack, signed poster prints, and signed original print of Ashley's painting
The Impact

column5: >Our club has built a classroom and a nutrition center in the area already. We aim to keep building classrooms and other buildings to help out the community.

column1: We want to provide water filters to those in need at our evacuation center. Each filter costs $50 and filters 1 Million gallons of water. Each filter provides water for about 100 people.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

The main challenges that we will face is being able to teach members of the community how to use the filters correctly. I do not speak the native language so I would need to create visual aids to communicate my message.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about our project by sharing this project with your family and friends

","Short Summary My name is Ashley Teshima. I am a current design student at Grand Canyon University and hope to use my art to help communities in need. When the typhoons hit the Philippines, I knew that access to clean water would be an issue. I decided to design shirts and sell them in order to provide as many filters as I could to those in affected areas. Being born in the Philippines and spending a significant time of my life there, this project is close to my heart.

Our club is building a four-classroom schoolhouse/emergency evacuation center in Kabangbang, Bantayan Island Cebu. I am already passing out school supplies to the children at the school and thought it would be a perfect time to also pass out water filters.
What You Get

$5 Sticker pack$10 (1) shirt of your choice $25 Both styles of shirts and sticker pack$50 2 shirts, sticker pack, and signed poster prints $100 2 shirts, sticker pack, signed poster prints, and signed original print of Ashley's painting
The Impact
Our club has built a classroom and a nutrition center in the area already. We aim to keep building classrooms and other buildings to help out the community.
We want to provide water filters to those in need at our evacuation center. Each filter costs $50 and filters 1 Million gallons of water. Each filter provides water for about 100 people.

Risks & Challenges The main challenges that we will face is being able to teach members of the community how to use the filters correctly. I do not speak the native language so I would need to create visual aids to communicate my message.
Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word about our project by sharing this project with your family and friends",7.0,0,"1 Campaign

Our Story
My name is Julio, and
I am the CEO of an organization called CONSES in Cochabamba, Bolivia.  I
am a Bolivian civil engineer, and throughout my time living here ecological
awareness and proper sanitation has often been overlooked.  With the large
migration of rural populations to the city of Cochabamba in recent years, many
families lack access to proper sanitation and clean water.  Improper sanitation contributes to pollution and
dangerous health conditions, particularly in the most impoverished parts of the
city.  Since many communities lack access to a sewer system or septic
system, standalone ecological bathrooms have become a more feasible
solution.  Nevertheless, many people
still lack any appropriate bathroom facility, and the health consequences are
significant.
Currently 40% of the people
in Cochabamba lack access to these basic services.  This overall
percentage, however, does not tell the whole story.  Many times there is complete sanitary sewer
service coverage in the wealthier parts of the city, while impoverished
communities have little to no adequate sanitation infrastructure.  Due to the lack of these services, the
children get many different gastrointestinal diseases that produce diarrhea.
As a result, many children die before they are 5 years old.  The infant
mortality rate (under 1 year of age) for all of Bolivia is roughly 7 times the
rate in the United States.  In
communities lacking proper sanitation and clean water, the rate can be as much as 20 times the infant mortality rate in United States. Thus, the
people in Cochabamba who suffer from this lack of access to proper sanitation
and clean water typically must pay 5 to 10 times the average cost to have water
delivered by trucks from other areas.
Fortunately, there is
a way you can help us <span>flush
away the pollution and improve health conditions.  I have partnered
with a civil engineer from the United States, Jason Obergfell, and together we
have worked on developing innovative ways to make ecological bathrooms more
economical and effective.  Jason has
worked on water and basic sanitation projects in Bolivia for over 8 years.  Our experience has helped us identify ways to
improve upon the ecological bathroom options that are currently used.  The funds we are raising will be used to buy
the mold for producing our new composting toilet model made of high strength
plastic.  Each time plastic is injected into the mold, it will produce
another new toilet for an ecological bathroom.  The mold will be used to
help form the toilet seat, the urine separator, the chamber that will hold a storage
receptacle, and the ventilation system.  Your contribution can assist us
in taking this integral step to providing new composting toilets to more
people in impoverished communities within Cochabamba.
Since its foundation,
our organization, CONSES, has designed new models of composting toilets for
ecological bathrooms at a low cost while using new materials friendly to the
environment.  This has addressed the treatment and utilization of the
treated waste for fertilizer in less than 2 months.  Many of the families
that enjoy the benefits of our ecological sanitation training workshops and
composting toilets regularly give positive feedback.  Overall, CONSES and
other organizations in Cochabamba have already launched public outreach
campaigns to more than 20% of people in the marginalized areas of Cochabamba to
familiarize people with ecological bathrooms.
Moreover, many
experiences in my life have influenced my work.  For example, I once met a
family in which the mother was blind and the father had a very bad back from
working in mining near Potosi. Therefore, we resolved these issues when we
modified the design of the ecological bathroom by building appropriate stairs
and railing for this family.  Thus, this prompted us to establish CONSES
to improve these designs for elderly people, children and disabled persons
who have problems in having proper sanitation and clean water.  With your
help, we can continue assisting the various poor communities of Cochabamba by
using new funds to buy a mold that will help us construct a new compositing
toilet and provide proper sanitation to many.
In the green area of
Cochabamba, there is a lot of potable and clean water.  In the yellow area, there is some water, but
it is limited.  In the large red area of

Cochabamba, there is no potable or clean water in this poor area of the city.


The Better Option:
With your help, we can
use the funds to obtain a mold that will be used numerous times to economically
create more composting toilets for ecological bathrooms.
Additionally, the
current bunker model for composting toilets in Bolivia and many parts of the
developing world includes a small room made of brick, two chambers for compost,
and the actual toilet itself.  This bunker model has several disadvantages
to our proposed model:
1.
Cost: The bunker model requires a huge monetary
investment, in relative terms. The bunker model often requires over a thousand
dollars to construct.  Because of these high price tags, many of the
families who need composting toilets the most, the poor who live outside the
range of sewer services, cannot afford to build composting toilets.
2.
Portability: The bunker model is not portable for poorer
communities that always face the risk of having to move.  Often in poor
communities, there is no housing stability and communities move
frequently.  Fortunately, the new model is portable and more flexible than
the bunker. For households that do not have the space to construct a separate
latrine outside, they can simply utilize a space within their existing home.
This portable toilet model also allows families to bring their composting toilet
with them and not lose their investment.
3.
Reliability: Furthermore, the new model allows people that
have existing toilets and bathrooms to more easily convert their toilet to a
composting toilet. In the bunker model, there is hardly a constant flow of composted
material. Human waste must remain in the composting chambers for six to eight
months. This means that there is not always fertilizer easily available. With
the new model, there is a more constant flow of material and therefore it is a
more reliable source of fertilizer. As a result, access to cleaner water has
become a more attainable reality, since these dry ecological toilets improve
the sanitation practices through providing poorer families with more basic
services.
4.
Recycling: Lastly, the new model can be constructed
entirely of recycled materials. While the bunker model is not incredibly
unsustainable, it still requires new bricks, sand, concrete, and metal. The new
model can be made of various grades of recycled plastics. With this model, your
empty plastic water bottle could become someone’s path to better health as an
ecological toilet.
Fortunately, given the
strong history of CONSES of working with composting toilets and ecological
bathrooms, our organization is incredibly capable of promoting and constructing
more ecological bathrooms with the innovative composting toilets that will be
produced with the mold that you can help us create with your contribution.  Together, we will be able to more
economically and effectively address the root causes of health-threatening
pollution in the communities that need it most.
First, donating to our campaign is much appreciated, and
you would be participating in our efforts to eliminate sanitation issues within
Cochabamba by helping us construct a new composting toilet option for ecological

bathrooms that can better serve the diverse sanitation need.  Please note:  Since CONSES is a partner organization of another NGO in Bolivia called Sustainable Bolivia, all donations will be sent to Sustainable Bolivia.  Afterwards, these funds will be sent to CONSES to be used for buying the mold to produce this new composting toilet option.
Additionally, the second way to help is to spread
awareness about our efforts through sharing this campaign to your friends and
family on social media (Facebook, Twitter, etc.).
Furthermore, the third way that you can help our
campaign is through volunteering with our organization.  Our partner organization, Sustainable Bolivia, facilitates volunteer and internship opportunities with CONSES and in Cochabamba.
Link to our page on

Sustainable Bolivia:  http://www.sustainablebolivia.org/partner_organizations/uccesise.html



Muchas Gracias
Our organization, CONSES, is very
appreciative of any assistance that you are willing to provide.  At the moment, our organization simply needs
your help to purchase the mold that will be used to make this new and innovative composting toilet.  Aside from the listed perks, helping us take
this final step will give you the benefit of knowing that another poor
community within Cochabamba will eventually have basic access to proper

sanitation and cleaner water because of the new composting toilet option.



Contact Information
Our email:  conses.cochabamba@gmail.com
Our phone

number:  +591 4 4292954 - +591 76900593

Our main website:  http://conses.org
Our website with
Sustainable Bolivia:  http://www.sustainablebolivia.org/partner_organizations/uccesise.html
Our Facebook
Page:  https://www.facebook.com/conses.cochabamba
Our Twitter

Page: https://twitter.com/consesbolivia

The Global Warming Express was founded by two 8-year-olds who decided to encourage adults to adopt more earth-friendly practices. Since then, GWE has grown from a small group of  10 kids to over 100 kids in a matter of months.

In the past year, GWE kids have spoken with elected officials on the local, state, and national level, organized letter writing campaigns, and helped their own schools adopt sustainable initiatives. In the coming year, they plan to bring reusable bags to Santa Fe, launch a kids' radio show on sustainability, and give their chapter book about the impacts of climate change to President Obama.
James Hansen, eminent climate scientist, told the GWE kids, “tell all the kids not to be afraid of climate change.”  They're not afraid – in fact, they're raring to go!
This organization was started by kids.  We are following their lead.

column2: >

column1: Here's what they've done during the past 2 school years:
Written
<ul>
• Wrote and illustrated a chapter book for kids on climate change (seeking a publisher)
<li>
Wrote letters to the editor, the Secretary General of the UN, and President Obama
<li>
Organized a letter-writing campaign against unsustainable palm oil production
Advocated
<ul>
<li>
Testified at the EPA hearings on coal in Denver (sponsored by the Sierra Club)
• Participated in the NYC Climate March
• Pushed the Santa Fe City Council to ban plastic bags and charge 10¢ for paper bags.
• Organized their own Keystone Pipeline rally
• Held a seat on the Mayor's Climate Action Task Force
Learned and taught
<ul>
• Partnered with Santa Fe Public Schools on green initiatives and sustainability actions, including a composting program and a low carbon footprint lunch program
• Requested and secured approval and funding for a solar installation at the original GWE elementary school
• Held a two-week climate change summer camp
• Formed a bi-lingual Green Team to teach custodians how and why to recycle
<ul>
<li>
Elementary School Solar Panels -  Advocating, planning, measuring, and testifying for solar panels at Acequia Madre Elementary school.
<li>

Global Warming Express Book - Now 12 years old, GWE founders Marina Weber (writer) and Joanna Whysner (illustrator) are finishing their book on climate change, The Global Warming Express, with hopes of presenting it to President Obama.
<li>
Reusable Bags - GWE is partnering with Mujeres de Adelante and Warehouse 21 to create reusable bags for residents and visitors of Santa Fe.
<li>
Radio Broadcasts - GWE is partnering with KSFR radio to start a GWE Sustainability Show with the GWE middle schoolers.
<li>

Every kid is a superhero. Here’s how the superheroes tackle this issue.
1. Learn - Kids are hungry for information, but don’t always have access to it. GWE offers a foundation in climate education. This includes:
<ul>
• climate science literacy
• sustainability awareness
• natural sciences
<ul>

2. Feel - The kids feel many things in reaction to what they learn. They might feel sad, frustrated, inspired, excited...  These feelings allow the kids to brainstorm and think creatively about how they want to respond.
3. Act - Students gain opportunities to act through:
<ul>
• public speaking training
• research and writing
• visual arts
• performance skills

","The Global Warming Express was founded by two 8-year-olds who decided to encourage adults to adopt more earth-friendly practices. Since then, GWE has grown from a small group of  10 kids to over 100 kids in a matter of months.

In the past year, GWE kids have spoken with elected officials on the local, state, and national level, organized letter writing campaigns, and helped their own schools adopt sustainable initiatives. In the coming year, they plan to bring reusable bags to Santa Fe, launch a kids' radio show on sustainability, and give their chapter book about the impacts of climate change to President Obama.
James Hansen, eminent climate scientist, told the GWE kids, “tell all the kids not to be afraid of climate change.”  They're not afraid – in fact, they're raring to go!
This organization was started by kids.  We are following their lead.
Here's what they've done during the past 2 school years:
Written
Wrote and illustrated a chapter book for kids on climate change (seeking a publisher)
Wrote letters to the editor, the Secretary General of the UN, and President Obama
Organized a letter-writing campaign against unsustainable palm oil production
Advocated
Testified at the EPA hearings on coal in Denver (sponsored by the Sierra Club)
Participated in the NYC Climate March
Pushed the Santa Fe City Council to ban plastic bags and charge 10¢ for paper bags.
Organized their own Keystone Pipeline rally
Held a seat on the Mayor's Climate Action Task Force
Learned and taught
Partnered with Santa Fe Public Schools on green initiatives and sustainability actions, including a composting program and a low carbon footprint lunch program
Requested and secured approval and funding for a solar installation at the original GWE elementary school
Held a two-week climate change summer camp
Formed a bi-lingual Green Team to teach custodians how and why to recycle
Elementary School Solar Panels -  Advocating, planning, measuring, and testifying for solar panels at Acequia Madre Elementary school.

Global Warming Express Book - Now 12 years old, GWE founders Marina Weber (writer) and Joanna Whysner (illustrator) are finishing their book on climate change, The Global Warming Express, with hopes of presenting it to President Obama.
Reusable Bags - GWE is partnering with Mujeres de Adelante and Warehouse 21 to create reusable bags for residents and visitors of Santa Fe.
Radio Broadcasts - GWE is partnering with KSFR radio to start a GWE Sustainability Show with the GWE middle schoolers.
Paris Climate Conference 2015 – Sponsorship for at least one GWE student to attend the conference is in place, how many more could we send?
Every kid is a superhero. Here’s how the superheroes tackle this issue.
1. Learn - Kids are hungry for information, but don’t always have access to it. GWE offers a foundation in climate education. This includes:
climate science literacy
sustainability awareness
natural sciences

2. Feel - The kids feel many things in reaction to what they learn. They might feel sad, frustrated, inspired, excited...  These feelings allow the kids to brainstorm and think creatively about how they want to respond.
3. Act - Students gain opportunities to act through:
public speaking training
research and writing
visual arts
performance skills
We have to do this quickly. After school classes start just as this campaign ends!
Schools all over Santa Fe are on a waiting list for GWE, and our curriculum is ready to be packed up for schools that wish to replicate our programs around the country.
These goals are just to get us started for the coming school year.
Our goals and how to get there:
Continue and expand our programs in Santa Fe schools.
Establish our curriculum for other schools to bring this program to their own area. You can create your own GWE!
Finish and publish the kid's climate change chapter book, and get it to President Obama.
Continue advocacy by going to climate events and talking with elected officials.
Pay our teachers to run the after-school programs.

To accomplish all of these reachable and essential goals we have both a Kids Board of Directors and an Adult Board of Directors. Kids make decisions on policy and advocacy, while the grown-ups organize behind the scenes.
We will use your contributions for:
Further program development: standardizing the curriculum, organizing & advocacy
Program operation: teaching in the classrooms, transportation, communication with schools, parents, and kids
Media, website, and marketing
Club house: GWE Kids' Headquarters + office space
Materials: for science and art projects
Snacks: organic and local, of course!
|","Santa Fe, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-global-warming-express/pica

""Promoting respect for animals, seeing them as an essential muscle for life”

A Big Thank You to all the supporters and contributors including a special thank you to The Zoo Project for the generous donations and fundraising! 
Please watch out for our ONLINE SHOP where you can continue to contribute!
PASEO DE LOS MONOS
ANIMAL RESCUE CENTRE  -
Our Aim is to To raise $36,000 to help a wildlife shelter acquire a patch of Amazon rainforest in Ecuador for nature conservation and to rehabilitate animals into the wild.
Véronique Grand and Yvan Bouvier, of swiss nationality, went to live in the Ecuadorian Amazonia in 2002. As many, they were worried for the environment and the treat

column5: >In the 2007 they created the Swiss-Ecuadorian foundation “Los Monos, Selva y Vida” which is devoted to the conservation of the fauna, the flora and the amazon indigenous traditions.
>Illegal hunters and poachers are leaving thousands of orphaned animals destined to be sold as pets or toys. They sadly end their lives in cages, tied up, mistreated or in laboratories.
>The Ecuadorian Amazonia has the biggest biodiversity in the world and we should take action now.

column1: <h2><b style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)

Paseo de los Monos is a wildlife shelter located near the city of Puyo in the province of Pastaza, Ecuador. The refuge has one hectare of native forest and has been receiving orphaned wild animal, the victims of trafficking, since 2005.

Their first goal is to offer the animals a new family in an adequate space appropriate to their natural mode of life. The animals here are living inside big parks of native vegetation.

The refuge shelters species in critical danger of extinction, for example primates like:

Woolly monkeys (Laothrix poepiggi) and Spider monkeys (Ateles Belzebuth) which are intensively hunted for human consumption, while the babies are sold in towns or cities.

Monkey meat is considered a delicacy in some regions. Sadly, these animals have a relatively short life expectancy and their rate of reproduction is very low: they live until 25 years old and can only have one baby every two or three years.

They reproduce at the same rate as they are killed.
(Woolly Monkey, Jack)

The three spider monkeys that live in Paseo de los Monos are the only animals that don´t have a suitable place which means they have to live in a large cage.

It is imperative we get them a piece of land with trees where they can move freely.

Other non-primate species that are under threat are also welcome at the wildlife shelter including:
<i style=""letter-spacing: 0px
capuchins (Cebus albifrons and Cebus apella)
(Saimiri sciureus)
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Also welcome are other species which are  as important as primates and largely killed

column1: as well as :

In 2014 they built the first serpentarium of the province with the aim of rescuing snakes which are found near houses or in perilous situations trying to avoid the highways. Before this project existed, people killed these animals in order to avoid a potential danger. So far 19 snakes have been rescued and are ready to be liberated into a national park far from the cities.

.
The Destruction of the Amazon
In  2013 the massive destruction of the Amazon from Brazil to Ecuador started.
The oil and mining companies and agricultural farming are incrementing their activities and as a result the forests are being fragmented.
This is a hard situation for the wildlife, since they are not able to follow their ancestral paths in order to find food and shelter.
The agony of the tropical forests are the first cause of extinction of animal and vegetable species which are necessary to preserve the fragile ecosystems of which we are part.
The more vulnerable will be disappear first, and if the destruction of the ¨Lungs of the World¨ goes on, all life will be endangered including humans.

The construction of highways, poaching, traffic of wildlife, the illegal trade of wood, development of places for human necessities like houses, fields for cropping and farming etc, will provoke the extinction of the forests and the contamination of the principal water resources.

For this we are working with The Paseo de los Monos, those involved in the reception and rehabilitation of animals in unnatural conditions and / or in danger of extinction in Puyo.
<span style=""background-color: initial
In the beginning,
the goal was to shelter and rehabilitate orphan animals in order to
form groups with them and free them into protected areas.
It is
important to preserve these rescued animals as a genetic resource and
their reproduction will allow them to re-inhabit the devastated zones
in the future.
In order to achieve
this goal, the members of Paseo de los Monos are trying to get a land
of virgin forest at the borders of Parque Nacional Sangay of 50 hectares.
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2:
>

The land will be preserved and the animals who have been

column1: rehabilitated can be liberated in this protected area. This
will allow Paseo de los Monos to shelter more wild animals who are
being currently victims of traffic and dispersed in cities or zoos
under poor conditions, chained or in cages.
Once the animals are
back into their habitat, they will be able to achieve their role in
nature, which is the dispersion of seed and preserve the equilibrium
of the ecosystems.

(Spider Monkey)

PLAN B

If the $35,000 goal is not met, Plan B is to build a new sanctuary for the 3 Spider Monkeys, who are the first in need of a more suitable place to live. This is will be in an area of 40 hectares of natural forest hosted by Jungle Dave, an Eco-Tourism operator in the area of San Juan Bosco that offer eco-tours, organic farming and are large supporters and funders of environmental education.

Plan B also promotes excellent future collaboration prospects with Paseo de Los Monos. 
http://www.jungledavestours.com/Pages/SJB/SJB.html

<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

The price of land surrounding the National Parks in Ecuador has skyrocketed up to 20 times more than what it was just a few years ago, leaving Paseo de Los Monos without the necessary means to purchase any land.
With the help of this crowd funding we hope this will once again become a possibility!

column1: This year our Nature Project fundraising team have been busy at The Zoo Project each and every Saturday engaging with the party people to inform them about the plight of the Amazon rainforest and its inhabitants as well as raising money for the cause through donations.
So far we’ve raised over €3000 at the Zoo alone so please chip in and help us help as many animals as possible!
For every euro we fundraise during the events - The Zoo Project as our main sponsor will match that amount to put towards the conservation plan!
(Guacuamayo)
<div>
Finally, Ibiza is known for the vast amount of posters and flyers produced on a daily basis as promotional tools for the island’s many bars and clubs.

This year we’re hoping to take a stand and lead the way in environmental promotion, actively encouraging less waste in Ibiza by providing participating venues with photographic canvases that allow people to download flyers instead of using promotional posters.
Many participating bars and clubs around the island will boast one of these amazing photographic artworks, all funded by The Zoo Project in order to bring awareness to the project.

Main Objectives of The Nature Project:
- The implementation of sustainable, autonomous and pro-life projects.
-  Helping animals in need.
-  Education about respect for animals.
- The preservation and promotion of minority and indigenous cultures.
- To promote artistic projects and strategically work in those that are aimed
at the conservation and protection of the animal environment.
Promote quality of life through creativity.
- Create initiatives for care of nature
- The protection and preservation of the environment through socio-cultural activities
- Provide eco friendly promotion and publicity alternatives
- Back different social sectors through art.

","""Promoting respect for animals, seeing them as an essential muscle for life”

A Big Thank You to all the supporters and contributors including a special thank you to The Zoo Project for the generous donations and fundraising! Please watch out for our ONLINE SHOP where you can continue to contribute!
PASEO DE LOS MONOS
ANIMAL RESCUE CENTRE  - Puyo, Amazonas, Ecuador
http://www.losmonos.org/
Our Aim is to To raise $36,000 to help a wildlife shelter acquire a patch of Amazon rainforest in Ecuador for nature conservation and to rehabilitate animals into the wild.
Véronique Grand and Yvan Bouvier, of swiss nationality, went to live in the Ecuadorian Amazonia in 2002. As many, they were worried for the environment and the treatment toward the animals.
In the 2007 they created the Swiss-Ecuadorian foundation “Los Monos, Selva y Vida” which is devoted to the conservation of the fauna, the flora and the amazon indigenous traditions.
Illegal hunters and poachers are leaving thousands of orphaned animals destined to be sold as pets or toys. They sadly end their lives in cages, tied up, mistreated or in laboratories.
The Ecuadorian Amazonia has the biggest biodiversity in the world and we should take action now.
Activities of “Paseo de los Monos”

Paseo de los Monos is a wildlife shelter located near the city of Puyo in the province of Pastaza, Ecuador. The refuge has one hectare of native forest and has been receiving orphaned wild animal, the victims of trafficking, since 2005.

Their first goal is to offer the animals a new family in an adequate space appropriate to their natural mode of life. The animals here are living inside big parks of native vegetation.The refuge shelters species in critical danger of extinction, for example primates like:Woolly monkeys (Laothrix poepiggi) and Spider monkeys (Ateles Belzebuth) which are intensively hunted for human consumption, while the babies are sold in towns or cities.Monkey meat is considered a delicacy in some regions. Sadly, these animals have a relatively short life expectancy and their rate of reproduction is very low: they live until 25 years old and can only have one baby every two or three years.They reproduce at the same rate as they are killed.
(Woolly Monkey, Jack)

The three spider monkeys that live in Paseo de los Monos are the only animals that don´t have a suitable place which means they have to live in a large cage.It is imperative we get them a piece of land with trees where they can move freely.Other non-primate species that are under threat are also welcome at the wildlife shelter including:
White and Black
capuchins (Cebus albifrons and Cebus apella)Squirrel monkeys
(Saimiri sciureus)Tamarins (Saguinus fuscicollis)
Also welcome are other species which are  as important as primates and largely killed
as well as : Coaties (Nasua nasua)Guatusas (amazonic rodents)Marguay (carnivor feline), TurtlesSnakes (Boa constrictor and Vipers).

In 2014 they built the first serpentarium of the province with the aim of rescuing snakes which are found near houses or in perilous situations trying to avoid the highways. Before this project existed, people killed these animals in order to avoid a potential danger. So far 19 snakes have been rescued and are ready to be liberated into a national park far from the cities..
The Destruction of the Amazon
In  2013 the massive destruction of the Amazon from Brazil to Ecuador started.
The oil and mining companies and agricultural farming are incrementing their activities and as a result the forests are being fragmented.
This is a hard situation for the wildlife, since they are not able to follow their ancestral paths in order to find food and shelter.
The agony of the tropical forests are the first cause of extinction of animal and vegetable species which are necessary to preserve the fragile ecosystems of which we are part.
The more vulnerable will be disappear first, and if the destruction of the ¨Lungs of the World¨ goes on, all life will be endangered including humans.

The construction of highways, poaching, traffic of wildlife, the illegal trade of wood, development of places for human necessities like houses, fields for cropping and farming etc, will provoke the extinction of the forests and the contamination of the principal water resources. For this we are working with The Paseo de los Monos, those involved in the reception and rehabilitation of animals in unnatural conditions and / or in danger of extinction in Puyo.
Our Goal and What We Need
In the beginning,
the goal was to shelter and rehabilitate orphan animals in order to
form groups with them and free them into protected areas.
It is
important to preserve these rescued animals as a genetic resource and
their reproduction will allow them to re-inhabit the devastated zones
in the future.
In order to achieve
this goal, the members of Paseo de los Monos are trying to get a land
of virgin forest at the borders of Parque Nacional Sangay of 50 hectares.
The land will be preserved and the animals who have been
rehabilitated can be liberated in this protected area. This
will allow Paseo de los Monos to shelter more wild animals who are
being currently victims of traffic and dispersed in cities or zoos
under poor conditions, chained or in cages.
Once the animals are
back into their habitat, they will be able to achieve their role in
nature, which is the dispersion of seed and preserve the equilibrium
of the ecosystems.

(Spider Monkey)PLAN BIf the $35,000 goal is not met, Plan B is to build a new sanctuary for the 3 Spider Monkeys, who are the first in need of a more suitable place to live. This is will be in an area of 40 hectares of natural forest hosted by Jungle Dave, an Eco-Tourism operator in the area of San Juan Bosco that offer eco-tours, organic farming and are large supporters and funders of environmental education.
Plan B also promotes excellent future collaboration prospects with Paseo de Los Monos. http://www.jungledavestours.com/Pages/SJB/SJB.html
Risks & Challenges

The price of land surrounding the National Parks in Ecuador has skyrocketed up to 20 times more than what it was just a few years ago, leaving Paseo de Los Monos without the necessary means to purchase any land.With the help of this crowd funding we hope this will once again become a possibility!
More About The Nature Project...
http://thezooproject.com/thenatureproject
The Nature Project was created through an alliance with ¨Paseo de Los Monos¨,  ¨Proartso, Spain¨ and ¨The Zoo Project, Ibiza¨
We are a non-profit organization that promotes and manages strategies for the preservation of the animal ecosystem, wildlife and the cultures that exert effort to preserve it.

The Zoo Project have a long history of collaborating with various local and global charities and The Nature Project represents the latest step on a collaborative journey that has seen us raise money and awareness with the likes of
Ibiza Diu No
Duo

Last Night A DJ Saved My Life
Green Heart Foundation.

This year our Nature Project fundraising team have been busy at The Zoo Project each and every Saturday engaging with the party people to inform them about the plight of the Amazon rainforest and its inhabitants as well as raising money for the cause through donations.
So far we’ve raised over €3000 at the Zoo alone so please chip in and help us help as many animals as possible!
For every euro we fundraise during the events - The Zoo Project as our main sponsor will match that amount to put towards the conservation plan!
(Guacuamayo)
Finally, Ibiza is known for the vast amount of posters and flyers produced on a daily basis as promotional tools for the island’s many bars and clubs.

This year we’re hoping to take a stand and lead the way in environmental promotion, actively encouraging less waste in Ibiza by providing participating venues with photographic canvases that allow people to download flyers instead of using promotional posters.
Many participating bars and clubs around the island will boast one of these amazing photographic artworks, all funded by The Zoo Project in order to bring awareness to the project.
(Capuchin Monkey)

- The implementation of sustainable, autonomous and pro-life projects.
-  Helping animals in need.
-  Education about respect for animals.
- The preservation and promotion of minority and indigenous cultures.
- To promote artistic projects and strategically work in those that are aimed
at the conservation and protection of the animal environment.
Promote quality of life through creativity.
- Create initiatives for care of nature
- The protection and preservation of the environment through socio-cultural activities
- Provide eco friendly promotion and publicity alternatives
- Back different social sectors through art.

column13: > are made of Arafat Sharipudin from Malaysia and Lucile Muller from France. We need your help to create a new quality in natural agriculture and community living.
column17: >We want to acquire small plot of land to grow a sustainable natural farm. We deeply believe that small and naturally etiquable farm with diversity in plant and livestock that distribute product on local level is the most important component to a wholesome society and organic sustainability.
column25: >For a long time now, we both have been exploring natural farming and the impact it can have to our frail environment at large. Lucile is a graduate of Agronomy Science and has been working/farming throughout all her adult life, while Arafat has experience in starting and running an experimental farm that hosted international volunteers on a leased land for the last two years. Arafat graduated in IT and left the desk job in 2012 to explore further in natural agriculture. Our experiences on small scale natural farming in Malaysia and France have led us to understand the benefits, practicality, financial viability, and importance of a well managed small farm.
column37: >We are currently traversing South America
column41:
> to delve and learn more methods and techniques in natural farming, low impact architecture, and economical viability of small scale farming in this part of the world. The fact that we are from different region of the world (Asia and Europe) make us choose to experience natural farming in South America, in order to have a complete understanding of the methods and different techniques.

You can visit our website www.thegreenjump.com to understand more about our agricultural vision. We also write articles about our findings here in our effort to create a referential platform in small scale natural farming.

THE GOAL

Our plan is to find a plot of land that is viable for us, in an area where it is safe, that has a steady demand of organically grown food from the surrounding community, and with supportive policy to grow naturally. We will be going places to locate the most potential site of farmland and steadily build our understanding in farming economy of the area and responsibly grow our farm. The period from now to the inception date will allow us enough theoretical preparation. Apart from vegetables and fruit orchard, we also plan to add poultry, cows, goats, and pigs to our farming ecosystem, on additional pasture.  Farm product will be sold and distributed via a local group and member purchase (like AMAP in France) , regional markets, and also online.  The goal of our farm is to add more variety and freshness to the food system in the community, while creating a healthy, financially productive farm manageable by a team of two and a small group of international volunteers.

We also believe that the world needs farmers who are able to innovate on small farms, produce a diverse variety of foods from a healthy ecosystem, and distribute locally.  Please consider helping our farm as a small step towards a more healthy and sustainable world!

The fundraising collection for The Green Jump will go towards acquiring a small plot of land, building of our abode, irrigation system, and our first seed-starting greenhouse.  We are trying to raise $25 000, which will allow our farm to begin operation in early 2017.  Any funds we receive that surpass our goal will go towards social enrichment activities and educational efforts around our farm. We also wish to help start a local organic market for small farmers if there is none available in the area.


Upon inception of the farm, we wish to open the door to others from all over the world to come help, share and learn together collectively. We believe the openness of idea sharing and working together to reach a certain common goal is the way to progress in the future.

Please visit our website www.thegreenjump.com to learn more of our natural farming adventure so far and to follow our progress.

A million thanks for now!

Arafat Sharipudin and Lucile Muller


","Hello kind souls ! The Green Jump are made of Arafat Sharipudin from Malaysia and Lucile Muller from France. We need your help to create a new quality in natural agriculture and community living.We want to acquire small plot of land to grow a sustainable natural farm. We deeply believe that small and naturally etiquable farm with diversity in plant and livestock that distribute product on local level is the most important component to a wholesome society and organic sustainability.For a long time now, we both have been exploring natural farming and the impact it can have to our frail environment at large. Lucile is a graduate of Agronomy Science and has been working/farming throughout all her adult life, while Arafat has experience in starting and running an experimental farm that hosted international volunteers on a leased land for the last two years. Arafat graduated in IT and left the desk job in 2012 to explore further in natural agriculture. Our experiences on small scale natural farming in Malaysia and France have led us to understand the benefits, practicality, financial viability, and importance of a well managed small farm.We are currently traversing South America to delve and learn more methods and techniques in natural farming, low impact architecture, and economical viability of small scale farming in this part of the world. The fact that we are from different region of the world (Asia and Europe) make us choose to experience natural farming in South America, in order to have a complete understanding of the methods and different techniques.You can visit our website www.thegreenjump.com to understand more about our agricultural vision. We also write articles about our findings here in our effort to create a referential platform in small scale natural farming.THE GOALOur plan is to find a plot of land that is viable for us, in an area where it is safe, that has a steady demand of organically grown food from the surrounding community, and with supportive policy to grow naturally. We will be going places to locate the most potential site of farmland and steadily build our understanding in farming economy of the area and responsibly grow our farm. The period from now to the inception date will allow us enough theoretical preparation. Apart from vegetables and fruit orchard, we also plan to add poultry, cows, goats, and pigs to our farming ecosystem, on additional pasture.  Farm product will be sold and distributed via a local group and member purchase (like AMAP in France) , regional markets, and also online.  The goal of our farm is to add more variety and freshness to the food system in the community, while creating a healthy, financially productive farm manageable by a team of two and a small group of international volunteers.We also believe that the world needs farmers who are able to innovate on small farms, produce a diverse variety of foods from a healthy ecosystem, and distribute locally.  Please consider helping our farm as a small step towards a more healthy and sustainable world!The fundraising collection for The Green Jump will go towards acquiring a small plot of land, building of our abode, irrigation system, and our first seed-starting greenhouse.  We are trying to raise $25 000, which will allow our farm to begin operation in early 2017.  Any funds we receive that surpass our goal will go towards social enrichment activities and educational efforts around our farm. We also wish to help start a local organic market for small farmers if there is none available in the area.Upon inception of the farm, we wish to open the door to others from all over the world to come help, share and learn together collectively. We believe the openness of idea sharing and working together to reach a certain common goal is the way to progress in the future.Please visit our website www.thegreenjump.com to learn more of our natural farming adventure so far and to follow our progress.A million thanks for now!Arafat Sharipudin and Lucile Muller",4.0,0,"1 Campaign

<h1><span style=""font-size: 24px

column7: >Glaciers are retreating at an alarming rate - taking with them valuable scientific information. You can help this non-profit team of expert volunteers gather data before it's too late.

column1: <h4><span style=""font-size: 24px

Glaciers are universally-accepted indicators of climate change and global warming. Most glaciers have crevasses, but fewer have complex cave systems. These caves offer an extraordinary x-ray view into the internal workings of a glacier.
column4: >Glacier Cave Explorers
column7: >pioneers new ways to collect valuable data from under the ice, before these unique scientific laboratories disappear completely.

column1: Glacier Cave Explorers team in the cavernous Godzilla Cave deep under the crater glacier on Mt St Helens, an active volcano

Most glacier research is conducted from the surface – from the top down. 
Our team studies glaciers from beneath the ice – from the inside out.

This research helps climatologists and glaciologists better understand how air currents and temperature within glacier caves can impact the characteristics of a glacier. By mapping the caves' physical changes, our team can track the glacier ice volume lost. 

In addition to climatology and geomorphology, this research contributes to a host of other scientific disciplines, including geochemistry, microbiology and astrobiology. These extreme environments simulate conditions found under ice packs on other bodies in our solar system, like Mars and Europa. The life forms found in these caves can provide valuable insight about possible microbial life ""out there.""  

Read more about Dr. Roberto Anitori's extremophile research in glacier caves.
column4: >Scientists use this data for their specific area of research, building a more accurate picture of our changing climate and glaciers, the chemical changes in volcanic soil and rock, and what we might find on other planets.

column1: Dr. Woody Peeples, M.D. (the expedition medical doctor) takes an ice density reading in East Crater summit caves on Mt Rainier. One of our 2016 goals is to buy an ice corer, which will provide more accurate ice density readings than the displacement method shown above.
Read more about science...
What Does This Mean To You?

Glacier caves reveal the many layers of ice that have accumulated over the centuries. They are like tree rings - the chemical make-up of the ice layer provides a literal ""blueprint"" of what was happening in the atmosphere that year.

Glaciers are HISTORY BOOKS of climate. By learning about our past, we understand how to deal with the future, learn what to expect, and how not to repeat the same mistakes. As the glaciers disappear, we lose more and more pages of climate history.

When glaciers disappear, so does their water. By finding out why our ice packs are disappearing and how the caves are influencing that, we become better informed about protecting them or planning for the consequences.

Dr. Andreas Pflitsch throws a data logger chain into Adelie Lake on Mt Rainier as his assistant Dave Holmgren watches. The data logger chain records temperature readings at various depths in the water.

Saving Lives

The cave maps we generate can be used by search and rescue teams to locate and extract lost and injured cavers and climbers.
<blockquote><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column4: >Lead cave surveyor Scott Linn takes field notes in the crater glacier caves on Mt St Helens.

column1: Millions of people live in the shadows of volcanoes. Our research can also help provide data to predict future destructive behavior and alert potential victims.

3-dimensional maps provide context for scientific readings and collections - data from different disciplines can be studied in relation to each other. The maps show changes in the caves, such as new moulins and retreating entrances.
We provide follow-up reports and information to help develop resource management and interpretive tools for the Forest Service and National Parks in charge of wilderness areas.
A Look At Our Future

Rare microbial communities live at the base of a glacier, where the ice touches the underlying lava rock, and steam fumaroles emit gases that provide nutrients for these microbes. Astrobiologists study these life forms to see how things might grow in space for our future colonization efforts.
Dr. Lee Florea and Tabby Cavendish collect sediment samples near Adelie Lake (background) in the East Crater Cave of Mt Rainier.
Read more about science...
Support Our Scientific Mission

column1: <blockquote>Summit camp on Mt Rainier: It takes a lot of gear and food just to survive and work in this extreme environment at 14,000 feet. Canadian cave surveyor Nick Vieira heats water for dinner and hot drinks. <span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
The glacier caves are remote and difficult to access, and these expeditions are complex. Our projects require the same level of care, detail and planning as you'd find on a Himalayan expedition.
Even though we donate our time, we need supplies to live and work in these inhospitable places.

We need survival and rescue gear, medical supplies, specialized science equipment, lab analysis of samples, helicopters, volcanic gas monitors, satellite phones, breathing apparatus, and expedition-quality food and tents. This all adds up.
Mt St Helens team hauls gear to Godzilla Hole for the first descent and initial cave survey. Cave 2 is in the background (below the climbers).
As we've become more successful with our expeditions, more scientists have expressed interest in this research.

column1: Most people can't do this work. These caves are remote, dangerous and undocumented, and these expeditions require a rare combination of skill-sets... mountaineering, glaciology, cave survey, ice-climbing, rope rigging, science methodology, wilderness medicine, expedition logistics planning, and more.

column4: >To meet our team, check out our Gallery tab, our Facebook page, and the glaciercaveexplorers.org website.

column1: Learn more about our team...

Our projects are ongoing scientific studies.  We currently have study sites on Mt Hood, Mt St Helens and Mt Rainier. All of these projects require research and wilderness permits, many volunteer hours, and funding.

column4: >The scientific value is in obtaining data points and monitoring changes over time.
column7: >In 2016, we plan to return to Mt Rainier and Mt Hood. In 2017, we will conduct our second Mt St Helens expedition. These projects represent three distinct and complementary types of glaciers - receding, growing, and balanced.

column4: >Read more about our projects...

column1: <div>

We work in incredibly challenging scientific venues in some of the most remote locations on earth... not just at altitude on the side of a glacier, but under a moving ice pack. Add the threat of avalanches, underground ice collapse, falling rocks, toxic volcanic gases and glacial flooding, and this is frontier work in uncharted territory.

Mountains make their own weather, and helicopter-based rescues are often not possible. We have to be completely self-reliant. We need our own rescue teams above and below ground, field hospitals, and the ability to manage mountain illness and wilderness trauma.

Glacier Cave Explorers includes Mountain Rescue Association (MRA) qualified rescue leaders, trained cave rescue experts from the National Cave Rescue Commission (NCRC), mountain expedition doctors and paramedics, logistics specialists and experienced expedition leaders.
<div>

Expedition leader Eddy Cartaya uses the satellite phone during the
Mt St Helens 2014 expedition. The sat phone provides vital safety communications with the outside world and a way to check the weather forecast throughout the day. Conditions change quickly.
<div>

Your contributions go into one big 'bucket' for all of our projects, along with any additional funds we receive from grants. If we receive the helicopter permit, the 2016 Mt Rainier expedition will cost approximately $30,000. Sandy Glacier on Mt Hood will cost around $5000, and Mt St Helens in 2017 approximately $10,000. These are minimum amounts to make these expeditions happen.

The first two years, Brent and Eddy paid out-of-pocket for these expeditions. Over time, Glacier Cave Explorers and the Oregon High Desert Grotto developed relationships resulting in much-needed grants, discounts and donations. As much as we appreciate grants, they do not cover all of the expenses. Grants can be unpredictable, and only a few are available for this type of work. That's why we need to pursue other types of funding, such as crowdfunding.
<div>
Read more about sponsors...
<h3><b style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif

We've received essential cooperation from the Forest Service and National Park Service. They read our study proposals and approve the permits necessary to do this work in public land under their jurisdiction. We honor their trust and work hard to manage and minimize our human impact in these fragile, protected places.
Media Coverage and Links

News and media organizations have documented our work and helped educate the public about our projects:  Oregon Public Broadcasting's Oregon Field Guide TV shows (Mt Hood,  Mt St Helens), National Parks Conservation Association magazine,  the Seattle Times newspaper, NSS News, National Geographic, TEDYouth Talks, Smithsonian Magazine, MRA's Meridian magazine, the Columbian.
