","MISSION CRITICAL
Glaciers are retreating at an alarming rate - taking with them valuable scientific information. You can help this non-profit team of expert volunteers gather data before it's too late.
Why This Matters

Glaciers are universally-accepted indicators of climate change and global warming. Most glaciers have crevasses, but fewer have complex cave systems. These caves offer an extraordinary x-ray view into the internal workings of a glacier. Glacier Cave Explorers pioneers new ways to collect valuable data from under the ice, before these unique scientific laboratories disappear completely.
Glacier Cave Explorers team in the cavernous Godzilla Cave deep under the crater glacier on Mt St Helens, an active volcano

Most glacier research is conducted from the surface – from the top down. Our team studies glaciers from beneath the ice – from the inside out.This research helps climatologists and glaciologists better understand how air currents and temperature within glacier caves can impact the characteristics of a glacier. By mapping the caves' physical changes, our team can track the glacier ice volume lost. In addition to climatology and geomorphology, this research contributes to a host of other scientific disciplines, including geochemistry, microbiology and astrobiology. These extreme environments simulate conditions found under ice packs on other bodies in our solar system, like Mars and Europa. The life forms found in these caves can provide valuable insight about possible microbial life ""out there.""  Read more about Dr. Roberto Anitori's extremophile research in glacier caves.Scientists use this data for their specific area of research, building a more accurate picture of our changing climate and glaciers, the chemical changes in volcanic soil and rock, and what we might find on other planets.

Dr. Woody Peeples, M.D. (the expedition medical doctor) takes an ice density reading in East Crater summit caves on Mt Rainier. One of our 2016 goals is to buy an ice corer, which will provide more accurate ice density readings than the displacement method shown above.
Read more about science...
What Does This Mean To You?
A Look At Our Past

Glacier caves reveal the many layers of ice that have accumulated over the centuries. They are like tree rings - the chemical make-up of the ice layer provides a literal ""blueprint"" of what was happening in the atmosphere that year.

Glaciers are HISTORY BOOKS of climate. By learning about our past, we understand how to deal with the future, learn what to expect, and how not to repeat the same mistakes. As the glaciers disappear, we lose more and more pages of climate history.
Watershed Impact

When glaciers disappear, so does their water. By finding out why our ice packs are disappearing and how the caves are influencing that, we become better informed about protecting them or planning for the consequences.

Dr. Andreas Pflitsch throws a data logger chain into Adelie Lake on Mt Rainier as his assistant Dave Holmgren watches. The data logger chain records temperature readings at various depths in the water.
Saving LivesThe cave maps we generate can be used by search and rescue teams to locate and extract lost and injured cavers and climbers.
Lead cave surveyor Scott Linn takes field notes in the crater glacier caves on Mt St Helens.
Millions of people live in the shadows of volcanoes. Our research can also help provide data to predict future destructive behavior and alert potential victims.

3-dimensional maps provide context for scientific readings and collections - data from different disciplines can be studied in relation to each other. The maps show changes in the caves, such as new moulins and retreating entrances.
Natural Resource Management
We provide follow-up reports and information to help develop resource management and interpretive tools for the Forest Service and National Parks in charge of wilderness areas.
A Look At Our Future

Rare microbial communities live at the base of a glacier, where the ice touches the underlying lava rock, and steam fumaroles emit gases that provide nutrients for these microbes. Astrobiologists study these life forms to see how things might grow in space for our future colonization efforts.
Dr. Lee Florea and Tabby Cavendish collect sediment samples near Adelie Lake (background) in the East Crater Cave of Mt Rainier.
Read more about science...
Support Our Scientific Mission
We need your help funding our 2016-2017 expeditions.
This work isn't easy or cheap - our volunteer experts need supplies and gear.

Summit camp on Mt Rainier: It takes a lot of gear and food just to survive and work in this extreme environment at 14,000 feet. Canadian cave surveyor Nick Vieira heats water for dinner and hot drinks.
The glacier caves are remote and difficult to access, and these expeditions are complex. Our projects require the same level of care, detail and planning as you'd find on a Himalayan expedition.
Even though we donate our time, we need supplies to live and work in these inhospitable places.

We need survival and rescue gear, medical supplies, specialized science equipment, lab analysis of samples, helicopters, volcanic gas monitors, satellite phones, breathing apparatus, and expedition-quality food and tents. This all adds up.
Mt St Helens team hauls gear to Godzilla Hole for the first descent and initial cave survey. Cave 2 is in the background (below the climbers).

As we've become more successful with our expeditions, more scientists have expressed interest in this research. Glacier Cave Explorers provides the expedition structure as well as the caving, rescue and alpine expertise to get scientists and support teams into these extreme locations. Most scientists can't make the trips themselves. That's why we often collect data for them under their remote guidance, following their strict methods.
Glacier Cave Explorers is continuing to
integrate more disciplines of science and grow the scope and depth of our
studies. This is good for the research and exciting for us. But by expanding our projects and by increasing their complexity, our costs are increasing as well.

Climatologist Dr. Andreas Pflitsch and Expedition Leader Eddy Cartaya check temperature and humidity readings in Pure Imagination Cave on Mt Hood's Sandy Glacier. The readings are transmitted via Bluetooth to the laptop from data loggers placed in the cave.
Who Are We?

Glacier Cave Explorers  is part of the Oregon High Desert Grotto (OHDG), a non-profit chapter of the National Speleological Society (NSS). The NSS is an organization dedicated to advancing the study, conservation, exploration, and knowledge of caves.
Glacier Cave Explorers was started by Eddy Cartaya and Brent McGregor, experienced cavers and mountaineers who share a passion for exploration and discovery.
Brent McGregor (right) and Eddy Cartaya (middle), expedition leaders and the driving force behind Glacier Cave Explorers
column2: View Eddy's  TED Talk for Youth

column1: In 2011, they surveyed and explored their first true glacier cave system and quickly discovered how these caves influence the life-cycle of glaciers. Since then, they have recruited a collaborative, multi-disciplinary team of experts and expanded their glacier cave projects.

Most people can't do this work. These caves are remote, dangerous and undocumented, and these expeditions require a rare combination of skill-sets... mountaineering, glaciology, cave survey, ice-climbing, rope rigging, science methodology, wilderness medicine, expedition logistics planning, and more.
To meet our team, check out our Gallery tab, our Facebook page, and the glaciercaveexplorers.org website.
Learn more about our team...
Our Projects

Our projects are ongoing scientific studies.  We currently have study sites on Mt Hood, Mt St Helens and Mt Rainier. All of these projects require research and wilderness permits, many volunteer hours, and funding.

The scientific value is in obtaining data points and monitoring changes over time. In 2016, we plan to return to Mt Rainier and Mt Hood. In 2017, we will conduct our second Mt St Helens expedition. These projects represent three distinct and complementary types of glaciers - receding, growing, and balanced.
Read more about our projects...
Risks and Challenges

We work in incredibly challenging scientific venues in some of the most remote locations on earth... not just at altitude on the side of a glacier, but under a moving ice pack. Add the threat of avalanches, underground ice collapse, falling rocks, toxic volcanic gases and glacial flooding, and this is frontier work in uncharted territory.

Mountains make their own weather, and helicopter-based rescues are often not possible. We have to be completely self-reliant. We need our own rescue teams above and below ground, field hospitals, and the ability to manage mountain illness and wilderness trauma.

Glacier Cave Explorers includes Mountain Rescue Association (MRA) qualified rescue leaders, trained cave rescue experts from the National Cave Rescue Commission (NCRC), mountain expedition doctors and paramedics, logistics specialists and experienced expedition leaders.

Expedition leader Eddy Cartaya uses the satellite phone during theMt St Helens 2014 expedition. The sat phone provides vital safety communications with the outside world and a way to check the weather forecast throughout the day. Conditions change quickly.
Where Your Money Goes

Your contributions go into one big 'bucket' for all of our projects, along with any additional funds we receive from grants. If we receive the helicopter permit, the 2016 Mt Rainier expedition will cost approximately $30,000. Sandy Glacier on Mt Hood will cost around $5000, and Mt St Helens in 2017 approximately $10,000. These are minimum amounts to make these expeditions happen.
Read more about costs...
Hilleberg tents (and Dr. Woody Peeples) withstood 80 mph winds on the Mt Rainier East summit crater.
Past and Present Supporters

The first two years, Brent and Eddy paid out-of-pocket for these expeditions. Over time, Glacier Cave Explorers and the Oregon High Desert Grotto developed relationships resulting in much-needed grants, discounts and donations. As much as we appreciate grants, they do not cover all of the expenses. Grants can be unpredictable, and only a few are available for this type of work. That's why we need to pursue other types of funding, such as crowdfunding.
Read more about sponsors...
Research Permits

We've received essential cooperation from the Forest Service and National Park Service. They read our study proposals and approve the permits necessary to do this work in public land under their jurisdiction. We honor their trust and work hard to manage and minimize our human impact in these fragile, protected places.
Media Coverage and Links

News and media organizations have documented our work and helped educate the public about our projects:  Oregon Public Broadcasting's Oregon Field Guide TV shows (Mt Hood,  Mt St Helens), National Parks Conservation Association magazine,  the Seattle Times newspaper, NSS News, National Geographic, TEDYouth Talks, Smithsonian Magazine, MRA's Meridian magazine, the Columbian.
OPB's Oregon Field Guide films the Mt St Helens 2014 expedition.
Some links are included on this site, but please search for us online as well.
WHAT YOU GET FOR YOUR CONTRIBUTION

You are now part of our team. We will provide you with updates here as well as on our Facebook page. You can watch our progress and read about new findings and initiatives. Please stay involved any way you can.
Take great satisfaction in knowing that you contributed to real science, which will lead to publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals.
Pick Your Perks

Part of our mission is to take those snapshots in time that document this constantly-evolving, living art. We want to share these spectacular inner landscapes with you, so you can discover these wild places for yourself.
OUR PERKS reflect this desire to 'take you there,' as well as our passion for educating others about these amazing discoveries.

Who are we and why Ukraine?

The Lawrence Anthony Earth Organization Ukraine (LAEOU), headed up by Director, Lionel de Lange, a South African living in Ukraine has been active in rescuing, relocating and assisting zoo's and abused wildlife in Ukraine since 2014.

Ukraine's animal rights are virtually non-existent and most laws governing animals are the same laws that existed in the Soviet Union days. We work hard to try and change this and to give these creatures a more humane way of life. And as we say ""BECAUSE NONE SURVIVE ALONE"" we are there each and every day to make a change and a life more livable.
<h3>The story of Nathan and the 3 lionesses, Luca, Charlie &amp

It is critical we move them before winter sets in as they do not have a heated shelters and that will be very expensive to build for the 2 separate enclosures as Nathan and the lionesses are not housed together.

NATHAN - rescued by Lionel, Director of The Lawrence Anthony Earth Organization - Ukraine from an evil animal trader and animal circus trainer in Ukraine. Nathan and his sister were taken from their parents at about 2 months old and were to be sold to a circus, private zoo or even as a pet. Fortunately, we were able to get Nathan out but his sister mysteriously disappeared, and unfortunately probably sold to one of the aforementioned places.

Nathan was then dumped in a concrete and steel cage of +/-15m², he was never able to explore, go outside, or even just enjoy the simple pleasure of lazing in the sun! Lionel and his team have since built a temporary enclosure for him to explore until we start with the relocation. Nathan is coming back to South Africa to live his life outside, freely and just be all he needs to be….. a lion.
LUCA, CHARLIE &
column2: KAI – Were found when Lionel was doing a 3 brown bear rescue and relocation from a privately owned zoo (if you can even call it that) in Sambir, Ukraine. The bears were relocated to a bear sanctuary in Synevir in the Carpathian Mountains. However, Lionel could not leave the 3 lionesses to live in the squalid conditions they were in. Their enclosure was only 35m² of concrete and steel cage. No direct sunlight, no fresh air, no enrichment, just filth. He managed to negotiate and secure their release into his care. He was able to raise some funds and build them a temporary enclosure while prepping them for their trip to their forever home in South Africa. They are loving their temporary enclosure spend lots of time playing with the enrichment, stalking each other and lazing in the sun. Its their first chance in life to be lions and it was amazing to see the change in them from being caged to having the run of a 280m² enclosure.

column1: All the lions have been vaccinated, chipped and documented in accordance with CITES and are we now waiting CITES export certificate which should be soon, then we apply for CITES import in South Africa and when that is granted which should be about the 1st of 2nd week of October, they will fly HOME.
All 4 lions are been relocated to the Kragga Kamma Game Park in Port Elizabeth, Eastern Cape, South Africa where they will be homed in a very large roam free enclosure.
Relocation Costs:
• Flights for the 4 lions,  $35100 (Turkish Airlines) we are still hoping different other options.
• Road Transport to Kiev Airport and from JHB to Port Elizabeth $2900
<li>Flights for team (vet &amp
• Travel Crate Nathan $900
• Adapt 3 crates existing travel crates $800
• Admin fees, banking charges, perks.
Challenges

Keeping the lions safe, healthy and fed has been our biggest concern and also very expensive. We built temporary shelters for them to get them out of the horrid conditions they were kept in and also it prepares them for the large enclosures that will be their new home in South Africa. CITES too is not an easy process and we hope that we will have the necessary funds by the time we have their CITES travel permits.

Winter is just around the corner and we do not wish to waste the funds we have to turn their night shelters in heated rooms as it would eat up the funds we do have. We have also only budgeted on food until end of September but will need to extend this and this is also another reason to move them soonest as we do not wish to use the travel funding for feeding but its what we will need to do if we are not able to fly towards end of October.
Other Ways You Can Help
<ul>
• Spread the word, SHARE with all your friends and contacts.
• South African supporters - we need fencing and building materials for their new enclosures.
• www.laeoukraine.org/how-to-help
","Who are we and why Ukraine?

The Lawrence Anthony Earth Organization Ukraine (LAEOU), headed up by Director, Lionel de Lange, a South African living in Ukraine has been active in rescuing, relocating and assisting zoo's and abused wildlife in Ukraine since 2014.

Ukraine's animal rights are virtually non-existent and most laws governing animals are the same laws that existed in the Soviet Union days. We work hard to try and change this and to give these creatures a more humane way of life. And as we say ""BECAUSE NONE SURVIVE ALONE"" we are there each and every day to make a change and a life more livable.
The story of Nathan and the 3 lionesses, Luca, Charlie & Kai

It is critical we move them before winter sets in as they do not have a heated shelters and that will be very expensive to build for the 2 separate enclosures as Nathan and the lionesses are not housed together.

NATHAN - rescued by Lionel, Director of The Lawrence Anthony Earth Organization - Ukraine from an evil animal trader and animal circus trainer in Ukraine. Nathan and his sister were taken from their parents at about 2 months old and were to be sold to a circus, private zoo or even as a pet. Fortunately, we were able to get Nathan out but his sister mysteriously disappeared, and unfortunately probably sold to one of the aforementioned places.

Nathan was then dumped in a concrete and steel cage of +/-15m², he was never able to explore, go outside, or even just enjoy the simple pleasure of lazing in the sun! Lionel and his team have since built a temporary enclosure for him to explore until we start with the relocation. Nathan is coming back to South Africa to live his life outside, freely and just be all he needs to be….. a lion.

LUCA, CHARLIE & KAI – Were found when Lionel was doing a 3 brown bear rescue and relocation from a privately owned zoo (if you can even call it that) in Sambir, Ukraine. The bears were relocated to a bear sanctuary in Synevir in the Carpathian Mountains. However, Lionel could not leave the 3 lionesses to live in the squalid conditions they were in. Their enclosure was only 35m² of concrete and steel cage. No direct sunlight, no fresh air, no enrichment, just filth. He managed to negotiate and secure their release into his care. He was able to raise some funds and build them a temporary enclosure while prepping them for their trip to their forever home in South Africa. They are loving their temporary enclosure spend lots of time playing with the enrichment, stalking each other and lazing in the sun. Its their first chance in life to be lions and it was amazing to see the change in them from being caged to having the run of a 280m² enclosure.

All the lions have been vaccinated, chipped and documented in accordance with CITES and are we now waiting CITES export certificate which should be soon, then we apply for CITES import in South Africa and when that is granted which should be about the 1st of 2nd week of October, they will fly HOME.
All 4 lions are been relocated to the Kragga Kamma Game Park in Port Elizabeth, Eastern Cape, South Africa where they will be homed in a very large roam free enclosure.
Relocation Costs:
Flights for the 4 lions,  $35100 (Turkish Airlines) we are still hoping different other options.
Road Transport to Kiev Airport and from JHB to Port Elizabeth $2900
Flights for team (vet & 2 team members) $3300
Travel Crate Nathan $900
Adapt 3 crates existing travel crates $800
Admin fees, banking charges, perks.
Challenges

Keeping the lions safe, healthy and fed has been our biggest concern and also very expensive. We built temporary shelters for them to get them out of the horrid conditions they were kept in and also it prepares them for the large enclosures that will be their new home in South Africa. CITES too is not an easy process and we hope that we will have the necessary funds by the time we have their CITES travel permits.

Winter is just around the corner and we do not wish to waste the funds we have to turn their night shelters in heated rooms as it would eat up the funds we do have. We have also only budgeted on food until end of September but will need to extend this and this is also another reason to move them soonest as we do not wish to use the travel funding for feeding but its what we will need to do if we are not able to fly towards end of October.
Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word, SHARE with all your friends and contacts.
South African supporters - we need fencing and building materials for their new enclosures.

This is a message is to thank all the beautiful
people that have already donated to this campaign and also to give you an

update on where the funds are going.    We are aiming to reach $50,000 USD to build 250 bambu shelters in small comunities in Ecuador where the relief from other organizations will take longer to reach.   So far we have the materials to build the first 40 shelters :) thanks to locals in Ecuador that are donnating them, with your help we will increase the number of shelters we can provide.
On April 16th, Ecuador was hit with a
devastating 7.8 earthquake that destroyed many thousands of homes in dozens of
towns and killed + 500 people and we are still many hundreds missing :(. The
epicenter was on the coast and many of the villages affected are small rural
access communities with poor infrastructure and few resources. A first
estimation states that we need 3Billion USD to restore  the  affected área.<span>  This is money that will be very hard to
attain by Ecuador.  The immediate needs are
temporary shelter and safe drinking water.
Many International and local NGOs as well as
the government and municipalities are working hard to provide relief to this
towns, nevertheless the devastation is critical, and many Ecuadorians have team
up to develop and deployed projects to help the people in most need.
A critical need at the moment are shelters.    We are raising funds towards a project to build 250 temporary ecological and save shelters
for many families that are now homeless. (Total needs $50,000 USD)
The shelters are made from bamboo that is being donated by the
project leaders Manuel Pallares and his wife Cristina Latorre.<span>  The design was develop by Manuel, who is
one of the best Biologists in Ecuador with the help of one of our top architects:
Mario Arias López, who holds a Degree from the Ecole Nationale Superieure des
Arts Appliques- Paris, who is both a Professor of two of the main universities
in Ecuador and a CEO of his own design firm.
They start working immediately after the earthquake on a
solution for the coastal region, also given that Manuel and Cristina are a couple
that has been working for many years with the local communities in the
rainforest and in the coast.
The cost per shelter is approx. 200 USD - that includes the
transportation of the materials and also a small wage that will be paid to the
local people that will help cutting the bamboo, also as a way to give them some
money and restore their dignity-.  And of
course many other volunteers from all over Ecuador will help on the
constructions of the shelters too
Thank you very much beautiful people that has already supported
this campaign! Thanks to you we will be able to build 20 shelters so far, and we
hope you help us spread the word so we reach the objective of building 250 shelters/homes.<span> So far with local
donation plus your charity we can built 60 shelters! (40 have come from locals donating materials)
Any additional funds will also purchase
desperately needed potable water and medications.

Below more details of the Project :)

The areas that we want to reach:  (Chamanga, Canaverales, Jama, Cojimies)
The Design
(consider this was done immediately and in a way it can be easily spread around
the community so they can also build them by themselves)
Characteristics of the
Design and time to build:
Between 3 or 4 people can be put together a
shelter in 2 or 3 hours
Advantages
Size:  it Has 8x6 m (48 m2) using 8
bamboo 8 m long.
Easy
to make: The reeds/bamboo can be cut with common
tools that the farmers have: machete, ax, hammer and if there is, chainsaw.
Ventilation: the ceiling is high -3.5 meters-, which allows ventilation, and in
almost all the space an adult can stand up.
It
allows collecting water: In the lateral gutters a
PVC tube will be place to drain water that can be keep in water tanks to use
the water from the rain that can also be mineralize to make it drinkable.
It
is durable: The plastic greenhouse and buried
bamboo can last for at least three years, as we know the reality is that it
will take many years to rebuilt all the homes that have been destroyed.
Improvable:  you can add walls recycled
wood or bamboo / bamboo floor etc. so it can be converted into a temporary
house.
Solid: The structure is strong and allows, for example, hanging hammocks.
Standardized: they can be prepared in large quantities because standard measures are
being used: rods plastic 8 meters and 6 meters wide. Although plastic, may vary
in width. Common trucks can carry rods up to 8 m, with drawers 6 m long.
Scalable from different properties that have bamboo and are located near the
affected area kits to build them can be sent.
Modular: the kits can be attached to larger structures such as schools or

medical clinics

The Team :)

Project creators and leaders, Manuel and Cristina
The architect

Mario Arias Lopez

Degree from the Ecole Nationale Superieure des Arts Appliques- Paris. 


We are many other volunteers helping on this, we will update the information of all of them in a blog we are creating.

With the support of:

ASA: www.asosolac.org

www.becocoa.com


http://oskistudio.com/es/

http://www.amurt.net/

Welcome to Stephanie's Masai Education Fund!

Have you read the book, the 'White Masai'? Well that pretty much sums up my story:

I came to Tanzania straight after graduating from University and fell in love with both the beautiful country and a Masai warrior. 

We married and I moved to his family’s traditional Masai home in the Masai Steppe of Tanzania. 

Despite facing every greater challenges in doing so, the Masai try to hold on to their ancient values and traditions as part of a culture that is based around their cattle. Traditionally they live in wild, remote places where they find enough pasture lands but these days, an increasing human population is destroying the wilderness the Masai depend on. Woodland is deforested to be turned into farmland and grasslands are turning into desert, overgrazed by too many cattle.

The wildlife that used to coexist with the Masai and their herds has gone and even cattle do not find enough grass to feed on anymore and often starve to death in the dry season.

I have witnessed this for six years now and I believe now is the time to turn the tide. It hurts me to see this beautiful wilderness being turned to ashes and it is frightening to see how little understanding the Masai have of how much their cattle and their culture depend on the survival of this wilderness. I want to help them understand that the way they treat their land now, will have a direct impact on the survival of their tribal culture and on the way their children will live.

With my campaign, I aim to rekindle the ancient connection the Masai used to have with their land to let them once again be guardians over it. I hope to see grasslands and woodlands grow again and bring back the local wildlife while preserving the Masai’s culture and reducing hunger for men as well as animals.

In the long run, I hope to increase efforts to interest the Masai in family planning with a view to reducing birth rates and aim to advertise a reduction in cattle numbers to move from high quantity herds to high quality ones.

A successful project will therefore have positive environmental, social and economic effects on the local community.

 

To achieve these goals, I would like for four Masai from our village (two chosen by me and two by the village) and myself to be trained in land management and sustainable grazing at the Mara Training Centre in Kenya (www.maratrainingcentre.com).

It is a centre for holistic management that has in recent years established a locally led and trained community centred project that teaches pastoralists to sustainably manage their land and improve their livelihoods. Their achievements have inspired me to introduce their approach to our community here in Tanzania.

Please find below an estimate of the costs involved for a week long course at the Training Centre.

 

Estimated cost for an 5-day course for 5 people at the Mara Training Centre (MTC):

Course:                           100$ pp/day                                      2500$ total

 

Accomodation +

Meals during course: 50$ pp/day                                         1250$ total

 

Travel Lesoit – MTC

(3-day trip):                 15$ pp bus: Lesoit-Arusha                   75$ total

                                         50$ pp flight: Arusha-Nairobi          250$ total

                                          15$ pp bus: Nairobi-MTC                     75$ total

                                                                                                   

 

Additional costs for transport, hotel and

food in Arusha and Nairobi + visa, estimated:                    250$ total

 

Travel costs as above for return trip:                                    400$ total

 

Grand Total:                                                                            4800$

 

I really appreciate you taking the time to read my pledge and would be thrilled if you would consider donating to this important cause. As a token of appreciation I offer anyone donating 200$ or more the once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to experience the Masai’s unique culture by staying in our traditional Masai home.

The generous donor + 1 are welcome to stay with us free of charge for up to 5 nights.

Donors contributing 100$ or more receive a 30% discount from prices quoted on our website: https://masailife.weebly.com. My husband and I also welcome it if you invite your friends or family to take your place, should you, our generous supporter, not be able to take us up on the offer.

We appreciate all of you and donations of any size and will give shout outs on our social media sites to anyone who has chosen to donate or spread the word about our cause.

All funds will go towards providing education and training for our community. Funds that go beyond our goal, will be saved to provide training for a new group at a later point and to buy implementation tools for sustainable grazing (fences, GPS equipment, etc.). Even if your generous donations fail to reach our goal, I will aim to provide the necessary training for our community at a later point when further funding has been secured.

 

Tanzania is a country that I deeply love and the Masai are people that have touched my heart. Wanting to save the environment they live in and thereby preserving their ancient way of life is inspired by the love I feel for them.

I believe, by opening the Masai's eyes and hearts to the fact that their land is their biggest asset, they will get inspired to work towards regenerating it which will in the long run counteract desertification and climate change. This campaign therefore has potential worldwide effects, starting at a local level.

What qualifies me to lead this campaign is my background in conservation and the knowledge I have acquired about the Masai and their culture in the eight years that I have lived in Tanzania. I have gained a deep understanding about the issues surrounding conservation and the need to combine efforts to save our wildlife with communal education and anthropological knowledge. I speak fluent Swahili and basic Maa and am known and respected in our community. 

If I can inspire just a handful of people from our community to look after their land, I believe they will pass their knowledge on to others and work together towards a more secure future.

 

It is coming up to Christmas now, the season of love and giving. It is a time to remember that we all have only this one planet to live on. For now, it is a wonderful place to live in - but we have to look after it, ALL OF US. Let me ask you today, to think of all the places in the world where people might not be as lucky as you and where the beauty of our planet is threatened by ignorance and greed.

I am here, in one of these places and I am reaching out to you to ask for YOUR HELP .

 

Help me to make a difference by spreading the word to your friends and family and followers on your social media accounts and by using the share tools provided here on my indiegogo campaign page.

 

A big heartfelt thank you to everyone!

Let me ask you today, to think of all the places in the world where people might not be as lucky as you and where the beauty of our planet is threatened by ignorance and greed.I am here, in one of these places and I am reaching out to you to ask for YOUR HELP . Help me to make a difference by spreading the word to your friends and family and followers on your social media accounts and by using the share tools provided here on my indiegogo campaign page. A big heartfelt thank you to everyone!",0.0,0,"3 Campaigns
|","Lesoit, Kiteto, Tanzania, United Republic of",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/stephanie-s-masai-education-fund/pica

Most of the planet is not cities

column2: >It easy to forget that millions of people are still living in huts on poles, in the forests and by the rivers. Fishing and working the land, with limited access to the internet and the stream of information we are used to. column1: Their fish is full of plastic, the livestock eats it and gets sick, and even if they get exposed to campaigns and information about plastic pollution, it is to a large degree simply too external to take in and understand. They might see polluted beaches, the great gyres, whales washed up on some beach and clogged rivers with plastic, but this is outside their world.

Plastic is a fairly new concept in the third world, and in all history, their system of the renovation was to discard with all items no longer needed in the rivers and nature. When this was purely based on organic materials, which everything in their practical life consisted of, there was no problem. Now the material has changed from wood,  plant fibre, glass, metal and minerals to plastic, but the habits of discernment have not changed.
Who am I, and who are we?

Humans created plastic, but I do not accept this is a suicidal attempt from mother earth`s side. Childhood do leave scars, but we will recover and grow

column1: If you are not out travelling, maybe you know someone who is?
","Most of the planet is not cities

It easy to forget that millions of people are still living in huts on poles, in the forests and by the rivers. Fishing and working the land, with limited access to the internet and the stream of information we are used to. They do simply not get exposed to the fact that pollution is a worldwide problem, more than what they observe themselves.

Their fish is full of plastic, the livestock eats it and gets sick, and even if they get exposed to campaigns and information about plastic pollution, it is to a large degree simply too external to take in and understand. They might see polluted beaches, the great gyres, whales washed up on some beach and clogged rivers with plastic, but this is outside their world.

Plastic is a fairly new concept in the third world, and in all history, their system of the renovation was to discard with all items no longer needed in the rivers and nature. When this was purely based on organic materials, which everything in their practical life consisted of, there was no problem. Now the material has changed from wood,  plant fibre, glass, metal and minerals to plastic, but the habits of discernment have not changed.
Who am I, and who are we?

I`m Martin, 26-year-old, sailing around the world in my boat Chilli. In the past year since I left home, I've seen things I did not believe. I mean, whales, what the hell!? Astonishing nature, truly mindblowing what this blue ball has been able to create. It also created humans, which is in itself unbelievable. Humans created plastic, but I do not accept this is a suicidal attempt from mother earth`s side. Childhood do leave scars, but we will recover and grow
column2: I recognize the current time-period as the modern humans' adolescence and its time to tackle some childhood trauma.

column1: What I almost daily observe is people casually throwing full bags of garbidge straight in the river. Restaurant owners emptying their trashbin straight in the river. Discardings of all things in the water, just for convenience. Large pieces of polystyrene discharged overboard from the fishing vessels. There is to a large degree simply no awareness that plastic does not belong in the water!
This happens all over Amazonas, which results in more than 66 000 tonnes of plastic entering the oceans every year from only this river.

Being raised in a part of the world with a tremendous focus on environmental morale and awareness, we knew that we helped to save the world as long as we folded the milk-cartons, turned the light off, sorted and recycled waste with precision.

What I recognize is that we have to some degree continued this hyper-awareness about our own backyard, polishing the Tesla, while we forget that the neighbours' house is on fire, and the fire is spreading.

There is, hands down, an extraordinary array of great people, companies, and solutions being applied nowadays, but after meeting countless sailors and travellers who see and experience the same as I, and are equally clewless about what to do about it (other than cleaning beaches)
I really ought to exploit this group of nomads by giving them (us) a tool to make a difference in all the strangest corners of the world we might happen to be and explore.
The We
As well as asking for economic support to put this concept to life, we are
Calling all sailors, nomads, travellers and locals,looking to have an impact.

Noone can save the world alone, so I am with this, looking to combine forces with people with the same intentions, and build a platform for communication to support a community, and share skills and knowledge.
As by now, ""the we"" consists of ""Chilli"", ""Thorben"", a swiss-brazilian activist couple with decades of experience in Brazil, and our local friends, supplying invaluable strategic information.
What do we do about it?

“Stop it at Source”- aims to address the problem locally, in their language, with an approach the locals understand. This is radically different than how we do it in the west. It requires an understanding of the local cultures mentality, values, hierarchies and capacity of understanding.
The aim is to design a package of printable flyers and posters easily editable to fit the local environment, print and distribute.Specific content aimed at
The general public
Fishermen / farmers
Restaurants and Cafes
Convenience stores and farmers markets
Schools
This is also meant as a tool for local NGO`s to get an easily accessible tool to distribute information without extended skills in graphic design, access or knowledge about software and computers.
Goals pr Location
Step 1: The educational campaign - address the problem, raise consciousness
Step 2: Establish local NGO
Step 3: Introduce Empower - Giving plastic a value! (see empower.eco)
Why start here?

Marajo is an enormous isle covering the whole mouth of the Amazon basin, meaning all water going out to the ocean passes here. Soure is the capital of the island, which is a great starting point for working inwards through Amazonas (which does not need further introduction regards importance). There is also tourism here, meaning it`s already a focus on tidiness.
To get the information out, it has to be hands-on, physical presence, ""offline"" presentations of media and printed content.
Only the start
Amazonas is only the start. I aim to interrogate as many of the great rivers of the world as possible during my circumnavigation, and calling for partners to report and educate where they are.
The 10 great rivers of the world contribute to more than 90% of all plastic-pollution!
What we need
To do this we would humbly ask support for
Prints
Distribution
A computer powerful enough to work with media
There is truly frustrating to have knowledge of media production and resources to set it out to life, but not the basic tools to do it!
Não Dineros? Não Problema!

Reaching out to all sailors, nomads and travellers in all corners of the world who will help to spread the knowledge and battling plastic pollution - get in touch! Your geographical position may be golden
column2: there is the local presence which is key to this project, and we would be super excited to grow the base of Source Ambassadors!

GoViably is a women and minority owned business with over 60 years of combined experience in clean energy, energy storage and energy efficiency, consulting, business startup and development, business strategy and finance. Pulling from our many different experiences we are able to make great strides together advancing toward our shared vision.

We are creating a central hub where consumerism intersects with industry to create the sustainable global economy of the future. We will solve a problem that many consumers of sustainable products face
column2: how do I find products that are 100% verified to be sustainably sourced? In addition we will solve a problem for vendors: how do I scale my business in a financially and environmentally sustainable way?

column1: We are developing a certification that will allow us to designate which Businesses have been fully vetted to be responsibly sourcing, manufacturing and distributing, making the consumer experience that much easier. In addition we will help businesses create and implement strategies and gameplans with social and environmental responsibility built into the core from company culture all the way to product life cycle and in between.

In helping GoViably you would be helping to accelerate the reality of a sustainable and more resilient global economy. We will be using all funds to assist in app development, website development and a certification process for businesses.
<ul>
•               Goal 1. Create the beta application and web page.
•               Goal 2. Sign Up Clients
•               Goal 3. Begin trial run of Application with consumers and vendors

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
A MESSAGE FROM TOM HAYDEN
(Climate Change Activist and former CA State Senator)
THE PROBLEM
On
May 22, 2015, I had a stroke while investigating fracking waste ponds in Kern
County, California.<span>  That these poisoning
pits continue to pollute the poor and serve the interests of the oil and gas
industry is just one example of why we all must work to create a new model for
climate change in the 21st Century.
Thankfully,
I am well recovered from my stroke and continuing to work as the Executive
Director of the Peace and Justice Resource Center where we are implementing
this new global model for climate change.<span>
We
want to take this fight to the California State Legislature, the White House
and beyond. California’s
climate policies have become a real leverage point for National and
International policy. Everything that starts in California is copied globally
and around the capitol of our own country.<span>
But we need your help!
We must raise at least $50,000 for 2016 and $150,000 in three
years to implement our plan – building an effective team to keep battling to
completion the maximum goals of the Gov. Brown era in CA and the next
administration in Washington.
Giving what you can will help us get there!
THE PLAN
Having been involved in social movements for 55 years,
and 20 years as an elected official in the California Legislature, I am
requesting your help in a 3 year project involving climate change, social
justice and conveying the lessons of politics to a new generation.  This will include:
<ul>
• Achieving our goal of a 100% renewable
energy future by 2050.<span>  It’s only
possible through a grassroots set of movements combined with the states that
are already the laboratory of the future.
• Passing legislation to
bring justice to people impacted by gas and oil drilling.<span>  Current California law says gas and oil
drilling should serve the goal of profits and development. PJRC is working to
end that 100 year old custom and pass a new law requiring 21st century air
quality and anti-toxics standards and the protection of due process for the
people affected, not the profiteers who always seem to win. Not this time.  Help us get this law passed in Sacramento
next year!
• Advancing a model of reducing dangerous
carbon emissions while increasing jobs and health care for disadvantaged
communities.
<li>
Organizing and training activists in poor
communities.
• Traveling to the capitol,
meeting with the governor and state officials and rallying public
support to bring us into modern 21st century environmental standards.
• Building on
California’s global status as a clean energy model for the world.<span>  Our State’s climate policies have become a
real leverage point for National and International policy. Everything that
starts in California is copied globally and around the capitol of our own
country.
• Creating a continuous stream of
information gathering and dissemination to educate the public including
reports, newspaper articles and speeches on a new clean energy model for the
world.
• Engaging is constant dialogue with State
Officials, environmental leaders and community activists on the ground.
• Conducting intensive workshops to train
those activists in how to frame this and generate results.
Please help us move our country into a 21st
Century model for climate change by making a tax-deductible contribution to our
campaign today!
OUR ACHIEVEMENTS
<ul>
• This year alone the Peace
and Justice Resource Center has helped to draft and pass legislation to divest
state pension funds from coal.<span>  We expect
this legislation to be replicated in states across the country.
• We
worked with the California Governor’s climate team and the state Senate
leadership on ways to advance most rapidly towards a California model of
reducing dangerous carbon emissions while increasing jobs and health care for
disadvantaged communities, culminating in landmark climate change legislation
in California.
There is much to be done in 2016 and beyond!
With your help and support, we can move
environmental legislation nationally and globally in 2016!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px

We are a team of professionals interested in the prehistoric exploration of Artsakh and the rest of the Armenian Highlands. This current cave project aims to contribute to the scientific wealth of the area through the extensive excavation work in a virgin Paleolithic cave that has not been disturbed.  We have already done preliminary work within this site and found strong evidence on its scientific potential in terms of early human colonization and the overall environment at this period of time.  Because this cave is located in Artsakh, the lack of international recognition makes formal funding impossible, and the individual contributions of interested participants is the only way we can secure this wealth of research and scientific discovery awaiting us. Each contribution and the word of mouth spread by people about this project is invaluable to ultimately place Artsakh as an important center of scientific inquiry and discovery.  Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

The project head, Professor Levon Yepiskoposyan, is extensively involved in the field of human population genetics and paleontology, and has been a local partner of the internationally conducted excavations in the famous paleolithic cave of Azokh (also in Artsakh), since 2002.  Levon graduated from Moscow State University with a degree in anthropology and has a doctorate of science in the field of genetics. He has numerous published works in international scientific journals.  From 1995-1996, he was the rector of Arstakh State University.  Currently, he's leading the Ethnogenomics Lab in the Institute of Molecular Biology, Armenian National Academy of Sciences. Levon has been collecting DNA samples from both modern Armenians, and ancient DNA from burials in Armenia and Artsakh that extent to the Neolithic period. Under his guidance, the first ever extensive Genetic Map of Historical Armenia is currently in development, which can be accessed by the general public.

Team member Peter Hrechdakian is the volunteer administrator of the Armenian DNA Project at Family Tree DNA.  Using the latest genetic tools, he seeks to understand how the diverse Armenian genetic pool was affected by broad historical processes such as invasions, migrations, wars, forced population transfers, natural catastrophes, etc. and also subtle historical processes such as admixture, conversion, micro-migration… He has given a number of lectures and conferences on the subject.  Peter has a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics and Philosophy from Cornell University (Ithaca, New York) and a Masters in Business Administration degree from Harvard Business School (Boston, Massachussetts). He lives between Brussels, Belgium and Beirut, Lebanon. Peter has already contributed financially to the preliminary survey and exploration of the Alexana Cave in 2015.

Armen Martirosian is a physician and scientist focused on the origin of the Armenian population.  He currently lives in Yerevan, but hails from Honolulu Hawaii.  He has a Bachelor of Science in pre-medical studies from Hawaii Pacific University, and has continued his medical education in Armenia.  He has been a physical anthropology consultant on a recently uncovered archaeological site (the Necropolis of Karmir Blur) in Yerevan and has participated in DNA collection from rural areas of Armenia.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

The necessary funding for our project is at $40,000, which is the cost required
column3: >to cover all expenses related to the excavations

column1: in Alexana Cave.  This will cover the July-August 2016 period which will include 10 team members, 5 local assistants, a driver,
housing, meals, equipment, conservation of finds, and local transportation during

the course of ~3 weeks.  We will post updates during the field work, and will include regular posts that you can follow on Facebook or via other social media.  You are welcome to join us and participate, even virtually in our excavation and other areas of our scientific activities.

column2:
>The available perks are numerous, particularly via the personal exploration of your own genome, and upon your visit to Armenia, your welcomed participation ranging from field work, to our DNA collection in Armenian villages, and a visit to our facility with an introduction to the principle members of this project, meal included. Further, all contributors will be acknowledged in the scientific papers that result from this exploration, and those contributing over $1000, will have their names engraved on a plaque that will be placed upon the entrance of this cave.

The Impact

The difference your contributions will make here are invaluable, as they will increase interest in the scientific exploration of Artsakh, it will reconfirm that peaceful activities are an important part of Artsakh's independence, and that the Armenian Highlands are a very important region of human activity and migration for at least 1.8 million years.  The cave is tucked away in a quiet area not far from the town of Shushi, and is far from the active Line of Contact, and thus, is not in any danger.  It's located in a very hilly and wooden area fully protected from water erosion and other impacts from natural disasters.  The stone tools that have been found in the area indicate extensive human activity, and a sheltered cave has perhaps the greatest concentration of these traces.  We can also reconstruct the environmental changes that have occurred for the last tens of thousands of years.  The changes to the environment by human activity cannot be overstated, and we will have a detailed window into all of this. We have preliminary work available from previous explorations of this site within the last two years, but this is our first attempt to start a full scale exploratory work involving extensive excavation and processing of found materials.  We have included photos of our previous visits to the site, and please feel free to follow through on sources, particularly published works by Professor Levon Yepiskoposyan.

Risks &
column3:
Challenges

The greatest challenge we may face is the pace of scientific discovery, as some forms of analysis may take longer then we estimate, and publication of the results may be delayed.  There's also the possibility that we may not recover extensive human remains as we expect but what's certain is we'll recover and reconstruct the extensive environmental conditions, including the broad variety of flora and fauna species, some long since extinct, Because Artsakh is a conflict zone, we take every precaution necessary for the safety of the team and in the unlikely event of a full scale military conflict, we will then be forced to delay the work.

column1: <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column3: >We understand that not every individual who wants to contribute to this amazing exploration has the financial capacity to do so, but we value your passion and hope that you can spread the message of this funding campaign so we can truly make an impact.  Please don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools available here, which will ensure that a much broader audience will contribute to this project.

column1: For more details on this project, please see below:
The south-eastern part of
the Lesser Caucasus where Karabakh is located has provided numerous evidence of
continuous human settlement throughout the Pleistocene. The geographical position
of paleoanthropological sites (e.g. Dmanisi in Georgia and Azokh Cave in
Karabakh) indicates the persistence of a natural corridor named the “Caucasus
Isthmus” or the “Trans-Caucasian Corridor”, through which humans have entered
Europe for at least the last 1.8 million years.
Test
excavations were made at Alexana Cave, in the Shushi region, in July, 2014,
June and September, 2015. The field work was conducted by Prof. Levon
Yepiskoposyan (anthropologist, geneticist, Armenia), Dr. Thomas Stafford, Jr.
(geologist, USA), Dr. Morten Allentoft (palaeontologist, geneticist, Denmark),
and Dr. Ashot Margaryan (geneticist, Armenia, Denmark). An approximately 2 m
long X 1.5 m wide X 1.8 m deep test pit approximately 30 meters from the cave mouth
was excavated with shovels and archaeological trowels.
The
scientific importance of Alexana Cave derives from the site containing sediments
that startnear the
limit of <sup>14</sup>C (Carbon 14) and whose vertebrate fossils have
significant potential for yielding ancient DNA (aDNA). If human remains are
encountered in the Cave, they could preserve an unrivalled aDNA record not seen
for any human fossils dating &gt
The site could yield ancient genetic data far exceeding the quality of
any present European or Eurasian archaeological locality. The vertebrate fossil

","Short Summary

We are a team of professionals interested in the prehistoric exploration of Artsakh and the rest of the Armenian Highlands. This current cave project aims to contribute to the scientific wealth of the area through the extensive excavation work in a virgin Paleolithic cave that has not been disturbed.  We have already done preliminary work within this site and found strong evidence on its scientific potential in terms of early human colonization and the overall environment at this period of time.  Because this cave is located in Artsakh, the lack of international recognition makes formal funding impossible, and the individual contributions of interested participants is the only way we can secure this wealth of research and scientific discovery awaiting us. Each contribution and the word of mouth spread by people about this project is invaluable to ultimately place Artsakh as an important center of scientific inquiry and discovery.  Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

The project head, Professor Levon Yepiskoposyan, is extensively involved in the field of human population genetics and paleontology, and has been a local partner of the internationally conducted excavations in the famous paleolithic cave of Azokh (also in Artsakh), since 2002.  Levon graduated from Moscow State University with a degree in anthropology and has a doctorate of science in the field of genetics. He has numerous published works in international scientific journals.  From 1995-1996, he was the rector of Arstakh State University.  Currently, he's leading the Ethnogenomics Lab in the Institute of Molecular Biology, Armenian National Academy of Sciences. Levon has been collecting DNA samples from both modern Armenians, and ancient DNA from burials in Armenia and Artsakh that extent to the Neolithic period. Under his guidance, the first ever extensive Genetic Map of Historical Armenia is currently in development, which can be accessed by the general public.

Team member Peter Hrechdakian is the volunteer administrator of the Armenian DNA Project at Family Tree DNA.  Using the latest genetic tools, he seeks to understand how the diverse Armenian genetic pool was affected by broad historical processes such as invasions, migrations, wars, forced population transfers, natural catastrophes, etc. and also subtle historical processes such as admixture, conversion, micro-migration… He has given a number of lectures and conferences on the subject.  Peter has a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics and Philosophy from Cornell University (Ithaca, New York) and a Masters in Business Administration degree from Harvard Business School (Boston, Massachussetts). He lives between Brussels, Belgium and Beirut, Lebanon. Peter has already contributed financially to the preliminary survey and exploration of the Alexana Cave in 2015.

Armen Martirosian is a physician and scientist focused on the origin of the Armenian population.  He currently lives in Yerevan, but hails from Honolulu Hawaii.  He has a Bachelor of Science in pre-medical studies from Hawaii Pacific University, and has continued his medical education in Armenia.  He has been a physical anthropology consultant on a recently uncovered archaeological site (the Necropolis of Karmir Blur) in Yerevan and has participated in DNA collection from rural areas of Armenia.   What We Need & What You Get The necessary funding for our project is at $40,000, which is the cost required to cover all expenses related to the excavations
in Alexana Cave.  This will cover the July-August 2016 period which will include 10 team members, 5 local assistants, a driver,
housing, meals, equipment, conservation of finds, and local transportation during

the course of ~3 weeks.  We will post updates during the field work, and will include regular posts that you can follow on Facebook or via other social media.  You are welcome to join us and participate, even virtually in our excavation and other areas of our scientific activities.

The available perks are numerous, particularly via the personal exploration of your own genome, and upon your visit to Armenia, your welcomed participation ranging from field work, to our DNA collection in Armenian villages, and a visit to our facility with an introduction to the principle members of this project, meal included. Further, all contributors will be acknowledged in the scientific papers that result from this exploration, and those contributing over $1000, will have their names engraved on a plaque that will be placed upon the entrance of this cave.   The Impact The difference your contributions will make here are invaluable, as they will increase interest in the scientific exploration of Artsakh, it will reconfirm that peaceful activities are an important part of Artsakh's independence, and that the Armenian Highlands are a very important region of human activity and migration for at least 1.8 million years.  The cave is tucked away in a quiet area not far from the town of Shushi, and is far from the active Line of Contact, and thus, is not in any danger.  It's located in a very hilly and wooden area fully protected from water erosion and other impacts from natural disasters.  The stone tools that have been found in the area indicate extensive human activity, and a sheltered cave has perhaps the greatest concentration of these traces.  We can also reconstruct the environmental changes that have occurred for the last tens of thousands of years.  The changes to the environment by human activity cannot be overstated, and we will have a detailed window into all of this. We have preliminary work available from previous explorations of this site within the last two years, but this is our first attempt to start a full scale exploratory work involving extensive excavation and processing of found materials.  We have included photos of our previous visits to the site, and please feel free to follow through on sources, particularly published works by Professor Levon Yepiskoposyan.   Risks & Challenges The greatest challenge we may face is the pace of scientific discovery, as some forms of analysis may take longer then we estimate, and publication of the results may be delayed.  There's also the possibility that we may not recover extensive human remains as we expect but what's certain is we'll recover and reconstruct the extensive environmental conditions, including the broad variety of flora and fauna species, some long since extinct, Because Artsakh is a conflict zone, we take every precaution necessary for the safety of the team and in the unlikely event of a full scale military conflict, we will then be forced to delay the work.
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not every individual who wants to contribute to this amazing exploration has the financial capacity to do so, but we value your passion and hope that you can spread the message of this funding campaign so we can truly make an impact.  Please don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools available here, which will ensure that a much broader audience will contribute to this project.
For more details on this project, please see below:
The south-eastern part of
the Lesser Caucasus where Karabakh is located has provided numerous evidence of
continuous human settlement throughout the Pleistocene. The geographical position
of paleoanthropological sites (e.g. Dmanisi in Georgia and Azokh Cave in
Karabakh) indicates the persistence of a natural corridor named the “Caucasus
Isthmus” or the “Trans-Caucasian Corridor”, through which humans have entered
Europe for at least the last 1.8 million years.
Test
excavations were made at Alexana Cave, in the Shushi region, in July, 2014,
June and September, 2015. The field work was conducted by Prof. Levon
Yepiskoposyan (anthropologist, geneticist, Armenia), Dr. Thomas Stafford, Jr.
(geologist, USA), Dr. Morten Allentoft (palaeontologist, geneticist, Denmark),
and Dr. Ashot Margaryan (geneticist, Armenia, Denmark). An approximately 2 m
long X 1.5 m wide X 1.8 m deep test pit approximately 30 meters from the cave mouth
was excavated with shovels and archaeological trowels.
The
scientific importance of Alexana Cave derives from the site containing sediments
that startnear the
limit of 14C (Carbon 14) and whose vertebrate fossils have
significant potential for yielding ancient DNA (aDNA). If human remains are
encountered in the Cave, they could preserve an unrivalled aDNA record not seen
for any human fossils dating >40,000 years.
The site could yield ancient genetic data far exceeding the quality of
any present European or Eurasian archaeological locality. The vertebrate fossil
record is exceptionally rich and is evidence that paleontological data alone
from Alexana Cave could define it as overwhelmingly important well of scientific
discovery.
We
can state that there is a real
possibility that we may in fact identify two Homo species (H.
neanderthalensis, and H. sapiens)
in this exceptionally promising site. To date, there have been reassuring
signs of early human habitation within the Armenian Highland, but mainly
through various indirect links, such as early human tools. This site will
give us a true glimpse of prehistoric human presence within the Armenian
plateau. In general, we consider that any such scientific activity within
Karabakh will greatly impact its active involvement in contemporary research.
Bones
observed during excavation were collected in situ, were recorded by stratigraphic
position and later radiocarbon dated by using AMS 14C. Significant numbers
of medium to large mammal bones and one large bird were encountered during test
excavations. In addition, small mammals ranging from shrews to voles were
recovered, which when combined with the large fauna, will provide an excellent
paleoecological history for the region.
Three
stratigraphic positions in Test Pit 1 were dated by using four AMS 14C
measurements on medium-sized mammal bone. The ages range from >41,700 to >50,000
Radiocarbon Years (RC) and are evidence that sediments from at least 47 cm below
the modern cave floor are beyond the limit of radiocarbon dating (~48-50,000 years).
The
significance of the preliminary survey results so far are:
Sediments
less than 0.5 meters beneath the modern cave floor surface are >42,000 years
old.
Bones
from medium to large mammals dating >42,000 years old have unusually good
chemical preservation considering their significant geological age.
The
sedimentary sequence contains significant amounts of vertebrate microfauna
(shrews, voles and other rodents) that are otherwise rare paleontological finds.
These
data are an indication of the cave’s enormous potential for future archaeological
and paleontological research. First, sediments less than 0.5 m below the cave floor
are greater than 42,000 years old. This indicates that Neanderthal-age strata are
readily accessible by shallow excavation and could be present on the surface. It
is possible that the uppermost decimetres of Test Pit 1 are also >40,000 years
old, which indicates that essentially no sedimentation has occurred for tens of
thousands of years. A possible explanation for this zero-to-low sedimentation rate
is the sediments originated from a now-closed cave fissure immediately above or
adjacent to Test Pit 1. Although bones within a meter vertically of the cave floor
are >42,000 to 50,000 years old, their chemical preservation resembles fossils
that are less than 10,000 years old. This relatively good preservation portends
that ancient DNA (aDNA) could be preserved in fossils dating to the Neanderthal
period and older.
Although
the test pit sediments are at least 42,000 years old and beyond the limits of present
radiocarbon dating techniques, the microfauna, especially from the microtine
rodents, will enable biochronologic age dating of sediments older than 50,000
years.
We would like to start large-scale
excavations in a more thorough manner, hoping to obtain
detailed core samples of the sedimentary strata and uncover convincing evidence
of early human habitation. We are planning to work in the cave for ~20 days in the summer 2016.  Once we know
the maximum depth of the sediments, we could postulate the absolute age at the
bottom and determine whether it’s 60,000 years old or even 150,000.
If
human remains are encountered in Alexana Cave, they could preserve an
unrivalled aDNA record not seen for any human fossils dating >40,000 years.
The site could yield ancient genetic data far exceeding the quality of any
present European or Eurasian archaeological locality. The vertebrate fossil
record is exceptionally rich and is evidence that paleontological data alone
from Alexana could define the cave as a regionally important scientific
discovery.
In
conclusion, I can state that there is a real possibility that we may in fact
identify two human species (H. neanderthalensis, and early H. sapiens) in this
exceptionally promising site. To date, there have been promising signs of
early human habitation within the Armenian Highland, but mainly through various
indirect links, such as early human tools. This site will give us a true
glimpse of prehistoric human presence within the Armenian plateau. In general,
we consider that any such scientific activity within Karabakh will greatly
impact its active involvement in contemporary research.
To cover all expenses related to the excavations
in Alexana Cave (July-August 2016, 10 team members, 5 local assistants, driver,
housing, meals, equipment, conservation of finds and local transportation during
the course of ~3 weeks) we need approximately 40,000 USD.
Sincerely Yours,
Levon Yepiskoposyan, Sc.D., Prof.
Head of Ethnogenomics laboratory
Institute of Molecular Biology
National Academy of Sciences of Armenia

>Our Mission

We think deer and people benefit from environmental solutions that are both effective and compassionate, and if you agree, we hope you'll add your name to our growing list of supporters.

column1: <h3><b style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif

<h3><span style=""font-size: 24px

The funds we raise in this campaign will help our wildlife biologists and veterinarians treat deer in our Clifton herd this Fall.  These are deer who would be targeted by bow-hunters but for our program.  Equally important, your donations support the research that may make non-lethal deer herd management techniques possible in other communities - saving the lives of many more deer while also protecting our drivers, yards, and parks.
How we thank you
As a thank you for your generosity, check out our awesome deer swag perks, featuring members of our very own Clifton deer herd!  These are our exclusive designs - you won't find them anywhere else!

Where your Donations go

Great Turning Advisors (#Venture4Impact)

We ignite growth in companies that are solving social and environmental problems by actively mentoring entrepreneurs and aligning them with investors.
  • We are a team of Millennials: we are creatives, marketers, investors, managers, college students, and entrepreneurs dedicated to finding the best solutions to our generation's toughest challenges (human rights, a healthy planet, sustainable living, equal opportunity, community building, and more).

• We are partnering with experienced investors and professionals in venture capital, government, and nonprofits to accelerate the growth of social enterprises (for-profit, mission-driven companies) located in the U.S. that have both local and global impact.
• What is #Venture4Impact? It's what we do: we support ventures that are creating impact with investment capital and mentorship. It's Venture Capital working for Impact instead of profit alone.
• GTA is proud to be majority women-led and (currently) all the companies we work with are women owned and managed!
• GTA is also proud to operate virtually which helps reduce our carbon footprint!
What We Need &

We need YOU to help us grow. By operating for profit, GTA will have more incentive to find the absolute best social entrepreneurs to accelerate (if we don't, we don't eat). Before we can line up investors for our fund, we need to accelerate as many social enterprises as possible to prove to them that #Venture4Impact is the best way to do good while making money. Why is that good? It means significantly more money being invested in doing good things in the world!
• While we look to raise our first impact fund this year (so we can be a truly sustainable business), we need your help awakening those world-changing entrepreneurs.
• Your contribution will support this year's activities (which are already underway):

Fall: Raise Our Impact Fund!  This means having a stable pool of money to invest in companies that are generating impact for the world and returns for investors. We are excited to prototype a brand new fund structure for our accelerator that helps entrepreneurs have a more equal partnership with investors!
What You Get:
<div><ol>

• You get to be a part of changing the world economy for the better. From now on any living person will be able to support good around the world and in their communities simply by using their dollars.
• You will be kept up-to-date on the most groundbreaking advancements and social-change models being advanced.
• Certain contributors will get to spend time meeting and collaborating with the GTA team and those we help! (see perks)

column2: >Our work aims to establish a more positive and sustainable future for the next generation, leaving a better earth for us and our children.

column1: Progress so far:
• We were winners in the 2015 SBA Growth Accelerator Fund Competition.
• We have received recognition from investors and government officials.

• We are an active part of the community: This year we exhibited at NetImpact, hosted a local InnovateHER competition, and are working with several entrepreneurs to help them follow their dreams of bettering the world.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

There are always risks when igniting a movement.  GTA is investing everything to make this work. We have an extremely qualified team skilled in finance, marketing, management and with creative talents and backgrounds that include the arts, the environment, nonprofits, and activism. We also have a highly reputable team of advisers that cover government, consumer products, energy, venture capital, women's advocacy and much more. We have tremendous faith in our team, but our biggest hurdle is funding until we raise our impact fund(s). This is how we intend to be sustainable going forward, but we first have to demonstrate to investors that impact investing is the way of the future. Many impact investors already exist and each day more capital is funneled into social and environmental solutions. We have what startups need to succeed in creating both impact and profit. Your contributions help fund our work in the short term while we continue to build a track record of success for our social entrepreneurs!

Spring: GTA's National Tour! We are traveling the country to speak at universities and in communities about social entrepreneurship and spark a national movement! This is going to help us find and awaken the best entrepreneurs to solve BIG challenges.

Summer: GTA's Social Innovation Conference & Demo Day! This is where/when everything comes together. We get to showcase all the wonderful social entrepreneurs that we're working with to investors and the world.

Fall: Raise Our Impact Fund!  This means having a stable pool of money to invest in companies that are generating impact for the world and returns for investors. We are excited to prototype a brand new fund structure for our accelerator that helps entrepreneurs have a more equal partnership with investors!
What You Get:
You get to be a part of changing the world economy for the better. From now on any living person will be able to support good around the world and in their communities simply by using their dollars.
You will be kept up-to-date on the most groundbreaking advancements and social-change models being advanced.
Certain contributors will get to spend time meeting and collaborating with the GTA team and those we help! (see perks)
The Impact
A healthier planet: less pollution and destruction
column2: better resource management: fewer famines and a better standard of living globally
column4: a more equal, free, and engaged society

column1: Our work aims to establish a more positive and sustainable future for the next generation, leaving a better earth for us and our children.
Progress so far:
We were winners in the 2015 SBA Growth Accelerator Fund Competition.
We have received recognition from investors and government officials.

We are an active part of the community: This year we exhibited at NetImpact, hosted a local InnovateHER competition, and are working with several entrepreneurs to help them follow their dreams of bettering the world.

Risks & Challenges  There are always risks when igniting a movement.  GTA is investing everything to make this work. We have an extremely qualified team skilled in finance, marketing, management and with creative talents and backgrounds that include the arts, the environment, nonprofits, and activism. We also have a highly reputable team of advisers that cover government, consumer products, energy, venture capital, women's advocacy and much more. We have tremendous faith in our team, but our biggest hurdle is funding until we raise our impact fund(s). This is how we intend to be sustainable going forward, but we first have to demonstrate to investors that impact investing is the way of the future. Many impact investors already exist and each day more capital is funneled into social and environmental solutions. We have what startups need to succeed in creating both impact and profit. Your contributions help fund our work in the short term while we continue to build a track record of success for our social entrepreneurs!
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, you can still help us be heard! Share this campaign with someone you know. Who knows, you may lead us to our next entrepreneur or investor!
Follow us...
Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/GreatTurningAdvisors/
Twitter
https://www.twitter.com/gta_accelerator
Instagram
https://www.instagram.com/gta_accelerator/
Web:
http://greatturningadvisors.com/
