column1: ","Short Summary

My name is Janos, i am a natural builder, living in Transylvania, Romania With this project, i would like to show the people, that they can build a really good house, just wit natural materials, very cheap and no need bank credits
Also, in this house will live my family (3 kids). We still rent a house after 11 years marriage.
What We Need & What You Get
I calculate that i need no more than 5000 euro to build a 80 sqm house

It will be an eco-friendly house, build with straw bales, mud (cob tehnique), stone foundation, also straw thatch on the roof. I need this money to pay the land (wich is half of the needed amount!), transportation of materials (wich i want to colect from nature), buying some windows and wood for the structure and the roof. Also i need to be sure that i will have water on the site. For that i need to pay people to dig a well. Money will go also for food for us (i want to build with my family) and volunteers, because people in Romania know me and they want to help because in this way they can learn from me.
I know that, i will build this house even if i will not reach the goal, but for me it would be very important to finish in the autum of 2016, to can move with my family in the house..
in these moment, everybody can follow the project on our blog : http://colibaverdedinardeal.webs.com. Now just in romanian and hungarian but we will start also in english very soon!
The Impact

If i can finish this project, it would be a very very good example for people that they don't need credits to build a house, and they can build really cheap a good house. Also, my family can move finally in our natural...home. Because people know me in Romania like a good natural builder (promote for free, through 3 websites the natural buildings and the natural living life style, trying to change the mentality), many of them want to come and help, expecting to learn a lot from me. So, if i will have enough money, i can build entirely the house, in this way i can teach lot of people. I think also, if i raise money (and i would like to call it „help”) , from here, it is a good example for people helping each other for good reasons. If WE are unite, we can do better things rather than to be a modern slave for corporations :)
Other Ways You Can Help
Don't worry if you can not contribute. :) If you like my project, it is enough if you share it to your friend. Thank you people very much!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

Some things about me ... Dawn
<ul>
• I am “Team Earth”
• I believe humans need tools to aid in their everyday consumption of food
• I believe these tools should be beautiful and invoke sacred ritual
• I believe using this kit will have a ripple effect out into the world ... others will witness this and it will spread
<li>I believe in CRITICAL MASS &amp
column2: THE TIPPING POINT and that we will shift for the better

column1: • I believe the use of this tool will become as common as carrying refillable water bottles and reusable grocery bags
My Background (Dawn Prokop)
7 years ago I started a recycling business = Re-Sourceress.
With the help of Ruth Bleeker, we successfully recycled indoor &
column2: outdoor festivals in Dallas for several years.  We promoted “education thru action” in an effort to show Dallas how to dispose of their trash.

column1: It was during an outdoor food festival that the vision of the utensil kits was born.  We asked the question, “What will it take to help people become more mindful about the way they consume?”
Fast-Forward 7 years and the vision materialized.   Dawn’s vision was brought to life with the help of CJ Vaughn (a self-taught engineer and product design specialist).
What You Get
<ul>
• Anyone who contributes $50 or more receives a Personal, Portable, Utensil Kit.
<li>Each Kit contains the following:<ul>
• 2 Acrylic Handles ... your choice of color
• 3 pieces of cutlery heads that screw into the handles (fork, knife, spoon) ... your choice of stainless steel or copper
• 2 wooden chopstick heads that screw into the handles
• 1 zipper pouch to store and transport parts
• 1 soft pouch with long shoulder strap for easy transportation
Thru personal savings and funds, the first batch of product has been created and is ready for shipment.  Product has been undergoing Quality Control and Testing for the past 6 months.
What We Need
<ul>
<li>We need capital to Produce &amp
<li>Marketing &amp
• We have near-future goals to contribute to “Ocean Clean Up” orgs thru proceeds from sales.
<li>
We are Seeking at least $2,500 Start-Up Capital
• Bulk order of raw materials = $1K
<li>Tools &amp
• 1 Desktop Lathe Machine = ~ $500
• 1 Laser Craft Engraving Machines for Wooden Boxes = $400
• Website Upgrade = $1K
<li>Marketing &amp
<li>New design creations = $1K<ul>
• Collapsible Straw
• Portable copper bowl / plate combo ... ideal for “to go” situations
The Impact

This is a Global Impact.  We are all responsible for our environment.  Our choices matter.  Consider that France has just banned all plastic utensils, cups and plates.  Our rate of consumption and disposal CANNOT CONTINUE.  We have to change our patterns.
Your purchase and use of this utensil will help create that shift.
We made the tools beautiful so that you will be proud to use them in any setting ... from a picnic ... to a working lunch ... to eating out at a nice restaurant !!!
Risks &
Airport Security:
Current challenge is whether this design is TSA compliant for carry-on.  We sell to several flight attendants and they have no problem carrying it on, but each terminal could be different.
Knife Attachment:

The solid copper knife head has the potential to bend.  Copper is a soft metal and the knife is not designed for heavy cutting.  We are working on a “steak knife” out of brass and stainless steel that will still complement each set.
Other Ways You Can Help
<ul>
• Spread The Word !!!
• Sharing this campaign and video and any social media posts is MOST APPRECIATED.
• Use your Indiegogo share tools to get the word out.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h3>

‘Legumes’ belong to a family of plants which we often refer to as 'peas' and 'beans'. They are grown as a food crop, mainly for their grain seed called pulse. They are regularly consumed in many households, and some of the most familiar members include soybeans, peanuts and lentils.

 

 

Apart from their economic and nutritional values, legumes have a unique ability that distinguishes them from all other plants. They are capable of forming beneficial partnerships with a special group of soil bacteria known as ‘rhizobia’. This collaboration between plant and bacteria makes it possible for legumes to harvest nitrogen from the air and convert it into forms usable for their growth and productivity.

 

 

The benefit of this 'nitrogen fixation' is not limited to the legume plant alone. Once the plant decomposes, nitrogen is returned to the soil, which is then available to every other plant in the vicinity. In other words, legumes can contribute additional external nitrogen to the crop-soil ecosystem.

 

 

Although legumes have long been used in agriculture, their natural process for harvesting nitrogen has largely been replaced with the application of synthetic nitrogen fertilisers that were first introduced around 200 years ago, during the agricultural revolution.

 

As the production of synthetic nitrogen fertilisers requires a great amount of energy, nitrogen fertiliser prices are staggering and continue to rise as a direct result of the current energy crisis. Another concern is that nitrogen fertilisers have a devastating effect on the environment. With pressing global environmental issues, the large-scale and continuous use of nitrogen fertilisers is unsustainable and is accelerating environmental degradation.

 

 

Our research proposes an alternative to current agricultural practices, in a way that is most productive to both farmers and the environment. By examining a variety of legume plants and beneficial soil bacteria, we aim to identify which plant-bacterium partners are the most efficient at harvesting and returning nitrogen to the soil.

 

 

Our project focuses on the development of tropical, small-scale farming systems to provide an immediate solution for underprivileged farmers in communities that are most sensitive to rises in agricultural costs and the environmental effects of global climate change. Developing new agricultural approaches and ensuring food security go hand in hand. Therefore, we have made the most vulnerable communities a priority within our study.

 

 

Human activity now has such a profound effect on the Earth’s climate and environment to have raised calls for there to be declared a new geological epoch – the Anthropocene
column2:
a time in which human influence dominates, and climate change is proceeding at an unprecedented rate. Modern high-input agriculture, through the emission of greenhouse gases and other pollutants, is a major factor in environmental change and the breakdown of natural ecosystems.

 

The agricultural revolutions of the twentieth century changed the world. In particular the development of synthetic nitrogen fixation and use of nitrogen fertiliser, that through improved food security allowed the population to more than double, and today reaching 7 billion. But paradoxically the use of fertilisers and other high input systems that have benefited humanity in the past, also threatens it today. The release of atmospheric nitrous oxide from agricultural use accounts for 67% of human nitrous oxide emissions. In the atmosphere nitrous oxide acts as a greenhouse gas and is a major contributor to climate change.

 

Problems associated with industrial agriculture is not restricted to the developed world, they are global. Communities in developing nations, particularly those in the tropics, will be the hardest hit by the adverse effects of climate change. This is largely due to the expected increase in the frequency and severity of natural events such as flooding, drought and disease outbreaks. Many people in less-developed nations are already facing serious food scarcity. They are extremely vulnerable to any external environmental changes which threaten their agricultural productivity.

 

There is clearly an urgent need to increase agricultural productivity in regions of widespread hunger and poverty. Also important to the alleviation of food insecurity is the application of sustainable agriculture. As many communities' livelihoods depend on farming, their fate is tightly interwoven with their environment. Practices which exacerbate environmental degeneration, such as slash and burn agriculture and land mismanagement must therefore be substituted with ones that would compliment both people's lives and the environment.

 

We require an immediate effort to reform our current agricultural systems, in a manner which will dramatically ameliorate environmental damages. How can we transform modern agricultural systems? More specifically, how can we make agriculture high-yielding and sustainable, particularly to developing communities that are vulnerable to food scarcity, malnutrition and poverty?

 

Biological Nitrogen Fixation (BNF) is a highly efficient natural process that converts atmospheric dinitrogen into forms that are useful to plants. BNF is the result of a symbiotic relationship between Legumes (members of the plant family Leguminosae) and nitrogen-fixing bacteria known as rhizobia. Nitrogen fixation occurs in a special root structure, called the nodule, which forms when legume roots become infected with rhizobia.

 

 

Of all the necessary nutrients for plant growth and productivity, nitrogen is required in the largest quantity and is often the most limiting factor of crop yield in agricultural systems. Despite being the most abundant element in the atmosphere, the availability of metabolically usable forms is governed by the process of nitrogen fixation.

 

This key biological system is under-utilised in modern agriculture and a neglected area of research, agriculture and ecology. BNF warrants further study, given that the system naturally produces nitrogen in forms available to plants, allowing us to bypass economically and ecologically costly production of nitrogen fertilisers.

 

There is ample evidence that leguminous species, in both wild habitats and agricultural systems, play a key role in ecosystem functioning by improving soil fertility and rehabilitating the ecosystem.

 

 

Certain legume species are able to successfully colonise hostile deserts due to their tolerance to highly dry and saline conditions. In Tamarugal Pampa, the Northern region of Chile, a legume species is being introduced to salt deserts to re-establish forests. These large leguminous trees have deep roots which can tap into ground water and redistribute water to upper ground levels

 

In African Savannas where the ecosystem is characterised by grassland and dispersed trees, legumes often nodulate well and actively fix nitrogen in presence of grasses (which remove and utilise nitrogen from soil). A study conducted by Ludwig et al., 2008 in Northern Tanzania showed that the forage quality of grasses growing under Acacia is significantly higher than those growing in open fields. Higher forage quality is accounted for by higher protein and lower fibre concentrations which allow large herbivores to satisfy nutrient requirements before maximum fibre intake was reached.

 

A wide variety of legumes have also been incorporated into tropical farming systems to provide soil cover and improve soil fertility. For instance, Pinto peanut is increasingly being cultivated in Southern Thailand. In this region, an expanding organic farm has been using Pinto peanut as a rotation crop for the past two years. Not only has the soil fertility been sustained over this period, but large fields of flowering peanuts have attracted many visitors to the farm which directly generates income and increases local interest in subsistence farming. Similarly, in rural areas of central Thailand, Mung bean has been introduced as a mean to improve soil health and overcome water shortages following harvesting season. Over the past ten years, Mung bean cultivation has benefited local farmers by improving soil fertility and increasing yields of subsequently grown crops. Their seeds also generate income as good yields are achieved at low cost and low labour inputs. In addition, this legume species is so well adapted to this region's soil that no inoculants, pesticides, herbicides or artificial fertilisers are required.

 

In the valleys of Beira Alta, the mountainous interior of Portugal, nitrogen sustainability has been managed through traditional ecological knowledge over the past 800 years. Two wild legume species have been encouraged to grow on a significant amount of farmland used to cultivate rye. A substantial amount of protein-rich rye grains have been exported from these farming regions to urban areas during this time. Biera Alta region has remained highly productive and sustainable largely due to field rotations with legumes which allowed restoration of cultivated soil fertility.

 

In association with the University of Edinburgh, the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh and the James Hutton Institute, we have had the opportunity to explore and undertake research on legume-rhizobia symbiosis. Having studied the symbiotic specificities of various tropical and arid legume species, we are aware that much remains unexplored in the field of nitrogen-fixing legumes.

 

Because most commercial and cultivated legumes have been selected to thrive in fertilised soils, their benefits to developing communities are likely to be minimal, given the low-input nature of many small-scale farming systems. It is therefore important for us to understand the dynamics of BNF by wild legumes which are adapted to their natural, indigenous soil and environments. These include wild legumes which are able to grow in nutrient poor soils.

 

Research implications (for both tropical and temperate regions):

column1: • Identification of novel rhizobia species/strains highly effective at fixing nitrogen.
• Directly increase pulse yields with new rhizobial inoculants and different varieties of legumes.
• Exclude the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilisers.
• Increase soil health and productivity for growth of various agricultural crops.
• Rehabilitate soil in natural ecosystems.
• Contribute to the knowledge of legume and rhizobia diversities in Thailand.

Our immediate goal is to assess the nodulation status of wild legumes growing in the Northern and North-Eastern regions of Thailand. Our project focuses on Thailand for several reasons. Firstly, there are many rural Thai communities that rely on low-input agriculture. Secondly, the country's tropical climate and topographical diversity are likely to harbour various legume and rhizobia species. Finally, thorough research on Thai legumes and their symbiotic partners is generally lacking.

 

Specifically, we aim to:
• Collect and preserve nodule samples from wild legume populations
• record sample site location and conduct a basic geological research (soil type, soil pH and average rainfall)
• Cultivate soil bacteria from nodule samples
• Characterise nodule bacteria by DNA sequencing
• Re-infect host legumes to authenticate nodule bacteria
Given sufficient funding, we further aim to:
• Infect other non-host legumes with isolated nodule bacteria
• Assess the nitrogen-fixation efficiency of each legume-rhizobia partners

All samples collected from Thailand will be preserved and brought back to Ghent, Belgium, where laboratory work will commence. We aim to complete data collection within 1.5 months and estimate laboratory work to to be completed within four months.

 

We are a non-profit initiative, and 100% of the funds will be used to conduct research work. Approximately one fifth of the total fund is required for travelling to and from Thailand. The remaining funds will contribute to field-study equipment and laboratory research. DNA sequencing is crucial to this project, and realistically, repeated sequencing may be required for each sample. For this reason, we have included the likely additional costs to sequencing. Any remaining funds will go towards building our website Legumes of Thailand.

 

We kindly ask for your help in order to launch this intriguing scientific research. We are confident of conducting a thorough and exciting research in which we hope will contribute to both the local communities and the scientific world. Our emerging understanding of BNF may enable us to not only optimise agricultural productivity in less-privileged communities, but to improve agriculture in a manner which minimises environmental degradation.

 

We thank you in advance for your contribution to this project, and welcome you to be part of this fascinating study!

 

You can help us launch this project by donating to our INDIEGOGO campaign. Also, please share our project to your friends and family! We hope you will all find our work as exciting as we do!

 

 

Because we consider all of our contributors a part of our team, we would be more than delighted to share the findings of this study with all of our backers. Following the completion of this project, we will construct a website: Legumes of Thailand with exclusive access for backers to view the scientific data. To accompany this, we will share our discussions and the significance of the data analyses. Any follow-up study will also be announced on the website.

 

For those who are curious of exactly how this study will be conducted, we will compile a short video for our backers, showing all of our work process, from field work to lab-based research. We also hope that our video will communicate the very real issues of modern agriculture, the environment and the effects they have on community livelihoods. At the same time, we would like everyone to see the precious and huge floral diversity of Thailand through our eyes. Enjoy!

 

Because we will conduct our project in Thailand, some of the funds raised will be allocated to international and domestic travelling costs.

 

A large part of the funds will be used for field-work and laboratory equipment as well as lab-based analyses.

 

Full details of the research budget are outlined here : 

https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-WuuXHEhNLzb...

 

 

Campaign creator, Script, Footage, Plant Scientist

Stephanie was raised in rural Thailand. Her father's work as an agricultural engineer in less-privileged communities has fueled her interest in plants and their importance to the local people from an early age. Her fascination for legume-rhizobia symbiosis stemmed from her 2015 project which looked at legume and nodule diversity within Eastern England and continental Western Europe populations. Subsequently, Stephanie completed her Plant Science dissertation at the University of Edinburgh which was titled: The occurrence of nodulation and rhizobial diversity in the RBGE, Edinburgh Legume collection.

 

Web Designer, Video Editor, Campaigner

Hailing from one of Belgium's greatest hidden treasures, Eeklo. Kasper is an experienced self-taught computer professional who loves building web applications. He is responsible for editing the short-documentary and for building the website.

 

Voice Over, Biologist, Campaigner

Gregory is a talented Medical Biology graduate from the University of Edinburgh. His well-rounded knowledge on modern day issues and strong scientific skills make him an indispensable part of this team.

 

Plant Scientist, Campaigner

Iain is a budding plant scientist from the University of Edinburgh. His innovative ideas and approach to scientific research is second to none. Iain is particularly interested in the genetics of legume nodulation.

column9: a time in which human influence dominates, and climate change is proceeding at an unprecedented rate. Modern high-input agriculture, through the emission of greenhouse gases and other pollutants, is a major factor in environmental change and the breakdown of natural ecosystems. The agricultural revolutions of the twentieth century changed the world. In particular the development of synthetic nitrogen fixation and use of nitrogen fertiliser, that through improved food security allowed the population to more than double, and today reaching 7 billion. But paradoxically the use of fertilisers and other high input systems that have benefited humanity in the past, also threatens it today. The release of atmospheric nitrous oxide from agricultural use accounts for 67% of human nitrous oxide emissions. In the atmosphere nitrous oxide acts as a greenhouse gas and is a major contributor to climate change. Problems associated with industrial agriculture is not restricted to the developed world, they are global. Communities in developing nations, particularly those in the tropics, will be the hardest hit by the adverse effects of climate change. This is largely due to the expected increase in the frequency and severity of natural events such as flooding, drought and disease outbreaks. Many people in less-developed nations are already facing serious food scarcity. They are extremely vulnerable to any external environmental changes which threaten their agricultural productivity. There is clearly an urgent need to increase agricultural productivity in regions of widespread hunger and poverty. Also important to the alleviation of food insecurity is the application of sustainable agriculture. As many communities' livelihoods depend on farming, their fate is tightly interwoven with their environment. Practices which exacerbate environmental degeneration, such as slash and burn agriculture and land mismanagement must therefore be substituted with ones that would compliment both people's lives and the environment. We require an immediate effort to reform our current agricultural systems, in a manner which will dramatically ameliorate environmental damages. How can we transform modern agricultural systems? More specifically, how can we make agriculture high-yielding and sustainable, particularly to developing communities that are vulnerable to food scarcity, malnutrition and poverty? Biological Nitrogen Fixation (BNF) is a highly efficient natural process that converts atmospheric dinitrogen into forms that are useful to plants. BNF is the result of a symbiotic relationship between Legumes (members of the plant family Leguminosae) and nitrogen-fixing bacteria known as rhizobia. Nitrogen fixation occurs in a special root structure, called the nodule, which forms when legume roots become infected with rhizobia.  Of all the necessary nutrients for plant growth and productivity, nitrogen is required in the largest quantity and is often the most limiting factor of crop yield in agricultural systems. Despite being the most abundant element in the atmosphere, the availability of metabolically usable forms is governed by the process of nitrogen fixation. This key biological system is under-utilised in modern agriculture and a neglected area of research, agriculture and ecology. BNF warrants further study, given that the system naturally produces nitrogen in forms available to plants, allowing us to bypass economically and ecologically costly production of nitrogen fertilisers. There is ample evidence that leguminous species, in both wild habitats and agricultural systems, play a key role in ecosystem functioning by improving soil fertility and rehabilitating the ecosystem.  Certain legume species are able to successfully colonise hostile deserts due to their tolerance to highly dry and saline conditions. In Tamarugal Pampa, the Northern region of Chile, a legume species is being introduced to salt deserts to re-establish forests. These large leguminous trees have deep roots which can tap into ground water and redistribute water to upper ground levels In African Savannas where the ecosystem is characterised by grassland and dispersed trees, legumes often nodulate well and actively fix nitrogen in presence of grasses (which remove and utilise nitrogen from soil). A study conducted by Ludwig et al., 2008 in Northern Tanzania showed that the forage quality of grasses growing under Acacia is significantly higher than those growing in open fields. Higher forage quality is accounted for by higher protein and lower fibre concentrations which allow large herbivores to satisfy nutrient requirements before maximum fibre intake was reached. A wide variety of legumes have also been incorporated into tropical farming systems to provide soil cover and improve soil fertility. For instance, Pinto peanut is increasingly being cultivated in Southern Thailand. In this region, an expanding organic farm has been using Pinto peanut as a rotation crop for the past two years. Not only has the soil fertility been sustained over this period, but large fields of flowering peanuts have attracted many visitors to the farm which directly generates income and increases local interest in subsistence farming. Similarly, in rural areas of central Thailand, Mung bean has been introduced as a mean to improve soil health and overcome water shortages following harvesting season. Over the past ten years, Mung bean cultivation has benefited local farmers by improving soil fertility and increasing yields of subsequently grown crops. Their seeds also generate income as good yields are achieved at low cost and low labour inputs. In addition, this legume species is so well adapted to this region's soil that no inoculants, pesticides, herbicides or artificial fertilisers are required. In the valleys of Beira Alta, the mountainous interior of Portugal, nitrogen sustainability has been managed through traditional ecological knowledge over the past 800 years. Two wild legume species have been encouraged to grow on a significant amount of farmland used to cultivate rye. A substantial amount of protein-rich rye grains have been exported from these farming regions to urban areas during this time. Biera Alta region has remained highly productive and sustainable largely due to field rotations with legumes which allowed restoration of cultivated soil fertility. In association with the University of Edinburgh, the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh and the James Hutton Institute, we have had the opportunity to explore and undertake research on legume-rhizobia symbiosis. Having studied the symbiotic specificities of various tropical and arid legume species, we are aware that much remains unexplored in the field of nitrogen-fixing legumes. Because most commercial and cultivated legumes have been selected to thrive in fertilised soils, their benefits to developing communities are likely to be minimal, given the low-input nature of many small-scale farming systems. It is therefore important for us to understand the dynamics of BNF by wild legumes which are adapted to their natural, indigenous soil and environments. These include wild legumes which are able to grow in nutrient poor soils. Research implications (for both tropical and temperate regions):

column1: Identification of novel rhizobia species/strains highly effective at fixing nitrogen.
Directly increase pulse yields with new rhizobial inoculants and different varieties of legumes.
Exclude the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilisers.
Increase soil health and productivity for growth of various agricultural crops.
Rehabilitate soil in natural ecosystems.
Contribute to the knowledge of legume and rhizobia diversities in Thailand.

Our immediate goal is to assess the nodulation status of wild legumes growing in the Northern and North-Eastern regions of Thailand. Our project focuses on Thailand for several reasons. Firstly, there are many rural Thai communities that rely on low-input agriculture. Secondly, the country's tropical climate and topographical diversity are likely to harbour various legume and rhizobia species. Finally, thorough research on Thai legumes and their symbiotic partners is generally lacking. Specifically, we aim to:
Collect and preserve nodule samples from wild legume populations
record sample site location and conduct a basic geological research (soil type, soil pH and average rainfall)
Cultivate soil bacteria from nodule samples
Characterise nodule bacteria by DNA sequencing
Re-infect host legumes to authenticate nodule bacteria
Given sufficient funding, we further aim to:
Infect other non-host legumes with isolated nodule bacteria
Assess the nitrogen-fixation efficiency of each legume-rhizobia partners

All samples collected from Thailand will be preserved and brought back to Ghent, Belgium, where laboratory work will commence. We aim to complete data collection within 1.5 months and estimate laboratory work to to be completed within four months. We are a non-profit initiative, and 100% of the funds will be used to conduct research work. Approximately one fifth of the total fund is required for travelling to and from Thailand. The remaining funds will contribute to field-study equipment and laboratory research. DNA sequencing is crucial to this project, and realistically, repeated sequencing may be required for each sample. For this reason, we have included the likely additional costs to sequencing. Any remaining funds will go towards building our website Legumes of Thailand. We kindly ask for your help in order to launch this intriguing scientific research. We are confident of conducting a thorough and exciting research in which we hope will contribute to both the local communities and the scientific world. Our emerging understanding of BNF may enable us to not only optimise agricultural productivity in less-privileged communities, but to improve agriculture in a manner which minimises environmental degradation. We thank you in advance for your contribution to this project, and welcome you to be part of this fascinating study! You can help us launch this project by donating to our INDIEGOGO campaign. Also, please share our project to your friends and family! We hope you will all find our work as exciting as we do!  Because we consider all of our contributors a part of our team, we would be more than delighted to share the findings of this study with all of our backers. Following the completion of this project, we will construct a website: Legumes of Thailand with exclusive access for backers to view the scientific data. To accompany this, we will share our discussions and the significance of the data analyses. Any follow-up study will also be announced on the website. For those who are curious of exactly how this study will be conducted, we will compile a short video for our backers, showing all of our work process, from field work to lab-based research. We also hope that our video will communicate the very real issues of modern agriculture, the environment and the effects they have on community livelihoods. At the same time, we would like everyone to see the precious and huge floral diversity of Thailand through our eyes. Enjoy! Because we will conduct our project in Thailand, some of the funds raised will be allocated to international and domestic travelling costs. A large part of the funds will be used for field-work and laboratory equipment as well as lab-based analyses. Full details of the research budget are outlined here : https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-WuuXHEhNLzb...  Campaign creator, Script, Footage, Plant ScientistStephanie was raised in rural Thailand. Her father's work as an agricultural engineer in less-privileged communities has fueled her interest in plants and their importance to the local people from an early age. Her fascination for legume-rhizobia symbiosis stemmed from her 2015 project which looked at legume and nodule diversity within Eastern England and continental Western Europe populations. Subsequently, Stephanie completed her Plant Science dissertation at the University of Edinburgh which was titled: The occurrence of nodulation and rhizobial diversity in the RBGE, Edinburgh Legume collection. Web Designer, Video Editor, CampaignerHailing from one of Belgium's greatest hidden treasures, Eeklo. Kasper is an experienced self-taught computer professional who loves building web applications. He is responsible for editing the short-documentary and for building the website. Voice Over, Biologist, CampaignerGregory is a talented Medical Biology graduate from the University of Edinburgh. His well-rounded knowledge on modern day issues and strong scientific skills make him an indispensable part of this team. Plant Scientist, CampaignerIain is a budding plant scientist from the University of Edinburgh. His innovative ideas and approach to scientific research is second to none. Iain is particularly interested in the genetics of legume nodulation.",35.0,0,"1 Campaign

•Rural population of 36% total of 19 million people

energy rich

of a typical human life

children, due to their smaller physical size and lung capacity.

into the ocean around Cape Town, South Africa in a single day

sewage outfall in Camps Bay and Green Point, Cape Town are already over their
licensed capacity
•5 billion gallons of waste motor oil is dumped
worldwide every year
•Coastlines
around the world are facing these problems on a daily basis including Sydney,
Barcelona and even New York
BUT NOW....
WE
CAN HELP SOLVE THE PROBLEM!!
WE CAN CREATE:
•A clean energy
SOLUTION using untreated effluent (combined with discard carbon-based feedstock)
•Create
ecologically safe resource advantages, with near ZERO emissions
•Create healthy profits and double your money

•Comply with legislation and help clean the OCEAN, air, stockpiles and all other waste (Discard coal, crop harvest, oil residue, petroleum coke, municipal solid waste, refuse-derived fuel and sewage sludge)
•We can create jobs and help solve poverty in small communities.
THIS SPECIFIC PROJECT:
Will
construct and operate a Waste-to-Energy (#W2E) plant as a proof of concept to
power 10 MW from sewage sludge, untreated effluent and discard
carbon-based feedstock as explained above.
This
plant will be a springboard to replicate similar solutions to more than 800
other potential cleanup opportunities within South Africa alone.
The
technology and cleanup projects can be implemented all over the world where
cities and countries are facing the same issues on a daily basis.

need to raise $11 000 000 for the Clear the ocean project.

breakdown:
Capital
equipment: +/- $9 250 000
Site
preparation cost: +/- $1 000 000
Commissioning
and testing: +/- $250 000
Legal
and compliance: +/- $500 000
THE TEAM
Mr.
Marcus Wiley is the founder, Chairman, and majority owner of TCG Global. Mr.
Wiley is the co-inventor and co-owner of all
patents underlying TCG’s gasification technology. In 2007,
Mr. Wiley constructed a commercial-scale gasifier based on TCG’s gasification technology.
Mr.
Wiley is a registered professional engineer in the state of Colorado, with 40
years of experience in mine engineering, mine
management and technology development. After a successful
career with Consolidation Coal Co., Mr. Wiley started Wiley Engineering, Inc,
in 1981 as a mining consultancy specializing in coal. Well known in litigation
support and mine planning, Mr. Wiley's client list includes
AMAX Coal Sales, Arch Minerals, BNI Coal, Consolidation Coal
Co., Devon Energy, Hartshorne Carbon Co., Inc., Intelligent Energy
Solutions, LLC, Marathon Oil Co., Meridian Minerals Co., MICARE/MIMOSA, Westmoreland
Resources, Inc., Placer Dome America, Public Service Company of Colorado, Public
Service Company of New Mexico, Progress Fuels Corp., Tucson Electric Power, and Western
Energy Co.
In 1998, Mr. Wiley
designed, built and placed in service an IRC Section 29 Synfuel Plant located
outside Charleston, WV. Under his management oversight, the plant ran
successfully for 10 years (1998-2007) and produced nearly 40
million tons of Synfuel with an overall efficiency (plant
availability) of 99%. To further his engineering consulting business, Mr. Wiley
formed Wiley Consulting, LLC in 2002.
As TCG Chairman,
Mark Wiley brings a considerable wealth of project development experience
to bear. During his tenure with Consolidated Coal Company and throughout his 30-year
career as an independent consultant / operator in the coal industry, Mr. Wiley
built and operated eight commercially successful plants.
TCG’s staff has collectively spent decades developing and
maintaining very close relationships with equipment fabricators and major
EPC contractors. TCG has the requisite experience and industry relationships to develop
projects ahead of schedule and under budget:
• The current team
at TCG built the first commercial gasifier (based on TCG technology)
in approximately 12 months, starting in late 2006. Additionally, they successfully
re-deployed the gasifier from Denver to Toledo in early 2008, and had the
system permitted and operational in Toledo in less than 90 days.
• In Q4 of 2011, TCG identified an opportunity to develop
three refined coal facilities, all of which needed to
be completed and certified as operational by December 31, 2011.
Despite an industry standard of 3-6 months of fabrication per refined coal system,
TCG was able to design, fabricate, install and certify three systems in 10 weeks,
and did so at 50% the cost of comparable systems.
Gary Williams
Managing Director: BCompt (Hons)
Gary is the founder of
Titanium VC 1 Ltd, a Venture Capital Company, and
was appointed as Managing Director in May 2015. He is also the founder and
Managing Director of TCG Projects. In 1986 Gary matriculated from Pretoria
Boys’ High School, and having completed National Service in the South
African Defence Force as an Officer in 1 Parachute Battalion, he commenced
his professional career. While serving articles and studying part-time, he
graduated with a Bachelor of Commerce Degree and then Honours Degree by
the time he completed articles with Cassells De Kooker CA (SA). Late 1993
he joined Vodacom as the Chief Accountant: Revenue and three years later
joined the Management Consulting Practice of Deloitte &amp
Touche. With an entrepreneurial inclination, Gary later started his own
specialized Management Consulting Business. Accumulating more than 20
years business experience in local and international markets, across
various industries ranging from small to fortune 500 companies, Gary has a
proven track record demonstrating the ability to successfully manage and deliver
complex business projects.
Melinda Malan
Financial Director: BCom (Hons) (CTA) CA (SA)
Melinda was appointed as the
Financial Director of Titanium VC 1 Ltd, a Venture Capital Company, in May 2015. She was
also appointed as the Financial Director of TCG Projects. Melinda is a
Chartered Accountant of South Africa. She graduated with a Bachelor of
Commerce in 2006 and in 2007 she completed a Certificate in the Theory of
Accounting. Melinda completed her articles at KPMG Inc. in December 2010.
In 2011, Melinda joined Imbalie Beauty Limited in the AltX listing
environment as Financial Director and has over four years’ experience in
corporate finance.
Risks and challenges
Environmental
Risk – None. Instead this project creates a real and sustainable way to reduce
pollution.
Project
Risk - If for some reason the objectives of this project are not met, Capital
equipment can be used for ANY other project in our pipeline that will generate
the same return.
Financial
Risk - Capital raised will only be utilized for a bankable project, therefore the
risks of not generating the expected returns are low.

   Hello everyone I am currently a paramedic student living here in Austin TX and I recently purchased a school bus in an attempt to create a green bus tinyhouse. In doing this I hope to inspire everyone I meet, but I need YOUR help purchasing solar energy materials waste vegetable filtering equipment and a composting toilet.
So basically theses are the things that I need!
<div><ul>
• Solar panels x4
• wiring
• solar controller
• deep cycle batteries x2
• WVO (waste vegetable oil) separator
• WVO tank
• WVO heating system
• composting toilet

I am trying to ""be the change that I want to see in the world"" and I would love for you to be apart of it! If all the funds are not met I will go with the solar energy system first and keep saving till there is enough to fully convert the bus!
Thanks, with love from Jake!

Join the solar energy revolution!
What if you could change the lives of a thousand children? Well, you can. With solar energy, culture and education. Join us to turn this project into reality!

Greenpeace Brazil wants to install solar panels in two public schools. They will be illuminated with clean energy, have discounts on the electricity bill and revert this value to invest in cultural activities for students. More than 1800 students will be benefited from this project!

Solar energy is one of the cleanest ways to generate electricity and Greenpeace Brazil wants thousands of children to be benefited by solar energy. We will install solar panels in the State School Professor Oswaldo Aranha Bandeira de Mello, in São Paulo, and the Municipal School Professor Milton Magalhães Porto, in Uberlândia, Minas Gerais, Brazil.

We want to show that solar energy is a possible way we can trail. Together we can support clean and renewable energy, disseminate knowledge in schools capacitating students with trainings and implementing energetic efficiency measures in schools.

Furthermore, the money economized in electricity bill will be reverted in cultural activities for students. Performing arts, cinema, theater and even travel may be included in the school schedule of these children.
Please collaborate to brighten these children´s smile up! Just click and contribute.
Rewards

Why solar?

Low emissions, low water consumption, no waste, 100% renewable and increasingly affordable… Interested? Here’s what you need to know to go solar.
column5: >Not only are solar panels becoming more affordable, they’re helping create jobs around the country.

column1: Important

Greenpeace Brazil really needs your help, but is important to our mission that we keep independent. We don’t accept donations from companies, governments or political parties. We just accept what each people, like you, can contribute.In case of corporate donation we will do the reversal thereof.
Shipping

Rewards will be shipped by the end of the crowdfunding. As they will be sent by international shipping, it may take between 10 and 20 days to arrive at your home. The cost of the shipping is included in the value of your donation.
If you have any questions please contact us via email relacionamento@greenpeace.org
On average 12% of your donation will be used for administrative spending on IndieGoGo.

Together we can support clean and renewable energy, disseminate knowledge in schools capacitating students with trainings and implementing energetic efficiency measures in schools.

Furthermore, the money economized in electricity bill will be reverted in cultural activities for students. Performing arts, cinema, theater and even travel may be included in the school schedule of these children.
Please collaborate to brighten these children´s smile up! Just click and contribute.
Rewards

Why solar?Low emissions, low water consumption, no waste, 100% renewable and increasingly affordable… Interested? Here’s what you need to know to go solar.Not only are solar panels becoming more affordable, they’re helping create jobs around the country.
Important

Greenpeace Brazil really needs your help, but is important to our mission that we keep independent. We don’t accept donations from companies, governments or political parties. We just accept what each people, like you, can contribute.In case of corporate donation we will do the reversal thereof.
Shipping

Rewards will be shipped by the end of the crowdfunding. As they will be sent by international shipping, it may take between 10 and 20 days to arrive at your home. The cost of the shipping is included in the value of your donation.
If you have any questions please contact us via email relacionamento@greenpeace.org
On average 12% of your donation will be used for administrative spending on IndieGoGo.",3.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","São Paulo, Brazil",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/greenpeace-bring-light-to-the-future-of-children/pica

column1: OUR INVITATION:
We invite you peruse the right side of the screen

at our available perks. We offer locally harvested wild honey from the Big Island of Hawai'i and some great opportunities to help name members of our hives. Your contribution can help save the bees and the future of sustainable food production.

We also strongly invite you to share our story with your friends and community even if you are unable to contribute financially. 

Mahalo. Thank you!

column1: ","THE ISSUE/NEED:Fast forward 5 years into the future: The watermelon at your local grocery store costs over $20. Whoa! How did this happen? With bees at risk of extinction, it may soon be necessary for agricultural crops worldwide to be hand-pollinated, thus significantly driving the up cost of produce. Bee populations in the U.S. mainland have been steadily declining 40-60% each year over the last 6-7 years. Bee loss is happening globally
column2: and there are literally farms of bee populations dissppearing overnight. Some of the problems bees are facing include colony collapse disorder, foul brood, genetic bottlenecking and invasion of Varroa mites and small hive beetles.The future of bees directly impacts the future of humans, with the biggest impact on our food supply.

column1: OUR MISSION:The Gentle Hive Bee Foundation's mission is to protect bees from extinction and return them to thriving by researching and promoting commercial friendly beekeeping techniques that are nonharmful to bees and their environments. Ultimately, we intend to come up with educational guidelines and laws that help implement non-chemical alternatives to commercial beekeeping.  Hawai'i is an optimal environment for beekeeping and research because of the perfect temperatures, abundant fruit and flowers, and limited GMO exposure. Having these elements in place can help control the research environment and focus on what some of the other factors (besides harsh temperatures, lack of variety for bees to eat and GMOs) are causing decline in bee populations.
OUR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES:
Secure funding for research projects in searching
for answers as to why the bee populations are disappearing and how to prevent
extinction.
Conduct research answering questions such as: How can we help to sustain bee life? How do we create a more natural bee hive and environment for sustainability?
Identify the specific challenges threatening the bees.
Implement and promote specific solutions for what we can do as a community to preserve and
grow our declining bee populations.

Assist  both the commercial beekeeping industry, who carries the brunt of the responsibility, and also backyard beekeepers who are the small time warriors in widespread consciousness of the problems at hand.
Provide education and dissimenate information to the public on the findings of this research both online via our website and through written materials.
Train new and existing beekepers in organic beekeeping methods
Help organic beekepers experiencing hive losses by replacing with new hives

OUR IMMEDIATE FUNDING NEEDS:The Gentle Hive Bee Foundation has gained charitable organization status from the State of Hawai'i to move forward as a nonprofit.  The money we raise here will be used to:
Complete the 501c paperwork ($400). This is needed  to receive our non-profit status from the IRS to receive funding
such as grants or donations from individuals and businesses that are tax deductible.
Hire a grant writer ($2600) to identify and write grants that will support our research and education.
Hire a business plan professional ($1200) to synthesize and articulate our ideas and present them to big contributors.
Additional funds will support the infrastructure (e.g., land, supplies, research equipment) and staff $2400 (ongoing necessity)
OUR INVITATION:
We invite you peruse the right side of the screen

at our available perks. We offer locally harvested wild honey from the Big Island of Hawai'i and some great opportunities to help name members of our hives. Your contribution can help save the bees and the future of sustainable food production.We also strongly invite you to share our story with your friends and community even if you are unable to contribute financially. Mahalo. Thank you!Additional reading regarding the plight of bees:http://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2015/09/economist-explains-2http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/13/130510-honeybee-bee-science-european-union-pesticides-colony-collapse-epa-science/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-13/u-s-bee-colonies-continue-to-decline-as-pests-chemicals-blamed",3.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Keaau, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/gentle-hive-bee-foundation/pica

Check it out
I’m raising funds to help cover equipment and transportation costs to
enable a group of young Peruvians to participate in this 19 day
whitewater expedition down the headwaters of the Amazon...before the construction of several major dams kills this river.
Paddling With Purpose
Paddling With Purpose is a project started by Benjamin Webb,
an Aussie environmental engineer. We believe that the Rio Marañon, and
the communities and ecosystems it supports are too important to lose.
This small grass roots effort is working on a series of projects at
local, national and international levels to show why the source of the
Amazon is more valuable in it’s free flowing state than stagnating
behind a series of mega-dams.
I am donating my time and expenses to participate in this project. I
hope that you are also inspired by this effort and will consider a
donation to support Paddling with Purpose and help me save/spread
awareness about the headwaters of the Amazon.
What is it we're going to do exactly?
Throughout our trip we will focus on teaching whitewater safety and
river/camping skills with the aim of making new connections and
partnerships and solidifying/replenishing the old ones for a single, united
purpose. The skills we share will open up new pathways to becoming
professional guides in the future. Our 19 day trip will complete the
Central and Lower Grand Canyon sections of the Rio Marañon.
Our “Training Expedition” is one of two training trips in addition to
the effort called Remando Juntos (translation is Paddling Together).
Remando Juntos is a project based in grassroots advocacy to (re)connect
the people of Peru with the river and show the whole of Peru why these
places are worth saving.
Partners
We have partnered with Conservamos por Naturaleza, Sierra Rios, and a growing list of local and international advocacy groups.
Risks &
• Taking inexperienced people on a long river trip (rapids are mainly Class II and Class III, but there are a few Class IV rapids to navigate.
• There will be communication and teamwork challenges to work through.
• Other normal challenges associated with a long expedition.
• By focusing on whitewater safety techniques and safe river management skills we will be doing the best we can to mitigate challenges of actually being on the water.
Me?
With my fluency and familiarization with the Spanish language and South
American cultures, professional raft guide experience, I am excited to
make a valuable contribution to this important project.
Why should you care about saving the headwaters of the Amazon River?
<ol>
<li>
Important ecosystem corridor
connecting the lush, jungle of the western Amazon with the semi-arid
highlands on the western side of the Cordillera with many undocumented
endemic species of fish, birds, plants, and other animals. The dams will have catastrophic environmental impacts.
<li>Documentation of archaeological and cultural resources, of
which only an estimated 5% of archaeological sites of the Chachapoya peoples have been excavated. Maccu Piccu? There are likely many more sites nearby.
• It is The Main Source of the Amazon!
<li>Thousands of lives will be directly displaced as the result of dams, as
well as hundreds of thousands or more indirectly affected by altering
the natural flow
<li>This isn’t the only river with planned to be dammed in the Amazon
Basin. Many more are planned all around Peru and surrounding countries.
This project is an important step to raise awareness about these plans
and inform people of their widely negative impacts. See Page 3 of this paper.
<li>Growing eco-tourism in the area. The river is in a free flowing state and more people want to see the
‘Grand Canyon of South America’ before it is destroyed. An increased
presence of tourism centered around the river can and will grow the
economy of the region in a sustainable fashion.
This is a once in a lifetime opportunity to experience and document this
river and the culture along it before it is changed forever, and
contribute to the growing stewardship that is necessary for a country
that has done so well with sustainability in the past. If anyone of you
has ever talked with me my about my experiences in South America, you
know that Peru in particular has a place deep in my heart. And this project is well aligned with my personal values of environmental conservation and responsible, human powered recreation.
Many thanks for all your help!!!
-Matt

Other Ways You Can Help

""Like"" and ""Share"" this page on Facebook to get the word out!

‘Grand Canyon of South America’ before it is destroyed. An increased

Mission:
The Palestine Museum of Natural History and its Palestine
Institute of Biodiversity and Sustainability (PIBS) aim to research, educate
about, and conserve our natural world and our Palestinian culture and heritage,
and to use this knowledge to promote responsible, empowered human interactions
with all components of our environment.
1. Explore the diversity of the fauna, flora,
and human ethnography of Palestine via collections and scientific research that
includes morphology and genetics. This includes cataloguing and building a
physical and an electronic database of geological specimens, fossils, and
existing animals and plants, as well as beginning to catalog and preserve
objects/specimens related to natural history and biodiversity, including human
diversity and history.
2. Promote environmental protection and
responsible interaction between people and the environment, by building
environmental awareness and encouraging conservation of natural resources,
while connecting this awareness to Palestinian heritage.
3- Use the knowledge gained, and the books and
databases and collections, to promote science education so that this institute
becomes one that helps all segments of society in areas such as biology,
ecology, technology, archaeology, ethnology etc.
4. Develop and increase respect: a) for
ourselves (self-empowerment), b) for our fellow human beings regardless of
background, and c) for all living creatures and our shared earth. This will
help create a more peaceful and sustainable world.
5.  Use research results in areas such as biodiversity, history,
culture, permaculture and biological control to promote sustainable communities,
focusing on marginalized communities under threat of continued ethnic
cleansing. The aim is to create a more livable world for all living things, including

contending human communities.

Accomplishments since launching (June 2014)
1) Started and developed the museum (PMNH) in
many areas from organization to furnishing, so that it is now an actual
functioning institution and can receive visitors including students,
researchers, volunteers, and community members.
2) Held a science festival that brought
hundreds of school <span>children and volunteers together for activities such
as experiments and discussions on topics
ranging from critical thinking to physics to environmental protection.
3) Published significant research on biodiversity
and initiated several new projects of research, some involving molecular and cytogenetic techniques
examples include “Decline in Vertebrate Biodiversity of Bethlehem,” and papers
on the scorpion Nebo and on amphibians).
4) Worked intensely on our land site to both
reclaim and create an <span>integrated ecosystem of endogenous Palestinian animals
and plants, in an attractive setting..
5) Began to rehabilitate some injured and
abandoned animals, mostly wild (owl, tortoise, Muscovy duck, etc.).
6) Began to develop permaculture and
aquaculture.
7) Began recycling and upcycling waste
material.
8) Expanded our digital library for fauna and flora.
9) Expanded our digital photo collection.
10) Undertook partnership with many
organizations and government entities (e.g. Qattan, Ministry of Agriculture,
and Environmental Quality Authority). Traveled to Europe and developed good
working relationships with dozens of facilities, individual scientists, and
others.
11) Raised some needed funds (all from
individual donations and mostly from Palestinians).
12) Developed a webpage (palestinenature.org),
a facebook page, and a twitter account, and published several articles about
the Museum in major magazines such as “This Week in Palestine,” and in books such
as Museums in Palestine.
13) Carried out over 50 field trips in various
parts of Palestine.  Over forty
volunteers have worked at the Museum in various capacities such as agriculture,
education, research, and conservation.
Partnerships
We
established a Cytogenetics Laboratory at Bethlehem University (affiliated with
the M.S. program in biotechnology and the Biology Department), which does
clinical and other service and research
the Museum now provides direct linkage and collaboration with that
facility.  We have international collaborations with the Jordan University
of Science and Technology (Irbid, Prof. Zuhair Amr), Museum Fur Naturkunde
(Berlin, Dr. Faysal Bibi), Senckenberg Museum, Royal Society for the
Conservation of Nature (Amman, Jordan), Museum of Natural Sciences (Brussels),
Jeunes Palestiniens en Chemin, Syracuse University (Syracuse, New York), and
the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History (Washington, DC).  Locally, we have collaborative arrangements
with the Palestine Museum currently being built on the campus of Birzeit
University, with the Palestine Center for Rapprochement Between People, with
the A.M. Qattan Foundation (focused on education), and with local schools and  other non-governmental organizations. These partnerships
center on education for empowerment, including sustainable living, and
environmental work. Additional partnerships are needed in order to increase our
activities in other high-priority areas, particularly behavioral.
Education and conservation through increased
respect
Principles: The Universal Declaration of Human
Rights (UN 1948) states: “Everyone has the right freely to participate in the
cultural life of the community, to enjoy the arts and to share in scientific
advancement and its benefits.” Various other international conventions have
been promulgated to protect the environment and ensure sustainability of
natural resources. We believe the key to this process lies in human capacity
hence our goal to increase respect:  a) for ourselves (self-empowerment), b) for
our fellow human beings, regardless of background, and c) for all living
creatures and our shared earth.</u> PMNH has embarked on an ambitious program
not only to research and document nature around us but also to conserve and
educate in the spirit of humanity living as part of an integrated balanced
ecosystem.
Education work: We have engaged in
education at all levels in Palestinian society: elementary schools, secondary
schools, undergraduate colleges, graduate schools, and the public at large. We
consider our task as coaches to be facilitation of active learning—rather than “teaching”
or “lecturing.”  We believe in the
Chinese proverb “I hear and I forget, I see and I remember, I do and I
understand.” Thus the museum we are creating is not a site for merely seeing
and hearing about things, but for DOING: that is, active learning.  Drawing
upon our previous activities, we have worked with summer camp students to
increase their appreciation of the wonder of nature and strengthen their inquisitive
minds through such modes as questioning and critical thinking. Since September
2014 we have been working with 8-to-10-year-olds at a local private school, on
a program of natural science exploration. We partnered with the A.M. Qattan
Foundation for the Science Festival, 20-29 November 2014, attended by hundreds
of students. Teachers and students worked together to design exhibits and
interactive modules for activities that help to change attitudes and behaviors
about science and the environment.
Conservation work: Using mostly volunteers
and our limited resources, the Museum has made considerable effort in a short
time—and with many successful examples to show for it. We wrote articles on
decline in biodiversity, and on best practices to protect our fragile environment,
increasingly threatened by climate change, overpopulation, habitat destruction,
colonial settlement activities, and so forth. We built an aviary which helps
rehabilitate injured birds. We took thousands of photographs of the beauty and
richness of the Palestinian environment, using them in education at over twenty
schools and hundreds of community gatherings. We worked with school children
and teachers on projects to increase awareness and carry on activities that
directly improve our environment (e.g. recycling, upcycling, composting,
reducing trash). We are also building an ecological pool on our property, which
will provide a sanctuary for migrating and endogenous birds, amphibians,
insects, and other animals and plants. A greenhouse is in the planning stage,
to propagate medicinal plants, herbal plants, and endangered plant species that
can then be returned to the wild.
Work Projects that need support/partnership
-- Survey of fauna in different parts of the occupied
Palestinian territories, especially marginal and threatened areas such as the
Jordan Valley, the South Hebron Hills, Wadi Qana, and others.
-- Study of impact of human activities in several areas,
particularly pollution, climate change, and habitat destruction.
-- Virtual tour of the museum, with background on Palestine’s
environmental challenges
--  Development and
promotion of aquaculture and permaculture.
--  Educational programs in schools dealing with environment,
critical thinking, sustainability etc.
-- Expansion of basic and applied research programs
with undergraduate and graduate students.
-- Development of museum exhibits that are effective
in changing human behavior.
-- Development of an animal rehabilitation unit.
-- Installation of an informatics system with

interactive computer screens for education and research

volunteers have worked at the Museum in various capacities such as agriculture,
education, research, and conservation.
Partnerships
We
established a Cytogenetics Laboratory at Bethlehem University (affiliated with
the M.S. program in biotechnology and the Biology Department), which does
clinical and other service and research
the Museum now provides direct linkage and collaboration with that
facility.  We have international collaborations with the Jordan University
of Science and Technology (Irbid, Prof. Zuhair Amr), Museum Fur Naturkunde
(Berlin, Dr. Faysal Bibi), Senckenberg Museum, Royal Society for the
Conservation of Nature (Amman, Jordan), Museum of Natural Sciences (Brussels),
Jeunes Palestiniens en Chemin, Syracuse University (Syracuse, New York), and
the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History (Washington, DC).  Locally, we have collaborative arrangements
with the Palestine Museum currently being built on the campus of Birzeit
University, with the Palestine Center for Rapprochement Between People, with
the A.M. Qattan Foundation (focused on education), and with local schools and  other non-governmental organizations. These partnerships
center on education for empowerment, including sustainable living, and
environmental work. Additional partnerships are needed in order to increase our
activities in other high-priority areas, particularly behavioral.
Education and conservation through increased
respect
Principles: The Universal Declaration of Human
Rights (UN 1948) states: “Everyone has the right freely to participate in the
cultural life of the community, to enjoy the arts and to share in scientific
advancement and its benefits.” Various other international conventions have
been promulgated to protect the environment and ensure sustainability of
natural resources. We believe the key to this process lies in human capacity
hence our goal to increase respect:  a) for ourselves (self-empowerment), b) for
our fellow human beings, regardless of background, and c) for all living
creatures and our shared earth. PMNH has embarked on an ambitious program
not only to research and document nature around us but also to conserve and
educate in the spirit of humanity living as part of an integrated balanced
ecosystem.
Education work: We have engaged in
education at all levels in Palestinian society: elementary schools, secondary
schools, undergraduate colleges, graduate schools, and the public at large. We
consider our task as coaches to be facilitation of active learning—rather than “teaching”
or “lecturing.”  We believe in the
Chinese proverb “I hear and I forget, I see and I remember, I do and I
understand.” Thus the museum we are creating is not a site for merely seeing
and hearing about things, but for DOING: that is, active learning.  Drawing
upon our previous activities, we have worked with summer camp students to
increase their appreciation of the wonder of nature and strengthen their inquisitive
minds through such modes as questioning and critical thinking. Since September
2014 we have been working with 8-to-10-year-olds at a local private school, on
a program of natural science exploration. We partnered with the A.M. Qattan
Foundation for the Science Festival, 20-29 November 2014, attended by hundreds
of students. Teachers and students worked together to design exhibits and
interactive modules for activities that help to change attitudes and behaviors
about science and the environment.
Conservation work: Using mostly volunteers
and our limited resources, the Museum has made considerable effort in a short
time—and with many successful examples to show for it. We wrote articles on
decline in biodiversity, and on best practices to protect our fragile environment,
increasingly threatened by climate change, overpopulation, habitat destruction,
colonial settlement activities, and so forth. We built an aviary which helps
rehabilitate injured birds. We took thousands of photographs of the beauty and
richness of the Palestinian environment, using them in education at over twenty
schools and hundreds of community gatherings. We worked with school children
and teachers on projects to increase awareness and carry on activities that
directly improve our environment (e.g. recycling, upcycling, composting,
reducing trash). We are also building an ecological pool on our property, which
will provide a sanctuary for migrating and endogenous birds, amphibians,
insects, and other animals and plants. A greenhouse is in the planning stage,
to propagate medicinal plants, herbal plants, and endangered plant species that
can then be returned to the wild.
Work Projects that need support/partnership
-- Survey of fauna in different parts of the occupied
Palestinian territories, especially marginal and threatened areas such as the
Jordan Valley, the South Hebron Hills, Wadi Qana, and others.
-- Study of impact of human activities in several areas,
particularly pollution, climate change, and habitat destruction.
-- Virtual tour of the museum, with background on Palestine’s
environmental challenges
--  Development and
promotion of aquaculture and permaculture.
--  Educational programs in schools dealing with environment,
critical thinking, sustainability etc.
-- Expansion of basic and applied research programs
with undergraduate and graduate students.
-- Development of museum exhibits that are effective
in changing human behavior.
-- Development of an animal rehabilitation unit.
-- Installation of an informatics system with
interactive computer screens for education and research",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

What would you give to spend the entire summer in Millay's (garden) bed?

By ""Getting in Bed"" with Millay you can...

Rescue Millay's original plants at Steepletop, her historic home.

From 1925 until her death, Millay lovingly guarded and grew the most astounding plants at her historic home known as Steepletop. 

During the 25 years Millay lived on the Upstate New York property, she transformed the rural acres surrounding her home into thirteen spectacular garden ""rooms"" that ultimately inspired her poetry and entertained her friends.
column4:
/>

Yet over time, these wonderful gardens have literally been swallowed up by wicked northeastern winters, and an onslaught of invasive species.

column1:
We are dedicated to preserving Steepletop and Millay's gardens. Our work is guided by historical references in and documentation we have found in Millay's personal journals and letters, poetry and photographs.

This monumental preservation task requires countless hours of work by our staff and volunteers. Each season we struggle to successfully restore what was planted by the famous Poet herself. 

Our immediate focus is on her ""Kitchen Garden"" that provided fresh herbs and vegetables, and a delightful array of flowers.
today and a personalized hand-made wooden garden stake with
your name (or the name of a loved one), will be placed on display in this historic
garden for the entire 2015 Steepletop season
column3:
/>

At the close of tours in October, we will mail you your keepsake garden stake in appreciation for your support. The name as your write it on the donation form is how it will appear on your garden stake. If you would like another name on your stake, please email us info@millay.org.

Short Summary
Welcome to Ingan Tours...
Do you love nature? Want to experience Aboriginal Culture? Are you adventurous?
If so, then please hear our story...

Ingan Tours was created by three family members who identify as Jirrbal Rainforest Aboriginal people.  Dr Ernie Grant (Jirrbal Elder), Sonya Jeffrey (Manager) and Caroline Grant (Senior Tour Guide) had a dream to share their authentic Aboriginal heritage and the ancient knowledge they possess with the world.
Left to Right: Sonya Jeffrey, Dr Ernie Grant, Caroline Grant

column5: >Our traditional lands as Rainforest Aboriginal people sit within beautiful World Heritage Listed Rainforest of Tropical North Queensland, Australia.

column1: <div>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Our culture has survived for over 40,000 years and our connection with the natural environment is interwoven and demonstrated through all of our unique cultural tour experiences.

column1: When on tour with our Aboriginal guides you learn to see the natural environment through our eyes, hear our creation stories and taste our unique bush food.

column5: >Over the past three and a half years our dream has been acknowledged!  It is now time for Ingan Tours to establish a base of operation in order to grow further.
>We urgently require assistance to enable us to continue our unique cultural tour operations and to develop long term employment outcomes for our people.

column1: By supporting our project you will provide invaluable support to local Aboriginal people in employment, continue to foster strong cultural values and most importantly, you ensure that the transmission of our cultural knowledge and customs continue to be passed down to future generations.
Ingan Tour Guide (Tonya Grant) sharing her weaving techniques with a guest...

Ingan Tours has been offered a wonderful opportunity by Queensland Rail to caretake and maintain the historical Tully Railway Station.  Currently the business has been operating from our personal residence.  This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for us to finally give our business a home!

Enjoy a cool drink by the swimming pool...
<b>Kitchen &amp
column6:
>
Tully Kayak Tour
Our Guided kayak tours are a great way to experience adventure in the Cassowary Coast Region at very reasonable rates.  Relax and breath in the beauty of the Bulgan Creek in Tully and paddle your way down stream and see the environment through Indigenous eyes.

column1: Soft Adventure for everyone...
Spirit of the Rainforest Tour

For thousands of years our Ancestors have walked through the rainforest across mountainous regions, creeks and rivers via Aboriginal trading routes.  These trading routes served as an essential resource to sustain life for our people.

Spirit of the Rainforest Tour takes you deep into the mountainous region of the Tully Valley to the beautiful Echo Creek Falls.  Aboriginal guides will interpret the rainforest environment along the walking track and allow you to view the rainforest environment through their eyes.
Night Spotlighting Tour
Mahogany Glider very elusive at night on our spotlighting tours... credits Daryl Dickson wildlife photographer.

column9: >If you require further information, please email, sonya@ingan.com.au

column1: <div>

There are so many challenges facing our people today.  Our people have overcome enormous hurdles to achieve great things for their communities and for Australia.  However, there are still many of our people who are disadvantaged in our country.  Statistically, Aboriginal people have poorer health, less educational opportunities, shorter life expectancy, limited employment options and many live in very remote areas.  Along with these issues, many still have to deal with negative and social attitudes.

One of the major challenges that unfortunately still faces Aboriginal communities today are the negative social attitudes that are still common.  Much has been done recently to create an understanding amongst non-indigenous people about their past and how it still affects them today.  Reconciliation has become important in creating better understanding of Aboriginal culture and building stronger relationships within the whole community.
<div>
Reconciliation - Creating better understanding of Aboriginal Culture...

<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >For Ingan Tours this is a harsh reality and we have worked extremely hard to participate in minimising these issues in the best way possible for our people.  One of the key criteria for our business is to improve and increase employment of local Aboriginal people, in particular our family members.  Just in the community of Tully alone there is a very high percentage of young Aboriginal people without jobs.

column1: We want this project to have a positive impact for the wider community, but, it has to be done right!  Being done right, means putting safety at the fore in the first instance.
Challenges
The only challenge that we foresee is raising sufficient funds to complete the project.
We have the option to apply for funding, however, our federal government has cut Indigenous funding by millions of dollars in recent months and has left Aboriginal communities in crisis.

By supporting our project, you will assist in finding a home for Ingan Tours and ensure ongoing employment for our people.  In recognition of our gratitude for your kind contribution we will include your name on a memorial plaque which will be  proudly displayed  in the Cultural Museum.
