","Short Summary
Welcome to Ingan Tours...
Do you love nature? Want to experience Aboriginal Culture? Are you adventurous?
If so, then please hear our story...

Ingan Tours was created by three family members who identify as Jirrbal Rainforest Aboriginal people.  Dr Ernie Grant (Jirrbal Elder), Sonya Jeffrey (Manager) and Caroline Grant (Senior Tour Guide) had a dream to share their authentic Aboriginal heritage and the ancient knowledge they possess with the world.
Left to Right: Sonya Jeffrey, Dr Ernie Grant, Caroline Grant
Our traditional lands as Rainforest Aboriginal people sit within beautiful World Heritage Listed Rainforest of Tropical North Queensland, Australia.
Our culture has survived for over 40,000 years and our connection with the natural environment is interwoven and demonstrated through all of our unique cultural tour experiences.
When on tour with our Aboriginal guides you learn to see the natural environment through our eyes, hear our creation stories and taste our unique bush food.
Over the past three and a half years our dream has been acknowledged!  It is now time for Ingan Tours to establish a base of operation in order to grow further.
We urgently require assistance to enable us to continue our unique cultural tour operations and to develop long term employment outcomes for our people.

By supporting our project you will provide invaluable support to local Aboriginal people in employment, continue to foster strong cultural values and most importantly, you ensure that the transmission of our cultural knowledge and customs continue to be passed down to future generations.
Ingan Tour Guide (Tonya Grant) sharing her weaving techniques with a guest...

Ingan Tours has been offered a wonderful opportunity by Queensland Rail to caretake and maintain the historical Tully Railway Station.  Currently the business has been operating from our personal residence.  This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for us to finally give our business a home!

Our  continuing dream doesn't just stop with Ingan Tours.  The restoration and beautification programme for the Tully Railway Station will have a very positive impact on our community and for guests visiting the region, either by train or vehicle.
What We Need & What You Get

Have you ever looked at an historical building in your community and wondered what it would look like restored to it's former glory?  Yep, I bet you have, well, this is what Ingan Tours is wishing to achieve - take a heritage  building back to it's former glory and proudly share this with our community and guests and most importantly, finally have a base from which to operate.
To simplify our proposal to you, we have provided a two part program.
Phase One
Restoration of the Tully Railway Station and grounds
Restoration of the Tully Railway Platform (photo below)
A current photo of the Tully Railway Station Platform...
How the Tully Railway Station Platform looked under the care of Dr Ernie Grant...
Phase Two
Your support will allow us to develop some really exciting ideas such as:
Cultural Museum & Aboriginal Art Gallery
Organic Cafe and Organic Fruit & Vegetable Shop
Gift Shop
Front Office/Reception and Tour Information
Staff Facilities
Conference Room
Organic vegetable gardens and orchards
Landscaped Gardens
Cultural Learning workshops to ensure the transmission of cultural knowledge
Learning to weave traditional baskets such as the Jawun (bicorneal weave) is important to our people...as it ensures the transmission of cultural knowledge
To achieve our dream, we have included an estimated cost below:

If we do not achieve our goal of $200,000USD then whatever funds are raised will still be used towards the renovations and refurbishments.  We will continue to improve the Tully Railway Station on limited income, but, this will obviously extend the timeframe to complete the works.To get the ball rolling, we would like to invite our first 10 Contributors to take up this unique opportunity...4 Night/3Day Package - (Free to 1 person) conditions apply

The first 10 people to donate $500USD to our cause will win a 4 Night/3 Day package free of charge (airfares not included) Package applies to 1 person only, extra travelling person will be charged at the rate of $700AUD.
The package comprises 4 nights accommodation at Ingan Eco Lodge, our Bed and Breakfast accommodation set high on a hill,
with spectacular views of the Bulgun Creek area and surrounding mountain
ranges.  One day kayak tour, full day hike on ancient aboriginal trading routes and a chance to spotlight some of North Queensland's marsupials at night.

Package Includes:4 Nights accommodation - Ingan Eco LodgeTully Kayak TourSpirit of the Rainforest TourIngan Spotlighting TourTransfers Ex Cairns, North Queensland, AustraliaSome Meals:  Tropical breakfast for 1 and picnic hamper for 1Ingan Eco LodgeIngan Eco Lodge offers three, luxurious in-house sleeping combinations for your comfort and ease whilst travelling and experiencing the splendour of Tropical North Queensland.

Just a ten minute stroll will take you to Alligators Nest Day Use Area, a beautiful and refreshing swimming hole located in the Tully Gorge National Park.  Take a picnic lunch with you and enjoy a day swimming, sunbathing, reading or exploring the lush tropical rainforest environment surrounds.
Enjoy a cool drink by the swimming pool...

Kitchen & Dining RoomTully Kayak TourOur Guided kayak tours are a great way to experience adventure in the Cassowary Coast Region at very reasonable rates.  Relax and breath in the beauty of the Bulgan Creek in Tully and paddle your way down stream and see the environment through Indigenous eyes.
Soft Adventure for everyone...
Spirit of the Rainforest Tour

For thousands of years our Ancestors have walked through the rainforest across mountainous regions, creeks and rivers via Aboriginal trading routes.  These trading routes served as an essential resource to sustain life for our people.

Spirit of the Rainforest Tour takes you deep into the mountainous region of the Tully Valley to the beautiful Echo Creek Falls.  Aboriginal guides will interpret the rainforest environment along the walking track and allow you to view the rainforest environment through their eyes.
Night Spotlighting Tour
Mahogany Glider very elusive at night on our spotlighting tours... credits Daryl Dickson wildlife photographer.
If you require further information, please email, sonya@ingan.com.au
The Impact

There are so many challenges facing our people today.  Our people have overcome enormous hurdles to achieve great things for their communities and for Australia.  However, there are still many of our people who are disadvantaged in our country.  Statistically, Aboriginal people have poorer health, less educational opportunities, shorter life expectancy, limited employment options and many live in very remote areas.  Along with these issues, many still have to deal with negative and social attitudes.

One of the major challenges that unfortunately still faces Aboriginal communities today are the negative social attitudes that are still common.  Much has been done recently to create an understanding amongst non-indigenous people about their past and how it still affects them today.  Reconciliation has become important in creating better understanding of Aboriginal culture and building stronger relationships within the whole community.
Reconciliation - Creating better understanding of Aboriginal Culture...

For Ingan Tours this is a harsh reality and we have worked extremely hard to participate in minimising these issues in the best way possible for our people.  One of the key criteria for our business is to improve and increase employment of local Aboriginal people, in particular our family members.  Just in the community of Tully alone there is a very high percentage of young Aboriginal people without jobs.

Your support in raising funds for the improvements to the Tully Railway Station are crucial to the plight of improving health, educational opportunities, life expectancy and most importantly, employment options.  Ingan Tours would welcome any support possible, knowing that it gives back to our people and our community in more ways than one.
Students from the American International Universities Program - learning from Dr Ernie Grant (Jirrbal Elder), that there are over 240 different language groups within the land mass of Australia...
Risks & Challenges

As a Tour Operator we are aware of risks and how best to minimise risks within our business.  We provide our staff with in house training and ensure that our policies and procedures align with all levels of government.
At this stage of the project we can only generalise on the type of risks associated with this project:
Washing of Walls and Ceilings
Cleaning walls and ceilings that may contain lead in the old paint
Allergic reaction to cleaning products
Cleaning in a confined space whilst using strong smelling chemicals
Cleaning Gardens & Removal of Rubbish
Allergic reaction to plants
incorrect use of garden tools
Injury from sharp tools (cane knife, chainsaw, whipper snipper)
Injury from lifting heavy objects
Building & Renovations
Removal of building debris
Repair of doors and windows
Painting and decorating
There is no silver lining to achieving this goal.  Unforeseen circumstances may arise, but, we will be ready to manage incidents in a timely and professional manner.

We will work with our staff, family members and volunteers to ensure that we provide a safe working environment and will create a risk management plan upon pre-inspection of the Tully Railway Station.  We will do the following:
Investigate the building site first and identify internal and external risks associated with this project.
Implement a risk management plan.
Rate the level of risk on a scale of 1 through to 10 (1 being a very minor risk and 10 being a very high risk).
Implement safety procedures for each risk identified.
Provide safety induction to participants prior to commencing work on the site.
Ensure that staff holding remote area first aid certificates are on site at all times to supervise and oversee the safety of the participants.
Provide personal protective clothing where required.

If we raise the funds needed to proceed with this project we will minimise a lot of risk through the engagement of locally qualified experts such as builders, plumbers, electricians and other certified suppliers.

A majority of the clean up work will be conducted by Ingan Tours and staff.  This will be on a voluntary basis but management is aware of their legal requirements to ensure a safe working environment and staff are aware of their duty of care to themselves and others when working in any environment.
We want this project to have a positive impact for the wider community, but, it has to be done right!  Being done right, means putting safety at the fore in the first instance.
Challenges
The only challenge that we foresee is raising sufficient funds to complete the project.
We have the option to apply for funding, however, our federal government has cut Indigenous funding by millions of dollars in recent months and has left Aboriginal communities in crisis.

By supporting our project, you will assist in finding a home for Ingan Tours and ensure ongoing employment for our people.  In recognition of our gratitude for your kind contribution we will include your name on a memorial plaque which will be  proudly displayed  in the Cultural Museum.
Other Ways You Can Help
Ingan Tours totally understands that people have limitations in life.  We are just humbled to be given the opportunity for you to hear our story.
Please help us to get the entire world excited and talking about our project!
Like us on Facebook, or forward a link to this campaign to people you think might be interested.
Anything you can do to help us reach a bigger audience, including using the Indiegogo share tools, would be much appreciated.
Thank You

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
<i>Support Joyous &amp

Passionate change agents from across the country are eager to devote their time and energy towards manifesting our shared aspirations. They need YOUR HELP and YOUR INVESTMENT in their training at action camp to equip them with the skills they need to fight for a more equitable and just society.
Why an Action Camp?

The world we long for and deserve is at odds with the unjust society that exists today. We see this injustice in runaway climate change, pollution and violence in our communities, racism and mass-incarceration, warmongering, and an economic system that breeds income insecurity and privileges the few. To pull our world towards equity and justice we need YOUR HELP empowering and supporting activists to take creative, strategic, and courageous principled direct action. Localize This! is a week-long intensive training camp that brings together activists from across multiple issues and movements to share and disseminate insights, lessons learned, and victory stories. The camp may be the closest thing to a college of activism. Localize This! is designed to equip new and veteran organizers with the skills they need to inspire collective action.
Impact of Localize This! Action Camp
<i>What started out as training ground for a community's fight to stop a
transnational corporation's environmental destruction
has turned into an annual celebration (this is our 7th year) of some of the best our movements

for justice have to offer.

Subsequent last year's camp, participants helped organize and deployed the epitome of a successful direct action. Their technical blockade of a oil train for 8 hours earned tons of media and was done in a manner sympathetic to and building alliance with railroad workers. After last year's camp a female activist took their climb training learned at camp and engaged in the first tree sit in Washington state in 14 years. This past year we took the lessons learned from the kayak flotilla during the gravel mine fight and the 6 years of offering kayak trainings at camps and trained 300+ activists to be part of the sHellNo! kayak flotilla's.  Now, kayaktivism is spreading across the globe from Alaska, Finland, Ukraine, to Australia and beyond as a new innovative tactic.
column3:
/>Localize This! is a hub for the cross-pollination of creative strategies and tactics for social transformation. Like dandelions seeds blowing in the wind, what starts at Localize This! sprouts into creative action all year across the country.

Why We Need Your Help

The week-long Localize This! Action camp consistently costs of between $13,000 and $27,000.

Renting the camp is $4,000 and food for participants is $4,000+. Many trainers have to take time off work and travel, so while it's not fair compensation, another $5,000 goes to support them and help in the kitchen. Additionally, there are hard travel and equipment expenses that we simply can't get donated. Our small community supported non-profit with 2-3 staff is already financial overburdened. We offer the camp at a sliding-scale with NO ONE TURNED AWAY FOR LACK OF FUNDS. If camp isn't fully funded the cost comes back to us, pulling finances away from all the other support we offer to communities across the country.

Many participants coming to camp are financially stretched and devote immense amounts of time to organizing. While they want to pitch-in their fair share, every dollar participants pay to camp often means that is time they have to take away from doing the community organizing the camp intends for them to do. There are additional costs to support those traveling from afar and we strive to make the camp accessible to as many people from different walks of life as possible.

If you needed another incentive to support this awesome camp we have some cool perks:

column1: • Rivera Sun's novel ""The Dandelion Insurrection,"" chock full of wisdom from movement leaders throughout history.
• The updated EarthFirst! Direct Action Manual
• T-Shirts from the sHellNo Kayaktivist mobilizations.
Thank you for sharing in our vision and supporting Localize This! Action Camp
Other ways you can help:
<li>
Help us promote this Indiegogo and camp itself. There are many people who would jump at the opportunity if they just knew it existed!
<li>
Host a house party or organize your own community to sponsor an activist to come or support this camp.
• Take bold action in your community. Host a training.

Help Hike the Pipe! Raise Awareness and Inspire Resistance Against the LNG Pipeline and Export Project in Oregon!

This summer, a group of concerned and passionate Oregonians will hike through 232 miles of our beautiful state to protest the Liquified Natural Gas (LNG) pipeline and export terminal that is proposed to cut through Southern Oregon. They will hike along the actual route of the pipeline, documenting their interaction with the individuals, communities, and ecosystems threatened by the project.

Their bold and novel form of activism will show policy makers that Oregon will not tolerate the exploitation of public and private land for private gain. Hike the Pipe! will generate awareness of the LNG issue in Oregon while building solidarity with affected communities, which will allow for more effective resistance to the LNG project.
<div>
Float the Pipe! (June 19-20): Kayaktivists floated the S. Umpqua River to protest the LNG pipeline and promote Hike the Pipe!
What is at Stake?
The Jordan Cove Energy Project is a proposal to construct a 232-mile pipeline through Southern Oregon as well as the West Coast's first Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) export terminal.
This pipeline would:
- clearcut hundreds of miles of forest
- cross more than 400 rivers and streams
- destroy large swaths of habitat for endangered birds and animals
- use eminent domain to take private property from hundreds of landowners
Here are a few facts on the export terminal:
-The powerplant built to support the terminal would become Oregon's largest greenhouse gas emitter
-Annual exports would be 235% what the entire state of Oregon burns annually

Thus, the export project would pollute our state while raising gas prices and increasing our dependence on foreign energy! The Canadian corporation in charge of the project is planning to build an industrial freeway through some of the most wild and scenic parts of Oregon, all to export fracked gas from the Rockies to Asian markets. This project not only poses major harms to communities and ecosystems, but also deepens the Climate Crisis by facilitating the expanded use of dirty fossil fuels.
<div>
<div>
This beautiful Sugar Pine tree is flagged to be cut down to make way for fracked natural gas.
<div>
Why Hike the Pipe?

Many concerned citizens in Oregon have been fighting this pipeline and export terminal for years throughout the permitting process. They have gone to meetings, written comments, lobbied politicians, and tried to make their voice heard in letters to the editor. Much work has been done, but now it is time to escalate our tactics and try more creative approaches.

Hike the Pipe! will allow the activists to develop a personal relationship with the land and landowners affected by the LNG pipeline. The stories they hear will be shared with the statewide audience through a multi-medium blog updated daily. By telling the story of the real lived experience in these communities, Oregonians from across the state will be able to understand the projects full scope, and in turn understand what makes it so controversial. 

Hike the Pipe! will also bring people together in protest and friendship as hikers participate in 4 different town events along the route. There will be one community event in each county directly affected by the project in order to display the broad base of opposition to LNG in Oregon. These events are being planned by members of the community, which will ensure they are organic and candid expressions of the community's story. Please help make this storytelling adventure possible!
Who Are We?

We are a grassroots group of activists hailing from all over the state of Oregon. We have lost faith in our political system's ability to confront important issues such as the Jordan Cove Energy Project, so we are sidestepping the political process to more effectively resist corporate exploitation of our land and resources.
We are not landowners or professional environmentalists
column2: however, we see ample opportunity for average citizens to mobilize and do meaningful political work. We are excited to use this special time in our young lives to do this project in solidarity with affected individuals and communities to make sure we keep the fossil fuel industry out of Oregon. We are not against jobs, nor are we against business
column3: we merely seek to have a more fulfilling discussion about jobs and business, one that has the public interest as its end goal. Such a conversation would help break down some of the barriers between urban and rural communities, allowing us to resist in solidarity against corporate greed and government overreach.

column1: <div>
Around seven hundred Oregonians gathered outside the state Capitol to protest the proposed LNG pipeline and export terminal (May 26).
<div><h3>What We Need &amp
Our fundraising goal is $11,600 to make this project happen safely and effectively. The money breaks down like this:

- $2,750 will go to materials to keep the hikers moving. Food, gas for transportation, gear, cameras, and internet hot spots so that we can make blog posts from the backcountry. This money will also help fund the gas for their support crew, who will be resupplying them every 2-4 days.
- $3,000 will go to an insurance plan to cover the liability of this project.
- $500 in postage/materials to reach out to hundreds of landowners affected by the pipeline.
- $3,000 dollars summer stipend for our main organizer who has a lot of work to do!
- $1,352 for administrative costs associated with our fiscal sponsor and indiegogo.
- $500 will go to printing and distributing promotional posters and brochures.

$11,600 is a large sum of money and we will need your help to ensure we have all the necessary funds to make this project a powerful and effective form of community resistance. We will be blogging, photographing, and taking video along the way so we can bring the rest of Oregon this story! The pressure is on, so please help us out on our adventurous road to protect Oregon from LNG exploitation.

Check out our awesome perks as a way to get some of the No LNG campaign for yourself. A donation of $50 supports exactly one mile of our 232 mile hike. Please pledge to protect a mile of old growth forest!
<div>
Activists and landowners protesting outside a Douglas County Board of Commissioners meeting (May 13)
Other Ways You Can Help
Can't donate? There are other ways you can help.
First, help us share our Indiegogo campaign! Send it to listserves or folks who would be interested, share it on facebook, help us get around the virtual world.

Second, come join us on our trek! If you are a backpacker, you are welcome to come hike with us. If you aren't, we are planning sections of the hike to accommodate those who'd like to march alongside hikers in solidarity. Please contact us at hikethepipe@gmail.com for more detailed updates about our schedule. We would love to see you on our journey!

Finally, if you are a pro photographer or videographer, please come lend us your skills for a day or a week on our trek. Contact hikethepipe@gmail.com, and we will figure out how we can use your skills!

column5: >To learn more check out: http://www.rogueclimate.org/hp_about

The Campaign

If you received an invitation to join this campaign you probably know about Maquipucuna. You have either volunteered there, gone as a student or visited as a tourist. Whatever the circumstances, your visit to Maquipucuna is bound to have had a positive impact in your life (continues after the version in Spanish).

Esta es la página perteneciente a la campaña para ayudar a la Reserva Maquipucuna, en sus 27 años. La reserva, protegida por la fundacion del mismo nombre, es un tesoro natural del Ecuador
column2:
6000 hectáreas de bosque nublado, ya casi único en el país debido al crecimiento urbano que amenaza a esta área. La reserva es parte del corredor ecológico Choco-Andino, que contiene uno de los niveles de bio-diversidad más altos del mundo.

Tu apoyo es vital. Ayuda haciendo una donación, o visita la reserva y promueve el turismo hacia un destino especial.

","The Campaign

If you received an invitation to join this campaign you probably know about Maquipucuna. You have either volunteered there, gone as a student or visited as a tourist. Whatever the circumstances, your visit to Maquipucuna is bound to have had a positive impact in your life (continues after the version in Spanish).---Esta es la página perteneciente a la campaña para ayudar a la Reserva Maquipucuna, en sus 27 años. La reserva, protegida por la fundacion del mismo nombre, es un tesoro natural del Ecuador
column2: 6000 hectáreas de bosque nublado, ya casi único en el país debido al crecimiento urbano que amenaza a esta área. La reserva es parte del corredor ecológico Choco-Andino, que contiene uno de los niveles de bio-diversidad más altos del mundo.Tu apoyo es vital. Ayuda haciendo una donación, o visita la reserva y promueve el turismo hacia un destino especial. Si tienes preguntas acerca de lo que tu puedes hacer por esta parte del patrimonio natural del Ecuador llama, en Quito al (2) 250-7200.---As you know the Maquipucuna Reserve is unique in every sense. 15,000 acres of Tropical Cloud Forest only a 120 minute drive from Quito, Ecuador's capital, with 405 endemic varieties of Orchids, 376 species of birds and over 1900 varieties of plants. Maquipucuna is also home to the Spectacled Bear (featured in the campaign picture).But protecting all these treasures from the encroachment of the ever expanding population takes the work of many people, and this means there is always a need for funding.On Saturday April 13, the Maquipucuna Reserve celebrates 27 years of vision, dedication and hard work on the part of the Maquipucuna Foundation.Today the Maquipucuna Foundation needs your help to continue to protect the reserve. Part of the funds will go to pay for the cost of the rangers so badly needed to ensure that the southern borders of the reserve are not affected by unscrupulous land traffickers.

Harry Schoell  Chairman and CTO of Cyclone Power Technologies, is the inventor of the Cyclone Engine that will power Team Steam USA’s attempt to break the Land Speed Record for steam vehicles. Under Harry’s leadership, Cyclone has received over 29 patents for the Cyclone Engine, the “Invention of the Year” Award from Popular Science, two SAE Tech Awards, and major contracts from Raytheon and the U.S. Army.  Harry is a life-long inventor, who before founding Cyclone, made his mark in the marine design, power and propulsion fields, and was recently named as one of the true “Game Changers” in the industry by Boating Magazine.

Nelson Hoyos is Director of Development and Driver for the Team. Nelson is a two-time NHRA Champion and Turbo Magazine “Driver of the Year”. He has been involved in the development, racing and business aspects of motorsports for over 30 years, and has been instrumental in leading high profile multi-million dollar race teams and marketing programs for the US Navy, Ford and Chevrolet Racing Divisions. As factory driver and engine technologies advisor, Nelson has set numerous drag racing records for Ford, Chevy and set a land speed record at Bonneville in excess of 243 mph for the GM Performance/Chevrolet division. Nelson founded and currently runs the Driven2Win Drag Racing School.  Along with his wife, Marla, they also own and manage Thunder Road Raceway in Gilliam, LA.

Team Steam USA:

The purpose of Team Steam USA is to fund steam powered projects to show the world that it is time for the Green  Clean Rankin Cycle all fuel engines to power more than our electric power plants (that has been for the last 100 years). Cyclone has taken this technology and made small power plants to be used in everything from a weed eater to 18 wheelers.  The $125,0000 will go to buying safety equipment and to get to race an Bonneville Salt Flats.

The Car
Based on the ground breaking designs of the George Poteet and Ron Main Bonneville-proven streamliner , Speed Demon, the Cyclone vehicle will feature state-of-the-art technology and unmatched aerodynamics.  The body is approximately 25’ long, 33” wide and 34” high (not including tail). The vehicle will have a drag coefficient (Cd) of an amazing 0.08.
  The Engine

Environmentally friendly, the  Cyclone Engine is a compact,  heat regenerative, external combustion engine that has been developed to achieve high thermal efficiencies and power-to-weight ratio. The engine, invented by Harry Schoell, operates on a Schoell cycle, and uses multiple heat recapturing processes off its cylinders, exhaust manifold and condenser to achieve thermal efficiencies over 30%.

The Cyclone Engine uses water as both its working fluid and lubricant, and can operate at super-critical pressures and temperatures, which results in greater power output relative to its size. The Cyclone is capable of running on virtually any liquid or gaseous fuel, including 100% biofuels and combusts these fuels much cleaner than an internal combustion engine.
The 6-cylinder, radial-format Cyclone Engine weighs only 250lbs (with combustion chamber), produces 100hp @ 3600rpm, and generates an impressive 850lbs-ft of torque at starting. With this power, no transmission is needed, ultimately making commercial vehicles lighter and cheaper.

• Please share on your favorite social media

The engine, invented by Harry Schoell, operates on a Schoell cycle, and uses multiple heat recapturing processes off its cylinders, exhaust manifold and condenser to achieve thermal efficiencies over 30%.The Cyclone Engine uses water as both its working fluid and lubricant, and can operate at super-critical pressures and temperatures, which results in greater power output relative to its size. The Cyclone is capable of running on virtually any liquid or gaseous fuel, including 100% biofuels and combusts these fuels much cleaner than an internal combustion engine. The 6-cylinder, radial-format Cyclone Engine weighs only 250lbs (with combustion chamber), produces 100hp @ 3600rpm, and generates an impressive 850lbs-ft of torque at starting. With this power, no transmission is needed, ultimately making commercial vehicles lighter and cheaper.
Please share on your favorite social media",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

<div>

Blued Trees is an eco-art project to save beautiful places endangered by pipelines and related fossil fuel infrastructure by deliberately installing art installations in corridors projected for gas pipelines expansion.

It uses an innovative, creative legal approach, leveraging copyright and property law to protect art embedded in forests and soils—while simultaneously restoring control of beloved spaces and personal property to individuals living in harm’s way. Since June 21, 2014, several miles of art have been installed.

We need your support now to fight this legal battle against the powerful and wealthy Spectra corporation, which plans to install a pipeline it calls “Algonquin,” grossly misusing the name of Native American tribe even as it readies to destroy thousands of acres of Nature’s gifts.!

Eco-artist Aviva Rahmani has filed Federal copyright on the ""Blued Trees"" art installation that encompasses trees and forests on private lands threatened with  ""condemnation"" via eminent domain to enrich fossil fuel corporations.

Legal advisers have suggested that it could take years — and millions of dollars — to bring this suit all the way to the Supreme Court of the United States and internationally. The ideas are already capturing the imagination of threatened communities and activists around the globe.

Right now we need to raise $12,000 for the first stage of legal filings and actions. We filed a cease-and-desist order against Algonquin Spectra September 30, 2015, but do not expect the fossil-fuel corporation to comply. Our team of attorneys are integrating copyright, and real estate/property eminent domain strategy. The PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION (cease and desist demand) was filed in New York before October 1, 2015, the scheduled date Spectra corporation had designated to destroy the art, and the habitat to install the Algonquin pipeline.

Won’t YOU join this innovative campaign? 

Aviva Rahmani, the ecological artist who created ""Blued Trees,"" has received much moral support for this project. She has spent thousands of dollars of her own money to bring it to this point, but she needs help from everyone who cares about nature, beauty, community and property rights to carry on the fight.
Please give as generously as you possibly can, and share this plea with everyone you know!
<div>
Aviva Rahmani, the ecological artist who created ""Blued Trees,"" is recognized as a pioneer in the genre, with an extensive international exhibition and publication record (www.Ghostnets.com).
Read more: http://pushingrocks.blogspot.com/2015/09/blued-trees-fact-sheet.html
Read an interview with the artist: http://hyperallergic.com/235429/using-art-to-stop-a-pipeline/
Locate Greek Chorus sites: http://www.gulftogulf.org/project_item/blued_trees/
Learn how you can join the copyrighted action and be part of the Blued Trees Greek Chorus:http://pushingrocks.blogspot.com/2015/06/greek-chorus-for-blued-trees.html

What is CoCo?

CoCo is a unique composting solution - we collect food waste in addition to providing a sustainable, local delivery service. We provide members clean bins every week which we use to integrate the delivery of local goods from our community partners.  

Compost Colorado is providing innovative and accessible ways to bolster environmentalism in the Denver Metropolitan area. We create the opportunity to lead by example and inspire others to adopt more sustainably centered mindsets. 

We want to make sustainability mainstream across Colorado in the most efficient way possible. 

 

Why Compost?

Climate change poses a real threat to life as we know it and it’s time for all hands on deck—we all have a part to play. Food waste is the number one material sent to landfills contributing to 20 percent of greenhouse gas emissions. Composting food waste minimizes greenhouse gases, reduces reliance on landfills and leads to nutrient rich, organic soil. 

Many progressive countries and cities across the world have enforced compost mandates in their communities to counteract climate change. It’s time for Coloradans to rise to the occasion and help protect the environment.

In order to make compost mainstream in Colorado, we have integrated our business with all aspects of Colorado lifestyle and culture. We support local food, art, music, nature and activism around the state. 

Supporting local, small businesses is another easy way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the best way to invest in the community. We make composting mainstream by making it convenient, affordable and engaging - it’s the CoCo mission. 

 

What we need

We have a lot of ground to cover across the front range and compost is heavy. As is, this means we are reliant upon fossil fuels to get the job done. Excessively using fossil fuels is one of the most damaging things you can do to the planet. This completely goes against the spirit of CoCo. 

Fortunately, we’ve figured out the perfect solution to our problem - a biodiesel truck. Biodiesel is a clean-burning alternative renewable fuel produced from vegetable oils (such as soybean oils) and yellow grease (recycled cooking oil from restaurants). Our goal is to invest into a Ford F-350, 7.3 Liter diesel truck.

CoCo is a startup. The costs associated with purchasing a biodiesel truck are a bit (okay, a lot) out of our budget for the business as it stands. Until now, most of the financing for CoCo has come out of pocket. The majority of work being put in by the CoCo team has been driven by none-other than a passion for creating a greener Colorado and reducing the effects of climate change the best way we know how.

 

Our Services

The city of Denver collects compost alongside waste and recycling BUT this service isn’t available for apartment dwellers or businesses. In Lakewood, Arvada, Englewood, Edgewater, Westminster and Littleton there are no municipality led composting services.

Compost Colorado picks up where these places leave off by collecting compost from homes and businesses all over the Denver-metro area and making environmental friendliness way easier, accessible and inclusive. 

Our composting services for businesses include office spaces, coffee shops, restaurants, and large commercial spaces. To have a more integrated approach to a sustainable lifestyle in Colorado, we offer the following additional services: Event Consultation, Green Training/Consultation, Zero-Waste Education for Schools, and Soil Delivery.
column2:
/>

 

Our Radius

Currently, CoCo serves Denver, Arvada, Lakewood, Broomfield, Wheatridge, Westminster, Edgewater, Englewood and Littleton. Our goal is to expand across the Front Range by 2020 and one day throughout all of Colorado. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Risks &
column3:
Challenges

We have already begun to reach out to truck dealerships looking for a match. Because older model Fords and GM trucks tend to run better on biodiesel fuel, it may take us several weeks before finding a compatible truck that is still in good shape. After purchasing a truck it will also take us a few weeks modifying it for our purposes.

 

Other Ways to Help

We empathize with your financial limitations. If you care about our cause and helping fight climate change, help us and spread the word by sharing this on social media, telling your family and friends, and shouting it out from the top of a mountain! We appreciate any and all support!!!

What we're about...

Jack's Solar Garden will be a one-of-a-kind community solar garden located in Boulder County, Colorado. We're a family-owned social enterprise that won the opportunity from Xcel Energy to build a 1.2 MW solar array on our farm to help make our land profitable once again. We’re collaborating with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Colorado State University, and the University of Arizona who will study crop and vegetation growth underneath and around our future solar panels. We will establish a large pollinator habitat of thick perennial bushes and trees around the outside of the solar array to provide forage for local bees. We plan to donate at least 2% of our electricity (enough for ~10 homes) to low-income households in Boulder County. We will offer educational tours for school kids and our community to get folks to learn more about the food and energy nexus. Plus, we want to work with the local arts community to showcase artist's work within the solar array via an artist in residence program.
Who we are ...

My grandfather, Jack, purchased my family's farm in 1972 to farm hay and alfalfa in his retirement. After my grandfather and grandmother passed away, the farm was transferred to my mother who owns the farm today. Jack's Solar Garden came about as a means to make our farm profitable as decreasing hay and alfalfa yields have made our current farming practices uneconomical.

My father and I are the sole owners of Jack's Solar Garden. We do not want to take investor funds to develop our solar garden, instead we're looking for community buy-in through subscriptions to our solar garden to make our idea financially feasible. Further, we started this crowdfunding campaign to find like-minded individuals unable to subscribe inside or outside our community that want to see our farm succeed by supporting us in this early stage to ensure we can build our solar garden this year. All your contributions will go towards Jack's Solar Garden donating an equivalent amount of our solar production as bill credits to a local non-profit organization(s).
Owners Bios:

Byron Kominek holds a B.Sc. in Biomedical Engineering and a M.Sc. in Environmental Engineering. He has worked for over 12 years in international development including work as a Peace Corps volunteer, a water and sanitation expert for Doctors Without Borders, and a diplomat with the U.S. Agency for International Development. He has spent 6 years in various parts of Africa working on natural resource management projects. He also speaks French and Portuguese.

Kurt Kominek holds a M.Sc in Systems Engineering and a Ph.D. in Chemical Engineering. He has about 20 years of working experience as an engineer and project manager and over 20 years of experience teaching computer science as a professor at Northeast State Technical Community College in Tennessee. Further, he has been a Boy Scout Scoutmaster for almost 40 years.
<h3>What We Need &amp

To build Jack's Solar Garden outright, we need $2 million for construction and upfront costs. Along with this crowdfunding campaign, we are actively seeking subscriber buy-in from local governments, companies, and residents in and around Boulder County. Long-term operations and maintenance of the solar garden will be supported via the sale of Renewable Energy Credits to Xcel Energy. Revenue generated from our social enterprise will support my family in maintaining Jack's Solar Garden over the following 20 years, which includes funds for unexpected damage to the system from hail, fire, or other calamities, AND help us start up new agricultural activities around the farm (e.g., caring for sheep, alpaca, turkeys, etc., expanding our apple orchard, improving our beekeeping venture).

We're looking to raise $30,000 through crowdfunding. This funding will help Jack's Solar Garden continue reaching out to community members to sign up as subscribers to ensure our community solar garden comes to fruition.
PLUS, once we reach this $30k mark, we'll donate ~5.7kW of power to a local Boulder County nonprofit organization(s) for a 20 year term!
If somehow we get more than $30k, we'll continue to donate power to local nonprofits at a rate of 380W for every $2,000 over our target.
For your contribution, not only do you get the satisfaction of supporting BOTH an innovative community solar garden initiative AND nonprofit organization by getting free power from us...
You'll be able to get the perks seen on the right side of your screen!
The Impact

By supporting Jack’s Solar Garden, YOU will put clean energy into OUR grid. YOU will kickstart a one-of-a-kind research site operated by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory and Colorado State University. YOU will teach children that food and energy can be farmed together. YOU will showcase Boulder County art, plant a habitat where local bees can forage, and freely share electricity with OUR neighbors in need.
<h3>Risks &amp
With any project, there are risks and challenges. We've simply already bypassed most of ours! We're down to our last major challenges. The last is the most challenging of the bunch...

1) Boulder County's Planning Commission (who voted 8-0 in favor on May 15th!) and County Commissioners (who will vote on June 13th) must vote in favor of Jack's Solar Garden for us to see our project come to fruition. Their votes are a part of Boulder County's Special Land Use Review coordinated via the County's Land Use Department. The respective dates of the County's hearings where votes will be cast for or against Jack's Solar Garden are May 15th and June 13th.

To us, it is unlikely that Boulder County's Commissioners will vote against Jack's Solar Garden as we have been working closely with the Land Use Department for the past year to ensure we are in compliance with their regulations and are promoting the ideals of the County through our project.

2) A Boulder County Building Permit must be received to commence with construction. It is very likely we will be able to easily receive this permit as our selected contractor, Namaste Solar, has worked on Boulder County permitting in the past and will know how best to quickly receive this building permit.

3) Xcel Energy must interconnect Jack's Solar Garden into their electrical grid. As we already won a bid from Xcel Energy to do this interconnection, the main aspects to achieve this objective are ensuring that our engineering specifications are in accordance with Xcel Energy's electrical grid needs. Again, as Namaste Solar has worked on solar gardens in Xcel Energy's network before, this may be a small challenge but unlikely to be much of a risk.

4) The MAIN risk / challenge Jack's Solar Garden has is ensuring we have enough subscribers signed up this summer to feel confident that we can begin construction at a time where we'll be able to sell out our subscriptions by the time construction is completed. We have calculated that we need 50% of our solar array subscriptions sold before we hit this level of confidence to ensure Jack's Solar Garden will happen. YOU can help with this by funding THIS project. YOUR donation will add up and provide free electricity bill credits to a non-profit organization in Boulder County. The donation YOU are about to make to us matters to us. So thanks!

What is Take Care?

At a young age we are taught to take care of the things we love. The same goes for the places we love. With just a little more effort we can all help take care of our extraordinary natural treasure.

Take Care was created by a team of designers, filmmakers and stand-up comedians who wanted to reimagine the way we encourage folks to look after our environment. Skip straws. Use a trash can. Pick up after your pet. See? Easy!

How does it work?

Take Care is 100% community-driven. It is designed for everyone to get involved — from individuals to organizations.

You can volunteer to distribute Take Care messages, help recruit partners, or chip in to the cause. Donations of any size will help us produce materials for use from shore to shore to shore to shore.

Organizations can join us as distribution partners or sponsor some of our bigger initiatives like cigarette butt collectors, water bottle filling stations and developing a community-resource website.

Why do we need your support?

Your help will enable us to launch the campaign with the organizations on the Cape that have joined our collaborative. We'll start by updating the existing messages for Cape Cod. Then, we will print signs, flags, and all the materials our partners need to spread the message. And finally, we will outfit street teams in each town with a complete Take Care kit for outdoor events and beach days.

Localize Take Care
• Create messages specific to Cape Cod
• Design new animal characters
Make all the materials
• Print eco-friendly stickers, signs, flags, boat bags and t-shirts
• Develop a community-resource website for the campaign
Launch!
<li>Distribute signs for partners to hang in parks, shops, beaches, trails &amp
• Outfit street team volunteers with complete beach-ready kits

Who is behind this?

Take Care was established in 2014 by a group of more than 30 organizations from Lake Tahoe, CA who wanted to see more people connecting with their beautiful natural environment. Inspired by their success, CARE for the Cape &
column2:
Islands, Center for Coastal Studies and the Cape Cod Anti-Litter Coalition joined forces to bring together over 60 organizations from Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket to discuss how they could protect the places they love.

From this meeting of environmental nonprofits, municipalities, chambers of commerce and local businesses, the Cape Cod Stewardship Collaborative was born to bring Take Care to the East Coast.

 

Media coverage

Cape Cod Times: Meeting tackles litter, pollution on Cape and Islands (Mar. 3, 2019)

Cape Cod Times: Cape group launches anti-littering campaign (June 12, 2019)

The Barnstable Patriot: CARE to launch environmental stewardship campaign in Hyannis (June 12, 2019)

Cape Cod Times: New Capewide campaign aims to reduce litter, waste (June 20, 2019)

 

Our partner organizations

350.org

column24: CARE for the Cape and Islands
column67: Waquoit Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve

Yarmouth Recycling and Solid Waste Advisory Committee

 

Our creative team

BRONTOSAURUS!

And finally, we will outfit street teams in each town with a complete Take Care kit for outdoor events and beach days.Localize Take Care
Create messages specific to Cape Cod
Design new animal characters
Make all the materials
Print eco-friendly stickers, signs, flags, boat bags and t-shirts
Develop a community-resource website for the campaign
Launch!
Distribute signs for partners to hang in parks, shops, beaches, trails & town centers
Outfit street team volunteers with complete beach-ready kits

Who is behind this?Take Care was established in 2014 by a group of more than 30 organizations from Lake Tahoe, CA who wanted to see more people connecting with their beautiful natural environment. Inspired by their success, CARE for the Cape & Islands, Center for Coastal Studies and the Cape Cod Anti-Litter Coalition joined forces to bring together over 60 organizations from Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket to discuss how they could protect the places they love.From this meeting of environmental nonprofits, municipalities, chambers of commerce and local businesses, the Cape Cod Stewardship Collaborative was born to bring Take Care to the East Coast. Media coverageCape Cod Times: Meeting tackles litter, pollution on Cape and Islands (Mar. 3, 2019)Cape Cod Times: Cape group launches anti-littering campaign (June 12, 2019)The Barnstable Patriot: CARE to launch environmental stewardship campaign in Hyannis (June 12, 2019)Cape Cod Times: New Capewide campaign aims to reduce litter, waste (June 20, 2019) Our partner organizations350.org

column23: CARE for the Cape and Islands
column65: Waquoit Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve
column72: Yarmouth Recycling and Solid Waste Advisory Committee Our creative teamBRONTOSAURUS!

Our story

We are Sari, Mareike and Paul, a team of ocean lovers and conservation experts that developed this idea at a marine conservation hackathon and proceeded to win a small amount of prize money. We used this money to do some field tests on willingness to pay for tourists and explored the application needed for this in more detail. We are now ready and informed fully to develop the app and launch it in the marine tourism and conservation sector.
<h3>What We Need &amp
<ul>
• We need  25 000 USD towards the development of  the prototype of the application and its associated financial functions in order to get a proof of concept in the field.
• For individuals donations of 500 USD or over you will get your name on our website and for companies with donations of 1000 USD or over you will get your logo as a sponsor on our website.
• Donations of 100 USD or over will get a digital marine life photograph and a personal thank you note.

• After the application is ready we can start implementing in the field and we will send all donors over 50 USD success stories of marine life numbers and community benefits one year after the application is launched so you can stay tuned and really see what wonderful impact your donation had.
The Impact

We and our many colleagues working in the biodiversity and marine conservation sectors believe this innovation is a game changing idea, especially in the developing country context where coastal communities lack incentives to protect marine life. Science has demonstrated that number one factor in successful marine protected areas is stakeholder buy in. This is what Ocean Eye is working at. It will enable a direct and transparent payment from tourists to the community and provide them an incentive to protect sharks, turtles, manta rays, dolphins and many other marine animals instead of killing them for short term cash.

As an example, shark fin is priced at 600 USD a kilo, a real example of shark sightings at a dive operation in Papua, Indonesia showed that if one shark sighting by divers was priced at 50cents, the local community would have received 4653 USD over one year as direct payment. Creating a real financial incentive to control shark fishing in the community.

It will also empower the tourists and the marine recreation sector to be part of the solution and provide a tangible benefit to the communities in the area they visit. In addition this app can provide much needed citizen's science that can further improve the conservation of these species.
<h3>Risks &amp

We are engaging an experienced tech company that has also worked with community interphases to do our app to ensure it will work well in various community and tourism situations and provide flexible enough functions to tailor the species and prices i.e. high end tourists vs budget destinations and to be able to adjust the species according to local issues and biodiversity.
The app has big potential to scale as it does not need ongoing NGO support or funding. The tourism sector can adopt it themselves to use in their areas to help achieve conservation outcomes.

There is always a risk involved when working with communities in conservation and we are consulting broadly with groups and experts in marine conservation and community work that will help us establish guidelines and best practices to ensure the best long-term environmental and social impacts.
Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread this campaign and the need for urgent action to halt biodiversity decline in our oceans. We have no time to waste. Join our mailing list on https://oceaneye.io  for more updates. Thank you!

JOIN US ON OUR VOYAGE - AND LET'S SEE WHAT WE CAN DISCOVER TOGETHER ...

Arctic Mission is asking for YOUR support to fund (and share with your friends on your social media) our work exploring, discovering and revealing the AMAZING ecosystem and wildlife 'up there', upon which we depend more than many of us realise.

Wildlife?! Seriously? Up there? Yes, orca aka (killer whale), all-white beluga whale, dark-skinned polar bear, bearded seal, narwhal (the original unicorn), Greenland shark (that live to 450 years old), King Eider (once producers of eider-down for bedding), and Arctic cod, and that's just the more famous ones. Marine animals go right down in size from the fish and squid to the single-cell plant life-forms which create 50% of our atmosphere's oxygen!

And why the urgency to think about protection? Because we are now all faced with a stark choice:

Protect all this wildlife ASAP ... Or They May Soon Be Lost to Us, Accidentally-on Purpose!

Even this summer commercial fishing fleets may start exploiting this area for money, and governments for power.

To advance scientific understanding of these possible threats to the region, and start a global public awareness campaign about the issues, British polar explorer, Pen Hadow, is setting sail this summer on a pioneering voyage towards the North Pole
column2:
and he and his team would like YOUR help to make this ambitious voyage as successful as possible.

Changes in the Arctic's climate and ocean have recently caused a massive loss of summer sea-ice cover, leaving the region's wildlife (once protected by the natural barrier created by the sea ice) now vulnerable to exploitation (commercial fishing), disruption (commercial shipping and tourism) and pollution (fishing, shipping and mining).

As many polar species are exceptionally slow to reproduce, grow and mature (e.g. the Greenland shark may not reach breeding age until its 250 years old), the North Pole's wildlife is at much higher risk of long-term damage than most other marine ecosystems.

A VOYAGE TO PROTECT ALL OUR FUTURES 

Known as Arctic Mission, in early August (2017), Pen and his specialist team will embark on their 3,500-mile voyage of exploration, explanation and protection - hopefully with YOU virtually onboard with us.

For six weeks we’ll be far out to sea, surveying the unexplored international waters of the Central Arctic Ocean around the North Pole. In so doing we may reach further North than any previous vessel under sail.

In our two 50-foot yachts we will be demonstrating to a global audience just how much open water there already is up there, where there used to be only sea ice. Up to 40% has been open water in recent summers (i.e. almost no sea ice), and it may be 50-60% ice-free this summer, looking at this year's satellite images. And if we can sail about in our small yachts, imagine what damage the much bigger, stronger commercial fishing vessels could do any time soon.

The other part of Arctic Mission's work is to reveal just how abundant the marine life is around the North Pole. We all know about the polar bears, and maybe the seals, but did you know about the zooplankton (animals that drift with the ocean currents) and phytoplankton (plants that drift ...), and then there's the extraordinary Arctic fox (that scavenges for polar bear kills hundreds of miles out to sea, but can't swim)?

And don't even get Pen started on marine microbes, of which up to x1,000,000 individuals live in every cubic millimetre of seawater - and between them they release more oxygen than rain-forests into the atmosphere - in fact half the oxygen in every breathe you take is produced by these tiny guys!

 

SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH IN UNEXPLORED WATERS

While breaking sailing records can make the news headlines, the main purpose of the expedition is far more important: to undertake the urgent and essential scientific research and information gathering that policy-makers MUST have, so that they can work out how best to protect this ecosystem. The region being so unexplored is therefore a problem! No one knows enough about it to know how best to protect it!

So our voyage's scientific work will be focused on:

column1: • Showing how melting sea ice is exposing vulnerable marine life to the immediate threat of irreversible exploitation and destruction.
• Communicating with the public in real time to promote the function and value of the Arctic Ocean’s unique ecosystem.
• Recording as many forms of marine life as possible including polar bear, whale, and seal, shark, birds, other fish, zooplankton, phytoplankton and those awesome microbes!
• Studying the characteristics of the ocean’s waters looking at sea-ice cover, temperature, salinity, currents and nutrients ... and taking air, ice and water samples for pollutant analysis.

PEN HADOW - OUR EXPEDITION LEADER

Pen Hadow, one of Britain’s foremost explorers, has been launching expeditions onto the Arctic's sea ice for more than 25 years. What started out as a series of fear-conquering adventures swiftly evolved into a pioneering polar guide service, which included organising the first all-woman expedition to the North Pole (1997). Most recently his work led to the running of a programme of scientific exploration across the Arctic Ocean. And all of this has now led to him embarking on his rest-of-life mission: to protect the North Pole's now-vulnerable wildlife . 

Previously, Pen led the £6.5m multi award-winning, international research programme, Catlin Arctic Survey (2008-2012) investigating the rates, causes and impacts of the Arctic Ocean’s rapidly melting sea ice. These Surveys secured £90m worth of news coverage worldwide about the issues relating to sea-ice loss and included TV documentaries on CNN, BBC and Channel 4.

Pen is the first person ever to have made it solo, without resupply, from Canada to the North Geographic Pole (2003) - a feat that has never been repeated
column2:
and is the first Briton to have reached both the North and South Geographic Poles (without resupply) from their respective continental coastlines.

He has written books, including the best-seller, Solo: Alone &
column3: Unsupported to the North Pole (Michael Joseph/Penguin)
column4: self-filmed, The Hardest Way to the North Pole (TV documentary, National Geographic)
column5: presented a literary series on BBC Radio 4 around Jules Vernon's works
column6:
and contributed to numerous TV documentaries and books about adventure and exploration.

He is patron of the Royal Scottish Geographical Society, British Exploring, and the Scientific Exploration Society, and has Honorary Doctorates from the University of Exeter (Laws) and University of Plymouth (Science).

ARCTIC MISSION'S EXPEDITION TEAM

Joining Pen Hadow onboard the expedition are:

Scientist - Tim Gordon

Doctor - Nick Carter

Journalist - Laura Hampton

Photographer - Conor McDonnell

Film-maker - Tegid Cartwright

Skippers &
column7: mates - Erik de Jong, Krystina Scheller, Frances Brann &amp
column8:
Jaap van Rijckevorsel

SO WHY GET INVOLVED?

As you can begin to see, Arctic Mission is not a small undertaking. The expedition is ambitious, hazardous and expensive, but Pen and his team see the greater purpose of their work and believe that it's necessary to maximise the possibility of the best protection for the North Pole's wildlife. 

We’re looking to raise £25,000 through the awesome things we have for sale in the PERKS section on this Indiegogo site. All the money raised here will go towards the delivery of the expedition and the projects it supports (e.g. school resources). The expedition's costs include:

column1: • Yacht charter
• Medical and yacht insurance
• Scientific research
• Professional fees
<li>Foods &amp
• Travel arrangements
<li>Equipment &amp
• Medical resources
• Satellite communications
• Specialist equipment
• London HQ support

ARCTIC MISSION IS ONLY THE BEGINNING

Arctic Mission is the first and essential initiative in Pen’s broader plan to protect permanently the waters around the North Pole from commercial fishing, shipping and mineral extraction. Something he can do with your help.

THANK YOU

Whatever you'd like to contribute to this Arctic Mission will be gratefully received by Pen and his team. And don't forget, you can also support our work by sharing this page across your own social platforms. Nice one!

column1: Who are we and why are we doing this?

We are a group of 7 people that started working towards a shared goal: to create a more sustainable and democratic society. We founded La Fábrica to democratize access to tools and new technologies and empower Uruguay's creative community. Our first objective is to set up a plastic recycling hub in our space, using open source machines created by Dutch designer Dave Hakkens (Precious Plastic).
What We Need
These are the plastic recycling machines we are building:
<ol>
• An Extrusion machine to produce raw material (filaments for a 3D printer)
• A Shredder to shred the plastic into small parts
• An Injection machine to inject heated plastic into molds
• A compression machine to compress plastic into molds

We already have some parts, but we need your help to get the rest and hire a welder to put it all together. In addition, we want to buy a 3D printer to create more detailed products from the plastic we extrude.
Here's a breakdown of our budget:
What you get
We have some neat perks for our backers!
Including:
A Limited Edition T-shirt

Get a special offer on this fantastic t-shirt. Help us melt plastic and get it off our streets and oceans! You'd be surprised at the kind of things our robot can make with this abundant resource. Big thanks to Luis Ramirez for the design.
Get a surprise product made with recycled plastic!

Let us surprise you with a product made with our machines! We want to give plastic a second life and we want you to see the results. We'll ship the product to your door and send you a lovely handwritten thank you letter as well as a goodie pack.
Our maker in residence program
Made especially for makers that like to travel, we're offering a unique opportunity to experience life in beautiful Montevideo and work in our space for a week! You get:
<ul>
• 1 week of room and board in Montevideo (Airbnb style)
• A free workplace with an internet connection and access to our plastic recycling machines
• The possibility to offer workshops and share your skills in our space (make a little extra cash)
• A personalized La Fábrica canvas bag for your travels (see below)
• A complete La Fábrica mate kit to get a full taste of this Uruguayan staple (see below)
<h3>An Album by the Uruguayan band <a href=""https://diegopezylospernoctantes.bandcamp.com/releases"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">Diego Pez &amp

Thanks to Diego and his band for donating 5 albums to our cause! You can now get a CD shipped to your door and enjoy original Uruguayan music for your donation. Plastic waste is polluting our oceans, but we can reverse the trend. It starts with initiatives like ours and you can support it!
Our glorious mate kit, for those that want to enjoy this beverage in style
La Fábrica Canvas bags, hand-painted by the team
La Fábrica t-shirts
La Fábrica badges and stickers
Get involved

There are many ways to get involved! You can support us by donating and sharing our campaign or contact info@lafabrica.uy to donate other tools for our space. We're bootstrapping our startup, so every little bit counts!

We are Grays Harbor Historical Seaport, a 501 (c)(3) educational non-profit public development authority based in Aberdeen, Washington. For more than 25 years, we have provided hands on education opportunities for people of all ages and backgrounds aboard the tall ships Lady Washington and Hawaiian Chieftain. With a focus on teamwork and empowerment, our programs explore our shared history and our daily connections to the world’s oceans.

Grays Harbor Historical Seaport is in the process of developing Seaport Landing on the site of a 38-acre former sawmill on the Aberdeen waterfront. The Seaport Landing project will transform a disused industrial brownfield into a mixed-use cultural destination. Offering space for community organizations, entrepreneurship, lodging, and a dock for Lady Washington and Hawaiian Chieftain.

This year our goal for Giving Tuesday is to turn an old water tower at our home port in Aberdeen into a welcoming sign for Seaport Landing. The total project cost is $14,000. Every gift of $30 will paint 55 square feet of this water tower. If you donate $1,000 or more, as a thank you, your name will be painted on the water tower for the whole community to see.  If you don’t want your name listed, you can instead use it to honor a loved one with this lasting gift.

We have a matching offer of $5,000 for the repainting of this water tower. That means every dollar you give to GHHS will be doubled on Giving Tuesday, Nov. 27th. Will you help us meet this matching amount?

We are transforming the maritime industry through education and training aboard Lady Washington and Hawaiian Chieftain and in Grays Harbor. Help us revitalize our home port by making a gift next week on #GivingTuesday! Thank you for helping us to improve our community one paint stroke at a time!

We are Babsi and Wolfi, we live in St.Pölten and are preparing our marriage this summer. People tell us we are a funny couple, we love animals and nature and we want to show the world what humans are able to do if they work together.

Our city has been for a long time small, cozy and sleepy. But recently, with a high- speed train connection to Vienna, more and more people want to live here. We love that and welcome you all! The upside is: Our city is getting bigger and there is more diversity. The downside: There is ever less space for trees and green areas.

OUR PROJECT

We built up the biggest Urban Garden project in Austria. There will be trees, plants, a pond, a place for barbecues and different innovations that tackle climate change. It starts with garages with small gardens on their roof, and solar panels and ends with areas, where students work on their researching projects and show their prototypes.

With thus project we want to show citizens in cities all over the planet how a green area can be integrated into a city concept and bring a beautiful garden to all the people who live in the neighborhood without a chance for an own garden. Parking, combined with small gardens, what better way to bring nature back into the cities? 

WHAT FOR?

On the one hand our project brings an area into the city, that reduces emission, improves the air quality and encourages residents to work on climate change, and get a reward for it. On the other hand, we get insights on how the single projects effect climate change and can be used economical in city concepts. We deliver a range of completed single-concepts including operating numbers and financial rewards.

HOW TO HELP

If you support us with 1 €, we are already happy. If you support us with more, we will dance and sing about how cool you are! 

WHAT ARE WE GOING TO DO WITH YOUR MONEY?

We buy a property and built up as many individual projects as possible.

Some examples:
• vegetable gardens for all the people who want to harvest their own veggies
• a pond, which will also be the source of water for the garden
<li>a family &amp
column2: friends area to meet your friends, learn for school or just have a cozy barbecue with your family

column1: • garages with small gardens on their top
• vertical gardening
• green noise barriers
• educational trail
• research projects
• e-parking
• solar energy
• minigardens

PLEASE TELL YOUR FRIENDS ABOUT OUR

CAMPAIGN!

THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Help Farmers Escape the Debt Trap

Over 8,000 farmers killed themselves last year. This is wrong. No more.

The root cause of these suicides is the debt trap.

We are the FIWE Agri-Institute, and we are working to train Agri-Gurus – skilled and educated individuals who can guide farmers out of this cycle of debt and despair - and into high-income, low water use, sustainable agriculture methods.

The Debt Trap
• Expensive Inputs (Requiring Loans)
• Income-Affecting Event
<li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
• Despair and Suicide
Agri-Guru Intervention
<li>
High-Income, Low-Input Techniques - Practiced for years in pockets around India
<li>
Financial Guidance - Information on government schemes and other financial services
<li>
Market Support - Networked access to suppliers and sellers
<li>
Counseling - Trained counseling to help farmers in despair

In a year where a normal farmer makes no profit, an Agri-Guru trained farmer’s income should greatly exceed costs - enabling him to avoid a debt trap.

 

One Agri-Guru For Every At-Risk Village - $500,000
Where Will This $500,000 Come From?
• We (FORCE Institute of Water Efficiency) are contributing $100,000 and a plot of land
<li>
Established donors - $200,000 (We are in advanced stages of talks with donors who have supported our work with marginalized communities through FORCE)
• Through other Institute activities - $100,000 (such as advisory services and consulting)
• Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign - $100,000

Any additional support above our goal amount will still be extremely beneficial as we train more Agri-Gurus to reach out to more farmers.

 

With This $500,000, We Will Train 500 Agri-Gurus

Train 500 Agri-Gurus - farmers trained in our methods, who can in turn train other farmers in these practices. 

We aim to remove the root cause of the suicide - the low-income high-debt trap. 

FIWE has designed a unique year-long course to train the Agri-Gurus. The course borrows from multiple disciplines to equip the Agri Gurus with:

1) Knowledge of the types and methods of High Income Water Efficient agriculture – With an emphasis on those that reduce farmers’ susceptibility to drought and water availability variations, and those that free them from the need to use chemical fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides.

2) Networks with potential market partners – to support the farmers with low cost products and farming equipment suppliers, and to help them sell their product for a higher price.

3) Knowledge of financial support options – including insurance, government schemes, grants, soft loans and other innovative finance packages available to farmers.

4) Communication skills – on a personal level to connect better with the farmer and in business communication to help the farmer connect with his market partners.

5) Computer skills – to leverage the best that technology can offer and train the farmers in its use.

6) Behavioral and counselling skills – with a special focus on understanding the psychology of the farmers and symptoms of distress.

We ask for your help in funding these Agri-Gurus. The total tuition cost is $1,000, for a one-year course.​

 

 

WHO IS AT RISK?

These are some of the hardest working men and women in India. They feed the 2nd most populous nation in the world.

Yet more and more of them are feeling such hopelessness, such despair, that they feel they have no other choice but to end their lives.

This is wrong. No more.

The root cause of these suicides is the debt trap. A small farmer, trying to eke out a living from an unresponsive soil in unpredictable weather is marketed a bevy of chemical fertilizers, herbicides and pesticide and a bore-well – as miracle cures.

With global warming, as water scarcity and climate change push more and more villages towards nonviable agriculture –

All villages may be at risk.

- Source: Times of India

 

We must restore dignity and profit to farmers

 

WHO IS NOT 'AT-RISK'?

Some farmers have found a way out of the debt trap. Using different techniques, they do high income farming which uses less of the expensive chemical herbicides, pesticides, fertilizers and water. Some have also learnt to take advantage of the opportunities hidden in increasingly complex supply chains and markets.

If at-risk farmers could apply these techniques, they would no longer be 'at-risk'

We, the FIWE Agri-Institute, are preparing 'Agri-Gurus' to be sent to at-risk villages.  An Agri-Guru will be the farmer's technical, market and finance guide for High Income Water Efficient (HIWE) farming. The Agri-Guru will guide the farmer as he transitions from traditional agriculture to new methods. The Agri-Guru will also be the farmer's sounding board and psychological counselor in times of distress.  

  

What We Do - FIWE Agri-Institute

The FORCE Institute of Water Efficiency (FIWE) is part of the FORCE Group, which began over a decade ago with FORCE NGO. Until 2014, FORCE worked towards the cause of water availability in India primarily through water access projects – rainwater harvesting, and water and sanitation facilities in slums.

Yet over time we realized the issues couldn’t be solved on a piece-meal basis. India used more and more water with each passing year, but water availability wasn’t increasing to keep pace. We saw the devastation water scarcity caused both in urban and rural areas. The country – and the world – need large improvements in water efficiency, and quickly. Unless we do that, we will not be able to remove poverty, hunger and disease.  

In India, the agricultural sector accounts for approximately 80% of the country’s water use. Therefore, agriculture is a major focus area for FIWE – through the FIWE Agri-Institute. We especially promote techniques that reduce water use and at the same time increase the farmer's profitability and environmental sustainability.

The methods we advance have a firm track record are combinations of proven techniques such as intercropping and drought-resistant irrigation. In addition to agricultural techniques, Agri-Guru learnings will include new ways to harness market power and technologies as well as financial guidance for farmers. They will also act as psychological counselors in times of distress.
column3:
'>We are working for a water-efficient world. Yet water efficiency isn’t an end to itself. Our end goal is sustainable and resilient livelihoods for everyone.

 

 

Cover Photo - Associated Press

Music in video - bensound.com

Generous thank you to Mission FAPRO for their video content of naturalized farming methods

There have been BioBlitz events all over Canada, the United States, Australia, Africa, China, and Europe— and in 2015, t
