column2:
>AUSTRALIA'S FIRST
SOCIAL ENTERPRISE BEER COMPANY

The Good Beer Co. is Australia’s first social enterprise beer company. The Great Barrier Beer is our first beer. By investing in our campaign, you could become a founding member in an Australian beer company that gives back, and to save the world doing what you quite possibly do anyway, buying and drinking one Good Beer at a time.
column4:
>WE ARE NOW SHIPPING TO NZ!

New Zealand beer and reef lovers we've added some Great Barrier Beer pre-order perks just for you, so you can bring the Good Beer Movement to New Zealand!

column2: >

column1: Want to feature Good Beer in the media? Contact Us here

column3:
/>

Great Barrier Beer will be a delicious craft beer that aims to donate 50% of its profits to the Australian Marine Conservation Society, to help them protect the Great Barrier Reef, the world's largest coral reef,  located in the Coral Sea, off the coast of Queensland, Australia.
column8:
>

WE NEED YOUR HELP TO BREW OUR FIRST GOOD BEER - GREAT BARRIER BEER - BY INVESTING IN OUR CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN!

column1: Great Barrier Beer brings together two of Australia’s best-loved icons – beer and the
Great Barrier Reef. Brewed in Bundaberg by Bargara Brewing Company and overseen
by a group of beer experts, Great Barrier Beer will be an easy drinking,
quality craft beer. Best of all, its profits will go to protecting its
namesake through the legendary Australian Marine Conservation Society.
These funds will help us brew,
distribute and promote the Great Barrier Beer. They will also allow us to partner
with other great craft micro-breweries from around Australia to run more great social enterprise campaigns
and continue to sell Good Beer That Does Good in the future.
BACK A BEER THAT GIVES BACK
We want to give every beer-drinking
person with a conscience the opportunity to raise money for a great cause simply by raising a glass. We call it drinking
socially responsibly!

BEER BY THE PEOPLE, FOR THE PEOPLE (AND THE REEF DWELLERS)

We’re a movement for Good Beer. A democratic
beer company that invites its drinkers, stockists and supporters to join the
Good Beer Movement and have their say in how our beer can make a difference.

EVERYONE WHO BACKS OUR CAMPAIGN WILL GET GOOD BEER CO. FOUNDING MEMBER RIGHTS

This means taste
testing, voting on label designs, an invitation to our AGM party and deciding

which beers to get behind and which charities and causes to support next. Can you think of a better organisation to join?


OUR FIRST BREWING PARTNER - THE BARGARA BREWING COMPANY

The Bargara Brewing Company is a craft beer
company committed to quality beer and protecting the environment.<div>
The microbrewery, based in Bargara - the
gateway of The Great Barrier Reef in Queensland, Australia - was founded in 2014 by six mates. Today,
they’re all about the culture of drinking, authenticity, mateship, innovation,
respect, awareness and appreciation.
“Craft beer is not just better beer, it is
a culture. We’re really proud to be getting behind Great Barrier Beer and doing
our bit for the Great Barrier Reef."" - <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
Alongside their best selling Thirsty Turtle
Bright Lager and Drunk Fish Pale Ale, the Great Barrier Beer will be a swimmingly good drink.
For more on our brilliant brewing buddies,
visit www.bargarabrewingco.com
OUR CHARITY PARTNER
The Australian Marine Conservation Society
AMCS is an independent national charity,
responsible for protecting Australia's ocean wildlife and their homes for over
50 years. It’s thanks to them the Great Barrier Reef is a recognised marine
national park with World Heritage status.
They are staffed
by a committed group of professional and passionate scientists, educators and
advocates who have defended Australia's oceans for over 50 years.
With your beer drinking help, the
Great Barrier Beer will give them a sustainable and reliable income stream.
That way they can spend more time protecting one of the Seven Wonders of the
World and less time worrying about where their next dollar’s going to come from
“Our iconic Great Barrier Reef is at
a tipping point, having lost about half of its coral cover in the past 30
years. Unless we take action now to protect it, the outlook for this natural
wonder of the world looks bleak.
“However, by helping to crowd-fund
Great Barrier Beer, Australians will be helping to reverse damage to the Reef
and protect it for future generations.”
Darren Kindleysides, AMCS CEO
Check out their great work at www.marineconservation.org.au
WHO'S BEHIND IT?
The Good Beer Co. and Great Barrier
Beer are led by James Grugeon. James has more than 17 years experience in
leadership, business development, advocacy and social and environmental action.
He has worked as a board level strategist, leader and senior manager for a
range of public and private sector organisations, ranging from the UK FTSE 100
to start up social enterprises and was CEO of the UK’s oldest environmental
NGO.
Most recently James drove the
successful Better Power consumer action campaign with campaigning organisation GetUp
on behalf of Australia’s Greenest power company - Powershop (Greenpeace). James
helped over 12,500 GetUp members switch their power supplier to renewable
energy backed Powershop, raising over $1.2million for GetUp in the process and
helping Powershop start up in Victoria and NSW, in less than 12 months.
James will work directly with an
independent advisory board and charitable trust. The advisory board will guide
our work, review our profits and allocate funds to charity partners via The
Good Beer Co’s charitable trust.
Our charitable trust exists to oversee Good
Beer giving back. It’s an important part of how The Good Beer Co. ensures that
you can feel confident that when we say we give back to our charity partners,

we mean it.

You can find out more about The Good Beer Co. and Founder James Grugeon on our website: www.thegoodbeerco.com.au
OUR MISSION
Good Beer That Does Good

OUR VISION

To be a leading independent Australian beer company working with
leading craft brewers across Australia to shake up the industry for better,
driving down environmental impact, brewing popular and award winning beer and
leading sustainable and transformative funding for our charity partners.
PROOF OF CONCEPT
The Good Beer Co. is Australia’s
first social enterprise beer company. However, the concept is not a totally new
one.
Our business model, strategy and
approach is informed by other successful social enterprises and not for profit
beer companies. That’s why we’re confident it’s a good idea.
There are two companies in
particular that have pioneered social enterprise beer and are great examples of
how successful it can be. We are lucky enough that they have been very generous
in lending their support and advice and encouragement to The Good Beer Co. They
are Two Fingers Brewery in the UK http://twofingersbrewing.co/ and Finnegan’s Beer in the USA
http://finnegans.org/.
OUR AIM IS TO RAISE $100,000
<b>The Good Beer Co. &amp
<ul>
<li>
We will give 50% of profits to the
Australian Marine Conservation Society
<li>
We're a new business model – Australia's
first social enterprise beer
<li>
We’re a people-powered,
democratic movement for Good Beer
• We support responsible drinking
<li>
We work with Australia's premier craft brewers
<li>
We want to set the standard for
the beer industry in Australia
<li>
We minimise our beer's impact
on the environment
<li>
We lead by example
<li>
We work with local breweries to
support local jobs and investment
<li>
We don't think it's cool to
drink and drive
<li>
We champion craft beer over the
big beer companies
Being a social enterprise we rely on your
support and others. Our movement only exists thanks to those from our legal
company, branding agency and partner brewery, all of whom have worked with us
at low costs to help us maximise profits for our charity partners.
But while we may be asking for money for
beer, we are not a lost cause. We are a good cause. A socially and
environmentally conscious cause that gives back. A movement bringing together
good people, to drink Good Beer and do good at the same time.
This is your chance to join us.
If you’d like to join the Movement for
Good Beer and help us brew the Great Barrier Beer, then make your pledge today
and back a beer that gives back.
THANK YOU
For supporting us and helping share Good Beer Co with the world.
The Good Beer Co. and Great Barrier Beer.

","AUSTRALIA'S FIRST SOCIAL ENTERPRISE BEER COMPANYThe Good Beer Co. is Australia’s first social enterprise beer company. The Great Barrier Beer is our first beer. By investing in our campaign, you could become a founding member in an Australian beer company that gives back, and to save the world doing what you quite possibly do anyway, buying and drinking one Good Beer at a time. WE ARE NOW SHIPPING TO NZ!New Zealand beer and reef lovers we've added some Great Barrier Beer pre-order perks just for you, so you can bring the Good Beer Movement to New Zealand!GOOD BEER HAS BEEN FEATURED ON
Want to feature Good Beer in the media? Contact Us here

Great Barrier Beer will be a delicious craft beer that aims to donate 50% of its profits to the Australian Marine Conservation Society, to help them protect the Great Barrier Reef, the world's largest coral reef,  located in the Coral Sea, off the coast of Queensland, Australia.WE NEED YOUR HELP TO BREW OUR FIRST GOOD BEER - GREAT BARRIER BEER - BY INVESTING IN OUR CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN!
Great Barrier Beer brings together two of Australia’s best-loved icons – beer and the
Great Barrier Reef. Brewed in Bundaberg by Bargara Brewing Company and overseen
by a group of beer experts, Great Barrier Beer will be an easy drinking,
quality craft beer. Best of all, its profits will go to protecting its
namesake through the legendary Australian Marine Conservation Society.
OUR AIM IS TO RAISE $100,000
These funds will help us brew,
distribute and promote the Great Barrier Beer. They will also allow us to partner
with other great craft micro-breweries from around Australia to run more great social enterprise campaigns
and continue to sell Good Beer That Does Good in the future.
BACK A BEER THAT GIVES BACK
We want to give every beer-drinking
person with a conscience the opportunity to raise money for a great cause simply by raising a glass. We call it drinking
socially responsibly!
BEER BY THE PEOPLE, FOR THE PEOPLE (AND THE REEF DWELLERS)We’re a movement for Good Beer. A democratic
beer company that invites its drinkers, stockists and supporters to join the
Good Beer Movement and have their say in how our beer can make a difference.
EVERYONE WHO BACKS OUR CAMPAIGN WILL GET GOOD BEER CO. FOUNDING MEMBER RIGHTSThis means taste
testing, voting on label designs, an invitation to our AGM party and deciding

which beers to get behind and which charities and causes to support next. Can you think of a better organisation to join?OUR FIRST BREWING PARTNER - THE BARGARA BREWING COMPANYThe Bargara Brewing Company is a craft beer
company committed to quality beer and protecting the environment.
The microbrewery, based in Bargara - the
gateway of The Great Barrier Reef in Queensland, Australia - was founded in 2014 by six mates. Today,
they’re all about the culture of drinking, authenticity, mateship, innovation,
respect, awareness and appreciation.
“Craft beer is not just better beer, it is
a culture. We’re really proud to be getting behind Great Barrier Beer and doing
our bit for the Great Barrier Reef."" - Jack Milbank, Founder Barbara Brewing Company
Alongside their best selling Thirsty Turtle
Bright Lager and Drunk Fish Pale Ale, the Great Barrier Beer will be a swimmingly good drink.
For more on our brilliant brewing buddies,
visit www.bargarabrewingco.com
OUR CHARITY PARTNER
The Australian Marine Conservation Society
AMCS is an independent national charity,
responsible for protecting Australia's ocean wildlife and their homes for over
50 years. It’s thanks to them the Great Barrier Reef is a recognised marine
national park with World Heritage status.
They are staffed
by a committed group of professional and passionate scientists, educators and
advocates who have defended Australia's oceans for over 50 years.
With your beer drinking help, the
Great Barrier Beer will give them a sustainable and reliable income stream.
That way they can spend more time protecting one of the Seven Wonders of the
World and less time worrying about where their next dollar’s going to come from
“Our iconic Great Barrier Reef is at
a tipping point, having lost about half of its coral cover in the past 30
years. Unless we take action now to protect it, the outlook for this natural
wonder of the world looks bleak.
“However, by helping to crowd-fund
Great Barrier Beer, Australians will be helping to reverse damage to the Reef

Darren Kindleysides, AMCS CEO

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a="""">In
surface waters all over the Earth there are perfectly-evolved solar power
factories called Diatoms. Diatoms are surface algae that are mostly made of
silica (glass). These single-celled creatures have been perfecting their
beautiful, energy efficient forms since the Jurassic era. In my research I have
discovered that these creatures are constantly putting out a small voltage, day
and night, with their microscopic, sturdy glass exoskeletons. I have been
working on a method to harvest and apply this free, naturally-produced
electricity. The goal of this campaign is to expand upon my research with the
purchase of materials and tools in order to apply this technology.
column5:
schema=youtube"" width=""580"">
Yes, that's power from pondwater, upcycled kombucha bottles, and some hardware store materials. The donor light for the battery charger cost $1.

column1: capturing and testing diatoms I've discovered that there is a voltage produced
by each “cell” of pond water, typically a quart glass jar. This voltage can be increased when they are wired in series, just like conventional solar panels and batteries. Right now the
anodes (points where electrons can gather and be used) are made of steel and
copper, corresponding to negative and positive electrical charge. Diatoms are
found commonly in pond and salt water. It is my aim to utilize microscopes, computerized real-time multimeters, and more strictly controlled tank building materials (and
possible styles) to discern more about these creatures and why and how it is
this energy becomes available.
Thus far I have read as much as
18.5V in direct sunlight, although the jars seem to read relatively high at
night when it is starry as well – versus when there is cloud cover. This odd

effect is one of many I hope to document and research. This is peculiar, but isn't new to biology - there is actually a known fungus found in the old Chernobyl reactor that consumes gamma radiation alone.  Could other ""everyday"" microbes be doing this too, at least in part? The idea of a PV ""stellar cell"" is tantalizing to say the least.
column3:
/>

Scientists have already worked on something like this, harvesting energy from
column14: sig2=0Qm1R-XWs_kiwkUOm4Obnw"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank""> moss. The table to the right is embedded with moss in ceramic pots, with similar anodes/electrodes tapping the spare electrons from photosynthesis. The light is running off the moss, and the moss from a combination of light sources. Theoretically any plant can put out energy that can be used to power applications. What attracted me to working with diatoms, however, was their beautiful glass houses that they make out of silicon - the same material we make solar panels with.

column1: nanoresearch in solar is using the power of these little power plants to
design the next generation of solar panels. What these researchers are finding is that the glass houses these creatures build around themselves are ideal for this process of converting

sunlight into energy. Using diatoms to create solar power this way is brilliant and absolutely will change the industry for the better. We aim to look at what they might be missing, however, as they are killing the architects of
this technology, the diatoms themselves, in order to get pure power

from their dead shells' natural ability. There may be benefits to a symbiotic relationship with living algae that this cut-and-dried approach may be missing. I want to put this energy to work while keeping the diatoms alive - even seeing if they can adapt over time to produce more energy.
column3:
/>

Perks added - get first dibs on algae reading lights and smartphone chargers for a sunny windowsill near you!

Here are some of the questions we want to answer:

column1: ·
Where is the electricity coming
from?
·
Which sort of light effects the
diatom energy production best?
·
Is the electricity influenced by the
glass structures of their bodies as they capture incoming light within their
shell structures?
·
Do organisms with high amounts of
silicon produce high amounts of electricity?
·
How does tapping the diatom-infused
pond water affect the diatom population, or individual health?
·
Are there ways to increase the
population of diatoms by intervention, and will that affect the energy
production?
·
Which structural types of diatom
shells produce the highest amount of energy?
·
What kind of electromagnetic field
do the diatoms create?
·
How does the technology scale
are the limits, how much can we power?
·
How can we apply this technology in
practical, daily applications?
Here are some of the things I need money for:
<ul>
• Microscopes (to see what's happening down there)
<li>Computerized smart voltage meters (to log data in real
time automatically)
<li>Solar charge controllers (to make use of the power and
charge batteries)
• Diodes
• Transformers
• Copper wire
• Sheet metal
• Steel spikes
• Copper pipe
• Deep cycle batteries
I don't want to get rich doing this,
but I do need monetary help if this project is to succeed. Ultimately, I would like to live comfortably but beyond
that I am more interested in the Earth becoming a kinder, gentler place with
energy becoming more freely available and sourced through easily accessible, less
damaging means. My aim is to turn developing projects like this into a career
and I would like your support.
EVERYTHING I DISCOVER HERE WILL
ALWAYS BE FREE TO EVERYBODY, PERIOD. I refuse to patent this research. I want it to be available to the entire world, to have them
see what I've done and be able to further this technology, themselves. What
applications come, I hope will be able to be recreated with anyone’s own hands,
to repeat and learn from it on their own - then power their homes and businesses.
Everything I've accomplished so far has been with recycled and basic hardware
store materials, and I intend to keep what applications I discover as simple to
recreate. As of right now, this tech is currently licensed under an extension
of the GPL as an open-source application. According to my logic, the technology
belongs to the diatoms, and can't be patented. I hope we can all utilize it to
make new businesses and organizations that change the way we think about life,
technology and power.
Please help me develop this

technology further. Contribute even $1 to keep my campaign in the public eye.

column3: '>I,  Lisa Blair, invite you to help me raise awareness of climate change and empower people to take
column9: '> by sponsoring your unique post it note (just a few dollars will do) that you can add your message on climate action.  These notes will be collaged together and displayed as part of a digital wrap on the hull of my yacht.  The yacht will be raced by me in this years high profile Rolex Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race enabling me to combine my absolute love of sailing with my extreme passion for the planet.   Together we can deliver a very strong message which will receive a high level of media attention and create some meaningful conversations around this topic.

column3: '>It is about being a part of the exciting Rolex Sydney Hobart Yacht Race!
column5: '>It is about how many post it notes I can get on my yacht for the race!
column7: '>It is about conversation around our need for CLIMATE ACTION NOW!
column9: '>It is about capturing the attention of a nation!

column3: '>How many notes can we get........1000? 5000? 10,000? or more.

column6: > my many years at sea I have noticed the impact that man made climate change has on our environment. For me personally the storms are more aggressive and less predictable, the absence of wild life when years earlier those seas were brimming with life and the increased risk of collision with ice as the glaciers keep melting.  These are all symptoms
column7: > of man-made climate change.  What we know is that action needs to be taken and a greater awareness needs to be reached.

column4: >My project CLIMATE ACTION NOW is designed not to focus
column5: > on the problem but instead on actions we are taking or can be taking towards a solution by utilising the power of 'note' sharing.
column7: '>Purchase a perk or donate to get a post it note and add an action that you are already taking towards a better future.  This could be 'I ride to work for climate action', or 'I recycle for climate action'.

column3: '>All of your messages received before the 30th of November will be collaged together and transferred onto the hull of the yacht, lending a voice to the individual. It will have an impressive visual impact, attract media and empower others to take CLIMATE ACTION NOW!

'>The vessel will be racing under the name ""Climate Action Now"" to further enhance coverage.  All post it notes received after the 30th Nov will be utilised on my website, social media and supporting platforms.  Together we can create a movement of messages.

column1: Climate Change 101 with Bill Nye.

column8: '>urtsey of The Climate Reality Project Australia,

column1: <div>
The Race
<div>
<span style='letter-spacing: 0px
column3: '>Over the past 70 years, the Rolex Sydney Hobart has become an icon of Australia's summer sport.  Rarely in the world a yachting event attracts such a huge media coverage than the start of the Rolex Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race in Sydney Harbour.  This makes the Rolex Sydney to Hobart a perfect platform to raise awareness of this important issue.

column1: <li>
<span style='letter-spacing: 0px

column1: <div>
The Power of Post it Notes

column3: '>I want to focus on actions we can all take towards a solution.  'Climate Action Now' was born as a means to spread this message, to empower communities to become personally involved and give individuals a voice on climate change.  This is to be achieved through the 'post it note' campaign.

'>Since the 60's people have been using post it notes to create messages.  Tapping in to this established movement of messages we will be using the strength in numbers method to reach a greater audience.  The yacht, 'Climate Action Now' is to be branded with your messages on post it notes and will look something like the image below.
'>These notes will encase the boat in a digital wrap of positive actions that you, the people, are already
column5: '>taking towards climate action. Messages like 'I ride to work for climate
column7: '>action', or 'I recycle for climate action'
column11: '>ideas to reduce emissions in everyday life will be carried across the oceans in a unique symbolic gesture indicating your strong support towards
column13: '>CLIMATE ACTION NOW and inspire others to take action. How many notes can we collect for maximum impact and conversation.

column1: The Sailor

column3: '>In my 10 years of sailing I have achieved many things including circumnavigating in 2011-12 in the Clipper Round the
column5: '>World Yacht Race, working for Hugo Boss on their open 60 racing yacht and sailing solo to New Zealand and back.  I have clocked up over 50 000 nm of ocean racing making me more than qualified for the Sydney to Hobart. I also hold a commercial Yacht Master Offshore, Master 5 and Marine Engine Driver 3. I will skipper the race with a total crew of 8 people.

column1: The Boat

column3: '>I have recently purchased, with the help of my family, the yacht Funnel-Web, a Robert Hick designed open 50 racing yacht.  It was commissioned by Ivan Macfadyen to compete in the Vendee Globe - a solo non-stop and unassisted around the world yacht race.  She is a truly competitive ocean racing yacht that will make a large impact.

column1: <div>

All money received will go towards aiding my efforts to raise awareness of Climate Action.  Here is a list of what your money will be used for, please keep in mind that this is the bare minimum that I need for the boat.
<div>
<ul>
• Hull Wrap $10 000
• Branding on the Sails $5 000
• Insurance for race $5 000
• Anti Foul (to make the boat fast) $4 000
• Bobs and bits that I need to comply with race requirements $1 000
There are always more costs involved with a campaign like this so any surplus funds raised will be going towards those costs, printing and marketing of the message Climate Action Now.
Stretch Goals $700 000
After the completion of the 2015 Rolex Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race I will begin raising the funds for my next big project.

My goal is to become the first female to circumnavigate Antarctica solo, non-stop and unassisted, in a 100 % eco powered yacht and hopefully break the men's record while I am there.  I will be departing in Dec 2016 for this world record Antarctic Cup  campaign. Given that climate change is directly affecting this journey with the increased risk of ice it makes for another great platform to raise awareness of CLIMATE ACTION NOW. Any left over funds will be going towards this campaign.
<div>
If you would like to find out more or contact me to discuss sponsorship please visit my website www.LisaBlairSailstheWorld.com

<span style=""line-height: 30px
column5: >More on the Science of Climate Change.

column1: <div style=""font-weight: bold
Graphical representation of the greenhouse effect.  Source: CO2 Cooperative Research Centre
<div style=""font-weight: bold
<ul>
• Greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, methane and water vapor, trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere and warm the planet.

• In general, the greenhouse effect is a good thing. Without greenhouse gases, the temperature on Earth would be too cold to support life. With too many, it would heat up beyond survivable levels. Earth is sometimes called the Goldilocks Planet because it is ""just right.""
• Since 1958, the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has been measured from an observatory on Mauna Loa, a volcano in Hawaii.
• The pre-industrial concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere was 280 parts per million (ppm). As of March 2009, it has reached 387 ppm.
• Today, the amount of carbon dioxide is higher than at any time in the last 650,000 years. And the Earth's average temperature is increasing faster than ever before.

• The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change projects that temperatures will rise 3.2 - 7.2 degrees Fahrenheit in the 21st century. Dramatically reducing levels of global warming pollution may keep the rise in the lower part of this range.
Contributing to Climate Change
<ul>

• The United States releases more carbon dioxide than any other country, though it is home to just five percent of the world's population. If everyone in the world lived the way people do in the U.S., it would take five Earths to provide enough resources for everyone!
• The amount of carbon dioxide emitted by the average family in the United States breaks down this way:
<li>
One half from heating and cooling the house
<li>
One quarter from transportation
<li>
One quarter from using electricity
•  Burning one gallon of gasoline puts 19 pounds of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
Effects on People, Wildlife and the Planet
<ul>

• Average sea level is expected to rise 7 - 23 inches before the end of this century - and perhaps as much as 31 inches (if, as some models predict, the rate of ice melting from Greenland and Antarctica increases).
• All but 100 of 1,100 glaciers researched are receding (more ice melts in summer than re-forms the next winter).
• The current pace of global average temperature rise puts approximately 20 to 30 percent of plant and animal species at increased risk of extinction.

• Rain forest destruction contributes to climate change. That's because trees store carbon dioxide as they grow. Clearing and burning forests releases large amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

• Coral reefs are as important to marine wildlife as rainforests are to land-based wildlife. Rising seawater temperatures threaten their survival. The world lost about 16% of all coral reefs in 1998, the second hottest year on record.

Curtsey of https://www.nwf.org/Eco-Schools-USA/Become-an-Eco-School/Pathways/Climate-Change/Facts.aspx 
Resources
The Intergovermental Panel on Climate Change http://www.ipcc.ch/activities/activities.shtml
NASA on Climate Change http://climate.nasa.gov/
The Climate Reality Project http://www.climatereality.org.au/
New South Wales department of Primary Industrys http://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/research/topics/climate-change/causes
Documentary on Climate Change ""Chasing Ice"" https://chasingice.com/

column2: >CLIMATE ACTION NOW - Post it, Share it, Embrace it.

column1: ","Summary

I,  Lisa Blair, invite you to help me raise awareness of climate change and empower people to take CLIMATE ACTION NOW!  Get involved by sponsoring your unique post it note (just a few dollars will do) that you can add your message on climate action.  These notes will be collaged together and displayed as part of a digital wrap on the hull of my yacht.  The yacht will be raced by me in this years high profile Rolex Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race enabling me to combine my absolute love of sailing with my extreme passion for the planet.   Together we can deliver a very strong message which will receive a high level of media attention and create some meaningful conversations around this topic.

It is about being a part of the exciting Rolex Sydney Hobart Yacht Race!It is about how many post it notes I can get on my yacht for the race!It is about conversation around our need for CLIMATE ACTION NOW!It is about capturing the attention of a nation!
How many notes can we get........1000? 5000? 10,000? or more.

Over my many years at sea I have noticed the impact that man made climate change has on our environment. For me personally the storms are more aggressive and less predictable, the absence of wild life when years earlier those seas were brimming with life and the increased risk of collision with ice as the glaciers keep melting.  These are all symptoms of man-made climate change.  What we know is that action needs to be taken and a greater awareness needs to be reached.

My project CLIMATE ACTION NOW is designed not to focus on the problem but instead on actions we are taking or can be taking towards a solution by utilising the power of 'note' sharing.  Purchase a perk or donate to get a post it note and add an action that you are already taking towards a better future.  This could be 'I ride to work for climate action', or 'I recycle for climate action'.

All of your messages received before the 30th of November will be collaged together and transferred onto the hull of the yacht, lending a voice to the individual. It will have an impressive visual impact, attract media and empower others to take CLIMATE ACTION NOW!

The vessel will be racing under the name ""Climate Action Now"" to further enhance coverage.  All post it notes received after the 30th Nov will be utilised on my website, social media and supporting platforms.  Together we can create a movement of messages.
What is man-made climate change?
Climate Change 101 with Bill Nye.
Curtsey of The Climate Reality Project Australia, www.ClimateReality.org
The Opportunity
The Race

Over the past 70 years, the Rolex Sydney Hobart has become an icon of Australia's summer sport.  Rarely in the world a yachting event attracts such a huge media coverage than the start of the Rolex Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race in Sydney Harbour.  This makes the Rolex Sydney to Hobart a perfect platform to raise awareness of this important issue.
The Reach
Over 600 000 people converge on Sydney's foreshore to witness the race start.
The race start is broadcast Live at 12.20 pm on Boxing Day by Channel 7, a 90 minute program.
The race start will be webcast on Yahoo7, ABC TV will document the race down the eastern seaboard.

I will be documenting challenges before and during the race and will post blogs on the Australian Sailing and Yachting magazine's website www.mysailing.com.au These will be shared around my website and social media outlets.
The Power of Post it Notes

I want to focus on actions we can all take towards a solution.  'Climate Action Now' was born as a means to spread this message, to empower communities to become personally involved and give individuals a voice on climate change.  This is to be achieved through the 'post it note' campaign.

Since the 60's people have been using post it notes to create messages.  Tapping in to this established movement of messages we will be using the strength in numbers method to reach a greater audience.  The yacht, 'Climate Action Now' is to be branded with your messages on post it notes and will look something like the image below.

These notes will encase the boat in a digital wrap of positive actions that you, the people, are already taking towards climate action. Messages like 'I ride to work for climate action', or 'I recycle for climate action' creating a simple sharing of ideas to reduce emissions in everyday life will be carried across the oceans in a unique symbolic gesture indicating your strong support towards CLIMATE ACTION NOW and inspire others to take action. How many notes can we collect for maximum impact and conversation.
The Sailor

In my 10 years of sailing I have achieved many things including circumnavigating in 2011-12 in the Clipper Round the World Yacht Race, working for Hugo Boss on their open 60 racing yacht and sailing solo to New Zealand and back.  I have clocked up over 50 000 nm of ocean racing making me more than qualified for the Sydney to Hobart. I also hold a commercial Yacht Master Offshore, Master 5 and Marine Engine Driver 3. I will skipper the race with a total crew of 8 people.
The Boat

I have recently purchased, with the help of my family, the yacht Funnel-Web, a Robert Hick designed open 50 racing yacht.  It was commissioned by Ivan Macfadyen to compete in the Vendee Globe - a solo non-stop and unassisted around the world yacht race.  She is a truly competitive ocean racing yacht that will make a large impact.

All money received will go towards aiding my efforts to raise awareness of Climate Action.  Here is a list of what your money will be used for, please keep in mind that this is the bare minimum that I need for the boat.
Hull Wrap $10 000
Branding on the Sails $5 000
Insurance for race $5 000
Anti Foul (to make the boat fast) $4 000
Bobs and bits that I need to comply with race requirements $1 000
There are always more costs involved with a campaign like this so any surplus funds raised will be going towards those costs, printing and marketing of the message Climate Action Now.
Stretch Goals $700 000
After the completion of the 2015 Rolex Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race I will begin raising the funds for my next big project.

My goal is to become the first female to circumnavigate Antarctica solo, non-stop and unassisted, in a 100 % eco powered yacht and hopefully break the men's record while I am there.  I will be departing in Dec 2016 for this world record Antarctic Cup  campaign. Given that climate change is directly affecting this journey with the increased risk of ice it makes for another great platform to raise awareness of CLIMATE ACTION NOW. Any left over funds will be going towards this campaign.
If you would like to find out more or contact me to discuss sponsorship please visit my website www.LisaBlairSailstheWorld.com

Graphical representation of the greenhouse effect.  Source: CO2 Cooperative Research Centre
Facts on Climate Change
Greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, methane and water vapor, trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere and warm the planet.

In general, the greenhouse effect is a good thing. Without greenhouse gases, the temperature on Earth would be too cold to support life. With too many, it would heat up beyond survivable levels. Earth is sometimes called the Goldilocks Planet because it is ""just right.""
Since 1958, the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has been measured from an observatory on Mauna Loa, a volcano in Hawaii.
The pre-industrial concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere was 280 parts per million (ppm). As of March 2009, it has reached 387 ppm.
Today, the amount of carbon dioxide is higher than at any time in the last 650,000 years. And the Earth's average temperature is increasing faster than ever before.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change projects that temperatures will rise 3.2 - 7.2 degrees Fahrenheit in the 21st century. Dramatically reducing levels of global warming pollution may keep the rise in the lower part of this range.

The United States releases more carbon dioxide than any other country, though it is home to just five percent of the world's population. If everyone in the world lived the way people do in the U.S., it would take five Earths to provide enough resources for everyone!
The amount of carbon dioxide emitted by the average family in the United States breaks down this way:
One half from heating and cooling the house
One quarter from transportation
One quarter from using electricity
Burning one gallon of gasoline puts 19 pounds of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

Average sea level is expected to rise 7 - 23 inches before the end of this century - and perhaps as much as 31 inches (if, as some models predict, the rate of ice melting from Greenland and Antarctica increases).

We don't believe that knowledge is a commodity we believe it is a right. Because we make our programs available to educators, students and the public all over the world without charge we need your help.
<div>

With your support we can bear the financial costs for the necessary technical equipment, logistical planing and for contracting the most talented artists to help us in this endeavor. We are making an amazing, life-changing series of films on how to create jobs, support families and communities by restoring natural ecological function. You can help us make those films, translate them into many languages and allow them to be seen around the world.
<div>
<span style=""font-size: 24px
<div>

With your help we will also be able to create a sophisticated platform to share our extensive library. In 20 years we have built an enormous archive of images from all continents to help educators, students and the general public to better understand what we are collectively facing at this time and what each individual and all of us together can do: be the change we want to see in the world.

column1: <div>
<i>The <a href=""http://eempc.org/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #009c23
Environmental Education Media Project (EEMP)
has been working to educate people about the environment and the
Earth's ecosystems for the past 20 years.
Beginning in China as the
Environmental Education Media Project for China (EEMPC) to help raise
awareness and participation to address the serious problems in China the
name was shortened when the United Nations and other organizations asked
us to work in Mongolia, Africa and South America.
<div>
<i>The EEMP is best known for the documentation of the Loess Plateau
restoration in China which has led to scientific, policy and physical
changes in several countries and holds important solutions to Climate
Change.
<i><b>EEMP is driven by volunteers and has very low administrative costs.
We believe with all our hearts in what we do.
","We know how natural Earth systems function and that there is a strong relationship between healthy ecosystems, climate change, societal sustainability, happiness, wealth and equality.
If you laughed about this drawing, it was indeed our purpose, we love to cheer you up from time to time :)
This knowledge must become part of human collective consciousness.

Teaching the basic relationships between ecological health and human wellbeing has been central to our mission and can be seen as a continuing thread in many of our films such as ""Lessons of the Loess Plateau"", ""Hope in a Changing Climate"", ""Green Gold"", ""Forests of Hope"", ""The Promise of the Commons"", ""Healing the Earth and the Human Spirit"" and others.
Help us Make Effective Television Programs and Provide Them to Audiences Worldwide for Free!

We work for you and people all over the world because we believe that everyone needs and deserves access to the same information on the environment and ecology. We don't believe that knowledge is a commodity we believe it is a right. Because we make our programs available to educators, students and the public all over the world without charge we need your help.

With your support we can bear the financial costs for the necessary technical equipment, logistical planing and for contracting the most talented artists to help us in this endeavor. We are making an amazing, life-changing series of films on how to create jobs, support families and communities by restoring natural ecological function. You can help us make those films, translate them into many languages and allow them to be seen around the world.
We have built a precious library.

With your help we will also be able to create a sophisticated platform to share our extensive library. In 20 years we have built an enormous archive of images from all continents to help educators, students and the general public to better understand what we are collectively facing at this time and what each individual and all of us together can do: be the change we want to see in the world.
Be the change you want to see in the world!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <h3>
<span style=""font-size: 30px

As you are probably aware, the world’s bee population is under threat. Around the globe, colonies are declining drastically and that’s bad news for more than honey fans. Bees are directly responsible for a third of all the food we eat. Without their pollination, things will get very serious. But we want to ensure that never happens, but we need your help.
So who are we? Andy Cory you may have already met in the video above.
column2: >He has been a beekeeper for over 35 years and is a specialist in queen bee

column1: breeding. He owns and directly oversees 3,000 hives in New Zealand and 1,000 hives in
Niue. He is widely considered one of the Pacific’s leading apiculturists.
When Andy first took on these bees located on the Pacific island of Niue 15 years ago, he never dreamt that the world's stock of honey bees would subsequently get into such peril.  H
he would be left with the healthiest last known significant and sufficiently isolated stock of Italian honey bees (
mellifera ligustica

They were brought to Niue many years ago, well before the major honey bee diseases, parasites and chemicals afflicting today’s bees could affect them. They’ve since been effectively isolated in a tropical paradise for bees.
<b><i>""Niue has no honey bee diseases or pests of quarantine
concern and arguably has the highest bee health status of the Pacific Island
countries which export bee products to New Zealand.""  Niue Honey Bee Disease Survey (SPC) July 2013.

Thankfully, he persevered through the many trials associated with Pacific beekeeping, even surviving a huge cyclone in 2004, and kept the bees alive! It was also a bonus that Andy had the only bees on Niue and that they were purely of Italian stock, so there were no issues of cross breeding with other undesirable strains of honey bee. Additionally, Niue's relative isolation, limited ports and tourism and ideal size (not too big and not to small - the 'Goldilocks' factor) had made it the ideal location for a ""natural and near quarantine"". Consequently, Andy already had an informal bee sanctuary.

Nevertheless, as the rest of the world's honey bees have become increasingly threatened by a host of causes, sometimes summed up in the term ""colony collapse disorder"" (CCD), Andy decided the time had come to convert the Niue operation into a formal and internationally recognised Global Bee Sanctuary. Discussions with the Government of Niue and other potential partners started accordingly. As other remedies are explored for solving the international bee crisis, a bee sanctuary on Niue is critical to ensure there will always be healthy and protected stock from which to draw from in the future - in effect, insurance against the continuing decline of the honey bee and the resulting impact on global food security.
<div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe class=""embedly-embed"" height=""435"" src=""https://cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fplayer.vimeo.com%2Fvideo%2F128045140&amp
<b><i>""In summary, the bees were the healthiest bees the

author has seen for a long time and this is supported by laboratory tests."" Niue Honey Bee Disease Survey (SPC) July 2013.

But creating and funding a Bee Sanctuary, with the aim of eventually being able to potentially export clean, healthy and gentle bee stock to other countries was going to take some time. We put our heads together and came up with the plan to create a ""Save the Bee"" retail honey brand to self-fund this important initiative. However, getting sufficient sales was going to take some time and the honey bees were coming under increasing threat (with an hugely alarming 42% mortality rate in the US over the last year!). So, we needed to fast-track the initiative, and that's where you come in . . .
Be part of building a Global Bee Sanctuary
<div>
This campaign is an opportunity to play
a unique and pivotal role in the creation of a Global Bee Sanctuary through an innovative
‘social business’ model,
thereby promoting regional agricultural productivity, environment and
biodiversity protection, and ultimately safeguarding global food security.
We are looking for your help to:
<ul>
• facilitate the timely development of a Global Bee Sanctuary on Niue with the aim of safeguarding the genetic stock of the Italian bee.

• help fast-track the development of the existing apiculture operation from a regional wholesale honey sales organisation to a self-funded globally branded “save the bee” retail bee product sales organisation.

• pursue opportunities to spread Niue's honeybee stock. Initially, into other suitable Pacific Island nations as livelihood projects with other NGO and regional agency partners, and then into Northern Hemisphere countries in order to augment pollination services.
<ul>
<div>
Why crowdfunding

The purpose of this crowdfunding campaign is to raise funds to fast-track the transition of the current commercial wholesale venture into a self-funding retail-based social venture. In doing so, the foundation will be laid for generating future revenue sufficient to create and sustain a Global Bee Sanctuary.
<div>
From where the social venture stands today, it is proceeding forward in two broad phases:

column2: >Phase 1: strengthen and grow the current apiculture operation on

column1: Niue
column4: >in order to generate revenue, build partnerships and learning. And provide a solid foundation and financial resources sufficient
column6: > the creation and sustain the operation of a Global Bee Sanctuary.

column1: Phase 2: develop the ‘Global Bee Sanctuary’ and begin to export live bee stocks and/or genetic breeding material to other Pacific Island countries, as well as other key food producing countries.
This is where the venture shifts to regional and then global in its impact.
The Phase 1 funding target of this campaign is $160,000, which will be assigned to the following areas:
$15,000 - Biosecurity enhancements (training and communications: the Government of Niue already does a great job of banning all honey and bee stock imports).

$25,000 - Retail 'Save The Bee' honey bottles (we have had some initial design funding from Pacific Island Trade and Invest, hence the great bottle design you see in this campaign. Nevertheless, for the first run of retail sales, we still need to source, test and buy the bottles, pack and distribute - all using organic certified processes).
$25,000 - New hives (to start the replacement of all the old hives on the island, eventually building to a maximum sustainable number of 4,000).
$30,000 - Honey factory upgrade (the old honey factory needs new floors and ceilings, plus the upgrade of the 1960s vintage honey and wax processing equipment).
$25,000 - Truck (ever tried to keep a truck going in the Pacific?! We need a new and reliable truck to make sure we can keep pace with the productivity requirements as the venture grows).

column2: D into Niue honey bioactive properties (there is anecdotal evidence that Niue honey might have valuable and unique bioactive components).

column1: $20,000 - Disease Audit (the bees on Niue are inspected by an external agency every few years, but we need to bring the frequency up to an annual inspection in order to retain export clearance to New Zealand and from there to the rest of the world).

If our funding goal is not reached, we would concentrate the funds that were raised on the first two categories above (biosecurity and bottles), and continue to press on with the project! We won't stop now, the stakes are too high!

In the case of raising more funds than the campaign target, we would be able to stretch straight into the subsequent regional and global phases of the project, instead of having to wait until the honey sales created the necessary funds. FYI - certification for live bee exports alone could run close to a 7 figure sum!
What Unique Perks do You Get

So what do you get . . . other than playing a role in saving the bee! We've got some great perks for you as an expression of our gratitude, as well as to remind you of your pledge and commitment to the honey bee (and we would love for you to also tell everyone about where you got them).
column2: >All supporters will be recognised accordingly on our website (in development) and receive

column1: THE BEE TEE:

You can select a T-shirt or polo shirt with our ""Infinity Bee"" logo that represents our plan, and your pledge, to ensure that honey bees will survive for future generations (remember to send your size and colour preference through to us on the same contact/email details as those used in your pledge).
<div>
<div>
<div>
ORGANIC CERTIFIED ""SAVE THE BEE"" HONEY:

Niue honey is the best honey in the world and here's your chance to be one of the first in world to obtain a bottle(s) of the ""Save the Bee"" foundational 2015 honey harvest. A tropical multi-floral blend with no pesticides, antibiotics or residues from genetically engineered nectar substitutes. It's all natural on Niue and we have official organic certification from BioGro NZ (refer below) to prove it.

Niue honey tastes incredible! It has an interesting mix of tropical flavours, but without any lingering or bitter aftertaste that can be present in other dark honeys. It's a unique flavour and one that we have had very positive initial and informal feedback from food writers and international honey judges . . . but you be the judge by putting your pledge through today. The foundational 2015 harvest will be limited, so get in quick!

With the kind funding assistance from regional agencies, as well as ""friends of the bees"" working pro bono, we've been able to commission unique and high quality packaging.  This will make the gifting of STB honey to friends and family a great option, not to mention a conversation piece (the packaging petals will have information on the honey bee and Niue). So put in a pledge for a ""Save the Bee"" honey multipack and get plenty for everyone. It's a great way to spread the word about the importance of the honey bee!
SPONSOR A HIVE:

We currently have 1,000 hives, and we need to replace the wooden hive boxes, floors and lids in the first instance, as well as building towards the maximum sustainable number of hives for the island (4,000). Sponsor a hive and we will put a plaque with your name on the hive, send you a framed photograph of the hive and let you know where it is located on the Island. Wouldn't it be great to be able to order honey in the future from a hive that you started!
SPONSOR AN APIARY:

As with the hive sponsorship above, sponsor an entire apiary/yard and we will also send you a photo of the apiary complete with its entrance sign with your name on it (or your organisation's). All apiaries will eventually be traceable online when mapping coordinates are uploaded, and you will be able to show your friends, family and colleagues where you have invested in the future of the honey bee!
TOUR OF NIUE:

Why not come to Niue and go out on the bees with Andy. Niue is a fantastic place for a holiday, especially if interested in a bit of adventure, such as fishing, snorkelling, scuba diving, tramping/hiking . . . and beekeeping! Andy's a great host, and you will be able to hear firsthand some of his stories of re-establishing the bees on Niue, and the plans to expand this stock into the region. We will commemorate your pledge with a signed and framed photograph of your stay, and recognition of one of the foundational champions of the Global Bee Sanctuary!
<div>
<div>
ANDY'S LANDY:

OK, so everyone's got their quirks . . . and for Andy it's keeping his old 1972 Land Rover 2A going! It's been a faithful partner since the start, but Pacific Island conditions can be harsh. Sure there are flashier and more expensive alternatives, but we don't think Andy's the kind of guy to be tempted by a younger model. Having reliable transport on Island is essential for ensuring Andy and his local beekeeping team can effectively monitor hives on all parts of the Island. Sponsor Andy's Landy and we will put your name, or the name of your organisation, on the side, and send you a framed photograph recognising your support of the Pacific Bee Sanctuary. We will also give you regular updates on the project, recognition on the website and if you ever visit Niue, you can use Andy's Landy for your personal transport.
TRUCK SPONSORSHIP:

Speaking of harsh conditions for machinery, it is Andy's dream to be able to make the transformation to a ""two-truck operation""! You know the old story . . . the truck breaks down and the part needed isn't deliverable until the next boat (currently monthly). Nevertheless, we would be very thankful for just one reliable truck (with a few essential spare parts) which will help us attain our objectives of raising productivity, as well as being able to ensure the bees are regularly visited and monitored. If you pledge to be our truck sponsor(s), we will put your name on the side, send you a framed photograph and give you recognition on the website.

column1: If honey bee stocks continue to decline, and especially in the context of conflicting messages about the cause(s), we need to do more than just plant flowers (important as this is). We need to urgently protect the best honey bees that remain, and hopefully we will never have to call on them as a result of an absolutely catastrophic situation . . . albeit things are pretty bad at the moment!
<div>
What Can Go Wrong

The biggest risks to us are biosecurity related, particularly the introduction of the varroa mite and/or European foulbrood (EFB), the former being a setback to productivity (and organic certification) and the latter being a deal-breaker for entry and/or transit of live bees via New Zealand (as all Niuean exports go via Auckland, NZ). Consequently, the requirement of getting biosecurity levels up to the maximum possible is essential. The Government of Niue has done an excellent job in strengthening biosecurity measures to ban the import of all bees and bee products. They are also positive about putting their weight in behind the emerging Global Bee Sanctuary plans and we are currently discussing how to support each other during this next phase in a public-private partnership.

We had a recent scare when a minor case of American foulbrood (AFB) was found, the first in eight years. The few affected hives were dealt with, but it was a salutary lesson of the need to enhance biosecurity arrangements and renew old gear. Indeed, one of the interim goals as we progress through the project phases is for Niue to be able to declare itself the first country to have eradicated AFB. Nosema has also been present on the Island, but has had negligible effect on the health of the bees and will be reduced through re-queening and renewal of hive parts as one of the short term goals of this project.

Agricultural in the Pacific is always under threat from cyclones. As previously mentioned, Andy nearly lost all the bees in 2004. He is grateful to the French navy who at the time brought him sugar to feed as a supplement until native vegetation recovered. Consequently, to mitigate against the risk of losing all the bees in the aftermath of future cyclones, we now have a sufficient store of organic sugar on Island.
This job is too big for just Andy

Thanks so much for taking the time to read through our campaign! We trust you can see that we are passionate about this critical project and that it is of real significance to all of us. We are looking for equally passionate supporters who can join with us on this journey. As Andy often likes to say,""it's been a 15 year love affair with the bees on Niue!"" He didn't expect to have to be the custodian for this genetic stock when he first came to Niue, but he has diligently and faithfully performed his duty . . . now he needs your help to keep them safe and available for future generations.

We hope you found a perk that suits you, but if not you can still play a very important role by making as much noise about this campaign as possible. Please tell your friends and colleagues (and bosses) about this important campaign .  . . there are even some Indiegogo share tools designed especially to assist you. As you can imagine, Andy is better on the bees than on the computer. So those of you with technical and social media expertise, let's get this campaign going viral (with the social media . . . not the bees!).
Thanks again and we hope to see you in Niue sometime . . . and remember to SAVE THE BEE!
","How we can Save the Bee

As you are probably aware, the world’s bee population is under threat. Around the globe, colonies are declining drastically and that’s bad news for more than honey fans. Bees are directly responsible for a third of all the food we eat. Without their pollination, things will get very serious. But we want to ensure that never happens, but we need your help.
So who are we? Andy Cory you may have already met in the video above. He has been a beekeeper for over 35 years and is a specialist in queen bee
breeding. He owns and directly oversees 3,000 hives in New Zealand and 1,000 hives in
Niue. He is widely considered one of the Pacific’s leading apiculturists.

When Andy first took on these bees located on the Pacific island of Niue 15 years ago, he never dreamt that the world's stock of honey bees would subsequently get into such peril.  He also never thought that
he would be left with the healthiest last known significant and sufficiently isolated stock of Italian honey bees (Apis
mellifera ligustica) in the region, and likely the world.

They were brought to Niue many years ago, well before the major honey bee diseases, parasites and chemicals afflicting today’s bees could affect them. They’ve since been effectively isolated in a tropical paradise for bees.
Niue has no honey bee diseases or pests of quarantine
concern and arguably has the highest bee health status of the Pacific Island
countries which export bee products to New Zealand.""  Niue Honey Bee Disease Survey (SPC) July 2013.

Thankfully, he persevered through the many trials associated with Pacific beekeeping, even surviving a huge cyclone in 2004, and kept the bees alive! It was also a bonus that Andy had the only bees on Niue and that they were purely of Italian stock, so there were no issues of cross breeding with other undesirable strains of honey bee. Additionally, Niue's relative isolation, limited ports and tourism and ideal size (not too big and not to small - the 'Goldilocks' factor) had made it the ideal location for a ""natural and near quarantine"". Consequently, Andy already had an informal bee sanctuary.

Nevertheless, as the rest of the world's honey bees have become increasingly threatened by a host of causes, sometimes summed up in the term ""colony collapse disorder"" (CCD), Andy decided the time had come to convert the Niue operation into a formal and internationally recognised Global Bee Sanctuary. Discussions with the Government of Niue and other potential partners started accordingly. As other remedies are explored for solving the international bee crisis, a bee sanctuary on Niue is critical to ensure there will always be healthy and protected stock from which to draw from in the future - in effect, insurance against the continuing decline of the honey bee and the resulting impact on global food security.
In summary, the bees were the healthiest bees the

author has seen for a long time and this is supported by laboratory tests."" Niue Honey Bee Disease Survey (SPC) July 2013.But creating and funding a Bee Sanctuary, with the aim of eventually being able to potentially export clean, healthy and gentle bee stock to other countries was going to take some time. We put our heads together and came up with the plan to create a ""Save the Bee"" retail honey brand to self-fund this important initiative. However, getting sufficient sales was going to take some time and the honey bees were coming under increasing threat (with an hugely alarming 42% mortality rate in the US over the last year!). So, we needed to fast-track the initiative, and that's where you come in . . .
Be part of building a Global Bee Sanctuary
This campaign is an opportunity to play
a unique and pivotal role in the creation of a Global Bee Sanctuary through an innovative
‘social business’ model,
thereby promoting regional agricultural productivity, environment and
biodiversity protection, and ultimately safeguarding global food security.
We are looking for your help to:
facilitate the timely development of a Global Bee Sanctuary on Niue with the aim of safeguarding the genetic stock of the Italian bee.

help fast-track the development of the existing apiculture operation from a regional wholesale honey sales organisation to a self-funded globally branded “save the bee” retail bee product sales organisation.

pursue opportunities to spread Niue's honeybee stock. Initially, into other suitable Pacific Island nations as livelihood projects with other NGO and regional agency partners, and then into Northern Hemisphere countries in order to augment pollination services.
Why crowdfunding

The purpose of this crowdfunding campaign is to raise funds to fast-track the transition of the current commercial wholesale venture into a self-funding retail-based social venture. In doing so, the foundation will be laid for generating future revenue sufficient to create and sustain a Global Bee Sanctuary.
From where the social venture stands today, it is proceeding forward in two broad phases:
Phase 1: strengthen and grow the current apiculture operation on

Niue and develop export markets in order to generate revenue, build partnerships and learning. And provide a solid foundation and financial resources sufficient to underwrite the creation and sustain the operation of a Global Bee Sanctuary.
Phase 2: develop the ‘Global Bee Sanctuary’ and begin to export live bee stocks and/or genetic breeding material to other Pacific Island countries, as well as other key food producing countries.
This is where the venture shifts to regional and then global in its impact.
The Phase 1 funding target of this campaign is $160,000, which will be assigned to the following areas:
$15,000 - Biosecurity enhancements (training and communications: the Government of Niue already does a great job of banning all honey and bee stock imports).

$25,000 - Retail 'Save The Bee' honey bottles (we have had some initial design funding from Pacific Island Trade and Invest, hence the great bottle design you see in this campaign. Nevertheless, for the first run of retail sales, we still need to source, test and buy the bottles, pack and distribute - all using organic certified processes).
$25,000 - New hives (to start the replacement of all the old hives on the island, eventually building to a maximum sustainable number of 4,000).
$30,000 - Honey factory upgrade (the old honey factory needs new floors and ceilings, plus the upgrade of the 1960s vintage honey and wax processing equipment).
$25,000 - Truck (ever tried to keep a truck going in the Pacific?! We need a new and reliable truck to make sure we can keep pace with the productivity requirements as the venture grows).
$20,000 - R&D into Niue honey bioactive properties (there is anecdotal evidence that Niue honey might have valuable and unique bioactive components).

$20,000 - Disease Audit (the bees on Niue are inspected by an external agency every few years, but we need to bring the frequency up to an annual inspection in order to retain export clearance to New Zealand and from there to the rest of the world).

If our funding goal is not reached, we would concentrate the funds that were raised on the first two categories above (biosecurity and bottles), and continue to press on with the project! We won't stop now, the stakes are too high!

In the case of raising more funds than the campaign target, we would be able to stretch straight into the subsequent regional and global phases of the project, instead of having to wait until the honey sales created the necessary funds. FYI - certification for live bee exports alone could run close to a 7 figure sum!
What Unique Perks do You Get

So what do you get . . . other than playing a role in saving the bee! We've got some great perks for you as an expression of our gratitude, as well as to remind you of your pledge and commitment to the honey bee (and we would love for you to also tell everyone about where you got them). All supporters will be recognised accordingly on our website (in development) and receive regular updates.
THE BEE TEE:

You can select a T-shirt or polo shirt with our ""Infinity Bee"" logo that represents our plan, and your pledge, to ensure that honey bees will survive for future generations (remember to send your size and colour preference through to us on the same contact/email details as those used in your pledge).
ORGANIC CERTIFIED ""SAVE THE BEE"" HONEY:

Niue honey is the best honey in the world and here's your chance to be one of the first in world to obtain a bottle(s) of the ""Save the Bee"" foundational 2015 honey harvest. A tropical multi-floral blend with no pesticides, antibiotics or residues from genetically engineered nectar substitutes. It's all natural on Niue and we have official organic certification from BioGro NZ (refer below) to prove it.

Niue honey tastes incredible! It has an interesting mix of tropical flavours, but without any lingering or bitter aftertaste that can be present in other dark honeys. It's a unique flavour and one that we have had very positive initial and informal feedback from food writers and international honey judges . . . but you be the judge by putting your pledge through today. The foundational 2015 harvest will be limited, so get in quick!

With the kind funding assistance from regional agencies, as well as ""friends of the bees"" working pro bono, we've been able to commission unique and high quality packaging.  This will make the gifting of STB honey to friends and family a great option, not to mention a conversation piece (the packaging petals will have information on the honey bee and Niue). So put in a pledge for a ""Save the Bee"" honey multipack and get plenty for everyone. It's a great way to spread the word about the importance of the honey bee!
SPONSOR A HIVE:

We currently have 1,000 hives, and we need to replace the wooden hive boxes, floors and lids in the first instance, as well as building towards the maximum sustainable number of hives for the island (4,000). Sponsor a hive and we will put a plaque with your name on the hive, send you a framed photograph of the hive and let you know where it is located on the Island. Wouldn't it be great to be able to order honey in the future from a hive that you started!
SPONSOR AN APIARY:

As with the hive sponsorship above, sponsor an entire apiary/yard and we will also send you a photo of the apiary complete with its entrance sign with your name on it (or your organisation's). All apiaries will eventually be traceable online when mapping coordinates are uploaded, and you will be able to show your friends, family and colleagues where you have invested in the future of the honey bee!
TOUR OF NIUE:

Why not come to Niue and go out on the bees with Andy. Niue is a fantastic place for a holiday, especially if interested in a bit of adventure, such as fishing, snorkelling, scuba diving, tramping/hiking . . . and beekeeping! Andy's a great host, and you will be able to hear firsthand some of his stories of re-establishing the bees on Niue, and the plans to expand this stock into the region. We will commemorate your pledge with a signed and framed photograph of your stay, and recognition of one of the foundational champions of the Global Bee Sanctuary!
ANDY'S LANDY:

OK, so everyone's got their quirks . . . and for Andy it's keeping his old 1972 Land Rover 2A going! It's been a faithful partner since the start, but Pacific Island conditions can be harsh. Sure there are flashier and more expensive alternatives, but we don't think Andy's the kind of guy to be tempted by a younger model. Having reliable transport on Island is essential for ensuring Andy and his local beekeeping team can effectively monitor hives on all parts of the Island. Sponsor Andy's Landy and we will put your name, or the name of your organisation, on the side, and send you a framed photograph recognising your support of the Pacific Bee Sanctuary. We will also give you regular updates on the project, recognition on the website and if you ever visit Niue, you can use Andy's Landy for your personal transport.
TRUCK SPONSORSHIP:

Speaking of harsh conditions for machinery, it is Andy's dream to be able to make the transformation to a ""two-truck operation""! You know the old story . . . the truck breaks down and the part needed isn't deliverable until the next boat (currently monthly). Nevertheless, we would be very thankful for just one reliable truck (with a few essential spare parts) which will help us attain our objectives of raising productivity, as well as being able to ensure the bees are regularly visited and monitored. If you pledge to be our truck sponsor(s), we will put your name on the side, send you a framed photograph and give you recognition on the website.
FACTORY AND MACHINERY SPONSORSHIP:

When Andy first bought Niue Honey it took him two days to cut his way through the overgrown bush to get into the honey factory! It has been a great facility to get him going, but it's time for an upgrade to repair the floors and ceiling that are well worn. We also plan to upgrade the 1960s extraction equipment in order to keep pace with our expansion plans. As the Honey Factory II Sponsor, we will hold a naming ceremony in your honour (or your organisation's), which you would of course be most welcome to join! Local and regional VIPs would be invited and we would send you framed photographs of the plaque affixed to the upgraded facility. As with all pledges, you would receive regular updates and due recognition on our website.
Everyone's depending on the Bee

This is were we get serious again as there could be serious consequences if we fail to preserve the bees we have left. This campaign represents a Call-to-Action for those of us who want to do something significant for the honey bee and global food security. The social enterprise model also has a wider set of benefits, some of which are:
Protection of honeybee biodiversity and the genetic purity of the Italian honeybee for future generations.
Development of an alternative and sustainable source of bee imports for
Northern Hemisphere pollination requirements (while other solutions are being
developed).
Formation of an authentic and compelling communication platform to
promote the linkages between bee health, regional sustainable agriculture and global
food security to an increasingly concerned international audience.
Establishment of a Pacific education and research centre to further
timely R&D into bee health and integrate with other complementary
initiatives.
Augmentation of regional agricultural productivity initiatives through
‘re-stocking’ the region from a pure source of gentle bee stock.
Provision of vital livelihoods for Pacific Island communities, while also
spreading Italian bee stock.
Contribute towards native bush regeneration, thereby mitigating the
effects of global warming and soil degeneration.
Expansion of revenue opportunities for landowners with hive rental
arrangements.

Additional local employment opportunities as a result of expanded activities and product development, as well as via the creation of retail production facilities on Island, such as bottling and other value-added supply chain activity.

Provision of an alternative source of revenue for the government of Niue as a recipient of social venture donations (such revenue could be used to enhance and underwrite some of the Island’s biosecurity arrangements, removing such expense from recurrent budget expenditure).

If honey bee stocks continue to decline, and especially in the context of conflicting messages about the cause(s), we need to do more than just plant flowers (important as this is). We need to urgently protect the best honey bees that remain, and hopefully we will never have to call on them as a result of an absolutely catastrophic situation . . . albeit things are pretty bad at the moment!

Indeed, one of the interim goals as we progress through the project phases is for Niue to be able to declare itself the first country to have eradicated AFB. He is grateful to the French navy who at the time brought him sugar to feed as a supplement until native vegetation recovered. Consequently, to mitigate against the risk of losing all the bees in the aftermath of future cyclones, we now have a sufficient store of organic sugar on Island.

Why create a Botanical Sanctuary?

To ensure that
herbal medicine is accessible to all, reconnect people to nature and
its life force, educate the public about conservation of at risk herbal
plants in North America. Demonstrate that many medicinal plants can be
grown in Alberta climate and teach others about natural farming and

permaculture. 

I made the decision to become guardian of the 10 acres of Crowfoot Indian land after receiving strong guidance from my Higher Self and the nature spirits that a place was needed for people to
return to Mother Earth—our ultimate healer. In addition to creating a
place of sanctity, the land is being cultivated using
permaculturally-inspired methods that work in harmony with the natural
landscape. The focus is one of conservation, sustainability, resiliency,

soulful healing and spiritually aligned purpose. Currently there are over 40 North American medicinal plants on the ""At Risk"" (endangered) and ""To Watch"" list including Echinacea, American Ginseng, Goldenseal, Black Cohosh, Wild Yam and Blue Cohosh.  The Senses of the Soul Botanical Sanctuary is a proud member of United Plant Savers and part of the medicinal plant conservation program.  This type of botanical sanctuary is the first of its kind in Alberta and one of only four in Canada!

“Nature’s
medicine supports us to safely die a little each time so that we may be
reborn again.  Plants and other nature allies are about life, death,
resurrection and change.” - (Samantha)
Join me on a journey of  conservation and co-creation. Donate

to the Senses of the Soul Botanical Sanctuary and Farm now. 

The
money donated will help to finish the construction of the one acre garden (that has 7 separate chakra gardens), buy
seeds and plants over the next two years, build a solar
greenhouse (for medicinal plant propagation) and allow the creation of an educational video series about ""at risk""medicinal plants and the

botanical sanctuary.

Thank you to all the beautiful co-creators who have contributed to the growth of the Botanical Sanctuary and Farm thus far!

Senses of the Soul: www.sensesofthesoul.ca

Please support United Plant Savers!
Become a member!
United Plant Savers At Risk list:
www.unitedplantsavers.org/species-at-risk

column4: >Growing Industrial hemp for its biomass is one

soil.

column4: >Hemp buildings lock up the carbon rich biomass and create carbon sinks. When the hemp is regionally sourced, this combination is hard to beat

column1: <span style=""font-size: 16px
column5: >Although we're still small, through partnering with farmers, we've supplied the materials into most of the hemp buildings in Australia and for a Gallery in the Singapore Botanic Gardens.  We're the lead Australian developer of certified hemp-lime construction materials. We've been waiting for state legislations and the farming

Our goal is to trigger large scale carbon farming, better farming practices and new Australian businesses, by encouraging farming of high biomass hemp crops for construction projects.
As a company we're at a critical time. We have a growing list of clients planning builds, however from the point of someone being interested, to actually starting a build takes quite a long time.
