column1: Our Approach
Australian Hemp Masonry Pty Ltd’s work spans across the hemp construction and hemp farming sectors.  Our goal is to contribute to a smooth transition from a fossil fuel to a carbon based economy.

We have done most of our work in Australia but we did train the crew and supply the materials for Singapore's first zero energy public building, the Green Gallery and Heritage Museum in the Singapore Botanic Gardens.

Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong officially opened the Building saying “I am, happy that many companies are supporting the environment as part of your corporate social responsibility, like CDL Green Gallery – a commitment to eco-friendly development and practices.""
Our Research

We're serious about carbon management and being net positive. So as well as developing building materials, we've done a lot of research into hemp farming and processing and we work with groups of farmers to help them to develop regional industries.
Although life cycle analysis of products is only starting to be broadly discussed, truly sustainable products consider all the steps in their manufacture and distribution.

The Lime Binder and Hemp lime Render products we supply for new builds and retrofits are certified and were developed and tested over a 6 year period at the Australian Centre for Construction Innovation at UNSW and for a further 6 years in the field.
The aims of our research were to develop a product and identify a process that would:
a) maximise the renewable resource (hemp) in the building material
b) minimise the energy-intensive heated and mined materials (limes) in the Binder
c) produce a carbon neutral building material.

column2: >Australian Hemp Masonry is amongst the most sustainable Hemp Lime Construction materials available globally.

column1: <h3>What We Need &amp

We need your support to keep educating and advocating to ensure that we develop a sustainable hemp farming industry in Australia while we continue in our development of further Hemp Building materials like Hemp lime prefabricated panels, especially for social housing.
We are also asking for your support to kickstart a social housing project.
Through supporting us you will also indirectly reap the benefits of carbon abatement, cleaner air and cleaner water!
As well you'll be contributing to a positive future for future generations and the planet. Thank you!

column1: <div>
$900 - Hemp Builder

We've been delivering Hemp Building training since 2009 and we've been running monthly workshops for the last 9 months. So far this year we've been to Tasmania, Perth, Gold Coast, the Hunter Valley and NSW Central Coast  and we're in Sydney in August.

You will receive a place at an Australian Hemp Masonry Hemp Building Workshop near you, plus a hard copy of the Australian Hemp Masonry Construction Manual and an e-postcard of one of the Australian Hemp Farms we're working with, with our personal thanks!

Come along and benefit from our ongoing research.  Or gift a workshop place to someone who you know would be interested. We'll be delivering workshops in most Australian Capital cities within the next 18 months.
<div>
<div>
<b style=""background-color: initial
<div>

Our 2 day workshops include formal and hands on training about building with certified BCA compliant Hemp Masonry (Hemp lime) construction materials – for Builders, Building designers, Architects and Owner builders.

Covers: Batch preparation, tools and equipment, installation and options for formwork, curing requirements, design elements, fixtures and finishing, thermal performance, carbon profile and Building Code (BCA) compliance, WH&
Hours: Saturday 8.00am for 8.30 start through to 4pm / Sunday 8.00am to 4pm (Please note some workshops offer additional options)
All training is delivered by an accredited workplace trainer and assessor and includes AHMC Construction Manual, lunches and light refreshments.

All new enterprises need benefactors to really get the ball rolling. Along with the obvious personal letter of appreciation, If you choose this contribution then we will also thank you in a video on our website in which we explain the progress you will have helped us to achieve, acknowledging you as one of the key benefactors that helped us (and the farmers we work with) to get up and running. Thank you!

$10000 - Customised Workshop

A customised 2 day Hemp Building Workshop at your site plus 10% discount on AHMC's materials for the workshop and an e-postcard of one of the Australian Hemp Farms we're working with, with our personal thanks! Participants are supplied with hands on experience and a  Construction Manual and supporting technical information.
This is an opportunity for you to support us, as well as to organise a workshop in your regional area at a suitable site.

column1: We'll cover our costs in Australia. For regions outside Australia our costs are additional. Freight for materials is additional.
<div><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

Your support will enable us to continue to be Australian Green Industry Drivers, further developing our model for regional production supporting local farmers.  You will also be directly enabling the transition to industry based on carbon rather than fossil fuels. If our infrastructure is viewed as a potential way to create carbon sinks, we can make a massive difference.

Each time we can engage a hemp farmer to grow and process half a hectare of industrial hemp for a small building, we collectively lock up 2 - 4 tonnes of harmful carbon emissions.  In Southwold in the UK a 2400 sq m hemp lime brewery and distribution centre has no refrigeration. 500 tonnes of carbon are locked into this building. It is the UK's greenest warehouse. Lime hemp’s manufacture  produces one-tenth of the carbon dioxide generated in making a conventional concrete block. Please support us to make a green economy for Australia real.

Other positive impacts you will help to realise are regional development and the creation of the jobs of the future, like in Dungog in the NSW Hunter Valley where a disused timber mill has been converted to a Hemp Mill producing the hemp for an ecovillage closeby.  We have no direct financial interest in farming however we are actively involved in helping this community and other regional communities to build industry based on hemp.
Hopefully we'll also make a start on improving Aboriginal housing in remote communities.
Risks &
<div>

A major risk for the Australian hemp industry is investment from overseas corporations dominating the industry. Imported European subsidised materials with a higher carbon footprint will compete with the emerging Australian hemp farming and processing industries if we don't support our farmers and processors to grow our own industry .

We have worked for many years developing and perfecting our materials, however we are committed to continuous improvement and we hope to improve and innovate informed by your feedback. By pledging to support this innovation you are  making Green Industry possible - allowing cutting edge technology to be realised.

MANUFACTURING: We are working closely with a manufacturer who has been able to produce our materials at a high quality so we have already resolved many of the manufacturing challenges. However, to produce on a larger scale will require increased tooling and production equipment. This is a complex transition for a small company.
FULFILMENT:

We have already co-sponsored and run two workshops for Aboriginal participants to construct a small hemp masonry (hemp lime) cabin with some support from NSW Trade and Investment). Our goal from these preliminary workshops was to gauge interest and whether we could offer a valuable contribution.

Two of our staff are qualified VET trainers and we both have experience in working  in education with Aboriginal communities. Ben has worked for the past 5 years in Alice Springs, NT project managing environmental and community projects.

As a staff member of North Coast TAFE  Klara, the company's General Manager won the North Coast Institute Staff Award for Excellence in Aboriginal Community Partnerships in 2010 and was the project manager for a  2014 project ""The Trickle Effect – Working flexibly with Aboriginal communities to build capability in resource efficiency"" which was a finalist in the Social Responsibility category of the Green Gown Awards Australasia

http://www.acts.asn.au/initiatives/ggaa/sharing-awards-success/2014-winners-finalists/social-responsibility/

While we hope that your support on Indiegogo will enable us to transition to production on a commercial scale, until we get your feedback we have no idea if it will be 'business as usual' for us, or an overwhelming demand. Currently we have a great track record and we're determined to maintain that. Early backers will be given priority to receive materials and workshop places.
<div>

PRODUCT ADJUSTMENTS: Extensive testing of our materials has taken place over the past 10 years, however we are continuously researching and improving aspects of our products and supply chain, including packaging and distribution. This will result in an even better product but may briefly delay production or shipment in some cases. We'll do our best to minimise any impacts!
Other Ways You Can Help

Please support us by sharing our campaign around your networks. If you would  like to support the work that we are doing directly, then please contact us! 
  •  Make some noise about our campaign! 
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for supporting us to build a more sustainable future one house at a time! 

","We have arrived at a time of major transition where we need to reduce our dependence on mining, and quickly.
At the same time we need better materials that we can sustainably use and produce.
We also need to harvest carbon from the atmosphere because greenhouse gases are at unsafe levels.""
Growing Industrial hemp for its biomass is one
of the cleanest, fastest and most economical ways to harvest carbon from the atmosphere. It's multifunctional.  It also adds to soil carbon and improves the
soil.
Hemp buildings lock up the carbon rich biomass and create carbon sinks. When the hemp is regionally sourced, this combination is hard to beat

Although we're still small, through partnering with farmers, we've supplied the materials into most of the hemp buildings in Australia and for a Gallery in the Singapore Botanic Gardens.  We're the lead Australian developer of certified hemp-lime construction materials. We've been waiting for state legislations and the farming
industry to catch up with us!
Because we know that sustainably farmed hemp and regional models are the best long term option, we've made it a part of our core business to work closely with
regional Australian farmers and processors.
Our goal is to trigger large scale carbon farming, better farming practices and new Australian businesses, by encouraging farming of high biomass hemp crops for construction projects.

As a company we're at a critical time. We have a growing list of clients planning builds, however from the point of someone being interested, to actually starting a build takes quite a long time. We need to grow so we can move from small to larger scale manufacturing because of that growing interest.

We're asking for your support to educate Australians about the benefits of hemp building, hemp farming and the hemp industry. A huge challenge for this industry is the misinformation about Hemp which is a hangover from prohibition. We are working to develop truly sustainable, regional industry. The only way to do that is support Australia's regional hemp farmers, while we develop.
We'd also like to kickstart a social housing project with your help, where we'll share our knowledge of hemp building skills using the materials you donate.
You'll notice most of our perks are educational ...

WHAT WE DO
We provide consultancy services. We also deliver training to Architects, Building Designers, Builders and Owner builders to make sure that our products are accessible to the broader community.
We've got a strong record in R & D

Our materials significantly reduce ongoing operational energy use in commercial and residential buildings. That translates into fewer greenhouse emissions from construction, as well as fewer greenhouse gas emissions from the building's reduced energy  use.
We lobby government and work in industry associations to support farmers across the broader hemp industry.
We support small to medium scale Australian Farmers to stay on their farms

We're definitely interested in mainstreaming hemp construction but we're also  engaged in working effectively with global transition groups and Indigenous communities who are looking for sustainable housing solutions.
We're big on education and knowledge sharing.

Video courtesy of Maitland Mercury  -  Bob is one of the lead farmers in Australia and works with a co-operative of growers in NSW. This hemp is currently being processed to supply many of our builds.
Our Approach
Australian Hemp Masonry Pty Ltd’s work spans across the hemp construction and hemp farming sectors.  Our goal is to contribute to a smooth transition from a fossil fuel to a carbon based economy.

We have done most of our work in Australia but we did train the crew and supply the materials for Singapore's first zero energy public building, the Green Gallery and Heritage Museum in the Singapore Botanic Gardens.

Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong officially opened the Building saying “I am, happy that many companies are supporting the environment as part of your corporate social responsibility, like CDL Green Gallery – a commitment to eco-friendly development and practices.""
Our Research

We're serious about carbon management and being net positive. So as well as developing building materials, we've done a lot of research into hemp farming and processing and we work with groups of farmers to help them to develop regional industries.
Although life cycle analysis of products is only starting to be broadly discussed, truly sustainable products consider all the steps in their manufacture and distribution.

The Lime Binder and Hemp lime Render products we supply for new builds and retrofits are certified and were developed and tested over a 6 year period at the Australian Centre for Construction Innovation at UNSW and for a further 6 years in the field.
The aims of our research were to develop a product and identify a process that would:
a) maximise the renewable resource (hemp) in the building material
b) minimise the energy-intensive heated and mined materials (limes) in the Binder
c) produce a carbon neutral building material.
Australian Hemp Masonry is amongst the most sustainable Hemp Lime Construction materials available globally.
What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to keep educating and advocating to ensure that we develop a sustainable hemp farming industry in Australia while we continue in our development of further Hemp Building materials like Hemp lime prefabricated panels, especially for social housing.
We are also asking for your support to kickstart a social housing project.
Through supporting us you will also indirectly reap the benefits of carbon abatement, cleaner air and cleaner water!
As well you'll be contributing to a positive future for future generations and the planet. Thank you!
$10 - Gifting - the Hemp Brick
Thank you for your support.  Help us to hand on skills and make a contribution.

These funds will be kept separate and your contribution will go towards the hemp lime materials for a social housing project in NSW, QLD or NT.  This project is about handing on skills and the initiative has come from discussions over some years with a number of Aboriginal Elders in communities in NSW, Qld and NT.

The cost of the AHMC materials for walls and subfloor and roofing insulation,  and AHMC Hemp lime Render for a 100 sq m building  (250mm thick walls, 150mm subfloor and 150mm roofing insulation) plus 3.7 tonnes of Hemp Hurd (from partner farmer) is approx $18,000.

This will create a comfortable, breathable living area (and carbon sink) which is thermally efficient, mitigates humidity well, provides a healthy living environment and will require less energy to run than conventional building materials. It will also be a carbon sink ...  and trigger more carbon farming ...

Although this is only a beginning it puts us in a great position to find other partners. A simple kit frame, windows, doors, fit out and heading out in a shipping container will require other partners and sponsors. However we have good networking skills. We also believe that a lot of Australians feel that there is an urgent need to improve the housing options in Aboriginal communities and your support will enable us to leverage additional funding for projects to start to happen. Working to support social housing is a part of our Vision
http://hempmasonry.com.au/company-overview/

As a staff member of North Coast TAFE  Klara, the company's General Manager won the North Coast Institute Staff Award for Excellence in Aboriginal Community Partnerships in 2010 and was the project manager for a  2014 project ""The Trickle Effect – Working flexibly with Aboriginal communities to build capability in resource efficiency"" which was a finalist in the Social Responsibility category of the Green Gown Awards Australasia

Currently we have a great track record and we're determined to maintain that. Early backers will be given priority to receive materials and workshop places.

PRODUCT ADJUSTMENTS: Extensive testing of our materials has taken place over the past 10 years, however we are continuously researching and improving aspects of our products and supply chain, including packaging and distribution. This will result in an even better product but may briefly delay production or shipment in some cases. We'll do our best to minimise any impacts!
Other Ways You Can Help

Please support us by sharing our campaign around your networks. If you would  like to support the work that we are doing directly, then please contact us!    Make some noise about our campaign!  Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!   Thank you for supporting us to build a more sustainable future one house at a time!",7.0,3,"1 Campaign
|","NSW, Australia",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/hemp-houses-building-a-renewable-future/pica

Bringing 'balance' to Swansea
column2: an eco-friendly and sustainable bulk food/zero waste shop

column1: The statistics are there for all to see
<ul>
• 300 million tonnes of plastic produced every year
• Half of that plastic is single use
• 8 million tonnes of plastic dumped into our oceans every year
• Every animal washed up on U.K. beaches found to have digested plastic
The list is endless, but we still carry on like nothing is wrong.
I have a daughter who loves all animals, most notably Dolphins. While watching Blue Planet II as many of us have, my eyes were opened to the mass destruction that we are causing our planet.
It was then that I realised I had to make changes in my life and encourage others to do the same.
With your support I will bring 'balance' to Swansea.
It will be an opportunity to give those of us who want to create a more sustainable and healthier planet the products to do so.
Supplying over 100 bulk foods including nuts, seeds, lentils, rice, pasta, herbs, spices, oils and more that you can take away in your own reusable containers.
We will also stock refill household cleaning and personal hygiene items that are kind to both you and our planet.
Finally we will have lots of hardware including reusable water bottles and coffee cups, bamboo toothbrushes and cutlery sets plus everyone's favourite the metal straw!

I thank you all from the bottom of my heart for your interest and your support and also on behalf of all zero waste stores around the world because we know people desperately want to make these changes and we hope to help you all on your journey to zero waste.
""How can we help?""
What a great question!
We are currently searching for the perfect location to bring a bulk food zero waste option to as many people of Swansea as possible.
<ul>
• We already have personal investment but with your donations we can go one step further and get the best food dispensers, filling them to the brim with lots of amazing and healthy products.
• We will also be able to buy state of the art commercial weighing scales to help make the buying process quicker.
• Finally we hope to have the latest gadgets in our shop in order to provide our customers with the likes of freshly ground nut butters and nut/oat based milks.
If we don't reach our entire funding goal the food and dispensers will of course be our priority.
""We'll scratch your back...""
We have some amazing perks to help you start your journey to zero waste.
<ul>

• From your name on our 'foundations wall' to 'shout outs' on social media so your friends and family hear about the amazing project you are supporting. We hope it will get them talking about the plastic and waste issue which is never a bad thing.
• Lots of cool zero waste themed hardware, some branded by us and some not. Either way they will be great to kick start you on your journey.
• Finally those helping out a little more will have the opportunity to sponsor our food bins along with other advertising perks in our shop and our website.
""Why should we support a project like this?""
We dream of beautiful clean oceans, stunning sandy beaches, sea creatures swimming freely in their habitat without fear of injury or death.
That can become a reality but we have to change now, and we all have to work together towards this one goal.
We need to accept responsibility for our part in this tragic situation and wake up to the possibilities that are there to reverse what we have done.

I know we can do it if we all make small changes to our habits and behaviours. We may not be around to see the results but our children and grandchildren will benefit from the foundations we lay today.
<h3>Risks &amp

Zero waste stores are slowly opening up all around the U.K. and the more the merrier. Every community deserves the opportunity to shop this way and I'm sure we will soon see the larger supermarkets changing to a more sustainable shopping experience. I know with everyone's help we will soon be on the right road to recovery and 'balance' will be there to encourage you as a community to help each other on our journey.
Other Ways You Can Help
Thank you for making it all the way to the end. Top marks!

All I ask now is if you can't donate yourself please, please, please share this link with your friends and family on social media. As the saying goes 'often it's not your friends who you benefit from the most but the friends of friends'.
I will keep you all updated when the shop location is confirmed and also after 30 days when I will have some extra exclusive perks to add to the list.
Peace out!

<h2 style=""text-align: center
<h3 style=""text-align: center

Coffee shops and cafés throw away coffee grounds on an industrial scale. 

 

At Single Origin Skincare we rescue what they call ""waste"", upcycle it into revitalising skincare products and look after planet and people at every stage in that process.

Dean Sprague is the founder of Single Origin Skincare. 

 

Not many people know this about Dean (because nowadays all he talks about is coffee grounds), but he is actually a highly experienced food technologist and a mean good professional chef. 

 

And he has a wealth of experience outside the kitchen too, helping people who have struggled with social and mental health issues find a fresh start in life in the food industry.

 

Think mad food scientist with a heart of gold…

 

… and a vision. 

 

“I walk around* all day looking at things that aren’t as they should be and thinking ‘What can I do about that?”

 

*This is a mis-representation. Dean is much more likely to be found sat in a coffee shop, which is actually where he does his best thinking. 

 

The answer, in coffee shops and cafés, is to stop throwing coffee grounds into landfill, where they get trapped in amongst the other trash, ferment into mulch and release industrial quantities of methane gas (one of the top 3 most potent greenhouse gasses). 

 

And 90% of cafes are doing this, every single day. 

 

It’s not a pretty picture… 

 

That coffee has proven its effectiveness in treating a range of skin conditions, including eczema, dermatitis, scarring and cellulite (mostly by increasing bloodflow just under the skin). 

 

Dean wants to offer an alternative vision:

 

We rescue those coffee grounds before they get to landfill and employ artisans in coffee growing regions to upcycle them into luxurious skincare products, where the caffeine can reinvigorate your skin.

 

And then we use the revenue we generate from those products to help growers implement organic and sustainable farming practices.

 

That way we can have the immediate impact of saving environmentally damaging waste from landfill…

 

… AND spread positive social and environmental change back through the coffee supply chain.

 

Imagine closing the loop on waste in the coffee industry, doing it in a way that benefits the all-too-invisible people at the other end of the supply chain, and caring for your body and skin at the same time.

 

Win-win-win!  

 

Dean’s thinking about industry-wide change here… and has already taken the first steps. 

 

So far, Single Origin Skincare has reclaimed 1500kg of used ground coffee from local cafés in the last twelve months.
And we've been busy making a range of luxurious skincare products with it.

We have set the target of reclaiming another 1500kg in the first six months of 2020. And doing that again over the next 6 months of 2020. 

 

If you’re quick on the math, you can see that means doubling the amount of coffee grounds we’re saving from landfill.

 

Up until now, we’ve processed all 1500kgs of used coffee grounds by hand, using shovels and buckets. 

 

It’s super low impact. But it’s not a solution that can scale. 

 

To reach the target of 3000kgs of used ground coffee in the next twelve months we need to purchase a mixer and a filler.
The mixer is exactly what it sounds like - a bigger, more powerful version of the cake mixer you might have in your kitchen. We'll use it for mixing the ingredients of our soaps more efficiently.

The filler stops any human hands from being involved with filling the beard oil bottles. This massively simplifies our hygeine procedures and literally frees our hands for other tasks.

 

Once our hands are free and the machines are whirring away, we’ll be able to:
<ul>
• Rescue even more grounds before they are wasted by deepening our partnerships with local coffee shops and cafes
• Offer more work and more valuable contracts to the local artisans who handcraft the skincare products
• Dedicate more time to educating growers about sustainable farming techniques
• Investigate further ways to address waste in the coffee industry (the agricultural applications of coffee grounds are top of our list)
• Shift our focus to the blossoming coffee scenes in India and China, where we can intervene before industrial levels of waste become a serious problem

And you can help.

 

All you have to do is wash your hands with this:
Or soften your beard (or your partner’s prickly face carpet) with this:
Or exfoliate your feet with this:

Doesn’t seem to bad, does it?

 

And if you don’t think it’s for you, then perhaps there’s a coffee lover you know who deserves to treat themselves for Christmas or the New Year?

 

You can also make smaller contributions to our campaign, and your own self-care, with a new, 0 impact bamboo hairbrush...
Or beard comb…

If you want to go true minimalist, and not acquire any more “stuff”, then you can bring about the change you want to see in the world with a donation. 

 

We’ll shout your great name from the tops of lungs to say thank you (or keep you completely anonymous, as you wish!). 

 

And we recognise that sometimes the best thing we can ask of you is just a share on social media.
We’ve been successful in producing a small run of soaps and selling them through our local network to check they’re good.
Verdict: yes, they are.
<div><div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/I5SmQjy_BKA?autohide=1&amp
column3:
showinfo=0""> 

But as an early stage business, we are very susceptible to risks.

 

Our biggest immediate risk factors are:

column1: <ul>
• The partners we source the coffee grounds from deciding that the benefits of upcycling with us do not outweigh the costs of implementing systems to capture the waste
• The artisans who produce the skincare products feeling that our contracts are not consistent enough for them to work with us
• Competition from greenwashing competitors who don’t share our values (but market themselves as environmentally and socially responsible)

That’s why we really need the mixer and filler. 

 

When we say those machines will help us “deepen our partnerships” with local coffee shops, we mean we’ll have more time and energy to help them showcase the positive environmental impact they are having. Their customers care about this, and it’s in all our interests to help them communicate it.

 

With the artisan workers we partner with, a big part of the value of our contracts is consistency. We want to increase the consistency of the contracts, so there’s no boom-and-bust situation.

 

And while we can’t can’t control how other people market themselves, we can work hard to communicate what work we’re doing to stay in line with our core values.

 

We recognise that not everyone will be able to contribute financially to this campaign. 

 

If nothing else, give us a share on Facebook or just email it to just one person you think might find it interesting. 

 

For reading this far: thank you!  

 

And we hope that you’ll read more about us as you follow our campaign. :)

Short Summary

Hello. My name is Heather. I am a teacher, mother and friend to my community. I recently quit my full time teaching job to make my dream a reality. I have been working with children for over 25 years now. Growing up I was encouraged to play outside, climb trees, throw stones in water, paint, sing, laugh, roll down grassy hills and explore the world around me. My mother taught me how to plant food and flowers out of necessity and for recreation. We hunted for dragons, honey combs and berries, fished, hiked, collected things to put in my nature journal, dipped candles, played homemade instruments, painted and generally had a really good time trying to figure out how things worked.
<div>My mom is gone now
column2: however the things she taught me are being passed on to the children and families I share my life with.

column1: There is no better place to build a sense of respect for the environment than by learning outdoors. Outdoor exploration offers a myriad of opportunities to learn science, build teamwork, practice social skills, exercise imagination, and simply to have fun!

I  guide groups of children along with their families on weekly adventures to explore nature. We track animals, pick berries and apples, study the stars and planets, explore tide pools, climb trees, observe insects and wildlife, jump in puddles, build snow forts, sing songs, play instruments, and engage in the world around us with those we love. No two days are ever alike. Rain, snow, wind and sunshine all add to the exploration opportunities we share each week.

Technology lends itself well to keeping us steadily connected and immersed in an almost endless amount of information. In and of itself, technology is not the enemy, but it has allowed children and families to lose touch with nature more easily than ever. We aim to provide an experience to moderate our children's balance of exposure to technology and media with a healthy dose of exposure to the outdoors and all the wonder that nature has to offer.
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

To make this project a success I need your help. I am looking for funding to help absorb some of the costs associated with initial operating expenses like registering and insuring the business as well as purchasing fine art materials for the groups. I teach painting and pottery with my students in addition to taking them on nature hikes and engaging in outdoor activities. Supplies we use regularly include watercolor paper, bees wax and wicks for candle making, brushes, and paints. We also use clay as well as a kiln. These things all add up in cost quickly.
My goal is to raise $850.00 to help meet these expenses.
I would be very grateful to meet this goal.

A lot of hard work has gotten me this far. I have literally scrubbed toilets, collected recycling, mended and laundered clothing, tutored students, offered nature mandala workshops, baby sat and sold fairy kisses (a mix of essential oil and water to calm a child's room) and homemade toys to help make this dream a reality.
My dream is that this seed will become a sapling and some day become a strong tree and drop more seeds.
At this time, our groups meet in a broad range of outdoor locations year round. Every season is magical in its own way and we love winter, spring, summer and fall in New England.

column5: >If my Million Dollar Challenge funds I would be able to secure the BIG dream.

column1: We would have enough funds to be able to set up a permanent location where families could engage in Nature based activities, fine and gross motor activities, study the stars, create artwork and engage in music. Children would enhance their language skills, learn to garden, prepare farm to table snacks and meals and share this experience with others.

Meeting this challenge would mean    we could also make this programming accessible to city children by purchasing a vehicle that would bring our tools on the road to children. Think ""Book Mobile"" only our tools of the trade are magnifying glasses, crickets, caterpillars, mud, seedlings, microscopes, plants and flowers, mobile raised bed gardens and telescopes to create more inquisitive minds.
The permanent location would be available free of charge to anyone who wanted to share their talents whether it be yoga, music, gardening, computer science or any other skill.

We would have a lending library/observatory/location to house camping and fishing equipment for the community to borrow free of charge and we would put a large portion into scholarships for teachers studying Environmental Education and anyone who needs help with continuing education costs.
We would have a home base to offer CPR and  First Aid training to anyone who wants it even if they feel they can't afford it. There is no reason why this should not be available to everyone!
Our calendars and special edition prints are a great visual reminder of the good you are doing for the next generation.

If the big dream comes true or we get close to it, we will be able to help teachers and parents guide the next generation of children into a mindset that promotes doing good simply for good's sake. 

The Impact

The impact is priceless. Allowing children to engage in activities that promote a sense of respect for the environment, physical activity, healthy eating habits, empathy and risk assessment will help shape them to make informed decisions.
We have an opportunity to instill values in our children and have them grow into a generation of people who think before they act and evaluate the impact they have on the earth.

Who knows, maybe one of these kids might be a Nobel prize winner or contributor to the Smithsonian Institute simply because we went on a hike and turned over a log unveiling a whole ecosystem that caused the child to question the world.

Stranger things have happened!

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

There really is no risk here. If we have a small amount of funding, we start small. If we have a large amount of funding we help a larger group of people faster. No matter how much we have we will work toward the goals set before you. It just might take a little longer.

column1: Other Ways You Can Help
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >You can support Forest Folk New England by hitting the SHARE button if you are unable to spare a dollar or more. We appreciate every click. Each share gets us closer to connecting with people who share our love of family, children and education. Thank you for supporting our cause!

A lot of hard work has gotten me this far. I have literally scrubbed toilets, collected recycling, mended and laundered clothing, tutored students, offered nature mandala workshops, baby sat and sold fairy kisses (a mix of essential oil and water to calm a child's room) and homemade toys to help make this dream a reality.
My dream is that this seed will become a sapling and some day become a strong tree and drop more seeds.
At this time, our groups meet in a broad range of outdoor locations year round. Every season is magical in its own way and we love winter, spring, summer and fall in New England.
If my Million Dollar Challenge funds I would be able to secure the BIG dream.

We would have enough funds to be able to set up a permanent location where families could engage in Nature based activities, fine and gross motor activities, study the stars, create artwork and engage in music. Children would enhance their language skills, learn to garden, prepare farm to table snacks and meals and share this experience with others.

Meeting this challenge would mean    we could also make this programming accessible to city children by purchasing a vehicle that would bring our tools on the road to children. Think ""Book Mobile"" only our tools of the trade are magnifying glasses, crickets, caterpillars, mud, seedlings, microscopes, plants and flowers, mobile raised bed gardens and telescopes to create more inquisitive minds.
The permanent location would be available free of charge to anyone who wanted to share their talents whether it be yoga, music, gardening, computer science or any other skill.

We would have a lending library/observatory/location to house camping and fishing equipment for the community to borrow free of charge and we would put a large portion into scholarships for teachers studying Environmental Education and anyone who needs help with continuing education costs.
We would have a home base to offer CPR and  First Aid training to anyone who wants it even if they feel they can't afford it. There is no reason why this should not be available to everyone!
Our calendars and special edition prints are a great visual reminder of the good you are doing for the next generation.

If the big dream comes true or we get close to it, we will be able to help teachers and parents guide the next generation of children into a mindset that promotes doing good simply for good's sake.    The Impact The impact is priceless. Allowing children to engage in activities that promote a sense of respect for the environment, physical activity, healthy eating habits, empathy and risk assessment will help shape them to make informed decisions.
We have an opportunity to instill values in our children and have them grow into a generation of people who think before they act and evaluate the impact they have on the earth.

Who knows, maybe one of these kids might be a Nobel prize winner or contributor to the Smithsonian Institute simply because we went on a hike and turned over a log unveiling a whole ecosystem that caused the child to question the world.

Stranger things have happened!   Risks & Challenges There really is no risk here. If we have a small amount of funding, we start small. If we have a large amount of funding we help a larger group of people faster. No matter how much we have we will work toward the goals set before you. It just might take a little longer.
Other Ways You Can Help

You can support Forest Folk New England by hitting the SHARE button if you are unable to spare a dollar or more. We appreciate every click. Each share gets us closer to connecting with people who share our love of family, children and education. Thank you for supporting our cause!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Kittery, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/forest-folk-new-england/pica

<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
Howdy co-creators!

This year, in September 2015, we're organising a Permaculture Design Course (PDC) with Rosemary Morrow in Greece. For those of you who don't know what this is, a PDC is an intensive course to teach people how to design resilient and sustainable eco-systems.

My name is Tina Lymberis and for the last 5 years, I've tuned into my permaculture passion: I've been organising and teaching seminars, sustaining a blog about permaculture with educational articles in greek (www.kangouro.gr), starting transition initiatives and now I'm about to print Greece's first permaculture guide in Greek (earth user's guide to permaculture, Rosemary Morrow).

column5: >The request is simple: raise enough cash to sponsor 15 Greek students to be able to attend this PDC and to give away 50 freshly translated permaculture books!

column1: That's it!
What We Need &
50 permaculture books X €40 = €2,000
Fees (paypal, fundraising platform, misc) = €2,500

TOTAL = €15,000

Perks = feel good about supporting Greeks to reclaim and love their land! Know that giving = receiving. We simply do not have the luxury of adding perks, since this would add to the funds we would need and to the time to organise it all. However, unofficially, if you do decide to visit Greece, and have contributed over €100, the people you have supported, will be happy to host you on their project/land, since we are very hospitable generally!

If we don't reach our entire goal, whatever we do raise, will be spread amongst the participants to reduce their participation fee. If, on the other hand, we raise more, the funds will support  the video-recording and sub-titling of the PDC, so that the material will become accessible to more people!

The Impact

Now is the time for us to spread permaculture in Greece! With the current situation, more and more people are turning to the land and they simply do not know what to do with it! This course inspires solutions and a new way of seeing the world - to see that the solutions are inherent in the  so-called 'problems' or, as I like to call them, challenges. To see that collaboration is the only way forward, not only with each other, but with the earth!

Other Ways You Can Help

Love it, spread it, tell everyone who cares about our planet and wants to see good things happening in Greece....you know the drill!
Heartfelt gratitude,
Tina

This year, in September 2015, we're organising a Permaculture Design Course (PDC) with Rosemary Morrow in Greece. For those of you who don't know what this is, a PDC is an intensive course to teach people how to design resilient and sustainable eco-systems.

The request is simple: raise enough cash to sponsor 15 Greek students to be able to attend this PDC and to give away 50 freshly translated permaculture books!
That's it!
What We Need & What You Get
15 PDC spaces X €700 = €10,500
50 permaculture books X €40 = €2,000
Fees (paypal, fundraising platform, misc) = €2,500

TOTAL = €15,000Perks = feel good about supporting Greeks to reclaim and love their land! Know that giving = receiving. We simply do not have the luxury of adding perks, since this would add to the funds we would need and to the time to organise it all. However, unofficially, if you do decide to visit Greece, and have contributed over €100, the people you have supported, will be happy to host you on their project/land, since we are very hospitable generally!

If we don't reach our entire goal, whatever we do raise, will be spread amongst the participants to reduce their participation fee. If, on the other hand, we raise more, the funds will support  the video-recording and sub-titling of the PDC, so that the material will become accessible to more people!

The Impact Now is the time for us to spread permaculture in Greece! With the current situation, more and more people are turning to the land and they simply do not know what to do with it! This course inspires solutions and a new way of seeing the world - to see that the solutions are inherent in the  so-called 'problems' or, as I like to call them, challenges. To see that collaboration is the only way forward, not only with each other, but with the earth!
Other Ways You Can Help Love it, spread it, tell everyone who cares about our planet and wants to see good things happening in Greece....you know the drill!
Heartfelt gratitude,
Tina",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

column6: '>A force of courageous people who risk their lives everyday to save the birds and animals. we are best in cruelty investigations, wild
column9: '>life raids, rescue, rehabilitation and medical care. Many Organizations call us to handle crisis, provide expertise on birds and wild life. We are on the mission to save Fauna and we are Fauna police.
column22: '>Our Inspiration: we really got inspired by the program called Animal Police on Discovery Channel. In this series a team goes in and rescues animals. we wanted to fill similar shoes, Hence the name fauna police. we wanted it to be a  TV program initially, but our team started making short videos that are regularly featured on India News.
column27: '>Established by Mr. Abhinav Srihan, a film maker by profession, India's first Animal rights officer in 2010 with two centers in Delhi, Dog's Inn (Noida) in sector 52. which can house 10 dogs at a given time. We provide first aid to animals and foster care. This adventurous journey began a few years ago when Abhinav started to rescue injured birds- birds that had fallen prey to kite flying and take them to shelters. we were surprised to see that most of shelters did not allow us to see the birds again.
column32: '>We later came to know that most of the places do not have an infrastructure to treat and rehabilitate birds. This urged us to start a  roof top bird's Aviary, in Sarojini Nagar and this was the first step towards building Fauna Police. Here birds get large enclosure mimicking a natural environment for the containment of birds. They are kept in aviaries and then after 30 days of rehabilitation before the release. The birds which mature in the aviary learn basic skills like flying and pecking. Socializing skills amongst other birds can be developed in an aviary. Nature of cases treated and nursed regularly at Fauna police include Maanjha (glass) thread cut, avian pox, orphaned new born Etc.
column37: '>Fauna police has now developed into an organization that works towards eradicating illegal Wild bird and Animal trade, helps to save animals from various emergencies
column38: Whether man made or natural. This group helps to fight against animal cruelty and shutting down puppy mills. We are radically different from other animal care centers because we not only treat rescued  species physically but emotionally too.

column6: '>Once abundant across large parts of India, the species like Parakeets, Mynas, Owls,Sparrows etc have slipped into the danger of extinction . A large part of this trade is meant for the International market and has no direct demand in India. Snatched from  the wild, Stolen from nests and left to die while smuggling, a staggering number of exotic birds that are sold in the local market are illegally brought in by heartless traders.This is a humble request to birds and animal lovers, say No to ""Bird Trade"". This is the first attempt to end cruelty and torture against birds.
column11: '>You can contribute in many ways to help us with the outreach of ""Uncage the Feather"". This is partly because the general public is completely ignorant about the laws, henceforth continue to encourage these nefarious activities by purchasing these innocent birds from these cruel traders.
column16: '>  A staggering number of birds are cruelly smuggled into India, lakhs per year, over porous borders and in appalling conditions.

column6: '>Parakeet: to catch wild parrots, the hunters take two of them as bait and puncture their eyes.These blind and wounded birds are left on a sheet, where they cry out for help. As soon as other concerned Parrots get attracted &
column7: descend towards the injured Parrots , the hunters throw a sheet on them hence capturing them. The hunters also use natural gums to trap them.
column17: '>OWLS: ""Despite the ban they are available for sale
column20: '>across the Country"", says Nikunj Sharma Government Affairs Liaison Head for PETA. Tantrics or Shamans use owls for black magic between months of October and November. Their blood, bones, claws, skull and organs are used and they are sacrificed during Diwali to bless a family.Birds are smuggled and fraudulently legitimized by saying that they are captive bred in India, which technically makes them aviary bred exotic birds. with captive bred birds the sellers can not  afford to let them die because the bird can command 3000 to 3500 dollars each. While a wild bird lays eggs only once in a year,the traders force it by injecting chemicals and hormones, which speeds up its reproductive cycle, says Koyama the Avian expert. This disturbs the life span and disrupts it's hormonal cycle. This is wrong on many counts:
column28: '>Once a bird, especially young ones have been in captivity for a certain duration which varies with species, they are very difficult to release into the wild and will definitely die a sad death, by starvation or preyed upon by scavengers and predators. Please DO NOT RELEASE THE BIRDS INTO THE WILD.
column33: '>However, the good news is that all this can stop, only if we make the choice. It is totally up to us to stop this nefarious and ecologically damaging activities. If we just stop buying birds as pets, captive breeding and the cruelty would stop too.
column38: '>Indian wild life species are banned for selling, purchasing or keeping.  There is a heavy penalty of up to INR 25,000 and or up to 3 years of imprisonment.
column48: '>
column53: '>Our vision is to eliminate wild life trafficking from the root and,  build a free flight Aviary  for rescued birds where a large enclosure would not confine birds, unlike cages aviary allows the birds to fly freely in larger living space.
column58: '>Another mission is to buy an ambulance for  rescue operations of bird and animals who have been deprived of freedom and gone through tremendous amount of inhuman treatments. The expense in building up an 3,000 Sqft Aviary would cost around $60,000 which, is only possible when there are kind hearted contributors like you.

column1:
Our Facebook link : https://www.facebook.com/Uncage-the-Feather-Hel...

","A force of courageous people who risk their lives everyday to save the birds and animals. we are best in cruelty investigations, wild life raids, rescue, rehabilitation and medical care. Many Organizations call us to handle crisis, provide expertise on birds and wild life. We are on the mission to save Fauna and we are Fauna police.                       Our Inspiration: we really got inspired by the program called Animal Police on Discovery Channel. In this series a team goes in and rescues animals. we wanted to fill similar shoes, Hence the name fauna police. we wanted it to be a  TV program initially, but our team started making short videos that are regularly featured on India News.Established by Mr. Abhinav Srihan, a film maker by profession, India's first Animal rights officer in 2010 with two centers in Delhi, Dog's Inn (Noida) in sector 52. which can house 10 dogs at a given time. We provide first aid to animals and foster care. This adventurous journey began a few years ago when Abhinav started to rescue injured birds- birds that had fallen prey to kite flying and take them to shelters. we were surprised to see that most of shelters did not allow us to see the birds again.We later came to know that most of the places do not have an infrastructure to treat and rehabilitate birds. This urged us to start a  roof top bird's Aviary, in Sarojini Nagar and this was the first step towards building Fauna Police. Here birds get large enclosure mimicking a natural environment for the containment of birds. They are kept in aviaries and then after 30 days of rehabilitation before the release. The birds which mature in the aviary learn basic skills like flying and pecking. Socializing skills amongst other birds can be developed in an aviary. Nature of cases treated and nursed regularly at Fauna police include Maanjha (glass) thread cut, avian pox, orphaned new born Etc.Fauna police has now developed into an organization that works towards eradicating illegal Wild bird and Animal trade, helps to save animals from various emergencies
column2: Whether man made or natural. This group helps to fight against animal cruelty and shutting down puppy mills. We are radically different from other animal care centers because we not only treat rescued  species physically but emotionally too.

column1: Once abundant across large parts of India, the species like Parakeets, Mynas, Owls,Sparrows etc have slipped into the danger of extinction . A large part of this trade is meant for the International market and has no direct demand in India. Snatched from  the wild, Stolen from nests and left to die while smuggling, a staggering number of exotic birds that are sold in the local market are illegally brought in by heartless traders.This is a humble request to birds and animal lovers, say No to ""Bird Trade"". This is the first attempt to end cruelty and torture against birds.You can contribute in many ways to help us with the outreach of ""Uncage the Feather"". This is partly because the general public is completely ignorant about the laws, henceforth continue to encourage these nefarious activities by purchasing these innocent birds from these cruel traders.  A staggering number of birds are cruelly smuggled into India, lakhs per year, over porous borders and in appalling conditions.

Parakeet: to catch wild parrots, the hunters take two of them as bait and puncture their eyes.These blind and wounded birds are left on a sheet, where they cry out for help. As soon as other concerned Parrots get attracted & descend towards the injured Parrots , the hunters throw a sheet on them hence capturing them. The hunters also use natural gums to trap them.OWLS: ""Despite the ban they are available for sale across the Country"", says Nikunj Sharma Government Affairs Liaison Head for PETA. Tantrics or Shamans use owls for black magic between months of October and November. Their blood, bones, claws, skull and organs are used and they are sacrificed during Diwali to bless a family.Birds are smuggled and fraudulently legitimized by saying that they are captive bred in India, which technically makes them aviary bred exotic birds. with captive bred birds the sellers can not  afford to let them die because the bird can command 3000 to 3500 dollars each. While a wild bird lays eggs only once in a year,the traders force it by injecting chemicals and hormones, which speeds up its reproductive cycle, says Koyama the Avian expert. This disturbs the life span and disrupts it's hormonal cycle. This is wrong on many counts:Once a bird, especially young ones have been in captivity for a certain duration which varies with species, they are very difficult to release into the wild and will definitely die a sad death, by starvation or preyed upon by scavengers and predators. Please DO NOT RELEASE THE BIRDS INTO THE WILD.However, the good news is that all this can stop, only if we make the choice. It is totally up to us to stop this nefarious and ecologically damaging activities. If we just stop buying birds as pets, captive breeding and the cruelty would stop too.Indian wild life species are banned for selling, purchasing or keeping.  There is a heavy penalty of up to INR 25,000 and or up to 3 years of imprisonment.                                                                         Our vision is to eliminate wild life trafficking from the root and,  build a free flight Aviary  for rescued birds where a large enclosure would not confine birds, unlike cages aviary allows the birds to fly freely in larger living space.Another mission is to buy an ambulance for  rescue operations of bird and animals who have been deprived of freedom and gone through tremendous amount of inhuman treatments. The expense in building up an 3,000 Sqft Aviary would cost around $60,000 which, is only possible when there are kind hearted contributors like you.
Sonpur (Chidiya Bazaar,North India)_-With the support of authorities like PFA and Animal welfare board, fauna police raided this market to put end to wild life trade.
Kanpur (North India) - with the support of Kamana Pandey we achieved great success in rescuing thousands of birds.
Gorakhpur and Lucknow (North India)

Hyderabad(Mehboob Chawk,South India)Where many markets were exposed and raided amongst 300 illegal wild life trade markets in India. We are yet to uncover many more markets like these. Help us uncage them and lets give a beautiful and caring, free flight aviary
Contribute in building a free flight aviary for birds
In summers, keep water for birds outside your homes.
Adopt dogs/cats but NO BIRDS (if you cannot  afford an aviary)
Educate your friends/Family etc by Sharing this Campaign on Social Media.

If you are not able to to aid financially, we would be grateful if you considered dedicating your precious time and help us spread the word by sharing this Campaign on  social media platforms i.e,Facebook, Twitter, Instagram & ask your friends and family to do the same.                               We deeply thank every one of you for taking out time and going through our campaign ""UNCAGE THE FEATHER"", also a big thanks to those who believed in us & supported our beliefs & who contributed in one way or the other. Lets together earn some good Karma's!

As Token of Gratitude Uncage The Feather Project would offer ' Uncage The Feather' T shirt. Fauna police would offer its exclusive range of T shirts /Lowers/Sling Bags/ Jackets/ wristbands and a Certificate of Appreciation to the contributors.We value your every effort/ contribution. The Perks are:
Our You tube Link:       https://youtu.be/2uvjwipyRQ0
Our Facebook link : https://www.facebook.com/Uncage-the-Feather-Hel...",18.0,0,"1 Campaign

The Story

Green sea turtles, also called the Hawaiian Honu, are
survivors…. they survived the fall of the dinosaurs, and the rise of the
industrial world . . . but will they survive 21<sup>st</sup> century marine debris, disease, fishing interactions, and habitat
loss?
Hawai`i Wildlife Fund
is launching a Crowd Funding campaign to help protect the threatened green
turtle.  . . . which has no choice but
to share its ocean and beach habitats . . . with people.
Green turtles spend most of their time in the nearshore
waters of Hawai`i – where they increasingly encounter snorkelers, scuba divers
and swimmers.
When turtles haul out to bask on beaches, they also
encounter people more frequently . . . people who can’t get enough of the
ancient, graceful creatures.
For the past five years, trained volunteers and staff with
the Hawai`i Wildlife Fund    -  <b>Honu Watch
Project – have been monitoring a few of the Maui beaches where turtles and
people meet.
On the beach or in the community, trained
volunteers help Maui residents and visitors alike understand why they should
not disturb turtles while they’re basking, foraging, or resting in the water .

. .  or at any other time.

Since 1996, Hawai`i Wildlife Fund has
been the only non-profit organization responsible for protecting Maui’s sea
turtles. We are marine life professionals and advocates who partner with local

state and federal agencies, and the volunteer public.

The Challenge

As you can imagine, managing teams of volunteers to protect Hawai`i's Green Sea Turtles requires individual and
group dedication, strong organizational skills, and lots of funding.   That’s
where you can help.
Our current funding level supports just four hours of
monitoring per day at only one basking beach on Maui.  Hawai’i Wildlife Fund needs to expand its Honu
Watch Project activity to most daylight hours on more beaches, every day of the
year.

Your contribution to our Campaign will help get us there. 

In addition to increasing the number of hours we can spend on the beach, your financial support of the Honu Watch Project
supplements the development of education materials, brochures,

pamphlets and signs.

Watching a turtle haul its 200-pound body out of the ocean and
drag it up onto the beach to bask, or rest, is breathtaking . . .  It’s
nature at her very best.
It’s no surprise that every year, tens of thousands of
people on Maui are attracted to popular turtle beaches.
Before Hawai`i Wildlife Fund implemented

the Honu Watch Project beach goers touched . . . and even rode. . .  basking green sea turtles.  People were loving them to death.

Today, thanks to the Honu Watch Project,
visitors and residents alike are advised to keep a respectful distance from ANY

basking sea turtle, or those swimming in the water.

A successful $20,000 dollar Hawai`i
Wildlife Fund Crowd Funding Campaign would cover the costs of recruiting and
training of additional conservation team members.
It also would help Hawai`i Wildlife Fund
continue assisting federal agencies responsible for conservation and education
efforts
column2: and Maui county lifeguards responsible for mitigating visitor-resident

column1: conflicts over turtle conservation issues.
The key is providing a safe, educational

environment for everyone to enjoy . . .  and the turtles to thrive. 

Your generous support during this Campaign
will help our volunteer-based non-profit expand its outreach capacity to more popular
beaches . . . . beaches where Green Sea Turtles, and people, bask in nature’s

glory to conserve energy and escape predators.

The Hawai`i Wildlife Fund Crowd Funding
Campaign runs through May 7, 2016.  Our
Your donation lays the foundation for the next
20 years of conservation work in and around Maui waters.    Thank you!

Tell Your Friends:   Call, text, facebook, snapchat – whatever it takes to make a difference for our turtles!

LEARN MORE
www.wildhawaii.org

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><blockquote>

HBP®, HempBioPlastic: for a circular and sustainable economy, from the ground up! #Kanesis

We use hemp waste to create new biocomposites suitable for 3D printing and a wide array of industrial and personal applications!
We use industrial hemp to produce our 3D printable HBP® filament
Henry Ford’s dream to ""provide an industrial market for the farmers' products"" has become reality with HBP®!

Kanèsis is committed to developing solutions for a sustainable world. Based on natural materials and especially designed for the manufacturing industry, our innovative HBP® filament minimizes environmental impact and provides all-round benefits.

An all-natural filament for 3D printing

HBP® (HempBioPlastic) is a brown filament derived entirely from industrial hemp waste. It is a highly efficient product ideal for the new generation of 3D printers, ensuring great results with no environmental impact.

Our new filament is the result of more than a year of efforts invested in the pursuit of an ambitious mission by a skilled team led by two young and resourceful Sicilians: Giovanni Milazzo (24) and Antonio Caruso (28), founders of the startup company Kanèsis®. “The wide interest and involvement in our project convinced us that we were on the right track"" explain Antonio and Giovanni. 



The Kanèsis People

Inspired by the principles of Chemurgy - using agricultural raw materials to create industrial products -  the Kanèsis team designs and develops products derived from hemp, the planet's most versatile, durable and ecological plant. The company name is a play on words between Canapa (Italian for hemp) and Kinesis (Latin for movement). ""The Kanèsis people work every day to promote an innovative and environmental friendly way of thinking and behaving. Our aim is to contribute to an exciting new beginning for both industry and agriculture"" the Kanèsis team explains.

column2: >FOLLOW US ON INSTAGRAM

column1: www.kanesis.eu
About us:
<div>
<div>
From scratch to finished product
<div>
After an initial stage of studies and experiments, the first ideas started to take shape and eventually led to the development of a new and innovative product.

In April 2015, the company submitted an Italian patent application for the new biocomposite derived from industrial hemp waste, followed by an international application in April 2016. The HBP® finish resembles that of wood and has proved to be more efficient than other bioplastics on the market.
<h2 style=""text-align: center
<h2 style=""text-align: center
Source: http://www.3d-printerstore.ch/Filaments-ABS-vs-PLA:_:11.html?language=en
Detail of 3D printing with ABS
Detail of 3D printing with PLA
Detail of 3D printing with HBP® showing a higher quality bonding between layers.
Initial testing shows that HBP® is 20% lighter and 30% stronger than PLA (Polylactic Acid), the most common type of bioplastic currently used.

Although one of the first applications considered for the new material was the extrusion of a special filament for 3D FDM printing, HBP® can also be used in precision applications such as injection molding, with endless possibilities for future developments.

The people at Kanèsis imagine a future where sustainability and respect for the environment will be the foundation of industrial production. Their commitment and contribution to turn this vision into a solid reality focuses on the development of solutions aimed at replacing petrochemical products with ecofriendly and sustainable materials.
www.kanesis.eu

Hemp field in Catania, Sicily
<blockquote>

column2: >The HBP® filament developed by Kanèsis is derived from hemp waste

column1: Hemp  - A 5000-year history

About 5000 years ago, wild hemp spread throughout Eastern Asia and was later introduced into India. This extraordinary plant was used in religious ceremonies, as an aid to meditation and for medicinal purposes as well as a source of fiber, oil and food. From the 5th century BC, hemp began to be cultivated in Europe, namely in Norway, Sweden, Germany and in the Celtic regions of the United Kingdom. Around 100 BC, hemp was also used for paper production. The plant was introduced into the Middle East by the nomadic tribes of central Asia.
<div>Historical records on hemp use trace back thousands of years. The Greek historian Herodotus (484 - 425 BC) described its use in funeral rituals
column2: in ancient Rome, Discorides - physician, pharmacologist and botanist during Nero's reign - mentioned its medical uses in several papers (90 AD) and Pliny the Elder (23 - 79 AD) reported that hemp was used to make sails and ropes.

column1: In the 1500s, the cultivation of hemp began in South America, followed by North America a century later.

column2: >Until the 1950s, hemp was used as raw material in various sectors, with Italy being one of the most important producing countries in the world, first for quality and second only to the Soviet Union for cultivated acres.
>Starting in the 1930s - 1950s, hemp cultivation began to rapidly decline for political reasons and due to pressure from the competing cotton, paper and petrochemical industries.

column1: 1 plant, 1000s of products!
<div>

3D printing is currently one of the fastest growing and evolving markets. According to Gartner Predicts (2015), in 2016 nearly 500,000 3D printers would be shipped worldwide, 103 % more than the predicted number in 2015. Analysts estimate that 3D printer sales will grow more than double every year between 2016 and 2019, when the distributed units will exceed 5.6 million worldwide.
<div style=""font-weight: bold
<div style=""text-align: center

column2: >“The 3D printing market continues its transformation from niche market to global market with a large user base among businesses and consumers”. (Gartner 2015)

column1: <div style=""text-align: left

The HBP® filament has significant advantages compared to its direct competitors in the 3D printing sector, such as ABS (Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene) and PLA (Polylactic Acid). In addition to offering an improved weight/volume ratio (lower specific weight), the HBP® filament is perfectly suited for FDM technology. The plant-derived microgranules embedded in its thermoplastic resin significantly improve bonding between individual layers during printing.

column2: >An HBP® printed object is therefore mechanically stronger than its counterpart printed with alternative materials, such as ABS and PLA, and about 30% lighter. Another strong point of this innovative filament is its competitive market price.

","HBP®, HempBioPlastic: for a circular and sustainable economy, from the ground up! #KanesisWe use hemp waste to create new biocomposites suitable for 3D printing and a wide array of industrial and personal applications!
We use industrial hemp to produce our 3D printable HBP® filament
Henry Ford’s dream to ""provide an industrial market for the farmers' products"" has become reality with HBP®!

Kanèsis is committed to developing solutions for a sustainable world. Based on natural materials and especially designed for the manufacturing industry, our innovative HBP® filament minimizes environmental impact and provides all-round benefits.

An all-natural filament for 3D printingHBP® (HempBioPlastic) is a brown filament derived entirely from industrial hemp waste. It is a highly efficient product ideal for the new generation of 3D printers, ensuring great results with no environmental impact.Our new filament is the result of more than a year of efforts invested in the pursuit of an ambitious mission by a skilled team led by two young and resourceful Sicilians: Giovanni Milazzo (24) and Antonio Caruso (28), founders of the startup company Kanèsis®. “The wide interest and involvement in our project convinced us that we were on the right track"" explain Antonio and Giovanni. The Kanèsis People

Inspired by the principles of Chemurgy - using agricultural raw materials to create industrial products -  the Kanèsis team designs and develops products derived from hemp, the planet's most versatile, durable and ecological plant. The company name is a play on words between Canapa (Italian for hemp) and Kinesis (Latin for movement). ""The Kanèsis people work every day to promote an innovative and environmental friendly way of thinking and behaving. Our aim is to contribute to an exciting new beginning for both industry and agriculture"" the Kanèsis team explains.

About us:
From scratch to finished product
After an initial stage of studies and experiments, the first ideas started to take shape and eventually led to the development of a new and innovative product.

In April 2015, the company submitted an Italian patent application for the new biocomposite derived from industrial hemp waste, followed by an international application in April 2016. The HBP® finish resembles that of wood and has proved to be more efficient than other bioplastics on the market.

Initial testing shows that HBP® is 20% lighter and 30% stronger than PLA (Polylactic Acid), the most common type of bioplastic currently used.

Although one of the first applications considered for the new material was the extrusion of a special filament for 3D FDM printing, HBP® can also be used in precision applications such as injection molding, with endless possibilities for future developments.

The people at Kanèsis imagine a future where sustainability and respect for the environment will be the foundation of industrial production. Their commitment and contribution to turn this vision into a solid reality focuses on the development of solutions aimed at replacing petrochemical products with ecofriendly and sustainable materials.

Hemp field in Catania, Sicily
The HBP® filament developed by Kanèsis is derived from hemp waste
HBP® Thermoplastic Granules for Injection Molding
Hemp  - A 5000-year history

About 5000 years ago, wild hemp spread throughout Eastern Asia and was later introduced into India. This extraordinary plant was used in religious ceremonies, as an aid to meditation and for medicinal purposes as well as a source of fiber, oil and food. From the 5th century BC, hemp began to be cultivated in Europe, namely in Norway, Sweden, Germany and in the Celtic regions of the United Kingdom. Around 100 BC, hemp was also used for paper production. The plant was introduced into the Middle East by the nomadic tribes of central Asia.
Historical records on hemp use trace back thousands of years. The Greek historian Herodotus (484 - 425 BC) described its use in funeral rituals
column2: in ancient Rome, Discorides - physician, pharmacologist and botanist during Nero's reign - mentioned its medical uses in several papers (90 AD) and Pliny the Elder (23 - 79 AD) reported that hemp was used to make sails and ropes.

column1: In the 1500s, the cultivation of hemp began in South America, followed by North America a century later.

Until the 1950s, hemp was used as raw material in various sectors, with Italy being one of the most important producing countries in the world, first for quality and second only to the Soviet Union for cultivated acres.
Starting in the 1930s - 1950s, hemp cultivation began to rapidly decline for political reasons and due to pressure from the competing cotton, paper and petrochemical industries.
1 plant, 1000s of products!
The 3D Printing Market

3D printing is currently one of the fastest growing and evolving markets. According to Gartner Predicts (2015), in 2016 nearly 500,000 3D printers would be shipped worldwide, 103 % more than the predicted number in 2015. Analysts estimate that 3D printer sales will grow more than double every year between 2016 and 2019, when the distributed units will exceed 5.6 million worldwide.
“The 3D printing market continues its transformation from niche market to global market with a large user base among businesses and consumers”. (Gartner 2015)
HBP® Advantages

The HBP® filament has significant advantages compared to its direct competitors in the 3D printing sector, such as ABS (Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene) and PLA (Polylactic Acid). In addition to offering an improved weight/volume ratio (lower specific weight), the HBP® filament is perfectly suited for FDM technology. The plant-derived microgranules embedded in its thermoplastic resin significantly improve bonding between individual layers during printing.
Drone made with HBP®

An HBP® printed object is therefore mechanically stronger than its counterpart printed with alternative materials, such as ABS and PLA, and about 30% lighter. Another strong point of this innovative filament is its competitive market price.
